text: The seeds for Sinsemilla Tips magazine were planted six years ago, when the authorities arrested Tom Alexander and seized his crop of 1,324 marijuana plants.
title: MAGAZINE FOR AMBITIOUS MARIJUANA GROWERS

text: Thirty hours in jail ridded Mr. Alexander of any desire to raise marijuana, even though he said a police officer had told him that ''my crop contained some of the best buds he'd ever seen.''
title: MAGAZINE FOR AMBITIOUS MARIJUANA GROWERS

text: But the charges of marijuana cultivation were dropped after Mr. Alexander found a technical error in the search warrant used in the raid near Corvallis, about 70 miles south of here.
title: MAGAZINE FOR AMBITIOUS MARIJUANA GROWERS

text: Mr. Alexander went back to his turn-of-the-century house near Corvallis, this time not to raise marijuana but to publish the nation's only trade magazine on the subject.
title: MAGAZINE FOR AMBITIOUS MARIJUANA GROWERS

text: ''There was no electricity, so with kerosene lamps I put together a 16-page magazine on newsprint,'' said Mr. Alexander, who is 34 years old and holds a bachelor's degree in business administration.
title: MAGAZINE FOR AMBITIOUS MARIJUANA GROWERS

text: Press Run Put at 10,000
title: MAGAZINE FOR AMBITIOUS MARIJUANA GROWERS

text: ''I knew nothing about journalism, but I had 1,000 copies printed up and I took them to Humboldt County,'' one of California's chief marijuana-growing areas, he said, adding that he ''sold them all at 50 cents apiece.''
title: MAGAZINE FOR AMBITIOUS MARIJUANA GROWERS

text: Gradually he placed the magazine in newsstands and bookstores. By the fall of 1980 he had a San Francisco-based national distributor. The quarterly magazine published in Corvallis now has a press run of 10,000 copies selling for $4 each.
title: MAGAZINE FOR AMBITIOUS MARIJUANA GROWERS

text: A recent 72-page edition contains advertisements for products ranging from a kit to detect the sex of marijuana buds (female buds are most potent) to gadgets that detect electronic eavesdropping devices and spot counterfeit money.
title: MAGAZINE FOR AMBITIOUS MARIJUANA GROWERS

text: Most of the articles in the magazine are geared to helping marijuana growers increase the yield and potency of their crop. Its title refers to seedless marijuana, the most powerful variety.
title: MAGAZINE FOR AMBITIOUS MARIJUANA GROWERS

text: The magazine also includes political comment, a four-page cartoon called ''Smokey Jokers,'' an article on what law-enforcement officers look for when flying over marijuana plots, and a question-and-answer column.
title: MAGAZINE FOR AMBITIOUS MARIJUANA GROWERS

text: ''I have heard so much about bat guano,'' one letter said. ''What is it, and how does it benefit plant growth?'' In its reply, the column said bat droppings were an excellent fertilizer.
title: MAGAZINE FOR AMBITIOUS MARIJUANA GROWERS

text: Sinsemilla Tips offers subscriptions, both foreign and domestic, but Mr. Alexander said most readers bought the magazine at bookstores and newsstands. The subscriber list, on computer disks, is closely guarded.
title: MAGAZINE FOR AMBITIOUS MARIJUANA GROWERS

text: ''I'm definitely conscious of the government doing dirty tricks,'' he said. ''So whenever I go anywhere, the disks go with me.''
title: MAGAZINE FOR AMBITIOUS MARIJUANA GROWERS

text: Wayne Botta, a Corvallis police detective, said the police had no problem with the magazine. ''They are totally legal,'' he said. ''I have read copies myself; it's a very informative magazine.''
title: MAGAZINE FOR AMBITIOUS MARIJUANA GROWERS

text: While there are thought to be two million to three million marijuana growers in the United States, Mr. Alexander said he had no direct competition. ''A couple of other publications have tried competing,'' he added, ''but they've lasted only one or two issues.''
title: MAGAZINE FOR AMBITIOUS MARIJUANA GROWERS

text: Mr. Alexander said the magazine grossed about $100,000 a year, but much of that is reinvested to assure future growth of the publication. He said he paid himself an annual salary of about $18,000.
title: MAGAZINE FOR AMBITIOUS MARIJUANA GROWERS

text: With increased aerial surveillance by law-enforcement officers, Mr. Alexander said, much marijuana growing has shifted indoors. But that does not mean large-scale growing is no longer done. On a recent trip to San Francisco, he said, he saw an entire warehouse being used to raise marijuana.
title: MAGAZINE FOR AMBITIOUS MARIJUANA GROWERS

text: ''The government is not losing the war against marijuana - they lost it long ago,'' he said. ''The government is like the advertising arm of the marijuana industry. Their eradication efforts give people the idea to grow it themselves.''
title: MAGAZINE FOR AMBITIOUS MARIJUANA GROWERS

text: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
title: Off for the Season

text: From the Queens County courthouse comes a Christmas story -Walter R. Christmas's story.
title: Off for the Season

text: The 33-year-old Mr. Christmas walked out of the courthouse yesterday after the office of District Attorney John J. Santucci had asked for an adjournment in contemplation of dismissal of charges against him.
title: Off for the Season

text: ''We don't think we want to put Mr. Christmas in jail two days before Christmas,'' an assistant district attorney, James O'Donnell, said.
title: Off for the Season

text: What had prompted the request for an adjournment - in effect, a six-month probation period - were Mr. Christmas's ''background and the nature of the charges,'' according to Mr. Santucci's office.
title: Off for the Season

text: Mr. Christmas, of Peekskill, N.Y., was arrested Sunday and charged with driving without a license, having an uninspected vehicle and possessing a small amount of marijuana.
title: Off for the Season

text: Prosecutors learned that Mr. Christmas was a disabled Vietnam veteran whose handicap had prevented him from getting work. The car he drove belonged to his girlfriend, who was mugged two weeks ago and is hospitalized. He was visiting his mother in Jamaica, Queens.
title: Off for the Season

text: ''It was close to Christmas, so they let me out because of my name,'' Mr. Christmas joked.
title: Off for the Season

text: JUST BEFORE CHRISTMAS OF 1980, I WAS SITTING IN THE Sevens, a neighborhood bar on Beacon Hill (don't all these stories of revelation begin in bars?), when a housepainter named Tony remarked out of the blue that he wanted to find a place to go to mass on Christmas Eve. I didn't say anything, but a thought came into my mind, as swift and unexpected as it was unfamiliar: I'd like to do that, too.
title: RETURNING TO CHURCH

text: I had not gone to church since leaving my boyhood Protestant faith as a rebellious Columbia College intellectual more than a quarter-century before, yet I found myself that Christmas Eve in King's Chapel, which I finally selected from the ads on The Boston Globe religion page because it seemed least threatening. It was Unitarian, I knew the minister slightly as a neighbor, and I assumed ''Candlelight Service'' meant nothing more religiously challenging than carol singing.
title: RETURNING TO CHURCH

text: As it happened, the Rev. Carl Scovel gave a sermon about ''the latecomers'' to the church on a text from an Evelyn Waugh novel called ''Helena.'' I slunk down in my pew, literally beginning to shiver from what I thought was only embarrassment at feeling singled out for personal attention, and discomfort at being in alien surroundings. It turned out that I had a temperature of 102 that kept me in bed for three days with a violent case of the flu and a fearful suspicion that church was a very dangerous place, at least if you weren't used to it.
title: RETURNING TO CHURCH

text: Perhaps my flesh was rebelling against this unaccustomed intrusion of spirit. Certainly going to church was out of character for me. My chosen public image was the jacket photo of ''Starting Over,'' my novel about a divorced man seeking salvation through drugs, alcohol and promiscuity. I proudly posed for the picture in 1973 at my new living room bar, flanked by bottles of favorite vodkas, bourbons and burgundies. It did not look like the picture of a man who was headed to church. IN THE YEAR THAT LED to my going to the Christmas Eve service, I felt I was headed for the edge of a cliff. I could have scored at the top of those magazine tests that list the greatest stresses of life, for that year saw the dissolution of a seven-year relationship with the woman I had fully expected to live with the rest of my life, I ran out of money, left the work I was doing, the house I owned, and the city I was living in, and attended the funeral of my father in May and my mother in November.
title: RETURNING TO CHURCH

text: In the midst of this chaos, I one day grabbed an old Bible from among my books, and with a desperate instinct turned to the 23d Psalm. It brought a sense of relief, and sometimes I recited it in my mind in the months that followed, but it did not give me any sense that I suddenly believed in God. It simply seemed an isolated source of solace and calm, such as any great poem might be. It certainly did not give rise to the notion of anything as radical as going to church. After my Christmas Eve experience at King's Chapel, I didn't get up the nerve to go back again until Easter. I did not have any attacks of shivering or chills in the spring sunshine of that service, so it seemed that even as a ''latecomer'' and former avowed atheist, I could safely enter a place regarded as a house of God. Still, the prospect was discomforting. My two initial trips of return had been on major holidays, occasions when ''regular'' people went to church, simply in observance of tradition. To go back again meant crossing the Boston Common on a nonholiday Sunday morning wearing a suit and tie, a giveaway sign of churchgoing. I did it furtively, as if I were engaged in something that would not be approved of by my peers. I hoped they would all be home doing brunch and the Sunday papers, so I would not be ''caught in the act.'' I recalled the remark of William F. Buckley Jr. in a television interview that if you mention God more than once at New York dinner parties, you aren't invited back.
title: RETURNING TO CHURCH

text: To my surprise, I recognized neighbors and even some people I considered friends at church, on a ''regular'' Sunday. I had simply assumed I did not know people who went to church, yet here they were, with intellects intact, worshiping God. Once inside the church myself, I understood the appeal. No doubt my friends and neighbors found, as I did, relief and refreshment in connecting with age-old rituals, reciting psalms and singing hymns. There was a calm reassurance in the stately language of the litanies and chants of the Book of Common Prayer. (King's Chapel is ''Unitarian in theology, Anglican in worship, and congregational in governance,'' a historical Boston amalgam that will be three centuries old next June.) I was grateful for the sense of shared reverence, of reaching beyond one's flimsy physical presence, while praying with a whole congregation.
title: RETURNING TO CHURCH

text: I began to appreciate what was meant by the church as ''sanctuary.'' The word itself took on new resonance for me; when I later heard of the ''sanctuary'' movement of New England churches offering shelter to Central American political refugees, I thought of the kind of private refuge that fortunate citizens like myself find in church from the daily assaults of business and personal pressures and worries, the psychic guerrilla warfare of everyday life.
title: RETURNING TO CHURCH

text: Caught in an escalation of that kind of battle in my own professional campaigns (more painful because so clearly brought on by my own blundering), I joined the church in May 1982, not wanting to wait until the second Christmas Eve anniversary of my entry, as I had planned. I wanted the immediate sense of safety and refuge implied in belonging, being a member - perhaps like getting a passport and fleeing to a powerful embassy in the midst of some chaotic revolution.
title: RETURNING TO CHURCH

text: Going to church, even belonging to it, did not solve life's problems - if anything, they seemed to intensify around this time - but it gave me a sense of living in a larger context, of being part of something greater than what I could see through the tunnel vision of my personal concerns. I now looked forward to Sunday because it meant going to church; what once was strange now felt not only natural but essential. Even more remarkably, the practice of regular attendance at Sunday services, which such a short time ago seemed religiously ''excessive,'' no longer seemed enough. Whatever it was I was getting from church on Sunday morning, I wanted -needed, it felt like - more of it.
title: RETURNING TO CHURCH

text: I experienced what is a common phenomenon for people who in some way or other begin a journey of the kind I so unexpectedly found myself on - a feeling simply and best described as a ''thirst'' for spiritual understanding and contact; to put it bluntly, I guess, for God. I noticed in the church bulletin an announcement of a Bible-study class in the parish house, and I went one stormy autumn evening to find myself with only the church's young seminarian on hand and one other parishioner. Rather than being disappointed by the tiny turnout, as I ordinarily would have been, I thought of the words ''Where two or three are gathered together in My name, there am I in the midst of them,'' and I felt an interior glow that the pouring rain outside and occasional claps of thunder only made seem more vital and precious. I don't remember what text we studied that evening, but I can still smell the rain and the coffee and feel the aura of light and warmth.
title: RETURNING TO CHURCH

text: Later in the season, I attended a Bible-study session the minister led for a gathering of about 20 people on the story of Abraham and Isaac, and I came away with a sense of the awesomeness and power of faith, a quality that loomed above me as tremendous and hard and challenging and tangibly real as mountains. The Bible-study classes, which I later, with other parishioners, learned to lead on occasion myself, became a source of power, like tapping into a rich vein.
title: RETURNING TO CHURCH

text: Bible study was not like examining history, but holding up a mirror to my own life, a mirror in which I sometimes saw things I was trying to keep hidden, even from myself. The first scripture passage I was assigned to lead was from Luke, about the man who cleans his house of demons, and seven worse ones come. I did not have any trouble relating this to ''contemporary life.'' It sounded unnervingly like an allegory about a man who had stopped drinking and so was enjoying much better health, but took up smoking marijuana to ''relax,'' all the while feeling good and even self-righteous about giving up the booze. It was my own story. I realized, with a shock, how I'd been deceiving myself, how much more ''housecleaning'' I had to do. I WAS NOT ONLY GOING to church and devoting time to Bible study and prayer during this period, I was actively engaged in purely secular programs of physical and mental therapy and ''personal growth'' to try to pull myself out of the pit I found myself in when I fled home to Boston in the spring of 1980. I got into an Exercycle and diet program that in six months cut my pulse rate from a dangerously stress-induced 120 to a healthy 60, and shed 20 pounds. I gave up the alcohol that I had used as regularly and purposely as daily medicine for 25 years, then gave up the marijuana that replaced it, and even threw away the faithful briar pipe I had clenched and puffed for a quarter of a century.
title: RETURNING TO CHURCH

text: I used to worry about which of these addictions I kicked through ''church'' and which through secular programs, as if I had to assign proper ''credit,'' and as if it were possible to compartmentalize and isolate the influence of God, like some kind of vitamin. The one thing I know about the deepest feeling connected with all my assortment of life-numbing addictions is that at some point or other they felt as if they were ''lifted,'' taken away, and instead of having to exercise iron control to resist them, it simply felt better not to have to do them anymore. The only concept I know to describe such experience is that of ''grace,'' and the accompanying adjective ''amazing'' comes to mind along with it.
title: RETURNING TO CHURCH

text: I do not for a moment suggest that giving up booze or even drugs, or losing weight or reducing the heart rate is necessarily - or even desirably -a byproduct of religious experience. For many people, such effects may not have anything to do with religion. Each person's quest is his own, with its own imperatives and directions.
title: RETURNING TO CHURCH

text: I became fascinated by other people's spiritual experiences and, 30 years after it was first recommended to me, I read Thomas Merton's ''The Seven Storey Mountain.'' I had avoided it even when the late poet Mark Van Doren, my favorite professor and Merton's former mentor at Columbia, had spoken of it with high regard, but now I devoured it, and went on to read everything else of Merton's I could get my hands on, from the sociopolitical ''Conjectures of a Guilty Bystander'' to the mystical ''The Ascent to Truth.'' Most meaningful of all was a slim ''meditation'' by Merton, called ''He Is Risen,'' which I found by chance in a New York bookstore; it says in matter-of-fact prose that Christ ''is in history with us, walking ahead of us to where we are going. . . .''
title: RETURNING TO CHURCH

text: I thought of these words walking the brick sidewalks of Beacon Hill, thinking for the first time of my life as a ''journey'' rather than a battle I was winning or losing that moment, on whose immediate crashing outcome the fate of the universe (i.e., the turbulent one in my own head) depend-ed. I remembered years ago reading Dorothy Day's column in The Catholic Worker when I lived in Greenwich Village, and I appreciated now for the first time the sense of the title: ''On Pilgrimage.''
title: RETURNING TO CHURCH

text: I CANNOT PINPOINT ANY PAR-ticular time when I suddenly believed in God again while all this was going on. I only know that such belief seemed as natural as for 25 or more years before it had been inconceivable. I realized this while looking at fish.
title: RETURNING TO CHURCH

text: I had gone with my girlfriend of the last several years to the New England Aquarium, and as we gazed at the astonishingly brilliant colors of some of the small tropical fish - reds and yellows and oranges and blues that seemed to be splashed on by some innovative artistic genius - and watched the amazing lights of the flashlight fish that blinked on like the beacons of some creature of a sci-fi epic, I wondered how anyone could think that all this was the result of some chain of accidental explosions! Yet I realized in frustration that to try to convince me otherwise five years before would have been hopeless. Was this what they called ''conversion?''
title: RETURNING TO CHURCH

text: The term bothered me because it suggested being ''born again,'' and like many of my contemporaries, I have been put off by what seems the melodramatic nature of that label, as well as the current political beliefs that seem to go along with it. Besides, I don't feel ''reborn.'' No voice came out of the sky nor did a thunderclap strike me on the path through the Boston Common on the way to King's Chapel. I was relieved when our minister explained that the literal translation of ''conversion'' in both the Hebrew and Greek is not ''rebirth'' but ''turning.'' That's what this has felt like - as if I were walking in one direction and then, in response to some inner pull, I turned -not even all the way around, but only at what seemed a slightly different angle.
title: RETURNING TO CHURCH

text: I wish I could say that this turning has put me on a straight, solid path with blue skies above and a warm, benevolent sun shining down. I certainly enjoy better health than when I began to ''turn'' five years ago, but the path I am on now seems often as dangerous and difficult as the one I was following before. Sometimes it doesn't even seem like a path at all. Sometimes I feel like a hapless passenger in the sort of small airplane they used to show in black and white movies of the 1930's, caught in a thunderstorm, bobbing through the night sky over jagged mountains without a compass.
title: RETURNING TO CHURCH

text: I find strength in the hard wisdom of those who have delved much deeper into the spiritual realm than I, like Henri Nouwen, the Dutch Roman Catholic theologian who wrote in a book our minister recommended, called ''Reaching Out,'' that ''. . . it would be just another illusion to believe that reaching out to God will free us from pain and suffering. Often, indeed, it will take us where we rather would not go. But we know that without going there we will not find our life.''
title: RETURNING TO CHURCH

text: I was thrilled to meet Nouwen at lunch a few years ago, through the consideration of my friend and neighbor James Carroll, the former priest, now novelist. I told Father Nouwen I had read and appreciated his work, but that it dismayed me to read of his anguish in ''Cry for Mercy: Prayers From the Genessee''; it made me wonder with discouragement what chance a neophyte had in pursuit of the spiritual, when someone as advanced as Father Nouwen experienced anguish and confusion in his relation to God (I was neglecting numerous other, even more powerful examples, such as Jesus Christ calling out from the cross). Father Nouwen answered sharply that contrary to what many people may think, ''Christianity is not for getting your life together!''
title: RETURNING TO CHURCH

text: About a year ago, I felt as if finally, with God's help, I was on the right track in my own journey. Then I had an experience that was like running head-on into a wall. First, shock, then a kind of psychic pain as unrelenting as a dentist's drill. And in the torment I prayed, and there was no relief, and twice I turned back to my old way of dealing with things, by trying to numb the pain with drugs. Throughout all this, I never lost faith in God, never imagined He was not there, but only that His presence was obscured. Then the storm broke, like a fever, and I felt in touch again, and in the light. I was grateful, but I also knew such storms would come again, perhaps even more violently.
title: RETURNING TO CHURCH

text: I learned that belief in God does not depend on how well things are going, that faith and prayer and good works do not necessarily have any correlation to earthly reward or even tranquillity, no matter how much we wish they would and think they should. I believe in God because the gift of faith (if not the gift of understanding) has been given to me, and I go to church and pray and meditate to try to be closer to His presence, and, most difficult to all, to discern His willn I know, as it says in the Book of Common Prayer, that His ''service is perfect freedom,'' and my great frustration and anxiety is in the constant choices of how best to serve, with the particular gifts as well as limitations I've been given.
title: RETURNING TO CHURCH

text: A month or so ago, I went to Glastonbury Abbey, a Benedictine monastery in Hingham, only 40 minutes or so from Boston, to spend a day and night in private retreat. I went with about 17 questions in my head about following God or the path He wills us to take. In the chapel bookstore, I saw a thin paperback volume, ''Abandonment to Divine Providence,'' which I picked up, took to my room and devoured. It was written by an 18th-century Jesuit named Jean-Pierre de Caussade, and it sounds (at least in this new translation) as if it had been written yesterday, specifically to answer my questions. I continue to read in it almost every day, and I always find some new passage that seems to speak to the urgency of that moment. This is what I read today, when I felt again jarred and confused about what to choose and where to turn:
title: RETURNING TO CHURCH

text: ''So we follow our wandering paths, and the very darkness acts as our guide and our doubts serve to reassure us. The more puzzled Isaac was at not finding a lamb for the sacrifice, the more confidently did Abraham leave all to providence.''
title: RETURNING TO CHURCH

text: By Philip Shabecoff, Special To the New York Times
title: E.P.A. PLANS TO DROP 8 SITES FROM LIST OF WORST DUMPS

text: The Environmental Protection Agency has announced plans to drop eight hazardous waste sites, including one in Upper Freehold, N.J., from its priority list of dumps requiring quick cleanup action.
title: E.P.A. PLANS TO DROP 8 SITES FROM LIST OF WORST DUMPS

text: There are now 850 sites around the country on or proposed for the priority list and agency officials have said the number could reach 2,000. Before the announcement Friday six sites had been cleaned up enough to warrant removal from the list, although one of those, the Butler tunnel site in Pittston, Pa., later started to leak dangerous substances after a hurricane.
title: E.P.A. PLANS TO DROP 8 SITES FROM LIST OF WORST DUMPS

text: Members of Congress, environmentalists and others have criticized the agency for moving too slowly under the toxic cleanup law to eliminate threats to human health and the environment. The law, the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Liability and Compensation Act of 1980, is often referred to as the Superfund.
title: E.P.A. PLANS TO DROP 8 SITES FROM LIST OF WORST DUMPS

text: The site in Upper Freehold that was removed from the list was the Friedman property, where there had been reports of illegal dumping in the 1950's and 60's. The agency said Friday, however, that tests had not disclosed contamination. Therefore, it said, no cleanup action was necessary and the site could be dropped from the list.
title: E.P.A. PLANS TO DROP 8 SITES FROM LIST OF WORST DUMPS

text: The agency recommended to the state, however, that it preclude excavation or any agricultural or residential use of the Friedman property.
title: E.P.A. PLANS TO DROP 8 SITES FROM LIST OF WORST DUMPS

text: The agency also decided that no action was needed at the Morris site in Morris, Minn., because it had been found that the arsenic-laden grasshopper bait dumped there in the late 1940's had not created unsafe levels of contamination in the soil and water.
title: E.P.A. PLANS TO DROP 8 SITES FROM LIST OF WORST DUMPS

text: Anther of the sites proposed for removal from the list is the Enterprise Avenue landfill in Philadelphia, which was used by the city for disposal of industrial wastes. The agency said that the contaminated soil and water had been removed or cleaned.
title: E.P.A. PLANS TO DROP 8 SITES FROM LIST OF WORST DUMPS

text: Also among the planned deletions from the list are 243 miles of road shoulders in 14 counties in North Carolina where PCB's, or polychlorinated biphenyls, were illegally deposited in 1978. PCB's, liquids used in electrical equipment, have been found to cause cancer.
title: E.P.A. PLANS TO DROP 8 SITES FROM LIST OF WORST DUMPS

text: Other planned deletions include the Lehigh Electric site in Old Forge, Pa.; a PCB warehouse in the Northern Mariana Islands, and PCB waste sites in the Trust Territory of the Pacific and the Taputimu farm in American Samoa. All have been cleaned up to the point where they do not constitute a danger, in the view of the agency.
title: E.P.A. PLANS TO DROP 8 SITES FROM LIST OF WORST DUMPS

text: Henry S. Cole, science director of the National Campaign Against Toxic Hazards, a coalition of citizen groups, complained that the eight sites removed from the priority list had been subject to ''out of sight, out of mind cleanups.''
title: E.P.A. PLANS TO DROP 8 SITES FROM LIST OF WORST DUMPS

text: Dr. Cole said in a telephone interview that in some cases hazardous substances had merely been contained on the sites, and in others the wastes had been carted to other disposal sites that were themselves unsafe.
title: E.P.A. PLANS TO DROP 8 SITES FROM LIST OF WORST DUMPS

text: At the Philadelphia site, he said, chemicals had been left in soil that lay in the floodplain of the Delaware River.
title: E.P.A. PLANS TO DROP 8 SITES FROM LIST OF WORST DUMPS

text: There is no doubt about it:
title: THREE HOURS PASS SWIFTLY IN A NEW 'ST. MATTHEW PASSION'

text: J. S. Bach's ''St. Matthew Passion'' is a long work.
title: THREE HOURS PASS SWIFTLY IN A NEW 'ST. MATTHEW PASSION'

text: Even an expeditious performance runs to nearly three hours plus intermission, and a lugubrious one can last a lifetime, or so it seems. This has presented problems. Little is known about the performing history of the work during Bach's lifetime, but the famous 1829 performance organized by Felix Mendelssohn as part of his Bach revival was stripped of well over an hour of music in the interests of ''heightening'' the dramatic impact. (The first complete performance of modern times took place as late as 1912).
title: THREE HOURS PASS SWIFTLY IN A NEW 'ST. MATTHEW PASSION'

text: Nowadays, uncut St. Matthew Passions are the norm, especially on recording; it would take a courageous conductor indeed to excise so much as a note from the score. This is to the good, both because of the current feeling that the composer knows best and because the St. Matthew Passion happens to work very well as it is. Attempts to bolster either the dramatic or the contemplative side of the composition invariably set it off balance structurally and lessen its overall effect.
title: THREE HOURS PASS SWIFTLY IN A NEW 'ST. MATTHEW PASSION'

text: Peter Schreier, the conductor of the readings on Philips 412 527-2 (three digital compact disks; four LP's, three cassettes), makes no such attempts. Rather, he respects the work's natural equilibrium. For example, dance rhythms abound, and, rather than playing them down as incongruous in a sacred work, he gives them their head and lets them fill the musical function Bach intended for them. When the score bursts out into theatrical ferocity (which can consist of a full-scale chorus representing the angry mob or a single dissonant harmony in a recitative), no move is made to tame it to bring it into line with the gentler portions.
title: THREE HOURS PASS SWIFTLY IN A NEW 'ST. MATTHEW PASSION'

text: That does not, as it might, make for a disjointed performance; the result is thoroughly satisfying, with the three hours of music passing with hardly a dull moment (only a couple of the bass arias, sung by Robert Holl, plod a little). The soprano Lucia Popp is delightful, and the contralto Marjana Lipovsek has a warm, plummy voice that loses nothing in clarity for all its richness; the tenor arias are sung appealingly by Eberhard Buchner.
title: THREE HOURS PASS SWIFTLY IN A NEW 'ST. MATTHEW PASSION'

text: But arias constitute only the lyrical and contemplative parts of the ''St. Matthew Passion''; the recitatives and choruses are where the action is carried forward, and any weakness in these areas is unfailingly disastrous. There is no such weakness here. For one thing, the conductor Peter Schreier is fortunate to have one of the foremost Evangelists on the musical scene pretty much on call: the tenor Peter Schreier. It is easy to fall into the trap of making assumptions about singers who turn to conducting, but rest assured that Mr. Schreier's voice is as fresh as ever. He has, in fact, been conducting on and off for about 15 years.
title: THREE HOURS PASS SWIFTLY IN A NEW 'ST. MATTHEW PASSION'

text: His Evangelist tells his tale expressively, but does not emote. This is not opera, and he is merely narrating the story, not living through it. Still, the dramatic climax of the work (when Peter realizes in dismay that he has thrice betrayed Christ) is no less moving for being understated.
title: THREE HOURS PASS SWIFTLY IN A NEW 'ST. MATTHEW PASSION'

text: Other soloists assigned to recitative duty include Theo Adam as Jesus. Mr. Adam is no newcomer to this score and does a thoroughly credible job, even if a slightly fresher sound might have been more appropriate. As Peter, Andreas Scheibner gives full value to musical contours but still manages a very natural-sounding, almost conversational, declamation; he brings his role to life in a way that is not as common as it ought to be in Bach recitative singing. Then there is Ekkehard Wlaschiha's Judas, which positively drips evil; the characterization stands on the verge of caricature, but stops just short of slipping over the edge.
title: THREE HOURS PASS SWIFTLY IN A NEW 'ST. MATTHEW PASSION'

text: This Philips recording was a co-production with the East German Government; the good orchestra is the Staatskapelle Dresden, and the choir is the Rundfunkchor Leipzig with the boys of the Dresdner Kapellknaben. The choral work is especially worthy of note. It could (but will not) be criticized for too great an attention to detail: some of the chorales - which, after all, are simple hymn tunes, even if they sometimes contain hair-raising harmonies - are tricked out with endless choirmasterly subtleties of phrasing and dynamics. But still, it is beautiful singing: full-throated, accurate, passionate. You will jump out of your seat at the dissonant cry of ''Barrabam!''
title: THREE HOURS PASS SWIFTLY IN A NEW 'ST. MATTHEW PASSION'

text: The ''St. Matthew Passion'' makes considerable use of bichoral effects, with discrete vocal and instrumental groups usually placed on either side of the platform. This stereo recording errs a trifle on the side of keeping them too separate at times. Everything sounds natural enough when the whole ensemble is playing, but when there is back-and-forth byplay between groups (as in the opening chorus) the impression is of an auditory tennis match, with the musical ball bouncing from speaker to speaker. This is a minor point, for the levels and balances are on the whole exemplary.
title: THREE HOURS PASS SWIFTLY IN A NEW 'ST. MATTHEW PASSION'

text: On a smaller scale altogether is another Philips compact disk release (411 458-2; also on LP and cassette), of Bach's Magnificat in D major and his cantata number 51, ''Jauchzet Gott in allen Landen'' for solo soprano and orchestra. Not only are the works themselves smaller, but they are performed by a smaller group, the English Baroque Soloists and the Monteverdi Choir, under the direction of John Eliot Gardiner. The Magnificat is a grand, festive work, with drums and trumpets; it is interesting to note that despite the smaller forces none of the grandeur is lost. Good, precise singing and playing, plus incisive rhythms, will do the trick every time.
title: THREE HOURS PASS SWIFTLY IN A NEW 'ST. MATTHEW PASSION'

text: The vocalists, choir and soloists alike, have a very pleasing, youthful sound. Some listeners will no doubt prefer bigger, more substantial voices, but no one will deny the stylishness and musicality of these performances.
title: THREE HOURS PASS SWIFTLY IN A NEW 'ST. MATTHEW PASSION'

text: The solo cantata is sung by Emma Kirkby, prettily if coolly. True success in this short, brilliant work depends as much on fervor as on technique and musicianship, and that fervor is missing. Alison Bury and Roy Goodman, who play the obbligato violin parts in the chorale, are just wonderful, which is particularly gratifying in light of the poor fiddling that continues to plague many performances on historical instruments.
title: THREE HOURS PASS SWIFTLY IN A NEW 'ST. MATTHEW PASSION'

text: A 26-year-old man was convicted yesterday of murder in the shooting of a high-school honor student four years ago outside a Manhattan doughnut shop owned by the victim's father.
title: Man, 26, Guilty In Youth's Killing

text: The defendant, Joel R. Cabangon, who surrendered and confessed to the police last year, was found guilty of murder by Judge Shirley R. Levittan in Criminal Court in Manhattan. Mr. Cabangon could face a life term when he is sentenced on Jan. 8.
title: Man, 26, Guilty In Youth's Killing

text: The 17-year-old victim, Allan Spiegel, attended W. Tresper Clarke High School in Westbury, L.I. He was returning to his father's doughnut shop, at 42d Street and Madison Avenue, after making a delivery, when Mr. Cabangon, who did not know him, shot him without warning. Mr. Cabangon fled to his native Philippines but returned to New York more than two years later.
title: Man, 26, Guilty In Youth's Killing

text: Judge Levittan said Mr. Cabangon's defense, that he had been given a marijuana cigarette laced - without his knowledge - with the drug PCP was ''inconclusive.''
title: Man, 26, Guilty In Youth's Killing

text: By Robert Reinhold, Special To the New York Times
title: U.S.-MEXICAN DRUG EFFORTS SAID TO PROGRESS

text: The Attorneys General of the United States and Mexico, ending a two-day meeting here, reported new progress in their cooperative efforts to control drug trafficking across the border. The meeting followed by just five days the cracking of what officials said was a major drug-smuggling ring.
title: U.S.-MEXICAN DRUG EFFORTS SAID TO PROGRESS

text: The discussions here went beyond drugs, officials said today, to include such other mutual concerns as the smuggling of stolen babies, vehicles and weapons across the border.
title: U.S.-MEXICAN DRUG EFFORTS SAID TO PROGRESS

text: It was the third meeting between Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d and his Mexican counterpart, Sergio Garcia Ramirez, since the recent torture and murder of Enrique Camarena Salazar, an American agent of the Drug Enforcement Administration in Mexico. American officials had expressed unhappiness with the pace of the Mexican investigation into the killing.
title: U.S.-MEXICAN DRUG EFFORTS SAID TO PROGRESS

text: At a news conference today, both Attorneys General sought to minimize any residual tension over the case. Mr. Meese said that ''significant progress'' had been made in the case and that the Attorneys General ''are both looking ahead to continued progress in the future.'' Speaking generally about the drug trade, Mr. Garcia said, ''For the time being we are encouraged by the progress we have achieved.''
title: U.S.-MEXICAN DRUG EFFORTS SAID TO PROGRESS

text: The meeting at the Hilton Palacio del Rio Hotel brought together seven top American law-enforcement and drug officials with their Mexican counterparts. It followed a Federal indictment of 48 people and corporations, including a Texas bank and its former president, last week on charges of importing a quarter of a million pounds of marijuana since 1980 and disguising the origins of the proceeds through numerous American banks.
title: U.S.-MEXICAN DRUG EFFORTS SAID TO PROGRESS

text: Officials are exultant over the case. ''We think it is one of the largest rings ever cracked,'' said Charles E. Lewis, an assistant United States attorney in Houston who is a regional coordinator for the Presidential Drug Task Force. ''We don't have any illusions this will shut down the drug problem. But it will have a high impact on this cartel.''
title: U.S.-MEXICAN DRUG EFFORTS SAID TO PROGRESS

text: Among those indicted were two uncles of Rafael Caro-Quintero, who has been charged in Mexico with the killing of Mr. Camarena and awaits trial. The uncles are Juan Jose Quintero-Payan, 37 years old, and Emilio Quintero-Payan, 32, both of Guadalajara.
title: U.S.-MEXICAN DRUG EFFORTS SAID TO PROGRESS

text: According to Mr. Lewis, Mr. Camarena was working on ''aspects'' of the current case when he was kidnapped last spring. But the indictment does not implicate any of the defendants in his murder.
title: U.S.-MEXICAN DRUG EFFORTS SAID TO PROGRESS

text: The Quintero brothers are fugitives, presumably still in Mexico, and Mr. Lewis acknowledged that he had little hope of extraditing them. ''The extradition of Mexican citizens from Mexico is rare to nonexistent,'' he said. Neither are American citizens generally extradited to Mexico.
title: U.S.-MEXICAN DRUG EFFORTS SAID TO PROGRESS

text: Still, 32 people, including two Mexican citizens, have been arrested and are being arraigned one by one in Federal District Court here this week on charges of smuggling, racketeering, conspiracy and perjury. Tens of millions of dollars in cash and real estate has been seized from the defendants.
title: U.S.-MEXICAN DRUG EFFORTS SAID TO PROGRESS

text: In flat legal language, the indictment gives a rare, revealing glimpse of the shadowy underworld that transports drugs across the porous Mexican-American border. It tells of water torture, of attempted murder of informers, of vans gliding through Texas loaded down with marijuana, and of real estate casually bought with hundreds of thousands of dollars in cash.
title: U.S.-MEXICAN DRUG EFFORTS SAID TO PROGRESS

text: A central figure in the ring was said to be Juan Frank Garcia, a 35-year-old former elementary-school teacher from Edinburg, Tex., now a fugitive, who is identified in the indictment as the principal American buyer of drugs from the Quinteros. The indictment says he bought $1.5 million in gold with drug profits and then, when $600,000 of it was stolen last year, kidnapped two suspects, beating one of them and using ''water torture'' on the other to force them to disclose its whereabouts.
title: U.S.-MEXICAN DRUG EFFORTS SAID TO PROGRESS

text: Oliver Revell, an aide to the director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, said the discussion ranged well beyond narcotics and the Camarena case, adding that traffic in stolen babies, heavy equipment and weapons were connected to the drug trade.
title: U.S.-MEXICAN DRUG EFFORTS SAID TO PROGRESS

text: The two sides agreed to establish a common data base for statistical information and to help coordinate action against drug traffickers. But no quick solutions were promised. ''We know we have a continuing problem that is not abating,'' Mr. Meese said.
title: U.S.-MEXICAN DRUG EFFORTS SAID TO PROGRESS

text: The Food and Drug Administration has approved use of synthetic THC, the psychoactive ingredient in marijuana, for treating the nausea and vomiting that often result from cancer chemotherapy. In past years, the drug has been available directly from the National Cancer Institute but now the way has been cleared for commercial production, according to The Medical Letter.
title: Nausea in Chemotherapy

text: The drug, which is taken orally, is known generically as dronabinol and will by marketed under the trade name Marinol. In controlled trials it proved to be an effective antiemetic following many types of chemotherapy although not for patients receiving the anticancer drug cisplatin. Just how THC combats these unpleasant side effects of chemotherapy is not known but evidence indicates it binds to opiate receptors in the forebrain and indirectly inhibits the vomiting center in an area of the brain known as the medulla.
title: Nausea in Chemotherapy

text: The side effects of ingesting THC include drowsiness and orthostatic hypotension, also known as ''dry mouth.'' Other effects such as dizziness, disorientation, depression, paranoia, hallucinations and manic psychosis sometimes occur and ''seem to be more troublesome in older patients, and those who have never used marijuana,'' The Medical Letter stated.
title: Nausea in Chemotherapy

text: Dronabinol will be listed as a Schedule II drug, the most restricted and controlled category of prescription drugs.
title: Nausea in Chemotherapy

text: The 21-year-old college student was failing her courses and feeling depressed. She dropped out of school and consulted a psychiatrist. ''He said, 'No cause to worry' - I was just suffering from adolescent problems and from the fact that I had been small as a child,'' the woman said the other day. ''I told him that I was drinking and taking drugs - marijuana, LSD - but he didn't want to discuss that at all.''
title: DOCTORS LEARNING TO DIAGNOSE ALCOHOLISM

text: A year later, the woman, who asked that her name not be used, consulted another psychiatrist. ''This one told me I was going through an identity crisis and simply needed time to work things out for myself,'' she recalled. Again, although she candidly described her dependence on alcohol and drugs, the doctor dismissed it.
title: DOCTORS LEARNING TO DIAGNOSE ALCOHOLISM

text: So did other physicians she consulted over the next several years for various ailments. Six more years elapsed, and finally a psychiatrist - whose name she had found in the Yellow Pages - said, ''Do you have a problem with alcohol?'' and referred her to Alcoholics Anonymous. ''I have been sober ever since,'' the woman said.
title: DOCTORS LEARNING TO DIAGNOSE ALCOHOLISM

text: The stone wall that this patient encountered is not unusual. For the most part, authorities on alcoholism say, physicians have failed to detect excessive drinking by patients, or when they have uncovered the problem, they have not known what to do about it. Even among doctors who recognized the symptoms, there was a tendency to ignore them, or to believe that alcoholics need only use a little willpower. Many physicians have viewed alcoholism as a moral failing and not a medical, biological, psychological and social condition.
title: DOCTORS LEARNING TO DIAGNOSE ALCOHOLISM

text: In the last decade, however, change has slowly come to the field of addiction treatment. Now the vast number of conditions provoked or exacerbated by alcoholism are being acknowledged and diagnosed, and there is a growing realization that alcoholism is eminently treatable. As Dr. Robert G. Niven, director of the National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism in Bethesda, Md., said, ''Though we still fall far short of the ideal - integration of education about alcohol and drug consumption into all medical and health professional schools - the situation is improving.''
title: DOCTORS LEARNING TO DIAGNOSE ALCOHOLISM

text: The statistics are not encouraging, however, as Dr. David C. Lewis, president of the Association of Medical Education and Research in Substance Abuse, a 400-member professional organization, found when he surveyed the medical literature. ''Some 20 to 40 percent of general-hospital admissions involve individuals with serious drinking or drug problems, most of them alcohol, as do 10 to 15 percent of ambulatory cases and 40 to 60 percent of emergency-room visits,'' Dr. Lewis said. ''But the actual diagnosis of the disorder is made in less than 5 percent of cases.''
title: DOCTORS LEARNING TO DIAGNOSE ALCOHOLISM

text: ''The implication is clear,'' said Dr. Lewis, professor of medicine and community health at Brown University, ''that physicians are mainly treating the complications of drinking without necessarily focusing on the treatment for those behaviors.'' Amersa, as the organization Dr. Lewis leads is known, met recently in California for a conference, co-sponsored by the National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism, the National Institute on Drug Abuse and the Betty Ford Center, to discuss what primary-care physicians ought to know and how to implement curriculum improvements.
title: DOCTORS LEARNING TO DIAGNOSE ALCOHOLISM

text: Dr. Lewis and his colleagues are optimistic. As Dr. Charles Rorhis, director of substance-abuse treatment at the New York Veterans Administration Medical Center, said: ''None of us dealing with this problem day in and out will ever feel that the approach of the medical profession is as good as we want it to be, but over the last 10 years, things have changed quite a bit. Doctors are more sensitive to problems associated with alcohol.''
title: DOCTORS LEARNING TO DIAGNOSE ALCOHOLISM

text: ''There are more treatment resources available,'' he said, ''more hospital beds for detoxification, more in-patient rehabilitation programs, more outpatient services, more community-based programs, psychotherapy clinics, therapeutic communities, halfway houses and freestanding specialty hospitals that deal only with alcohol. Third-party reimbursement has become available, and there is the whole self-help movement. Active research is continuously providing new information.''
title: DOCTORS LEARNING TO DIAGNOSE ALCOHOLISM

text: In the past, medical students generally spent a few hours on alcoholism during the course of their four years of study. But that has changed, in part due to the Career Teacher Program, which was financed by the Federal Government from 1971 to 1982. Under that program, faculty members from about 60 schools received grants to develop new courses or expand existing ones.
title: DOCTORS LEARNING TO DIAGNOSE ALCOHOLISM

text: Several schools became pioneers, including Dartmouth Medical School. In 1978, it began a four-year program called Project Cork, financed by the Joan B. Kroc Foundation. As Jean Kinney, the executive director, explained, ''It was designed to integrate alcohol education through every course in the medical school.'' The project was subsequently duplicated elsewhere and became a model for such schools as the University of Washington and Morehouse School of Medicine in Atlanta. Others leaders in the field are Brown and the New York University School of Medicine.
title: DOCTORS LEARNING TO DIAGNOSE ALCOHOLISM

text: Currently, at Johns Hopkins University the dean of the medical school, Dr. Richard S. Ross, and the president of the hospital, Dr. Robert M. Heyssel, are leading an innovative program. The goal is to familiarize everyone affiliated with the hospital and medical school, from first-year students to senior faculty members, with the symptoms of alcoholism and appropriate treatment.
title: DOCTORS LEARNING TO DIAGNOSE ALCOHOLISM

text: According to Dr. Emma J. Stokes, special assistant to the dean, the three-year project that began in the summer of 1984 has shown that ''we were addressing how the various organs such as the liver, heart and brain are affected by abuse, but we haven't addressed the clinical entity called alcoholism.''
title: DOCTORS LEARNING TO DIAGNOSE ALCOHOLISM

text: In patient care, she said, ''we don't routinely take effective alcohol histories, so students are not taught what is healthy versus unhealthy drinking, and they are unable to evaluate the answers.'' As the program progresses, they are learning to do that; students are also learning to assess their own attitudes, ''to teach them that they may be avoiding diagnosing somebody who looks just like their Aunt Mary,'' Dr. Stokes said.
title: DOCTORS LEARNING TO DIAGNOSE ALCOHOLISM

text: But not all of the impetus can come from the medical community. According to Allan Luks, executive director of the Alcoholism Council of Greater New York, the patient must bear some responsibility, too.
title: DOCTORS LEARNING TO DIAGNOSE ALCOHOLISM

text: ''We can't place the entire burden on the doctor,'' he said. ''In today's health-awareness age, so many questions are initiated by educated patients. We have not educated patients sufficiently in alcohol so that they can ask the right questions.''
title: DOCTORS LEARNING TO DIAGNOSE ALCOHOLISM

text: Last month, brochures describing alcohol-linked health problems were mailed by the council to physicians in the five boroughs and to corporate medical offices. To obtain a free copy, call 212-935-7070, and ask for the ''Health and Fitness Guide to Alcohol.''
title: DOCTORS LEARNING TO DIAGNOSE ALCOHOLISM

text: WHEN Charleston, W. Va., announced plans to use television surveillance in a redeveloped downtown plaza to deter crime, some residents objected. They said in August 1984 that the cameras would intrude on their privacy.
title: POLICING BY TV

text: The city said it would install the system and connect it to Police Headquarters before the year was out.
title: POLICING BY TV

text: For the last half-year, five cameras have been covering 200 stores in four blocks of what was once a high-crime area, and ''we have had really good success,'' says Police Chief William K. Carper.
title: POLICING BY TV

text: Aside from one mugging that the rotating cameras missed, they have led directly to more than a half-dozen arrests and furnished evidence on drug traffic, assaults and other crimes, the Chief says.
title: POLICING BY TV

text: In general, ''it's been well accepted'' by the public, reports Hugh Bosely, director of the Mayor's Office of Economic Community Development.
title: POLICING BY TV

text: Even though the cameras are not concealed, ''people don't pay any attention to them,'' the Chief says -especially criminals, whose intelligence he calls ''highly overrated.''
title: POLICING BY TV

text: ''They'll sit right out there in the open at a table smoking marijuana,'' he says. ''We even had a 13-person free-for-all that was all filmed.''
title: POLICING BY TV

text: ''We'd like to have more cameras, Chief Carper continues. ''My experience is that the best crime deterrent is a good, honest beat officer. Next to that, give me the cameras. Forget helicopters and dogs - I'll take the cameras.''
title: POLICING BY TV

text: In response to changing patterns of drug abuse, the Federal Drug Enforcement Administration has embarked on a new agenda in New York and stepped up the pursuit of organizations trafficking in cocaine, according to the newly appointed head of the agency's largest district office.
title: NEW ASSAULT ON COCAINE PLEDGE BY U.S. DRUG CHIEF IN NEW YORK

text: ''That doesn't mean we're denigrating heroin, but it's not the only problem anymore and so we have to change our priorities,'' said Robert M. Stutman, special agent in charge of the agency's office in New York. Mr. Stutman six weeks ago replaced Bruce M. Jensen, who retired.
title: NEW ASSAULT ON COCAINE PLEDGE BY U.S. DRUG CHIEF IN NEW YORK

text: In November, according to Mr. Stutman, 2,200 pounds of cocaine were seized by the agency in the metropolitan region, most of it during raids in Long Island and New Jersey suburbs. While large seizures are not a measure of the agency's success, Mr. Stutman said, the size of the recent raids is one indication of the growing cocaine problem.
title: NEW ASSAULT ON COCAINE PLEDGE BY U.S. DRUG CHIEF IN NEW YORK

text: The use of other illegal drugs, ranging from heroin to marijuana, has declined or stabilized in recent years, according to experts in law enforcement and treatment. Cocaine abuse, however, has grown, the experts say, with five million regular users in the United States and one million of them in the New York area.
title: NEW ASSAULT ON COCAINE PLEDGE BY U.S. DRUG CHIEF IN NEW YORK

text: Nonetheless, until recently, the agency's focus in New York remained the disruption of traditional crime organizations trafficking in heroin.
title: NEW ASSAULT ON COCAINE PLEDGE BY U.S. DRUG CHIEF IN NEW YORK

text: Mr. Stutman discussed the agency's plans in the New York metropolitan region during an interview last week in his office on West 57th Street, where Brahms played on the stereo and a vista of river and sky stretched outside the windows.
title: NEW ASSAULT ON COCAINE PLEDGE BY U.S. DRUG CHIEF IN NEW YORK

text: In addition to the increased emphasis on disrupting the Colombian-based cocaine trade, including the reassignment of agents, Mr. Stutman said he planned these changes in the operation of the New York office of the Drug Enforcement Administration, the agency responsible for the enforcement of Federal drug laws:
title: NEW ASSAULT ON COCAINE PLEDGE BY U.S. DRUG CHIEF IN NEW YORK

text: * Improved working relationships with other law enforcement bodies, including the New York City Police Department, the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the United States Attorneys.
title: NEW ASSAULT ON COCAINE PLEDGE BY U.S. DRUG CHIEF IN NEW YORK

text: * More contact with the public and news organizations, which Mr. Stutman said serves to build morale among agents, encourage potential informants and deter criminals.
title: NEW ASSAULT ON COCAINE PLEDGE BY U.S. DRUG CHIEF IN NEW YORK

text: * A role in school-based drug prevention programs. ''Anyone who thinks the Feds or the cops can stop drugs has no concept of the real world,'' Mr. Stutman said. ''We have to stop people from wanting to use the substances.''
title: NEW ASSAULT ON COCAINE PLEDGE BY U.S. DRUG CHIEF IN NEW YORK

text: After six years as head of the New England district office in Boston, Mr. Stutman, who is 43 years old, characterized his new post as the ''pinnacle'' for a narcotics agent, an opportunity to direct ''large-scale conspiracy cases'' that ''more often than not, affect what's happening all over the United States.''
title: NEW ASSAULT ON COCAINE PLEDGE BY U.S. DRUG CHIEF IN NEW YORK

text: In trying to stem the tide of cocaine, Mr. Stutman said that his agents -there are several hundred in the office - will focus on locating the Colombians who he said control the cocaine traffic here, incarcerating the leaders of the organizations and appropriating their assests.
title: NEW ASSAULT ON COCAINE PLEDGE BY U.S. DRUG CHIEF IN NEW YORK

text: To advance that goal, he has recently moved into supervisory positions several agents of Hispanic background, with field experience in Miami, which has been the center of the agency's cocaine operation. Mr. Stutman also said he planned to redeploy an undisclosed number of agents to cocaine-related assignments.
title: NEW ASSAULT ON COCAINE PLEDGE BY U.S. DRUG CHIEF IN NEW YORK

text: While virtually all the cocaine entering the United States passes through Florida, Mr. Stutman said, much of that traffic is controlled by organizations with headquarters in New York.
title: NEW ASSAULT ON COCAINE PLEDGE BY U.S. DRUG CHIEF IN NEW YORK

text: Unlike local police departments, which focus on so-called buy-and-bust operations - quick arrests of low-level dealers - Mr. Stutman pledged not to measure his success by the quantities of drugs seized. ''Our object is to disrupt organizations,'' Mr. Stutman said. ''Seizing their product is a nice byproduct, but not the be-all and end-all.''
title: NEW ASSAULT ON COCAINE PLEDGE BY U.S. DRUG CHIEF IN NEW YORK

text: ''The analogy I like to use is this,'' he continued. ''Could a well-run organization afford to lose a truckload of its product? Of course it could. But, could it afford to lose its president, all its vice presidents and its director of marketing? Probably not, and that's what we're aiming for. If we can do that by arresting five people instead of 5,000 people, I will have achieved my objective.''
title: NEW ASSAULT ON COCAINE PLEDGE BY U.S. DRUG CHIEF IN NEW YORK

text: One of Mr. Stutman's first priorities was meeting with local law enforcement officials, such as Benjamin Ward, the New York Police Commissioner; Rudolph W. Giuliani, the United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York; Raymond J. Dearie, the United States Attorney for the Eastern District, and John Hogan, the newly appointed head of the New York office of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.
title: NEW ASSAULT ON COCAINE PLEDGE BY U.S. DRUG CHIEF IN NEW YORK

text: Mr. Stutman praised the Police Department and the Federal prosecutors as the most sophisticated and aggressive in the country.
title: NEW ASSAULT ON COCAINE PLEDGE BY U.S. DRUG CHIEF IN NEW YORK

text: As for the F.B.I., Mr. Stutman said he hoped to relieve strain between the two agencies that since 1982 have shared jurisdiction for drug cases. In Boston, he said, the two groups once scorned each other - with the Drug Enforcement Administration agents joking that ''when an F.B.I. man went undercover he took his tie off,'' and the F.B.I. agents considering the D.E.A. operatives ''door-kicking animals.''
title: NEW ASSAULT ON COCAINE PLEDGE BY U.S. DRUG CHIEF IN NEW YORK

text: ''Eventually, we were able to form a close Federal response, as opposed to a D.E.A. response versus an F.B.I. response,'' Mr. Stutman said. ''When it works, it works, and there's room for improvment here.''
title: NEW ASSAULT ON COCAINE PLEDGE BY U.S. DRUG CHIEF IN NEW YORK

text: Mr. Stutman gained a reputation in Boston as a witty and urbane spokesman for an agency that historically has not relished publicity.
title: NEW ASSAULT ON COCAINE PLEDGE BY U.S. DRUG CHIEF IN NEW YORK

text: He said that his desire for exposure was a ''management tool'' and not an expression of political ambition. ''It's important for agents to feel good about who they are and what they do,'' Mr. Stutman said. ''One of the ways to do that is public recognition.''
title: NEW ASSAULT ON COCAINE PLEDGE BY U.S. DRUG CHIEF IN NEW YORK

text: In addition, he said, the agency depends on tips from citizens - ''sometimes bad guys and sometimes good guys'' - who are more likely to step forward if they are familiar with the agency's leadership. In Boston, Mr. Stutman said, a man in prison offered his services as an informant and provided information that led to 27 arrests.
title: NEW ASSAULT ON COCAINE PLEDGE BY U.S. DRUG CHIEF IN NEW YORK

text: A large part of Mr. Stutman's public profile in New England was his role as a zealous anti-drug lecturer in schools. He has no immediate invitations to speak in New York, but recently met with Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato and expressed interest in ''generating meaningful prevention and education programs for the kids of this state.''
title: NEW ASSAULT ON COCAINE PLEDGE BY U.S. DRUG CHIEF IN NEW YORK

text: Some educators and local politicians in New England shunned Mr. Stutman's frank approach with the students, but he was well received by audiences. ''I let them know in no uncertain terms that I know more about dope than they do,'' Mr. Stutman said. ''And I never lie and I never preach.''
title: NEW ASSAULT ON COCAINE PLEDGE BY U.S. DRUG CHIEF IN NEW YORK

text: Forty-four people, a Texas bank and two companies in the Cayman Islands have been indicted in connection with a drug ring that is said to have brought 250,000 pounds of marijuana into the United States from Mexico, it was announced today.
title: 44 PEOPLE, BANK AND 2 BUSINESSES INDICTED ON FEDERAL DRUG CHARGES

text: Federal officials in Texas said 26 of the people charged had been arrested.
title: 44 PEOPLE, BANK AND 2 BUSINESSES INDICTED ON FEDERAL DRUG CHARGES

text: The eight-count indictment unsealed in Federal Court in San Antonio, Tex., grew out of a drug investigation that was begun two years ago under a program created by the Reagan Administration to break up narcotics rings and apprehend people who handle illegal drug profits or finance drug trafficking, the Justice Department said.
title: 44 PEOPLE, BANK AND 2 BUSINESSES INDICTED ON FEDERAL DRUG CHARGES

text: The indictment said, among other things, that the organization charged with the trafficking had devised a scheme to use banks in Texas, California, New York and the Cayman Islands to disguise the source of drug profits.
title: 44 PEOPLE, BANK AND 2 BUSINESSES INDICTED ON FEDERAL DRUG CHARGES

text: The Justice Department said the trafficking began in 1980 and involved the importation from Mexico of marijuana and methaqualone, a hypnotic sedative that is the principal ingredient in the prescription drug Quaalude.
title: 44 PEOPLE, BANK AND 2 BUSINESSES INDICTED ON FEDERAL DRUG CHARGES

text: ''Marijuana was brought across the border by airplane and tanker truck, and an extensive distribution system was set up to take marijuana to Dallas and Houston and as far away as Chicago,'' the Government charged. It cited one shipment that contained 100,000 methaqualone pills.
title: 44 PEOPLE, BANK AND 2 BUSINESSES INDICTED ON FEDERAL DRUG CHARGES

text: The department said about 40 banks were used by members of the drug ring ''in their efforts to store, conceal and transfer the proceeds'' from their trafficking operation. The department said the value of drug-related assets seized so far has exceeded $30 million.
title: 44 PEOPLE, BANK AND 2 BUSINESSES INDICTED ON FEDERAL DRUG CHARGES

text: The bank named in the indictment is the Metropolitan National Bank of McAllen, Tex. The indictment also charged that James Fox, a former president of Metropolitan National Bank, had ordered that no reports be filed on currency transactions by one of the other defendants.
title: 44 PEOPLE, BANK AND 2 BUSINESSES INDICTED ON FEDERAL DRUG CHARGES

text: The Cayman Islands businesses were identified as European Commodities Ltd. and Continental Resources Ltd. Among the individual defendants were two Mexican nationals.
title: 44 PEOPLE, BANK AND 2 BUSINESSES INDICTED ON FEDERAL DRUG CHARGES

text: Some of the individuals named were accused of having conducted a continuing criminal enterprise, the most serious Federal drug offense. It is punishable by a maximum penalty of life in prison without possibility of parole.
title: 44 PEOPLE, BANK AND 2 BUSINESSES INDICTED ON FEDERAL DRUG CHARGES

text: By Robert Hanley, Special To the New York Times
title: THE VALIDITY OF STUDENT DRUG TESTING

text: In the last year or two, compulsory testing for drug use has started taking root - and winning judicial acceptance - in some sectors of American business, sport and government.
title: THE VALIDITY OF STUDENT DRUG TESTING

text: Against this backdrop, a small high school in New Jersey wants all of its students to undergo mandatory drug screening through urinalysis.
title: THE VALIDITY OF STUDENT DRUG TESTING

text: The constitutionality of the policy has been challenged, and a state judge, Peter Ciolino, of the New Jersey Superior Court, is expected to rule on its legality this week.
title: THE VALIDITY OF STUDENT DRUG TESTING

text: As this is a test case, Judge Ciolino's decision is expected to be carefully scrutinized by school administrators, law-enforcement officials, civil libertarians and parents in New Jersey and elsewhere.
title: THE VALIDITY OF STUDENT DRUG TESTING

text: The policy at issue was adopted in August by the school board for Becton Regional High School, which draws its 500 or so students from the adjacent middle-class towns of East Rutherford and Carlstadt in southern Bergen County.
title: THE VALIDITY OF STUDENT DRUG TESTING

text: The testing was incorporated into a comprehensive medical examination required of all high school students in New Jersey. Testing urine samples for symptoms of diabetes, kidney disorders and other ailments was already a routine part of the examination at Becton.
title: THE VALIDITY OF STUDENT DRUG TESTING

text: Becton Regional's board went a step further, however, by voting to have the urine samples of all students analyzed for traces of drugs.
title: THE VALIDITY OF STUDENT DRUG TESTING

text: A week after the policy was adopted, the American Civil Liberties Union, acting on behalf of five Becton students and their parents, filed suit, calling the drug testing an unconstitutional invasion of privacy and an illegal search and seizure prohibited by the Fourth Amendment.
title: THE VALIDITY OF STUDENT DRUG TESTING

text: Judge Ciolino barred this phase of the examination pending his ruling on its constitutionality.
title: THE VALIDITY OF STUDENT DRUG TESTING

text: Of the tens of thousands of school districts in the country, only a handful have tried to impose drug tests on students, principally because of the invasion-of-privacy question.
title: THE VALIDITY OF STUDENT DRUG TESTING

text: Experts on teen-age drug use say they know of only one district - in Milton, Wis. - using urinalysis. This program, begun in February 1984, requires urinalysis of any student who is suspected of drug use and denies it. If he refuses to submit to testing, he is suspended from school for three days and his parents are notified.
title: THE VALIDITY OF STUDENT DRUG TESTING

text: The Milton Superintendent, Jon C. Platts, said the program had identified about 40 drug users and referred them for treatment. ''It's been extremely well-received by the community,'' he said.
title: THE VALIDITY OF STUDENT DRUG TESTING

text: Last July, a New York State judge banned a urine test for 23 teachers seeking tenure in the Patchogue-Medford School District in Suffolk County, calling the plan an ''unconstitutional search'' of their bodies.
title: THE VALIDITY OF STUDENT DRUG TESTING

text: In contrast to the situation in schools, screening for drugs is gaining acceptance in the workplace and elsewhere.
title: THE VALIDITY OF STUDENT DRUG TESTING

text: In recent months, Federal judges have permitted it for military personnel; city employees in Marietta, Ga.; jockeys at racetracks in New Jersey, and employees of the Federal Railroad Administration.
title: THE VALIDITY OF STUDENT DRUG TESTING

text: Currently, about a quarter of the Fortune 500 companies require such testing of job applicants, according to Peter Bensinger, former head of the Federal Drug Enforcement Administration and now a consultant to industry on drug use.
title: THE VALIDITY OF STUDENT DRUG TESTING

text: The baseball commissioner, Peter Ueberroth, has ordered mandatory testing for all baseball employees under his jurisdiction, and he wants it extended to major league players.
title: THE VALIDITY OF STUDENT DRUG TESTING

text: Just before the summer recess last spring, several Becton students were taking drugs before classes one morning in a car in the school parking lot.
title: THE VALIDITY OF STUDENT DRUG TESTING

text: One girl passed out after using marijuana laced with the chemical PCP, or angel dust, according to Alfred L. Marbaise, the Superintendent at Becton. The other youths hurried into school.
title: THE VALIDITY OF STUDENT DRUG TESTING

text: ''The girl was unconscious and they just left her,'' Mr. Marbaise said. ''She was overdosed. She could have died.'' When school authorities heard about the girl, they had her taken to a hospital for treatment.
title: THE VALIDITY OF STUDENT DRUG TESTING

text: More than anything else, Mr. Marbaise said, the incident led to enactment of the screening policy.
title: THE VALIDITY OF STUDENT DRUG TESTING

text: During hearings before Judge Ciolino on Nov. 12, school officials disclosed that 28 of Becton's 520 students - or about 5 percent - sought assistance for drug or alcohol abuse in the last academic year. Dennis A. Maycher, the lawyer for the school system, said the figure was ''just the tip of the iceberg.''
title: THE VALIDITY OF STUDENT DRUG TESTING

text: ''We want to eliminate the possibility that anyone will experiment with it,'' Mr. Marbaise said. ''A responsibility of all of us in the teaching profession, in cooperation with parents, is to give students the best possible educational experience in terms of our guidance and morals - what's right and wrong.''
title: THE VALIDITY OF STUDENT DRUG TESTING

text: Becton's policy has received a ''100 percent'' endorsement from Dr. Robert DuPont, a former director of the National Institute on Drug Abuse, a Federal drug treatment and prevention office, and now a partner of Mr. Bensinger.
title: THE VALIDITY OF STUDENT DRUG TESTING

text: ''Schools have not only a right but a responsibility to insure that the classroom environment is drug-free,'' he said.
title: THE VALIDITY OF STUDENT DRUG TESTING

text: In the legal fight for their policy, Becton officials have argued that drug abuse is a disease. The screening, they said, is a medical procedure and part of a physical examination for all students. Thus, they argued, it does not have to meet constitutional standards of ''reasonable suspicion'' before it is administered.
title: THE VALIDITY OF STUDENT DRUG TESTING

text: Under the policy, anyone refusing to submit to urinalysis could be excluded from class on grounds he did not take the full examination and a doctor could not attest to his health.
title: THE VALIDITY OF STUDENT DRUG TESTING

text: Those testing positive would not be suspended or expelled, but would begin treatment after consultations with parents, the school doctor and school administrators. Positive tests will not be given to the police, authorities insist.
title: THE VALIDITY OF STUDENT DRUG TESTING

text: The American Civil Liberties Union is in the forefront of opposition. It has called Becton's argument that the screening is entirely a medical matter ''obscene.''
title: THE VALIDITY OF STUDENT DRUG TESTING

text: During court arguments, John L. Weichsel, a lawyer for the group, told Judge Ciolino that the question at hand was whether he would ''permit urine searches to creep into our schools on the coattails of forced medical examinations.''
title: THE VALIDITY OF STUDENT DRUG TESTING

text: Mr. Weichsel argued that ''devious or intelligent'' drug users would avoid detection, while law-abiding students would be forced to submit to ''degrading urine searches.''
title: THE VALIDITY OF STUDENT DRUG TESTING

text: He said drug use was not an illness, but ''plain old criminal conduct.'' Trying to combat it with ''forced medical examinations,'' he said, was a ''great intrusion on the individual's privacy.''
title: THE VALIDITY OF STUDENT DRUG TESTING

text: Those familiar with the case expect the losing side to appeal, thus further tying up the issue in the courts.
title: THE VALIDITY OF STUDENT DRUG TESTING

text: Other school districts in the state are believed to be watching the case.
title: THE VALIDITY OF STUDENT DRUG TESTING

text: The New Jersey School Boards Association is advising local boards that request guidance on the question to do nothing until the Becton ruling is made, Frank Belluscio, a spokesman for the association, said.
title: THE VALIDITY OF STUDENT DRUG TESTING

text: Haruo Otsu was a typical victim.
title: JAPANESE PUZZLE: THE VENDING MACHINE MURDERS

text: He went fishing one recent morning and stopped along the way for drinks at a vending machine. Among his purchases were two small bottles of something called Oronamin C, a vitamin-enriched juice that is especially popular in Japan among middle-aged men.
title: JAPANESE PUZZLE: THE VENDING MACHINE MURDERS

text: Halfway through the second bottle, Mr. Otsu, 52 years old, started to feel sick. A few hours later, he was taken to a hospital near his house in the central Japanese town of Tondabayashi. The next night, he stopped breathing.
title: JAPANESE PUZZLE: THE VENDING MACHINE MURDERS

text: Across Japan, tainted drinks have killed at least 10 people and left about 35 others seriously ill in the last few months.
title: JAPANESE PUZZLE: THE VENDING MACHINE MURDERS

text: The poison most commonly used was paraquat, a deadly herbicide easily obtained here and known to Americans as a chemical used by drug enforcement groups to kill marijuana plants. Often, victims were men who, like Mr. Otsu, swallowed vitamin-supplemented beverages. In almost every instance, the lethal drink had been deliberately put into or near vending machines, which are as much a fixture on Japanese streets as lamp posts.
title: JAPANESE PUZZLE: THE VENDING MACHINE MURDERS

text: A Spurt of Copycat Crimes
title: JAPANESE PUZZLE: THE VENDING MACHINE MURDERS

text: The randomness of the killings and the inability of the police thus far to catch those responsible has spread concern throughout the country. One by-product has been a spurt of copycat crimes. Twice in the last few weeks, for example, someone has left tainted containers of milk in schools in Mie Prefecture in central Japan.
title: JAPANESE PUZZLE: THE VENDING MACHINE MURDERS

text: Psychologists have begun to talk of a new breed of thrill-seeking criminal, known in Japanese as yukaihan. ''They cynically enjoy superiority by imagining the victims groaning, and do not feel any remorse,'' said Prof. Susumu Oda, a mental-health specialist at Tsukuba University northeast of Tokyo.
title: JAPANESE PUZZLE: THE VENDING MACHINE MURDERS

text: It is not clear how much these people have been influenced by one of Japan's more bizarre crimes of recent years, the attempted extortion of food companies by a band calling itself the ''mystery man with 21 faces.'' For more than a year, starting in the spring of 1984, this group threatened to poison targeted companies' products unless it received sizable cash payments. At one point, the extortionists went so far as to put cyanide-treated candies on supermarket shelves.
title: JAPANESE PUZZLE: THE VENDING MACHINE MURDERS

text: But labels warning of poison were conspicuously taped to the candy boxes. No harm was done, except perhaps to the pride of the National Police Agency, which was stumped.
title: JAPANESE PUZZLE: THE VENDING MACHINE MURDERS

text: Last August, the ''mystery man'' announced in letters to newspapers that he would stop, but, in the meantime, the new poisoning spree began. Without the benefit of even an extortion note as a clue, investigators seem to be far from making arrests.
title: JAPANESE PUZZLE: THE VENDING MACHINE MURDERS

text: That scared some people. ''The problem is that these abnormals are hiding somewhere in this society,'' the newspaper Asahi Shimbun said in an editorial.
title: JAPANESE PUZZLE: THE VENDING MACHINE MURDERS

text: This is still stoic Japan, however, and nothing akin to panic has set in.
title: JAPANESE PUZZLE: THE VENDING MACHINE MURDERS

text: Soft-drink companies, although not willing to reveal figures, say their sales have not noticeably declined. Nor is a campaign under way to redesign soda bottles, in the way that United States drug companies devised ''tamper proof'' packages after the Tylenol poisonings a few years ago.
title: JAPANESE PUZZLE: THE VENDING MACHINE MURDERS

text: In fact, bottlers are inclined to blame the victims for having been careless; they note that a seal must first be broken at the base of the bottle cap. ''If only consumers were more cautious, they would have seen that some tampering had been done,'' said Takeo Mizuuchi, a spokesman for the Japan Soft Drink Bottlers Association.
title: JAPANESE PUZZLE: THE VENDING MACHINE MURDERS

text: In many instances, tainted drinks were placed inside the vending machines' dispenser slots. Victims apparently inserted their coins, found two bottles in the dispenser, assumed they had got lucky and gave no thought to possible danger. As a result, Mr. Mizuuchi's organization has printed 1.3 million stickers to be pasted onto machines, warning customers to be careful.
title: JAPANESE PUZZLE: THE VENDING MACHINE MURDERS

text: The police choose not to discuss the cases, but people in the soft-drink industry say they believe a few deaths were suicides, not murders. Paraquat, the poison of usual choice, was used in 1,402 recorded suicide attempts in Japan last year. This is a country with many thousands of small farms, and the herbicide can often be bought over the counter by providing no more information than one's name and address.
title: JAPANESE PUZZLE: THE VENDING MACHINE MURDERS

text: A doctors' group and the Health Ministry have proposed that paraquat sales be more closely monitored. Others also recommend tightening controls over vending machines.
title: JAPANESE PUZZLE: THE VENDING MACHINE MURDERS

text: Nothing has been decided, according to the Japan Vendor Manufacturers Association, but one idea under discussion is to retool machines so that coins cannot be inserted when bottles are already in the dispensers. The manufacturers are not noticeably eager to make changes, however, because it would cost them many millions of dollars.
title: JAPANESE PUZZLE: THE VENDING MACHINE MURDERS

text: From northern Hokkaido to western Kyushu, Japan's narrow streets are dominated by computerized, blinking and occasionally talking vending machines.
