There are 5.1 million of them, selling - to name a few items - sodas, dried squid, bags of rice, coffee, cigarettes, whisky, magazines, bread, kegs of beer, eggs, shirts, Shinto shrine oracles, milk, panty hose and rice crackers wrapped in seaweed.
title: JAPANESE PUZZLE: THE VENDING MACHINE MURDERS

text: The United States has a slight edge in overall numbers, but industry figures show that the Japanese ratio of one machine for every 23 people is unsurpassed. Sales last year totaled $16 billion, or $133 for each Japanese.
title: JAPANESE PUZZLE: THE VENDING MACHINE MURDERS

text: It is a testament to the low-crime society that Japan has created for itself that nearly all machines stand on the street free of graffiti and vandalism. They invite other types of problems, however.
title: JAPANESE PUZZLE: THE VENDING MACHINE MURDERS

text: Periodically, parents groups demand crackdowns on machines selling magazines deemed to be pornographic. Last month, the National Tax Administration Agency asked liquor retailers to tighten controls on the 162,500 machines dispensing alcoholic beverages.
title: JAPANESE PUZZLE: THE VENDING MACHINE MURDERS

text: A liquor-industry group's policy is to have the machines switched off from 11 P.M. to 5 A.M. But the rule is routinely flouted, and even though stiff fines are sometimes imposed, none have been paid.
title: JAPANESE PUZZLE: THE VENDING MACHINE MURDERS

text: Still, the liquor and pornography problems strike many Japanese as inconsequential compared with the poison attacks.
title: JAPANESE PUZZLE: THE VENDING MACHINE MURDERS

text: There has not been a reported death for more than a month, leading some people to hope that publicity and greater consumer caution have solved the problem. Mr. Mizuuchi of the bottlers group is not so sure.
title: JAPANESE PUZZLE: THE VENDING MACHINE MURDERS

text: ''The number of cases may decline from now on,'' he said, ''but I don't think this is over.''
title: JAPANESE PUZZLE: THE VENDING MACHINE MURDERS

text: By Fox Butterfield, Special To the New York Times
title: FREE OFFER SETS TRAP;6 BITE BAIT

text: Sheriff Frank Hackett of Kennebec County, Me., figured he had a problem. There were 400 people in the county who had been named in arrest warrants in the last decade for failing to appear in court on charges ranging from drunken driving to rape and robbery. And his county was too big for him to go out looking for them all.
title: FREE OFFER SETS TRAP;6 BITE BAIT

text: But Sheriff Hackett also had an idea.
title: FREE OFFER SETS TRAP;6 BITE BAIT

text: ''Up here, we've got an old custom of the bean supper,'' he related. ''When some organization like a church puts on a bean supper, it seems everybody comes out of the woodwork.''
title: FREE OFFER SETS TRAP;6 BITE BAIT

text: So late last month Mr. Hackett devised his own sting. First he made up an imaginary television channel, the USA Cable Television Network. Then he printed up stationery and wrote letters, posted by his brother in New York, advising the scofflaws they had been chosen from a computer list to appear in a documentary about rural Maine.
title: FREE OFFER SETS TRAP;6 BITE BAIT

text: The letters, signed J. B. Dunn, invited the recipients to a free meal in an Augusta hotel.
title: FREE OFFER SETS TRAP;6 BITE BAIT

text: ''We would like to hear your thoughts, feelings, opinions and experiences of growing up and living in one of this country's most beautiful and rural areas,'' the letters read.
title: FREE OFFER SETS TRAP;6 BITE BAIT

text: What the recipients could not know, Mr. Hackett said, was that ''J.B. Dunn'' stood for ''justice be done,'' and that the free meal would be at the county jail.
title: FREE OFFER SETS TRAP;6 BITE BAIT

text: The six people who showed up were arrested. Fourteen others turned themselves in after hearing about the program.
title: FREE OFFER SETS TRAP;6 BITE BAIT

text: Some people showed up who had not been invited, including the father of one suspect. Deputies let them go.
title: FREE OFFER SETS TRAP;6 BITE BAIT

text: Lest he be accused of an illegal scheme, Sheriff Hackett had taken the precaution of gaining approval from the county district attorney, David Crook.
title: FREE OFFER SETS TRAP;6 BITE BAIT

text: For years, frugal citizens of northern Massachusetts have driven into New Hampshire to shop since New Hampshire has no sales tax. Indeed, New Hampshire's lack of state income and sales tax has helped make it the fastest growing state east of the Mississippi, after Florida.
title: FREE OFFER SETS TRAP;6 BITE BAIT

text: Despite all, New Hampshire has sneaked in a tax on meals and corporations.
title: FREE OFFER SETS TRAP;6 BITE BAIT

text: All this gave William McCabe, the head of New England Development, a real estate development company in Boston, an inspiration. He drew up plans for a new shopping center that would straddle the border.
title: FREE OFFER SETS TRAP;6 BITE BAIT

text: His creation, Pheasant Lane Mall, will open next July with its four big department stores, including Sears and Jordan Marsh, and 150 smaller retail outlets entirely on the New Hampshire side, in the city of Nashua. They are tax-free.
title: FREE OFFER SETS TRAP;6 BITE BAIT

text: But the parking lot, office buildings, a bank, theaters and restaurants will be in Tyngsborough, Mass.
title: FREE OFFER SETS TRAP;6 BITE BAIT

text: ''These businesses all get taxed in New Hampshire, so they really didn't mind being in Massachusetts,'' Mr. McCabe explained.
title: FREE OFFER SETS TRAP;6 BITE BAIT

text: The way Laurence O. McKinney recalls it, the saga began at a lavish fund raising event for Harvard University in 1981. A graduate of Harvard and the Harvard Business School and the scion of a family that had sent eight generations of sons to Harvard, Mr. McKinney ''felt terrible that I was flat broke and couldn't contribute.''
title: FREE OFFER SETS TRAP;6 BITE BAIT

text: But Mr. McKinney, who lives in Cambridge, had recently received a patent for a new chemical process, a patent he hoped to turn into a successful business, and so ''in a moment of inspiration,'' he pledged 15 percent of the stock of his embryonic enterprise to his alma mater.
title: FREE OFFER SETS TRAP;6 BITE BAIT

text: The patent was for extracting the psychoactive ingredient, tetrahydrocannabinol, or THC, from marijuana plants. His new company was the Cannabis Corporation of America.
title: FREE OFFER SETS TRAP;6 BITE BAIT

text: The only problem was the production of THC was illegal, until last spring, that is, when the Food and Drug Administration ruled that it could be used as an antinausea drug for patients getting chemotherapy.
title: FREE OFFER SETS TRAP;6 BITE BAIT

text: Delighted, Mr. McKinney, a rock guitarist and Buddhist, printed up stock certificates and delivered the shares to Harvard. An official stamped them ''received'' on July 5.
title: FREE OFFER SETS TRAP;6 BITE BAIT

text: Mr. McKinney still didn't have the $6 million needed to start his company. But he believed he had found ''the Buddhist way to make bucks'' - give his company away.
title: FREE OFFER SETS TRAP;6 BITE BAIT

text: By his analysis, the Securities and Exchange Commission would have jurisdiction over the Cannabis Corporation only if he tried to sell shares. So he distributed free shares to his classmates from the Harvard Business School and an assortment of European counts, rich Los Angelenos and Russian officials.
title: FREE OFFER SETS TRAP;6 BITE BAIT

text: If any were sufficiently interested to invest, Mr. McKinney would have his start-up capital and be outside S.E.C. control, he concluded.
title: FREE OFFER SETS TRAP;6 BITE BAIT

text: Harvard, however, was not interested. In a curt letter last month, John H. Hanselman, the school's recording secretary, told Mr. McKinney: ''Your offer earlier this year of stock in the Cannabis Corporation of America is not accepted by the university.''
title: FREE OFFER SETS TRAP;6 BITE BAIT

text: Mr. McKinney, who is planning a trip to Nepal later this month to check on marijuana, now says Harvard ''defamed'' him by the rejection. Therefore, he said, ''I will offer my stock to Yale.''
title: FREE OFFER SETS TRAP;6 BITE BAIT

text: FIVE years after John Lennon was murdered, television has taken notice of the Beatles' founder - with last week's ''John and Yoko: A Love Story,'' the weekend's showings of ''Magical Mystery Tour'' and ''Yellow Submarine'' and, last and definitely least, ''John Lennon Remembered'' tonight at 9 on Channel 5.
title: 'LENNON REMEMBERED'

text: It is a peculiar sort of memorial, grounded in tabloid journalism rather than any notion of Lennon's life or music. Seeming to search desperately for a seamy side, the interviewer John Torv talks to the former Beatle Paul McCartney; to Lennon's son Julian; to the band's first manager; to Lennon's grammar-school headmaster, and to a paramour, May Pang.
title: 'LENNON REMEMBERED'

text: Mr. Torv doesn't find much dirt, considering how well the Beatles have been documented. The most interesting tidbit comes from the band's producer, George Martin, who says that when Mr. Lennon's wife, Yoko Ono, was ill, her bed was taken to Beatles recording sessions so she could still take part.
title: 'LENNON REMEMBERED'

text: Beyond that, many adjectives are summoned and few facts are cited. Lennon is called ''volatile,'' ''acid'' and ''a hard nut with a soft center.'' During the Beatles' early years, when they were playing eight hours daily to Hamburg gangsters, their first manager allows that they were often rude, hopped-up or drunk. A disk jockey from the Liverpool club the Cavern asserts that Lennon had an ''offbeat'' sense of humor.
title: 'LENNON REMEMBERED'

text: May Pang says that Lennon was so good with words she was afraid to argue with him. Mr. McCartney, whose song ''Here Today'' closes the program, gives his usual account of collaborating on songs with Mr. Lennon - sometimes they wrote together, sometimes they didn't.
title: 'LENNON REMEMBERED'

text: There's also material from an Australian television interview with the ex-Beatle George Harrison. It is edited so that at one moment Mr. Harrison talks about pep pills and marijuana in the early 1960's, and the next about higher consciousness and out-of-body experiences, presumably from Eastern meditation. And then there's the part where Julian Lennon says he last saw his father ''two years ago in March'' - when was this program made, anyway?
title: 'LENNON REMEMBERED'

text: Mr. Lennon was, as the narrator Wolfman Jack puts it, ''no saint.'' He enjoyed making a public spectacle of himself; he was often bullish and wrong-headed. But he also created lasting music, spoke out for what he believed and was one of rock's greatest performers. Sketchy and sleazy, ''John Lennon Remembered'' doesn't even hint at what Lennon was all about.
title: 'LENNON REMEMBERED'

text: By Lindsey Gruson, Special To the New York Times
title: CONVICT-TURNED-DOCTOR PROVOKES PENNSYLVANIA LICENSE BATTLE

text: For 34 months, Timothy McCormick was number K1914, a convicted drug runner, one of hundreds of inmates who each year enter the century-old stone prison here with little hope for the future and a good chance of paying a return visit.
title: CONVICT-TURNED-DOCTOR PROVOKES PENNSYLVANIA LICENSE BATTLE

text: But driven by a dream he had as a sickly child, Mr. McCormick worked his way through college after he was released from prison and he graduated from medical school this June, hoping to become a surgeon.
title: CONVICT-TURNED-DOCTOR PROVOKES PENNSYLVANIA LICENSE BATTLE

text: In September, however, a state board rejected Dr. McCormick's application for a license, saying that under a new state law the panel could not permit a felon to practice medicine. That ruling has touched off a drawn-out legal battle, attacks on the Pennsylvania Medical and Licensure Board, and a legislative move to rewrite Pennsylvania's rules for licensing doctors for the second time in less than a year.
title: CONVICT-TURNED-DOCTOR PROVOKES PENNSYLVANIA LICENSE BATTLE

text: Dr. McCormick's life since prison has also focused attention on what has been hailed as an extraordinary tale of rehabilitation, and the rejection of his application has provoked charges that the state pays nothing more than lip service to its professed belief that criminals can become contributing members of society.
title: CONVICT-TURNED-DOCTOR PROVOKES PENNSYLVANIA LICENSE BATTLE

text: ''I don't know anyone else who has come out of Western Penitentiary and become a doctor,'' said James B. Lieber, executive director of the Western Pennsylvania American Civil Liberties Union. ''It's important that people who do change themselves, who do rehabilitate themselves, are given a chance and that some government agency doesn't arbitrarily deny them that chance.''
title: CONVICT-TURNED-DOCTOR PROVOKES PENNSYLVANIA LICENSE BATTLE

text: In the narrow view, the controversy centers on whether the medical board acted properly this September when it denied Dr. McCormick a license because he had been convicted on drug charges. Dr. McCormick, who is now 33 years old, was arrested in 1974 when he delivered a suitcase containing 23 pounds of marijuana to a friend and an undercover police officer. Dr. McCormick says he thought the suitcase contained clothes and was dropping it off as a favor to the friend.
title: CONVICT-TURNED-DOCTOR PROVOKES PENNSYLVANIA LICENSE BATTLE

text: After his conviction by a Beaver County jury he was sentenced to two to five years in jail for possession of marijuana with intent to deliver and one to two years for conspiracy.
title: CONVICT-TURNED-DOCTOR PROVOKES PENNSYLVANIA LICENSE BATTLE

text: While in the huge Western Penitentiary on the banks of the Ohio River here, a maximum-security prison with a history of violence, Mr. McCormick became something of a jailhouse lawyer, working on his appeals and those of other inmates. When he was paroled a friend suggested taking some pre-medical courses as part of his preparation for law school.
title: CONVICT-TURNED-DOCTOR PROVOKES PENNSYLVANIA LICENSE BATTLE

text: That, he said, rekindled his dream of becoming a surgeon. It was a dream that first came to him as a bedridden child fighting to overcome a potentially fatal kidney disease, a dream that seemed lost when he dropped out of college.
title: CONVICT-TURNED-DOCTOR PROVOKES PENNSYLVANIA LICENSE BATTLE

text: ''I had a lot of exposure to doctors and I was impressed,'' he recalled. ''I thought it's exciting, the greatest profession on earth.'' So, when he was released from jail, he re-enrolled in the University of Pittsburgh, graduating magna cum laude in 1981 with a degree in biology and chemistry.
title: CONVICT-TURNED-DOCTOR PROVOKES PENNSYLVANIA LICENSE BATTLE

text: After borrowing a total of $110,000 to finance his education, he graduated this June in the top third of his class from Hahnemann Medical College in Philadelphia. In the annual computer match of hospitals and residents, he was assigned to Allegheny General Hospital in Pittsburgh.
title: CONVICT-TURNED-DOCTOR PROVOKES PENNSYLVANIA LICENSE BATTLE

text: ''I went there planning to do a bang-up job,'' he said. ''And I would have. I'm a damn good surgeon.'' Before he had a chance to demonstrate his skills, however, the pursuit of his dream ran into the first of what has become a series of stumbling blocks.
title: CONVICT-TURNED-DOCTOR PROVOKES PENNSYLVANIA LICENSE BATTLE

text: As part of the application for a temporary license, he truthfully answered the question ''Have you ever been convicted of a crime?'' He said the hospital responded by delaying his application until it was too late for this year. Then he lost his apartment when the hospital did not confirm that he was employed there. Finally, he said, the hospital tried to get rid of him by offering to buy out his contract.
title: CONVICT-TURNED-DOCTOR PROVOKES PENNSYLVANIA LICENSE BATTLE

text: Dick W. Mount, the hospital's attorney, would not comment on the charges because they are part of a lawsuit Dr. McCormick filed, contending that Allegheny General breached a contract.
title: CONVICT-TURNED-DOCTOR PROVOKES PENNSYLVANIA LICENSE BATTLE

text: In September the state medical board rejected Dr. McCormick's application for a license, citing a law signed May 2 by Gov. Dick Thornburgh that it said required the denial of a license to anyone convicted of a felony.
title: CONVICT-TURNED-DOCTOR PROVOKES PENNSYLVANIA LICENSE BATTLE

text: But other state officials said the board's decision was based largely on politics. They contended that the board was angered by the new law, believing it infringed on its decision-making power, and used the McCormick case to get back at the Legislature.
title: CONVICT-TURNED-DOCTOR PROVOKES PENNSYLVANIA LICENSE BATTLE

text: Aim Was Doctors, Not Convicts
title: CONVICT-TURNED-DOCTOR PROVOKES PENNSYLVANIA LICENSE BATTLE

text: Dr. McCormick's lawyer, Lisle A. Zehner 3d, said the board had misinterpreted and misapplied the law.
title: CONVICT-TURNED-DOCTOR PROVOKES PENNSYLVANIA LICENSE BATTLE

text: The law gives the board discretion in this case, Mr. Zehner said, since the change was aimed at stiffening the punishment of doctors who deal in drugs, not at rehabilitated convicts.
title: CONVICT-TURNED-DOCTOR PROVOKES PENNSYLVANIA LICENSE BATTLE

text: He also argued that Dr. McCormick's crime was a misdemeanor, not a felony, and that the board had applied the law retroactively in violation of the state and Federal constitutions.
title: CONVICT-TURNED-DOCTOR PROVOKES PENNSYLVANIA LICENSE BATTLE

text: The board's decision quickly provoked a furor that was felt as far away as Harrisburg, the state capital. Pittsburgh's major newspapers, The Press and The Post-Gazette, published editorials criticizing the board. So did The Herald, which serves many of the city's suburbs.
title: CONVICT-TURNED-DOCTOR PROVOKES PENNSYLVANIA LICENSE BATTLE

text: ''The fight over his medical license,'' The Press said, ''suggests a maddening preoccupation with legal strictures and little sympathy for Dr. McCormick and his exemplary record of reforming his life.''
title: CONVICT-TURNED-DOCTOR PROVOKES PENNSYLVANIA LICENSE BATTLE

text: Dr. McCormick appealed the board's decision and a hearing examiner, Alfred S. Pelaez of the Duquesne University law school, agreed with Mr. Zehner's contentions, ruling last month that the board should have granted Dr. McCormick a license.
title: CONVICT-TURNED-DOCTOR PROVOKES PENNSYLVANIA LICENSE BATTLE

text: Spokesmen for the board would not discuss the case or whether it would appeal Mr. Pelaez's ruling into the courts. But Mr. Zehner and officials familiar with the case said they expected the board to fight the decision.
title: CONVICT-TURNED-DOCTOR PROVOKES PENNSYLVANIA LICENSE BATTLE

text: In an attempt to short-circuit what is expected to be a long legal struggle, state legislators have introduced a bill that would grant the board discretion in considering the licensing of felons if they were convicted at least 10 years ago. In a voice vote, the State Senate unanimously approved it last month; the bill is expected to come before the House of Representatives some time before Christmas.
title: CONVICT-TURNED-DOCTOR PROVOKES PENNSYLVANIA LICENSE BATTLE

text: ''This is an example of a person paying their dues, serving their debt to society and being totally rehabilitated,'' said State Representative Richard Cesser, the sponsor of the House bill. ''It's one of the most beautiful stories ever.''
title: CONVICT-TURNED-DOCTOR PROVOKES PENNSYLVANIA LICENSE BATTLE

text: A PROPOSED budget reduction for the Coast Guard could cause major problems on Long Island, which has a large number of recreational boats and fishing craft and where the Coast Guard is active in battling drug smuggling.
title: COAST GUARD ON L.I. FACES BUDGET CUT

text: The House of Representatives is seeking a way to counter a proposal approved by the Senate that would slash $230 million from the Coast Guard's 1986 proposed budget of about $1 billion. Every coastal area in the United States is expected to be affected if the money is not restored, but the East End might be particularly hard hit, officials say. The deadline for restoring the funds is Thursday, when the current Coast Guard budget runs out.
title: COAST GUARD ON L.I. FACES BUDGET CUT

text: The Coast Guard has eight stations on Long Island, four of them on the East End - at East Moriches, the Montauk Lighthouse and Star Island in Montauk, and the Shinnecock station in Hampton Bays.
title: COAST GUARD ON L.I. FACES BUDGET CUT

text: According to Jim McGranachan, a civilian spokesman at the Coast Guard's regional headquarters on Governors Island, ''those stations are some of the busiest search and rescue stations in the whole country.''
title: COAST GUARD ON L.I. FACES BUDGET CUT

text: He said that some nonemergency services have already been curtailed in anticipation of the budget cut, but it has not yet been determined how the Coast Guard would make up any cuts.
title: COAST GUARD ON L.I. FACES BUDGET CUT

text: According to Coast Guard officials and the office of Representative William Carney, a Republican of Hauppauge who represents the East End, there have been several attempts in recent years by President Reagan to cut the Coast Guard budget as part of an overall effort to reduce Federal spending.
title: COAST GUARD ON L.I. FACES BUDGET CUT

text: But the Senate and House have acted jointly to restore the cuts. This year, however, the Senate went along with the President's recommendations.
title: COAST GUARD ON L.I. FACES BUDGET CUT

text: ''If we were under the Department of Defense, we wouldn't be so vulnerable,'' said Lieut. Mark Watson, a spokesman at the Coast Guard's Shinnecock station. ''As it is, we're the only military service not under that department.''
title: COAST GUARD ON L.I. FACES BUDGET CUT

text: The Coast Guard is an armed service, and its pay scales and officer grades are similar to the other military services. But it is part of the Department of Transportation because the Constitution prohibits branches of the military from carrying out domestic law enforcement.
title: COAST GUARD ON L.I. FACES BUDGET CUT

text: If the budget cuts are made it is not expected that emergency rescue operations in East End waters - such as assisting sinking ships and people lost at sea - would be curtailed. However, according to Mr. McGranachan, ''too much of a reduction reduces the amount of training we can give - when a crisis occurs, we may not have adequately trained personnel available to respond.''
title: COAST GUARD ON L.I. FACES BUDGET CUT

text: One area expected to be affected is the Coast Guard's ''pollution strike teams'' - groups specifically trained to respond to a sudden environmental crisis. One such team was on the scene last month when an oil barge sank near Montauk, causing a spill that polluted some beaches and killed birds and marine life. There are three pollution strike teams in the United States. Coast Guard officials fear that two may have to be disbanded.
title: COAST GUARD ON L.I. FACES BUDGET CUT

text: Another function expected to be affected is the prevention of drug smuggling. In coastal areas the Coast Guard works with local law enforcement to stop and search ships suspected of carrying illegal drugs. Three weeks ago, the Coast Guard sank a ship carrying 28 tons of marijuana off the coast of Florida. a According to Mr. McGranachan, ''We've had some pretty good busts out on the East End, too.''
title: COAST GUARD ON L.I. FACES BUDGET CUT

text: ''Obviously, there's going to be an impact on drugs if these cuts go through,'' he said. ''There's no way we can keep ships operating at former levels, and some boats will get through that shouldn't.''
title: COAST GUARD ON L.I. FACES BUDGET CUT

text: The biggest impact, officials say, may be in nonemergency assistance the Coast Guard routinely provides, such as restarting engines of boats adrift at sea, offering gas to boaters who have run out of fuel, and arranging towing for boats that need repairs. The East End is particularly vulnerable because of the rapid increase in recreational boating.
title: COAST GUARD ON L.I. FACES BUDGET CUT

text: ''Five years ago, with the gas crunch, boating was at a 20-year low,'' said Tom Czletka of Southold, who operates a company called Sea Tow that provides the kind of nonemergency services the Coast Guard may have to reduce. ''Now people can take a bath in fuel and boating is way up, especially power boating. Just with the natural expansion of boating there's been a real crunch on the Coast Guard even without cutbacks.''
title: COAST GUARD ON L.I. FACES BUDGET CUT

text: Mr. Czletka said his company has 23 offices on the East Coast; by next summer it is expected to have 40 offices operating 150 vessels. It functions on the water, he said, much the way the AAA functions on highways.
title: COAST GUARD ON L.I. FACES BUDGET CUT

text: ''I don't believe the Coast Guard will turn away from emergency situations, and we don't charge for responding to emergencies,'' Mr. Czletka said. ''But everything else they do will probably be cut back. It's inevitable that their misfortune will be our gain. If we can't keep up with demand, though, everybody loses.''
title: COAST GUARD ON L.I. FACES BUDGET CUT

text: Two weeks ago, the House overwhelmingly endorsed a resolution protesting the Senate's budget cuts. Mr. Carney, who is on the House Merchant Marine Committee, is one of several Congressmen urging the full House to restore the money for the Coast Guard. He supports the enactment of a continuing resolution that would allow the House to bypass the Senate and the President and fund the Coast Guard directly.
title: COAST GUARD ON L.I. FACES BUDGET CUT

text: ''It looks good right now; there's a bipartisan feeling throughout the House that the Coast Guard should get full funding,'' said Eric Yoder, a spokesman for Mr. Carney in Washington. ''With the way things usually go, we probably won't vote on passage until just before midnight on the 11th, but I'm pretty sure we'll get it through.''
title: COAST GUARD ON L.I. FACES BUDGET CUT

text: Erasmus Hall High School in Brooklyn, singled out by the State Education Department last week as one of the two most ''deficient'' high schools in the city, is an institution teetering between its glorious past and a difficult present.
title: No Headline

text: ''It's like two schools here,'' said the principal, Stanley Saretsky. ''If you are really interested in school and have a stable family situation, you will do very well for yourself here.''
title: No Headline

text: Founded in 1787, Erasmus is the oldest high school in New York State and one of the city's most illustrious. But its experience over the past two decades parallels that of many inner-city schools around the country, and the efforts its teachers and students are now making to restore Erasmus to past glories are typical of schools in the same situation.
title: No Headline

text: Many aspects of life at Erasmus, which occupies an imposing full-block gothic building at 911 Flatbush Avenue, conform to the image of a troubled school. There is graffiti all along the walls of the school's two miles of interior hallways, the smell of marijuana sometimes drifts through stairwells and on Wednesday Mr. Saretsky detected what he thought was a puddle of urine on the floor just outside the lunchroom.
title: No Headline

text: Last month, someone broke into a trophy display case and stole an exhibition of student artwork. And on Wednesday, according to Gil Alvarez, a police officer who patrols Erasmus, a student was arrested on school grounds for possession of cocaine and a deadly weapon.
title: No Headline

text: But in a quiet, carpeted classroom in the same building, other students learn the language of computers on state-of-the-art IBM machines. Still others sit rapt in a science class taught by Martin Langan, who recently won a teacher-of-the-year award in a citywide competition.
title: No Headline

text: Mr. Saretsky, who became the principal in 1981, and other school officials can offer no clear answers why some students at Erasmus do well while others fall by the wayside. But they say that their fundamental goal is to steer more of the school's 4,000 students onto the road to success.
title: No Headline

text: Traditionally, Erasmus students have gone on to great things. The school's alumni include actresses such as Barbra Streisand, Susan Hayward and Barbara Stanwyck, the chess champion Bobby Fischer, the politi-cal cartoonist David Levine, and star athletes such as Sid Luckman and Billy Cunningham.
title: No Headline

text: In its heyday, Erasmus sometimes produced more winners in the Westinghouse Talent Search for gifted young scientists than any other high school in the country. A quarter of a century ago, the school also ranked high in national surveys of high schools whose graduates went on to earn Ph.D's.
title: No Headline

text: Even today, 80 percent of the school's graduates immediately go on to attend college, including, Mr. Saretsky said, citing school records, Harvard, Brown, Cornell, the University of California at Berkeley and other prestigious schools. Mr. Saretsky also said that in recent years Erasmus had also produced winners of the Westinghouse and other rigorous competitions.
title: No Headline

text: But when the State Education Department looked at Erasmus, it apparently saw only a high school that was ''deficient'' in all four academic categories being examined. Erasmus fell short of state standards in reading, writing and mathematics test scores and dropout rates, one of only two high schools of the 72 in the city deemed deficient to be named in every category.
title: No Headline

text: Last year, only 51.3 percent of Erasmus students taking the Regents Competency Test in reading passed the exam. The success rates on the state mathematics and writing tests were only 47.5 percent and 40.8 percent, respectively, and the school had a dropout rate of about 15 percent in 1983-84, according to state statistics.
title: No Headline

text: Mr. Saretsky acknowledges that the state evaluation and the test results imply that he and the school's 200 teachers are at fault. But the reality of the school's situation, he and many teachers said, is far more complicated.
title: No Headline

text: More than 80 percent of ninth graders at the school, they point out, are already below grade level in reading and writing when they enroll, according to school records. On one test given to this year's freshmen in October, students averaged a sixth-grade level in reading and a fifth-grade level in mathematics.
title: No Headline

text: ''It's not an excuse,'' Mr. Saretsky said. ''It's just a fact, and we have to deal with it.''
title: No Headline

text: The student body, which is 90 percent black and 9 percent Hispanic, must also contend with difficult economic circumstances. More than 90 percent of the students are eligible for Federal school lunch programs for the poor, according to Board of Education figures.
title: No Headline

text: ''A lot of students here have responsibilities that other kids don't,'' said Jess Resnick, an assistant principal at the school. ''They work at jobs after school because they have to in order to survive.''
title: No Headline

text: In addition, school officials say, Erasmus has a higher percentage of ''limited English proficiency'' students, including many newly arrived immigrants, than any high school in the city. The native language of one quarter of the student body is Haitian Creole, and another 10 percent of the students speak Spanish or Asian languages.
title: No Headline

text: ''Many of the recent immigrants are from the lower strata of their home society,'' said Yves Raymond, who teaches Haitian students in their own language and is coordinator of courses in English as a second language. ''Very often they have had very little schooling and are deficient in their own language, not to mention English.''
title: No Headline

text: ''We have students coming in here who don't even know the alphabet,'' said Phyllis Mehler, a foreign-language teacher and coordinator of bilingual programs. ''We're not talking about children, we're talking about teen-agers who can't even recognize 26 letters.''
title: No Headline

text: Immigrant parents, too, Mr. Raymond said, are hesitant to deal with the school system, and even when they do muster up the courage, there can be cultural misunderstandings. Mr. Raymond recalls the recent case of one Haitian parent who, after meeting with his child's teachers and hearing much talk of credits, approached him and asked where to find the neighborhood stores offering this ''credit.''
title: No Headline

text: Nevertheless, these newcomers are tested and scored the same as other students, sometimes within three months of their arrival, Mr. Saretsky said. Spanish-speakers can take exams in their own language, but the Haitian Creole speakers are tested in English.
title: No Headline

text: ''As far as I'm concerned, the state tests are not valid,'' said Teresa Jones, president of the school's Parent-Teacher Association. ''It would be more accurate to measure the performance of these students after they have been in our school a couple of years, by which time they have made considerable progress.''
title: No Headline

text: To stem the dropout rate, Mr. Saretsky has instituted new programs that he says are aimed at ''hooking'' the interest of students likely to leave school. They include not only the computer program, but tourism-guide and restaurant-management training, a summer program in conjunction with the Brooklyn Union Gas Company and a general equivalency diploma course for students 18 and older.
title: No Headline

text: Extra course requirements in mathematics, English and critical thinking have also been instituted. Mr. Saretsky said he has also beefed up both English as a Second Language and bilingual education courses so that immigrant students can make more rapid academic progress.
title: No Headline

text: He has also increased discipline. Classroom doors are locked at the beginning of each class period as a warning to latecomers, and passes are demanded of students found in the hall during class time. The students themselves have organized fund-raising efforts to paint over graffiti and beautify the school.
title: No Headline

text: ''It may take 10, 15 or 20 years, but this school will get better,'' said Mr. Saretsky, an after-hours runner who recently successfully completed a marathon. ''Personally, I think that we can do it in a couple of years.''
title: No Headline

text: This year may be remembered as the year the Pacific Ocean ceased to be America's lake. New Zealand refused port entry to a U.S. destroyer, Australia backed down from a commitment to help monitor an MX missile test and instability in the Philippines has raised questions about American bases there.
title: U.S. Neglect in the Pacific

text: Meanwhile, the Soviet Union, which set up a major naval base in Vietnam, has offered economic aid to small island nations in the area. One deal has been closed - a $1.7 million fishing pact with Kiribati, the former British colony of the Gilbert Islands. The Greenpeace affair has galvanized antinuclear sentiment in the region, much of it against the United States.
title: U.S. Neglect in the Pacific

text: A subtle battle for the Pacific has started, and the United States should take immediate steps to shore up its faltering relations in the region.
title: U.S. Neglect in the Pacific

text: First, Congress should immediately pass the Compact of Free Association, which establishes the future political relationship between the United States and its United Nations trusteeship, Micronesia. The Compact is a bargain for this country. It provides for indefinite ''strategic denial,'' preventing Soviet access to Micronesia, and assures use for the next 30 years of Kwajalein Atoll, an important missile range.
title: U.S. Neglect in the Pacific

text: Different versions of the Compact were recently passed by the Senate and House. Only a few legislative days remain this year, and the Micro-nesians are growing restless. The U.S. lease on Kwajalein Atoll has expired, and some landowners are occupying their islands.
title: U.S. Neglect in the Pacific

text: Second, the United States should sign a fishing pact with the Pacific island nations. Fishing rights are the most important resource of these nations, but the United States does not recognize these countries' 200-mile exclusive economic zones for tuna. Kiribati's fishing deal with the Soviet Union does not reflect any ideological shift to the left. Rather, it reflects a need for a reliable source of revenue, disgust with the American Tunaboat Association's failure to pay fishing fees and disappointment that the United States Government did not force the payment. Kiribati's annual budget is around $9 million, so failure to pay was catastrophic and made the Russian offer that much sweeter.
title: U.S. Neglect in the Pacific

text: The State Department is negotiating a regional fisheries agreement with the island nations of the area. If the United States refuses to recognize these nations' 200-mile fisheries, it is likely that Tonga, Tuvalu and Vanuatu will sign deals with the Russians soon.
title: U.S. Neglect in the Pacific

text: Third, the United States should play a more active role in the area. There are two United States Embassies among the dozen or so independent or self-governing island states in the Pacific, and one regional Agency for International Development office, which administers programs totaling $6 million annually. The answer is not necessarily more aid, but better programs. We could learn from China, whose 1984 foreign aid to Kiribati was 200 (much-loved) bicycles, or Japan, which gave that country excess rice to sell in stores below retail prices.
title: U.S. Neglect in the Pacific

text: Fourth, the United States must consider that these pro-American islands are challenging allied nuclear policies in the area. The Pacific has had direct contact with nuclear issues since Hiroshima. The United States conducted 66 nuclear tests in the Marshall Islands, and France continues testing at Mururoa Atoll. Japan has proposed dumping nuclear waste off the Northern Marianas.
title: U.S. Neglect in the Pacific

text: In response to these developments, the 13 members of the South Pacific Forum, including Australia and New Zealand, last summer ratified a treaty banning the manufacture, testing or stationing of nuclear arms in almost all the South Pacific. This wide antinuclear sentiment is summed up in a poster that says, ''If it's so safe, store it in Washington, dump it in Tokyo, and test it in Paris.''
title: U.S. Neglect in the Pacific

text: Washington should reassess its position on deep-sea nuclear dumping versus above-ground storage and the effect that French nuclear testing may have on the environment in the Pacific. If a cohesive policy for the region is not devised, the United States may lose the battle for the Pacific. The area has traditionally suffered from United States neglect because of the assumption that it is America's lake, but the lake may be drying up.
title: U.S. Neglect in the Pacific

text: The other Washington, the uneasy neighbor to the world of White House dinners, international conferences and marble memorials, only rarely comes into the public eye.
title: TRIAL IN BRUTAL MURDER FILLS CAPITAL COURTROOM

text: But just now that other city, a world of crime and violence outside the range of tourists' cameras, is capturing attention here in the trial of nine young men and a young woman.
title: TRIAL IN BRUTAL MURDER FILLS CAPITAL COURTROOM

text: They are charged taking part in a robbery that prosecutors say degenerated into unspeakable violence and death for its victim, Catherine L. Fuller, a 48-year-old mother of six children.
title: TRIAL IN BRUTAL MURDER FILLS CAPITAL COURTROOM

text: ''Mrs. Fuller was murdered in hideous fashion, there is no question about that,'' Allen Palmer, a defense lawyer, told the jury as the trial began four weeks ago.
title: TRIAL IN BRUTAL MURDER FILLS CAPITAL COURTROOM

text: Early in the evening of Oct. 1, 1984, on a bustling street a little more than a 15-minute walk from the Capitol, Mrs. Fuller stuffed a change purse with $50 into her brassiere as a group of young men watched from a local park.
title: TRIAL IN BRUTAL MURDER FILLS CAPITAL COURTROOM

text: Prosecutors say they were bored at the end of a day filled with alcohol, marijuana and PCP, a drug usually called ''angel dust.'' The prosecutors say the young men crossed the street and approached Mrs. Fuller, who was 4 feet 11 inches tall and weighed 99 pounds.
title: TRIAL IN BRUTAL MURDER FILLS CAPITAL COURTROOM

text: When she resisted them, prosecutors say several of the men pushed her into an alley and beat and kicked her, ripping her clothes off. Then, the prosecutors say they dragged her into a garage and killed her in particularly gruesome fashion.
title: TRIAL IN BRUTAL MURDER FILLS CAPITAL COURTROOM

text: Several witnesses, including two who pleaded guilty to taking part in the killing, have identified the men on trial as participants. And three broke into tears as they described the final, savage assault they said was committed by Levy Rouse, 20, one of the defendants.
title: TRIAL IN BRUTAL MURDER FILLS CAPITAL COURTROOM

text: The testimony has come from small-time drug dealers, children who admit using PCP daily, teen-aged girls who say they have children fathered by the defendants and, in one case, a mother who said she shares marijuana with her son. They have nicknames like ''Girl-Girl,'' ''Silky,'' ''Slinky'' and ''Southeast Wayne.''
title: TRIAL IN BRUTAL MURDER FILLS CAPITAL COURTROOM

text: ''We was talking about getting paid,'' said Calvin Lee Alston, 20, who pleaded guilty to second-degree murder. ''I said, 'Are y'all game for getting paid?
title: TRIAL IN BRUTAL MURDER FILLS CAPITAL COURTROOM

text: How about robbing her?' ''
title: TRIAL IN BRUTAL MURDER FILLS CAPITAL COURTROOM

text: He said he received $10 for his part in the attack.
title: TRIAL IN BRUTAL MURDER FILLS CAPITAL COURTROOM

text: Another witness, a 15-year-old girl, sucked her thumb like a small child and broke into tears for 15 minutes. Composing herself, the girl, Linda Lee Jacobs, whispered between sobs that she had witnessed the slaying.
title: TRIAL IN BRUTAL MURDER FILLS CAPITAL COURTROOM

text: Assistant United States Attorney Jerry S. Goren asked another witness, Harry James Bennett, if Mrs. Fuller had said anything.
title: TRIAL IN BRUTAL MURDER FILLS CAPITAL COURTROOM

text: Mr. Bennett, who pleaded guilty to manslaughter, also cried as he whispered the woman's last word: ''Stop!''
title: TRIAL IN BRUTAL MURDER FILLS CAPITAL COURTROOM

text: Five of the defendants - Mr. Rouse; Alphonzo Harris, 23; Kelvin Smith, 19; Charles Turner Jr., 21 and his brother, Christopher D. Turner, 20 - testified that they were elsewhere at the time of the slaying.
title: TRIAL IN BRUTAL MURDER FILLS CAPITAL COURTROOM

text: In a large courtroom packed with 10 United States marshals, 11 defense lawyers, 2 prosecutors, 2 rows of radio, television and newspaper reporters and more than 80 spectators, the men have testified that they were stripping an abandoned automobile, sleeping off a drunk, smoking marijuana or just ''hanging out'' at video arcades at the time.
title: TRIAL IN BRUTAL MURDER FILLS CAPITAL COURTROOM

text: Defense lawyers, who move each day for separate trials, say the conflicting interests of the various lawyers were helping prosecutors tie the men together.
title: TRIAL IN BRUTAL MURDER FILLS CAPITAL COURTROOM

text: ''The Government did not have very much when this trial began, but there case has gotten stronger as it moves along,'' said one defense lawyer who spoke on condition that he not be identified.
title: TRIAL IN BRUTAL MURDER FILLS CAPITAL COURTROOM

text: Special to the New York Times
title: PATERSON MAYOR PROPOSES CURFEW FOR CITY TROUBLED BY TEEN-AGERS' CRIMES

text: Late on a chilly Monday night hundreds of youths huddled on the street corners of this old industrial city, dancing to the beat blaring from box radios, drinking from bottles wrapped in brown bags, casually passing marijuana cigarettes.
title: PATERSON MAYOR PROPOSES CURFEW FOR CITY TROUBLED BY TEEN-AGERS' CRIMES

text: It is a scene that has become familiar, according to the police, city officials and many residents here. They say that each night, on scores of dimly lighted street corners, youths - some as young as 12 or 13 years old - openly sell drugs and often carry knives or small handguns.
title: PATERSON MAYOR PROPOSES CURFEW FOR CITY TROUBLED BY TEEN-AGERS' CRIMES

text: Many residents of this city of 138,000 on the Passaic River said in interviews that they avoided walking the streets at night out of fear that they would be mugged or attacked by the youths. Merchants worry that the youths will scare off customers and vandalize their stores. And police tell of increasing frustration in their efforts to reduce drug traffic, vandalism and late-night rowdiness.
title: PATERSON MAYOR PROPOSES CURFEW FOR CITY TROUBLED BY TEEN-AGERS' CRIMES

text: Now, Mayor Frank X. Graves Jr. wants a 10:30 P.M. curfew for children under 14 to help clear the streets at night and to counter what he calls a ''breakdown in the supervision'' of them.
title: PATERSON MAYOR PROPOSES CURFEW FOR CITY TROUBLED BY TEEN-AGERS' CRIMES

text: Under the proposal, parents of children under 14 found on the streets unsupervised between 10:30 P.M. and 5 A.M. would be fined $25 for a first offense. The fine would be increased by $25 for each subsequent offense, and youths caught violating the curfew more than three times would be referred to juvenile authorities.
title: PATERSON MAYOR PROPOSES CURFEW FOR CITY TROUBLED BY TEEN-AGERS' CRIMES

text: ''Kids today are defiant,'' Mayor Graves said. ''They tell their parents it's not against the law, and thousands of them are out there every night until 12, 1 and 2 in the morning. What I'm trying to do is put the parent back in charge.''
title: PATERSON MAYOR PROPOSES CURFEW FOR CITY TROUBLED BY TEEN-AGERS' CRIMES

text: Mr. Graves said he decided to seek the curfew after spending more than 60 nights touring Paterson's streets last summer. But while more than two-thirds of the 1,310 cases of juvenile crime referred to juvenile courts last year involved 14- to 17-year-olds, the Mayor said he would not consider including them in the curfew because it would be unfair for the city to tell high-school-age youths when to go home at night.
title: PATERSON MAYOR PROPOSES CURFEW FOR CITY TROUBLED BY TEEN-AGERS' CRIMES

text: Others are less than enthusiastic about the Mayor's proposal, which now goes to the nine-member City Council.
title: PATERSON MAYOR PROPOSES CURFEW FOR CITY TROUBLED BY TEEN-AGERS' CRIMES

text: The Council President, Marilee Jackson, called it a ''Band-Aid approach'' and suggested that the city provide activities to keep the youths off the streets instead of imposing an ''oppressive'' curfew.
title: PATERSON MAYOR PROPOSES CURFEW FOR CITY TROUBLED BY TEEN-AGERS' CRIMES

text: ''We have all these outcast kids with nowhere to go,'' Miss Jackson said. ''We don't have the basics in Paterson.''
title: PATERSON MAYOR PROPOSES CURFEW FOR CITY TROUBLED BY TEEN-AGERS' CRIMES

text: She said the city had no job-training programs for youths, no activities at public schools after 2:45 P.M. and no facilities for recreation other than a local boys' club and a Young Men's Christian Association.
title: PATERSON MAYOR PROPOSES CURFEW FOR CITY TROUBLED BY TEEN-AGERS' CRIMES

text: ''This proposal doesn't deal with the problem - it just asks to put the kids out of our sight by getting them off the streets,'' Miss Jackson said.
title: PATERSON MAYOR PROPOSES CURFEW FOR CITY TROUBLED BY TEEN-AGERS' CRIMES

text: Several other New Jersey cities have imposed curfews for juveniles. Both Newark and Camden have curfews for youths under 18. In Newark, juveniles not accompanied by an adult must be off the streets from 10 P.M. to 6 A.M. In Camden, curfew hours are from 10 P.M. to dawn Sunday through Thursday and from 11 P.M. to dawn Friday and Saturday.
title: PATERSON MAYOR PROPOSES CURFEW FOR CITY TROUBLED BY TEEN-AGERS' CRIMES

text: In Trenton, a curfew requires that youths under 17 be off the streets between 10 P.M. and 5 A.M. Sunday through Thursday and by 11:59 on Friday and Saturday nights. Between June 15 and Labor Day, the Trenton curfew is extended until 11:59 every night.
title: PATERSON MAYOR PROPOSES CURFEW FOR CITY TROUBLED BY TEEN-AGERS' CRIMES

text: New York City has no juvenile curfew.
title: PATERSON MAYOR PROPOSES CURFEW FOR CITY TROUBLED BY TEEN-AGERS' CRIMES

text: Police officials in the three New Jersey cities say the curfews have helped curb drug traffic and vandalism in areas where juvenile crime is concentrated. But, the officials said, enforcement of the curfews has been a low priority because strict enforcement would detract from efforts to fight more serious crime.
title: PATERSON MAYOR PROPOSES CURFEW FOR CITY TROUBLED BY TEEN-AGERS' CRIMES

text: The director of the New Jersey chapter of the American Civil Liberties Union, Jeffrey Fogel, criticized the Paterson proposal. He said it should be up to the parents, not city government, to decide when children go home at night. ''That's police-state mentality,'' he said of the curfew plan.
title: PATERSON MAYOR PROPOSES CURFEW FOR CITY TROUBLED BY TEEN-AGERS' CRIMES

text: But many residents were quick to dismiss such criticisms. They spoke less of juveniles' rights than of their rights to walk in their own neighborhoods without worrying about getting mugged or attacked or approached by youths trying to sell drugs.
title: PATERSON MAYOR PROPOSES CURFEW FOR CITY TROUBLED BY TEEN-AGERS' CRIMES

text: With dusk about to give way to darkness, Gale DeLeon hurried past the shops that line Market Street, one of the city's main thoroughfares. Holding her 3-year-old son, Ray, Mrs. DeLeon said: ''I'm really scared to be out here at night. I'm all for a curfew, anything to clear these streets at night.''
title: PATERSON MAYOR PROPOSES CURFEW FOR CITY TROUBLED BY TEEN-AGERS' CRIMES

text: About three blocks away, youths hanging out in front of a liquor store accosted strangers and bolted to the sides of stopped cars and began mumbling their sales pitch in the hurried staccato of an auctioneer: ''Smoke, smoke, cocaine.''
title: PATERSON MAYOR PROPOSES CURFEW FOR CITY TROUBLED BY TEEN-AGERS' CRIMES

text: ''They own the corners after dark,'' said Joseph Drakefield, as he stood behind a Market Street lunch counter where he works and pointed out the front window. ''I wouldn't walk out there at night.''
title: PATERSON MAYOR PROPOSES CURFEW FOR CITY TROUBLED BY TEEN-AGERS' CRIMES

text: A police officer, Wilfredo Duran, agreed. Sitting in his cruiser, Officer Duran gestured toward a group of about 40 youths standing outside a corner grocery store a block away.
title: PATERSON MAYOR PROPOSES CURFEW FOR CITY TROUBLED BY TEEN-AGERS' CRIMES

text: ''They practically live on the streets, and they learn very quickly,'' he said. ''We have kids armed and selling drugs by the time they're 13.''
title: PATERSON MAYOR PROPOSES CURFEW FOR CITY TROUBLED BY TEEN-AGERS' CRIMES

text: In the midst of an escalating dispute between owners and players over drug testing, club officials have indicated that virtually no testing of nonplaying major league personnel has been conducted under Commissioner Peter Ueberroth's mandatory drug-testing program.
title: BASEBALL'S TESTS FOR DRUGS STALLED

text: In his June 18 notice to major league clubs, Ueberroth said that major league managers, coaches, trainers and management personnel would be subject to testing for cocaine, amphetamines, marijuana, heroin and morphine. The testing, Ueberroth said, would take place from August through November.
title: BASEBALL'S TESTS FOR DRUGS STALLED

text: However, a survey of all 26 clubs made last week by The New York Times found executives of only two clubs saying that some of their employees had been tested. Executives and other front-office employees of 24 clubs said they knew of no one on their clubs who had been tested.
title: BASEBALL'S TESTS FOR DRUGS STALLED

text: For more than six months, Ueberroth has tried to induce the players to agree to testing. His effort, though, along with that of the owners, has deteriorated into a hardening labor-management dispute. In a recent series of events, Ueberroth bypassed the union and appealed directly to the players to participate voluntarily in his testing program, the owners unilaterally terminated their drug agreement with the players and, currently, an increasing number of clubs are putting mandatory testing clauses in guaranteed contracts.
title: BASEBALL'S TESTS FOR DRUGS STALLED

text: Donald Fehr, the union chief, who has borne the brunt of management and fan criticism over the testing issue, said he was not surprised by the results of the survey.
title: BASEBALL'S TESTS FOR DRUGS STALLED

text: ''If the facts are right,'' Fehr said, ''it does not surprise me that the program that was announced last spring never got put into operation.'' Recalling an Oct. 11 meeting with owners' labor representatives on the testing issue, Fehr added, ''We had some inkling of this because when we asked questions about how the program worked, the people at the table were not conversant with the program.''
title: BASEBALL'S TESTS FOR DRUGS STALLED

text: Ueberroth, who was not at that negotiating session, said there has been testing of major league personnel.
title: BASEBALL'S TESTS FOR DRUGS STALLED

text: ''There were a number of employees on clubs in both leagues tested,'' the commissioner said. ''We've asked them not to talk about it. We can't test everybody on a regular basis. There hasn't been a lot of testing. It's been about the same ratio as in the minor leagues. It's an expensive procedure. It's the only way to go if you want to guarantee 100 percent accuracy.''
title: BASEBALL'S TESTS FOR DRUGS STALLED

text: Early in October, the commissioner's office said that fewer than 20 per cent of minor league players and other personnel had been tested under the program. That was in response to a newspaper story quoting four minor league presidents as saying no one in their leagues had been tested. A week earlier, Ueberroth had said the program had brought about a ''dramatic decrease'' in drug use by minor league players and nonplaying personnel.
title: BASEBALL'S TESTS FOR DRUGS STALLED

text: Officials or other employees of all 12 National League clubs said none of their clubs' employees had been tested.
title: BASEBALL'S TESTS FOR DRUGS STALLED

text: ''I haven't personally been tested, and I haven't heard anyone around the building say they have been,'' said Joe McIlvaine, assistant vice president and director of player personnel of the Mets.
title: BASEBALL'S TESTS FOR DRUGS STALLED

text: ''With our club, they haven't been tested,'' said Joe O'Toole, vice president for administration of the Pittsburgh Pirates.
title: BASEBALL'S TESTS FOR DRUGS STALLED

text: ''We are eligible to be tested, but no one to my knowledge has been,'' said Al Campanis, the Los Angeles Dodgers' vice president for player personnel.
title: BASEBALL'S TESTS FOR DRUGS STALLED

text: And Al Rosen, general manager of the San Francisco Giants, who previously held that post with the Houston Astros, said no one on either team was tested under the commissioner's program.
title: BASEBALL'S TESTS FOR DRUGS STALLED

text: Tests at Seattle and Detroit
title: BASEBALL'S TESTS FOR DRUGS STALLED

text: In the American League, Bill Lajoie, general manager of the Detroit Tigers, and Charles Armstrong, president of the Seattle Mariners, said people on their clubs had been tested. Peter Bavasi, president of the Cleveland Indians; Mike Port, general manager of the California Angels, and John Schuerolz, general manager of the Kansas City Royals, declined to say if there had been testing, citing confidentiality. However, sources from all three clubs said no testing had been done.
title: BASEBALL'S TESTS FOR DRUGS STALLED

text: Officials of the other nine American League clubs said they were not aware of anyone who had been tested.
title: BASEBALL'S TESTS FOR DRUGS STALLED

text: Ueberroth said people could be tested without others knowing about it. ''It's not something you run out and talk about,'' he said.
title: BASEBALL'S TESTS FOR DRUGS STALLED

text: However, the commissioner also acknowledged that testing is conducted at each club's facilities, which means the three-member medical teams would have to operate at least somewhat in the open so that even people who were not being tested would know of their presence.
title: BASEBALL'S TESTS FOR DRUGS STALLED

text: ''I haven't heard of anybody being tested,'' Harry Dalton, general manager of the Milwaukee Brewers, said. ''Maybe they were, but if they were, I think I would've heard about it.''
title: BASEBALL'S TESTS FOR DRUGS STALLED

text: Even a lower-level employee of the Seattle front office heard about the testing of the Mariners' personnel. ''Word spread around the office real quick,'' he said. The employee even remembered that the testing was done ''when Detroit was in town.'' That was the last week in August. Armstrong, the Mariners' president, described what happened that day.
title: BASEBALL'S TESTS FOR DRUGS STALLED

text: ''They came in,'' Armstrong explained, ''and on what they said was random basis, they picked 10 or 12 people, from the controller to the farm director to, I think, one coach. I think they were there in August, but it might have been September.''
title: BASEBALL'S TESTS FOR DRUGS STALLED

text: Lajoie declined to elaborate on the testing among Detroit personnel, such as whether uniformed or nonuniformed personnel were tested. ''There have been salaried employees tested,'' he said. ''It's supposed to be confidential.''
title: BASEBALL'S TESTS FOR DRUGS STALLED

text: However, in his June 18 notice to the clubs providing details of the testing program, Ueberroth did not say that the testing itself was to be confidential. The only time he used the word ''confidential'' was in saying that ''the results of all tests will be kept confidential.''
title: BASEBALL'S TESTS FOR DRUGS STALLED

text: By Christopher S. Wren, Special To the New York Times
title: 'AIR FARCE' OFFERS CANADIAN HUMOR

text: What is the only major city in Canada whose name starts with zero?
title: 'AIR FARCE' OFFERS CANADIAN HUMOR

text: It is Ottawa, of course, a capital of modest origins that is today the home of Canada's real decision makers -the United States Embassy.
title: 'AIR FARCE' OFFERS CANADIAN HUMOR

text: Such is the whimsy offered by the Royal Canadian Air Farce, whose deft satirical commentary has become a weekly radio institution, at least among Canadians willing to laugh at their national character.
title: 'AIR FARCE' OFFERS CANADIAN HUMOR

text: The subtleties that define the difference between Canadians and Americans extend to their senses of humor. Canadians are more wry and self-deprecating, billing themselves with misleading modesty as the nation hidden away in North America's attic.
title: 'AIR FARCE' OFFERS CANADIAN HUMOR

text: Their wit, perhaps best known to Americans through the late Canadian humorist Stephen Leacock, tends to be polite rather than savage. ''It bites, but you don't bleed,'' explained Donald McSween, the director of the National Arts Center in Ottawa.
title: 'AIR FARCE' OFFERS CANADIAN HUMOR

text: ''It includes the humor that comes out of a sense that we are not a European power, we are not the republic to the south, but for a lot of quiet reasons we are better off,'' Mr. McSween said.
title: 'AIR FARCE' OFFERS CANADIAN HUMOR

text: But Canadian satire can still sting the status quo. ''I think we're still in the Mark Twain stage of using that droll approach and letting the listeners make the final connection,'' said Roger Abbott, a performer and writer for the Royal Canadian Air Farce, ''whereas a lot of Americans tend to do the pure 100 percent,''
title: 'AIR FARCE' OFFERS CANADIAN HUMOR

text: The Air Farce, now four men and one woman strong, was formed a dozen years ago by young comedians from improvisational theater in Montreal and Toronto who moved on to the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation.
title: 'AIR FARCE' OFFERS CANADIAN HUMOR

text: ''It's really a great way to maintain your childhood,'' Mr. Abbott said as he talked in the program's cluttered Toronto office, ''and we all presume some day it will end and wonder what we're going to do when it ends.''
title: 'AIR FARCE' OFFERS CANADIAN HUMOR

text: A half-million regular listeners hope that the Royal Canadian Air Farce won't end. Some fans have been known to drive to the supermarket early on Saturday and then sit chuckling inside their car until the half-hour radio program is over. When the show is rebroadcast on Sunday, some families schedule meals around it.
title: 'AIR FARCE' OFFERS CANADIAN HUMOR

text: The program - which is on at 9:34 A.M. Saturdays, Eastern standard time, on the CBC's FM station and 1:08 P.M. Sundays on the AM station - originates from various cities and is performed before a studio audience. It even draws a hard core of American listeners who pick it up across the border.
title: 'AIR FARCE' OFFERS CANADIAN HUMOR

text: ''We have certain expectations of our audience,'' Mr. Abbott said. ''You won't enjoy our show if you don't read a newspaper at least a few days a week. Our show is for people who choose to be informed.''
title: 'AIR FARCE' OFFERS CANADIAN HUMOR

text: Almost every show gets in a dig at the United States. The Air Farce has warned of a world filled with dangers - ''and most of them live in Washington.'' In its version of Prime Minister Brian Mulroney's visit to the White House, President Reagan had to consult a cue card to learn who his visitor was. ''We're going to do what we agreed,'' Mr. Reagan was depicted as telling Mr. Mulroney. ''Set up a dummy corporation that'll run Canada from Washington and relieve you of all those chores of government.''
title: 'AIR FARCE' OFFERS CANADIAN HUMOR

text: Such humor mocks not only the way in which the United States takes its northern neighbor for granted but also the perceptions that Canadians have of American intentions.
title: 'AIR FARCE' OFFERS CANADIAN HUMOR

text: ''Every Canadian has a love-hate relationship with the United States,'' said Don Ferguson, another Air Farce stalwart. ''The United States is very much admired and envied for its dynamism and standard of living. And the United States is very much feared for its power and influence.''
title: 'AIR FARCE' OFFERS CANADIAN HUMOR

text: And how does the Air Farce feel? ''We treat America as America treats Canada - with consummate ignorance,'' he said.
title: 'AIR FARCE' OFFERS CANADIAN HUMOR

text: But the ripest targets lie inside Canada's own political system. ''I think it's enormously healthy for any society to make fun of its politicians,'' said Mr. Ferguson.
title: 'AIR FARCE' OFFERS CANADIAN HUMOR

text: When the Air Farce presented a strategy session between Prime Minister Mulroney and his advisers, Mr. Mulroney asserted that ''we must come up with our own uniquely Canadian solutions.'' But then he kept asking, ''What's Ronnie doing?''
title: 'AIR FARCE' OFFERS CANADIAN HUMOR

text: Foreign Minister Joe Clark was portrayed as announcing effective, hard-hitting sanctions against South Africa: ''In the future, Canada will not send furs, Hudson Bay blankets or woolly underwear.''
title: 'AIR FARCE' OFFERS CANADIAN HUMOR

text: The Air Farce defined the philosophy that it said guided John Diefenbaker as Prime Minister in the late 1950's and early 60's: ''If you can fool some of the people all of the time and all of the people some of the time, go for it!''
title: 'AIR FARCE' OFFERS CANADIAN HUMOR

text: Dave Broadfoot, an Air Farce member, is popular for parodies of fatuous speeches in the House of Commons. In one episode, his fictional Member of Parliament for Kicking Horse Pass urged Canadians to look at the bright side of their problems, down to the corrosive salt used to thaw roads in winter: ''No invading army can ever take over this country. Their tanks would rot.'' If the weak Canadian dollar rules out a Florida vacation this winter, the M.P. advised, ''take your Canadian money and spend your two weeks in Labrador and enjoy all the money you'll save on suntan oil.''
title: 'AIR FARCE' OFFERS CANADIAN HUMOR

text: On another occasion, Mr. Broadfoot urged that Canadian athletes be trained to beat the Russians in chess, ''but with Canadian rules - on ice with sticks and full body contact.''
title: 'AIR FARCE' OFFERS CANADIAN HUMOR

text: Quips about Ottawa, a bureaucratic city that many Canadians love to hate, invariably draw a laugh. When Mr. Mulroney was asked at a mock news conference for his views on capital punishment, the Air Farce had him lamenting that ''if you're elected Prime Minister, you have to live in Ottawa.''
title: 'AIR FARCE' OFFERS CANADIAN HUMOR

text: The publicly owned Canadian Broadcasting Corporation has never tried to tone down the material, Mr. Abbott said, but the Prime Minister's office often requests a transcript of something that was said, ''and we don't think it's for their entertainment.''
title: 'AIR FARCE' OFFERS CANADIAN HUMOR

text: But the most complaints are prompted by jokes about the British monarchy, which many Canadians still revere. The troupe chose its name partly to mock such institutions.
title: 'AIR FARCE' OFFERS CANADIAN HUMOR

text: During the Queen's visit to Canada in 1984, after the police said marijuana was found in a suitcase belonging to the Premier of New Brunswick, Richard Hatfield - he was later acquitted of drug possession charges -the Air Farce explained that the suitcase actually belonged to the Queen, who needed the contraband to get her through the royal tour.
title: 'AIR FARCE' OFFERS CANADIAN HUMOR

text: The Air Farce has also parodied television evangelists and gun owners. When a customer in a skit tried to buy a gun to shoot his landlord, the wary sales clerk asked, ''How do I know you won't use the gun to go duck hunting?''
title: 'AIR FARCE' OFFERS CANADIAN HUMOR

text: The show's scattershot has reached to polluted Lake Erie, where, the Air Farce reported, a long-distance swimmer got tired two miles from shore last summer ''and had to walk the rest of the way.''
title: 'AIR FARCE' OFFERS CANADIAN HUMOR

text: Mr. Ferguson said he wanted to try out the Air Farce's humor on an American audience some day, even though some patter might sound too Canadian. ''Who's going to get a Mulroney joke in Iowa?'' he conceded. ''But what will travel,'' he added, ''is our attitude and an intelligent, friendly and jaundiced eye.''
title: 'AIR FARCE' OFFERS CANADIAN HUMOR

text: Besides, Mr. Ferguson confessed, America excites him. ''The thrill about going to the United States,'' he said, ''is you know everybody's armed.''
title: 'AIR FARCE' OFFERS CANADIAN HUMOR

text: A dispute over tribal powers and the performance of an Indian tribunal that one lawyer calls a ''kangaroo court'' has reached the reservation of the Red Lake band of Chippewas.
title: 3 INDIANS CHALLENGE TRIBAL COURT ON RIGHTS ISSUE

text: The tribal court's powers have been challenged in Federal District Court by three Indians, and tribal leaders have ordered two Federal officials off their land.
title: 3 INDIANS CHALLENGE TRIBAL COURT ON RIGHTS ISSUE

text: ''This is a closed reservation,'' said Roger Jourdain, the reservation's only chairman since the tribal government was created in 1958. ''We're exercising our sovereign power.''
title: 3 INDIANS CHALLENGE TRIBAL COURT ON RIGHTS ISSUE

text: In September a lawsuit was filed in the Federal court on behalf of three Indians who were jailed on the reservation. The suit asked that Federal financing for the Indian tribunal, the Red Lake Court of Indian Offenses, which hears cases on the Chippewa reservation, be halted until the court was reformed.
title: 3 INDIANS CHALLENGE TRIBAL COURT ON RIGHTS ISSUE

text: According to Richard Meshbesher, the lawyer for the three Indians, Red Lake court officials have been denying defendants the ''right of counsel, jury trial, in many cases requiring excessive bail or no bail.''
title: 3 INDIANS CHALLENGE TRIBAL COURT ON RIGHTS ISSUE

text: Tribal council members say that the Indian court, one of 22 in the country, has acted properly and that outsiders have no business meddling in its affairs.
title: 3 INDIANS CHALLENGE TRIBAL COURT ON RIGHTS ISSUE

text: Earlier this month, the Bureau of Indian Affairs in Washington ordered its area directors to assure that defendants' rights were respected in Indian courts. The courts are financed by the Government and staffed mostly by tribal members.
title: 3 INDIANS CHALLENGE TRIBAL COURT ON RIGHTS ISSUE

text: On Sunday, Chief Robert Moran, head of the tribal police force, and Rex Mayotte, superintendent of the bureau's Red Lake tribal agency, were ordered off the reservation, apparently for trying to enforce the bureau directive. The men were still on the reservation Tuesday, according to Mark Anderson, a bureau lawyer.
title: 3 INDIANS CHALLENGE TRIBAL COURT ON RIGHTS ISSUE

text: Mr. Meshbesher said the Indian court had been used to harass Mr. Jourdain's opponents. He also asserted that the rights guaranteed Indians under the Indian Civil Rights Act of 1968 had been denied for years.
title: 3 INDIANS CHALLENGE TRIBAL COURT ON RIGHTS ISSUE

text: ''They've badgered defendants into pleading guilty,'' he said. ''To the best of our knowledge, in 28 years they've only had two jury trials permitted, both for the same defendant.''
title: 3 INDIANS CHALLENGE TRIBAL COURT ON RIGHTS ISSUE

text: Mr. Anderson, of the bureau, said there was no evidence that anyone had been coerced into a guilty plea. ''Everyone is advised of his rights at the time of booking and arraignment,'' he said.
title: 3 INDIANS CHALLENGE TRIBAL COURT ON RIGHTS ISSUE

text: Mr. Jourdain, who is in his 70's, has refused to comment on the lawsuit. On Tuesday he said the controversy was his opponents' ''prelude'' to tribal elections in May.
title: 3 INDIANS CHALLENGE TRIBAL COURT ON RIGHTS ISSUE

text: Two Boys Killed in Takeover
title: 3 INDIANS CHALLENGE TRIBAL COURT ON RIGHTS ISSUE

text: Controversy is nothing new on the reservation. In 1979 seven buildings were burned and two teen-age boys were accidentally killed in an armed takeover of the reservation's law-enforcement center.
title: 3 INDIANS CHALLENGE TRIBAL COURT ON RIGHTS ISSUE

text: Five Chippewas were convicted in the takeover, which they called a protest against corruption in Mr. Jourdain's goverment. Mr. Jourdain's home was looted and burned, and he moved to Bemidji, 30 miles southeast of the reservation.
title: 3 INDIANS CHALLENGE TRIBAL COURT ON RIGHTS ISSUE

text: The Red Lake tribe has 7,200 members, including 3,500 who live on the reservation.
title: 3 INDIANS CHALLENGE TRIBAL COURT ON RIGHTS ISSUE

text: The Red Lake court has jurisdiction over any Indian on the heavily forested reservation 200 miles northwest of Minneapolis. Its three magistrates can impose no penalty heavier than a six-month jail sentence and $500 fine. Serious offenses are tried in the Federal courts.
title: 3 INDIANS CHALLENGE TRIBAL COURT ON RIGHTS ISSUE

text: The suit in Federal court alleges that Gregory Good, 27 years old, and Douglas Neaudeau, 30, were wrongly denied bail, jury trials and lawyers when they were arrested in March. Mr. Good pleaded guilty to possession and sale of marijuana, and Mr. Neaudeau pleaded guilty to not having a driver's license and possession of marijuana. Mr. Good was sentenced to six months in jail and Mr. Neaudeau to three months.
title: 3 INDIANS CHALLENGE TRIBAL COURT ON RIGHTS ISSUE

text: The suit also says Edward Cook, 27, was wrongly denied bail, a jury trial and a lawyer when he was arrested for resisting arrest, assault and battery and reckless driving. The suit contends his guilty plea in July was coerced.
title: 3 INDIANS CHALLENGE TRIBAL COURT ON RIGHTS ISSUE

text: Two Newark teen-agers were arrested today and charged in the fatal shooting of an Essex County sheriff's officer and the wounding of another during an apparent robbery attempt on Tuesday, officials said. A third suspect was being sought. The two in custody were Guyron Walker, 19 years old, and a 17-year-old whom the police did not identify because of his age. They were arrested at their homes after a 42-hour search, according to Thomas J. D'Alessio, the Essex County Sheriff.
title: 2 NEWARK TEEN-AGERS HELD IN SLAYING OF OFFICER AT BAR

text: Mr. Walker is being held at the Essex County Jail, and the 17-year-old is being held at the County Youth House, awaiting arraignment and the setting of bail on Monday. Youths under the age of 18 are considered minors under state law. #3d Suspect Being Sought Sheriff D'Alessio, in a news conference at the County Courts Building, said the authorities were searching for a third suspect, Edward Craig, 18 years old, of 280 Littleton Avenue in Newark.
title: 2 NEWARK TEEN-AGERS HELD IN SLAYING OF OFFICER AT BAR

text: Mr. Walker and Mr. Craig are charged with first-degree murder, robbery and aggravated assault; the 17-year-old is charged with felony murder and robbery, according to an assistant Essex County prosecutor, Norman Menz.
title: 2 NEWARK TEEN-AGERS HELD IN SLAYING OF OFFICER AT BAR

text: The shootings took place at 8 P.M. on Tuesday at the V & J Tavern, at 431 South Seventh Street in Newark's West Ward, where, authorities said, at least two gunmen entered and announced a holdup. When a patron tried to intervene, one of the officers, Sgt. Nathaniel Taylor, drew his service weapon and confronted one of the gunmen, authorities said. Sergeant Taylor was shot in the chest.
title: 2 NEWARK TEEN-AGERS HELD IN SLAYING OF OFFICER AT BAR

text: The other officer, Detective Robert Walls, was shot in the back. The gunmen then fled on foot, said the Newark Police Director, Charles Knox.
title: 2 NEWARK TEEN-AGERS HELD IN SLAYING OF OFFICER AT BAR

text: The officers, who were not in uniform, were taken to University Hospital, where Sergeant Taylor, 51, died shortly after arrival. Detective Walls, 54, underwent surgery and was listed in fair condition.
title: 2 NEWARK TEEN-AGERS HELD IN SLAYING OF OFFICER AT BAR

text: The two suspects arrested today live in the same block of Newark's Camden Street and were arrested after the authorities conducted a search of the 10 blocks surrounding the tavern at 437 South Seventh Street.
title: 2 NEWARK TEEN-AGERS HELD IN SLAYING OF OFFICER AT BAR

text: Twenty-five officers surrounded the houses to arrest the two men, who surrendered without incident, Sheriff D'Alessio said.
title: 2 NEWARK TEEN-AGERS HELD IN SLAYING OF OFFICER AT BAR

text: The authorities linked their arrests to a drug arrest made Wednesday night in a neighboring house. The suspect in that arrest was found with 69 bags of marijuana. The police said they found him while canvassing the area.
title: 2 NEWARK TEEN-AGERS HELD IN SLAYING OF OFFICER AT BAR

text: Officials declined to say how exactly the arrests were connected, but indicated that the drug arrest had produced information leading to capture of those suspected in the shootings.
title: 2 NEWARK TEEN-AGERS HELD IN SLAYING OF OFFICER AT BAR

text: Mr. Craig also lives within the 10-block area, according to officials, who said they were certain that he was still in Newark and would soon be arrested.
title: 2 NEWARK TEEN-AGERS HELD IN SLAYING OF OFFICER AT BAR

text: ''We talked to his mother, and she said he should give himself up,'' Sheriff D'Alessio said. ''It's in his best interest to turn himself in. We'll catch him anyway. It's over.''
title: 2 NEWARK TEEN-AGERS HELD IN SLAYING OF OFFICER AT BAR

text: Mr. Walker and Mr. Craig were suspected as the gunmen involved in the actual shooting, while the 17-year-old suspect was considered an accessory to the crime or the ''lookout man,'' Mr. Menz said.
title: 2 NEWARK TEEN-AGERS HELD IN SLAYING OF OFFICER AT BAR

text: Mr. Walker and Mr. Craig both have prior criminal records, mostly for juvenile offenses, Sheriff D'Alessio said, declining to offer information on the 17-year-old suspect.
title: 2 NEWARK TEEN-AGERS HELD IN SLAYING OF OFFICER AT BAR

text: A Federal jury today found that CBS Inc. and a commentator at the network's Chicago television station had libeled a tobacco company by broadcasting an anticigarette commentary.
title: CBS Held to Libel Company

text: The six-member jury returned the verdict after deliberating less than three hours. A CBS spokesman said the company would appeal the ruling and was confident of a reversal.
title: CBS Held to Libel Company

text: A separate hearing will be held next week before the same jury to determine whether the tobacco company, Brown & Williamson Tobacco Corporation, is entitled to damages. The Louisville company, a subsidiary of London-based B.A.T. Industries, has asked for $10 million in damages.
title: CBS Held to Libel Company

text: Brown & Williamson objected to a commentary written and broadcast in 1981 by Walter Jacobson, a newscaster at the television station owned and operated by CBS in Chicago. The company charged in the suit that the commentary was false and defamatory and done with malice, legally defined as actual knowledge that the material is false.
title: CBS Held to Libel Company

text: In the commentary, Mr. Jacobson said Brown & Williamson had adopted an advertising strategy of luring children into smoking its Viceroy brand by equating smoking with marijuana, sex, beer and other pursuits off-limits to youngsters. He referred to the company as the ''Viceroy slicksters.''
title: CBS Held to Libel Company

text: CBS and Jacobson contended they were only quoting from a Federal Trade Commission report, which they said reached the same conclusion, but Brown & Williamson argued that the advertising campaign was only a suggestion made by a consultant to its advertising agency, that it never made its way into any actual advertising and that it had warned Jacobson's producer the F.T.C. report was erroneous.
title: CBS Held to Libel Company

text: The CBS spokesman said that it was unfortunate the author of the F.T.C. report was not allowed to testify about it and the commentary. The judge ruled that the report had to speak for itself.
title: CBS Held to Libel Company

text: The author of the study said outside of court that he thought the commentary fairly reflected the report.
title: CBS Held to Libel Company

text: By Katherine Bishop, Special To the New York Times
title: WORKER DRUG TESTS RESISTED

text: Two court cases here involving an employer's right to test workers for alcohol and drug abuse are being closely watched by labor and management officials from around the country. The cases, along with a San Francisco ordinance that awaits action by the mayor, are at the forefront of a growing legal fight that pits an employer's need to ferret out substance abuse against a worker's right to privacy.
title: WORKER DRUG TESTS RESISTED
