text: An initial hearing was held today in one of the cases, a suit brought by a computer programmer against her former employer, the Southern Pacific Transportation Company, charging that she was improperly discharged because she refused to submit to a urine test.
title: WORKER DRUG TESTS RESISTED

text: In the second suit, a temporary restraining order against a Government program that would test railroad workers was lifted today by a Federal judge. The suit is considered a key public-sector case that could affect airlines and other federally regulated transportation companies throughout the nation.
title: WORKER DRUG TESTS RESISTED

text: The San Francisco ordinance, which has been passed by the Board of Supervisors, would greatly restrict use of blood and urine testing by private employers. Mayor Dianne Feinstein is expected to act by Friday on the measure, thought to be the first of its kind in the country., The flurry of legal activity reflects the increasing concern of employers about absenteeism, low productivity and workplace accidents, among other problems frequently linked to substance abuse.
title: WORKER DRUG TESTS RESISTED

text: But some of the techniques that have been used to detect the abuse -including mandatory urine testing, undercover investigations, surveillance cameras, drug-sniffing dogs and polygraph tests - have led to charges that such methods are widely abused and unnecessarily intrude on the personal life of employees.
title: WORKER DRUG TESTS RESISTED

text: ''It's a fascinating area, and one that's exploding,'' said John Mason, chief counsel for the Federal Railroad Administration in Washington., which is the defendant in the public-sector case here. ''All of a sudden people are very interested in substance abuse on the job after 10 to 15 years of laissez-faire.''
title: WORKER DRUG TESTS RESISTED

text: With the issues coming to the forefront only recently, ''there is precious little in court decisions,'' said David Ewing, managing editor of the Harvard Business Review. ''The whole privacy issue has been left almost untouched.''
title: WORKER DRUG TESTS RESISTED

text: One major reason for the change in attitude is the growing problems involving absenteeism and productivity. But employers have also become alarmed by a number of recent cases involving workers who become intoxicated on the job, according to Victor Schachter, a San Francisco lawyer. Juries are now showing a willingness to hold companies liable for accidents caused by these employees while on the way home, Mr. Schachter said.
title: WORKER DRUG TESTS RESISTED

text: Despite their concern, ''most organizations have no idea how to deal with this problem,'' said Ted Schramm, president of Behavior Research Inc., a San Diego-based company that advises corporations and government agencies on substance abuse issues.
title: WORKER DRUG TESTS RESISTED

text: Poorly planned policies often result in simplistic solutions and dubious practices such as having a supervisor ''burst into a restroom to see if anyone is smoking marijuana,'' Mr. Schramm said. ''Ninety percent of our time is cleaning up after bad policies,'' he added.
title: WORKER DRUG TESTS RESISTED

text: Many companies, including the International Business Machines Corporation, the Union Oil Company of California and The New York Times, require job applicants to submit to a urinalysis that detects drug use as part of the medical examination given at the time they are hired.
title: WORKER DRUG TESTS RESISTED

text: More complex legal issues come into play when employers try to extend similar testing to those already on the job.
title: WORKER DRUG TESTS RESISTED

text: In the case brought against Southern Pacific in San Francisco Superior Court, for example, the company was accused of selecting 489 employees to be tested on the basis of job classification rather than because of any particular suspicion that they were using drugs. The tests were given without advance notice.
title: WORKER DRUG TESTS RESISTED

text: The plaintiff, Barbara Luck, who had worked for Southern Pacific for six years, objected to furnishing a urine sample on grounds of personal privacy. She was the only employee to refuse to take the test.
title: WORKER DRUG TESTS RESISTED

text: According to Kathleen Lucas-Wallace, the San Francisco attorney who represents Mrs. Luck, the case is complicated by the fact that California, like a dozen other states, has a state constitutional provision guaranteeing individuals a right to privacy. This elevates the issue, she said, to a constitutional standard that requires a ''compelling interest,'' such as public safety, to allow such an intrusion. Mrs. Lucas-Wallace said that public safety was not at issue in Mrs. Luck's case.
title: WORKER DRUG TESTS RESISTED

text: In those cases in which testing is justified, Mrs. Lucas-Wallace contended that there are less intrusive ways of doing it, such as using machines to test hand-eye coordination.
title: WORKER DRUG TESTS RESISTED

text: Patrick W. Jordan, one of the San Francisco attorneys representing Southern Pacific, declined to discuss the merits of the case but acknowledged that the testing had been done without advance notice ''to be most effective.'' He said that testing was done at all levels of the company in an effort to be uniform and that every manager, including the president of the company, had been tested.
title: WORKER DRUG TESTS RESISTED

text: Some companies, such as Advanced Micro Devices in Sunnyvale, Calif., do not require drug testing but have used undercover investigations to detect the use or sale of drugs or alcohol on company premises.
title: WORKER DRUG TESTS RESISTED

text: The policy of The New York Times is that only truck drivers are subject to tests, which are given to them periodically, according to Elliott M. Sanger Jr., a spokesman for the company. Substance abuse problems are dealt with on an individual basis if they affect work performance and counseling sessions are made available, he said. Employees may also be granted leave to attend a recovery program.
title: WORKER DRUG TESTS RESISTED

text: San Francisco Federal Savings has recently adopted a strict policy, warning employees that they may be subjected to searches of their vehicles, briefcases, purses, lunch boxes, desks and lockers. The policy also provides for the use of drug-sniffing dogs and blood or urine tests without prior notice. Refusal to submit is a cause for termination.
title: WORKER DRUG TESTS RESISTED

text: Patrick H. Price, president of the thrift institution, said the policy had resulted from drug-related thefts of money and a case of money laundering that is under criminal investigation. Mr. Price said that so far none of the procedures had been used.
title: WORKER DRUG TESTS RESISTED

text: A portion of San Francisco Federal's policy, along with the urinalysis program at Southern Pacific, would be outlawed if the ordinance passed by the San Francisco Board of Supervisors earlier this month becomes law. Mayor Feinstein has not indicated whether she would sign or veto the measure.
title: WORKER DRUG TESTS RESISTED

text: The ordinance prohibits mandatory blood or urine testing except if an employer has reason to believe that a employee is impaired because of drug use and the impairment presents a clear danger to the safety of others. It applies to all companies doing business within the city and county of San Francisco and exempts only law enforcement, firefighting and emergency service vehicle agencies.
title: WORKER DRUG TESTS RESISTED

text: Supervisor Bill Maher, the sponsor of the measure, believes it is the first local ordinance in the country to try to extend to workers in private industry some of the same protections enjoyed by government employees. State and Federal workers already have broad safeguards against testing under general Fourth Amendment protections, Mr. Maher noted.
title: WORKER DRUG TESTS RESISTED

text: Even when employees consent to drug testing, challenges to the accuracy of the results can give rise to another set of problems. In a case filed here last Thursday, an office manager for Southern Pacific who consented to an unannounced urinalysis charged that he was forced to attend a drug rehabilitation program and submit to further testing in order to keep his job even though he claims the first test incorrectly showed a positive result and a second test was negative.
title: WORKER DRUG TESTS RESISTED

text: In the other case here that legal experts see as a crucial one for the public sector, United States District Judge Charles Legge lifted a temporary restraining order that he had imposed Nov. 1. The order had blocked the start of a Federal Railroad Administration program involving more than 200,000 workers.
title: WORKER DRUG TESTS RESISTED

text: The program requires mandatory testing of an employee in cases in which there is a ''reasonable suspicion'' that the worker is impaired by drugs or alcohol.
title: WORKER DRUG TESTS RESISTED

text: In today's ruling, the judge held that the Fourth Amendment guarantee against searches without ''probable cause'' - a tougher standard than ''reasonable suspicion'' - was outweighed by the public interest in railroad safety. He gave the railroad workers a week to appeal.
title: WORKER DRUG TESTS RESISTED

text: If it is not overturned, the court's ruling is expected to result in federally required drug testing in other transportation industries regulated by Washington and in local bus and subway systems that receive Federal funds, said Lawrence M. Mann, a Washington lawyer who is representing the railroad workers.
title: WORKER DRUG TESTS RESISTED

text: By the many thousands they step off the planes from Tokyo, two by two, one of the steadier processions of traveling couples since Noah's Ark.
title: THIS TIME TO MAKE MONEY

text: They are Japanese honeymooners, and the large numbers who flock every day to the northern tier of Micronesia provide evidence that Japan has regained economically some of the western Pacific islands that it lost militarily 40 years ago.
title: THIS TIME TO MAKE MONEY

text: Japan dominates here even though Saipan is part of a United States commonwealth these days. Much of the northern Marianas, in fact, has been turned into a Japanese warm-weather playground over the last 15 years.
title: THIS TIME TO MAKE MONEY

text: There is only one real industry, tourism, and most major hotels are in Japanese hands. Four of every five visitors to Saipan are Japanese, usually newlyweds lured by relatively inexpensive package tours.
title: THIS TIME TO MAKE MONEY

text: The same is true in far larger numbers on nearby Guam, which is an unincorporated United States territory with important American air and naval bases. Guam has even adopted the slogan ''Where America's day begins.''
title: THIS TIME TO MAKE MONEY

text: But of the 368,665 visitors to the island last year, 82 percent came from Japan. The $221 million that they spent accounted for about half of all retail sales.
title: THIS TIME TO MAKE MONEY

text: In some sections of Saipan and Guam, Japanese signs are almost the only ones to be seen. Maps of Guam available at the airport are written in Japanese, not English. Duty-free shops are stocked with high-priced clothes, liquors and other items considered prestige symbols in Tokyo and Osaka.
title: THIS TIME TO MAKE MONEY

text: The influx of Japanese tourists has meant growth for other industries as well.
title: THIS TIME TO MAKE MONEY

text: Two years ago there were three Japanese construction companies with offices on Guam. Now there are 10 because of the growing demand for new hotels, roads, airport construction and commercial buildings.
title: THIS TIME TO MAKE MONEY

text: A contractor from New Zealand told of attending a large meeting where bids were accepted for a small project related to a hotel being built on Saipan. Except for one or two South Koreans, he said, ''I was the only non-Japanese in the room.''
title: THIS TIME TO MAKE MONEY

text: Japan controlled Micronesia - the Marianas, plus the Caroline and Marshall islands - from 1918 to the end of World War II in 1945. Micronesia was, and remains, a strategically sensitive area, covering three million square miles of the Pacific and comprising about 2,000 islands that today have a total population of 135,000.
title: THIS TIME TO MAKE MONEY

text: Older islanders sometimes talk of the Japanese era as the good old days, partly reflecting disenchantment with the United States, whose trusteeship for the last 38 years has produced little in the way of economic development.
title: THIS TIME TO MAKE MONEY

text: In the 1930's Japan operated sugar-cane plantations, fisheries and phosphate mines on many islands. The Garapan section of Saipan bustled with shops, movie theaters and geisha houses. Islanders were treated like second-class citizens, but at least, some say, things were lively.
title: THIS TIME TO MAKE MONEY

text: The United States wrested military control of the Marianas from Japan after fierce battles in 1944. In a notably grim end to the fighting on Saipan, thousands of Japanese civilians committed suicide by hurling first their children and then themselves from cliffs on the island's northern end.
title: THIS TIME TO MAKE MONEY

text: Yesterday's horror, however, has become today's photo opportunity. Now, Japanese honeymoon couples take group bus tours to Suicide Cliff. Older Japanese, accompanied by Buddhist priests, come periodically on religious pilgrimages to hunt for the bones of dead relatives and friends.
title: THIS TIME TO MAKE MONEY

text: The resurgence of Japanese economic influence is concentrated in the Marianas, but it is beginning to be felt elsewhere in Micronesia, too. From Palau in the western part of island chain to the Marshalls in the east, local political leaders regard Japanese tourism as their best chance to stimulate economies now largely dependent on United States aid.
title: THIS TIME TO MAKE MONEY

text: The Japanese Government has also begun to show interest in its former territory once again. It has steadily increased economic assistance, giving $17.6 million since 1980 to three semiautonomous governments in the American trusteeship - Palau, the Marshall Islands and the Federated States of Micronesia.
title: THIS TIME TO MAKE MONEY

text: Money for Roads and Fisheries
title: THIS TIME TO MAKE MONEY

text: A good deal of this money has gone for road construction and for fishery-related projects such as deep-storage refrigerators being built on the islands of Ponape and Dublon in the Federated States. In addition, Japanese tuna-boat fleets contribute up to $2 million a year for the right to fish in Micronesian waters.
title: THIS TIME TO MAKE MONEY

text: Micronesians, especially those most critical of the American stewardship, say they are glad to receive the help.
title: THIS TIME TO MAKE MONEY

text: ''The Japanese went about it the right way,'' Asterio Takesy, a senior official on Ponape, said. ''They asked us what we need, what we want. The Americans are always telling us what to do. They say, 'This is what your problem is, and here's how you must solve it.' ''
title: THIS TIME TO MAKE MONEY

text: A Foreign Ministry official in Tokyo, Akihiro Aoki, said Japanese aid was based on the Government's belief that ''these countries have to be politically and economically stable.''
title: THIS TIME TO MAKE MONEY

text: How deep Tokyo's investment will go, however, is not clear. Japanese businessmen say they are hesitant to move in because of lingering economic and social problems that have kept Micronesian development at a low level throughout the postwar period.
title: THIS TIME TO MAKE MONEY

text: Nevertheless, some American officials worry that Japanese investors -and perhaps some from rapidly developing Asian countries like South Korea - are getting ready. One person who expresses concern is Fred M. Zeder, the Reagan Administration's chief representative in negotiations that would dissolve the American trusteeship and give emerging Micronesian states partial home rule and a guarantee of $2.4 billion in United States aid over the next 15 years.
title: THIS TIME TO MAKE MONEY

text: According to Mr. Zeder, a large share of that money, perhaps $1 billion, would be directed at economic development. But American businesses, he complained, may lose the competition for these funds because the United States House of Representatives recently rejected certain tax incentives for them that had been agreed to by Micronesians and the Administration.
title: THIS TIME TO MAKE MONEY

text: ''It's ridiculous,'' Mr. Zeder said. ''We are going to the Japanese, or whoever else wants to go after this region, and we are handing them a billion dollars on a platter.''
title: THIS TIME TO MAKE MONEY

text: GARDENS. By Holly Prado. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $14.95.) Mother Kate is in the attic, painting. Daughter Sheila is in her bedroom, writing.
title: IN SHORT: FICTION

text: Father Alex is conferring with his sibylline old art teacher, while grandmother Audrey is in her apartment rediscovering masturbation. It is, for the family, ''the last summer of a large part of their lives.'' Sheila has just graduated from San Francisco State and is home in Los Angeles. Alex has just decided to take up painting after a 20-year hiatus. Kate is about to take his job teaching art classes, which she has never done. This is the kind of family where dad asks daughter for some of her marijuana and she says, ''Have a good time''; where the decision of ''an odd little boy'' to go to law school is regarded as ''a waste of his spiritual nature''; and where mother and daughter invent an impromptu magic ritual using kitchen herbs. The domestic life of artists or poetasters can be the stuff of comedy or tragedy, but in Holly Prado's first novel it is mainly the stuff of mystical musings on everything from the flowers dying in the backyard to the nature of the city and of life itself. There is dialogue but no conversations; as if everyone were stoned, reactions are weirdly delayed or skewed. Nothing happens, even though there are ostensible events, because the family is subsumed by a myopic view that has the earnest smugness of someone murmuring to a hysteric, ''Go with the flow.''
title: IN SHORT: FICTION

text: A state judge has criticized Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d for not advocating immediate economic penalties against countries that export heroin to the United States.
title: STATE JUDGE FAULTS MEESE'S EFFORTS TO CURB HEROIN

text: The judge - Francis T. Murphy Jr., the presiding justice of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court's First Department - chastised Mr. Meese for saying recently that heroin-producing countries should be denied economic aid only ''as a last resort.''
title: STATE JUDGE FAULTS MEESE'S EFFORTS TO CURB HEROIN

text: Justice Murphy, whose department covers Manhattan and the Bronx, made his remarks Wednesday night in a speech at the Plaza Hotel to the Bronx County Bar Association.
title: STATE JUDGE FAULTS MEESE'S EFFORTS TO CURB HEROIN

text: Mr. Meese, the nation's leading law-enforcement official, has aroused unusual debate in judicial circles during his first eight months in office. In a speech Friday, he argued that many judges were reading the Constitution too broadly and were engaging in ''chameleon jurisprudence, changing color and form in each era.''
title: STATE JUDGE FAULTS MEESE'S EFFORTS TO CURB HEROIN

text: In the last month two United States Supreme Court Justices, William J. Brennan and John Paul Stevens, have publicly faulted Mr. Meese's interpretation of the Constitution.
title: STATE JUDGE FAULTS MEESE'S EFFORTS TO CURB HEROIN

text: The issues pressed by Justice Murphy were more local: the influx of heroin into New York City and the relationship between AIDS and intravenous drug use.
title: STATE JUDGE FAULTS MEESE'S EFFORTS TO CURB HEROIN

text: Experts estimate that there are 200,000 addicts - or 1 in 40 residents -in New York City. Drug use accounts for nearly a third of the local cases of AIDS.
title: STATE JUDGE FAULTS MEESE'S EFFORTS TO CURB HEROIN

text: Justice Murphy, speaking of Mr. Meese, said: ''Does he mean that, when 1 out of 30, or 1 out of 20, or 1 out of 10 residents of this city is an AIDS-infected addict, the United States military and economic aid will be stopped? How many white coffins of AIDS-infected children must be carried over the city's roads and bridges to cemeteries before we reach the Attorney General's point of last resort?''
title: STATE JUDGE FAULTS MEESE'S EFFORTS TO CURB HEROIN

text: Mr. Meese's remarks were made during an appearance in September before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, where he was reporting as the chairman of the National Drug Enforcement Policy Board, which fashions and supervises drug policy for the Reagan Administration.
title: STATE JUDGE FAULTS MEESE'S EFFORTS TO CURB HEROIN

text: Mr. Meese told the committee that the availability and use of cocaine remained widespread, but that marijuana and heroin were declining in popularity.
title: STATE JUDGE FAULTS MEESE'S EFFORTS TO CURB HEROIN

text: The Attorney General spoke of increased Federal law-enforcement and diplomatic efforts directed at drug-producing countries, but added that ''the only way we will ultimately be successful in the war against drugs is to curb the demand for them.''
title: STATE JUDGE FAULTS MEESE'S EFFORTS TO CURB HEROIN

text: Asked under what circumstances he would favor cutting off foreign aid, Mr. Meese said he would support such punitive actions ''as a last resort.''
title: STATE JUDGE FAULTS MEESE'S EFFORTS TO CURB HEROIN

text: Terry Eastland, a Justice Department spokesman, said the Attorney General had never specified the point at which aid to drug-exporting nations should be interrupted. ''We're interested in the whole question of dealing with the supply of drugs any way we can,'' Mr. Eastland said, ''but we're also interested in the demand side.''
title: STATE JUDGE FAULTS MEESE'S EFFORTS TO CURB HEROIN

text: Justice Murphy, in an interview before his speech, said: ''I don't think it's simplistic to say, 'Let's stop it at the source.' The Federal Government has the remedies, but has consistently refused to employ them - whether because of foreign policy or economics, I don't know the answer.''
title: STATE JUDGE FAULTS MEESE'S EFFORTS TO CURB HEROIN

text: Justice Murphy repeated his longstanding complaint that ''we don't own the parks or the streets the way we used to,'' and noted that drug abuse recently claimed a new category of victims.
title: STATE JUDGE FAULTS MEESE'S EFFORTS TO CURB HEROIN

text: ''It breeds the suffering of poor people, who are the addicts,'' he said, ''and it breeds the suffering of the victims of their crimes. But now it's been compounded, because we've added the terror of AIDS on top of that.''
title: STATE JUDGE FAULTS MEESE'S EFFORTS TO CURB HEROIN

text: AIDS, or acquired immune deficiency syndrome, cripples the body's ability to fight disease, leaving it susceptible to such illnesses as cancer and pneumonia.
title: STATE JUDGE FAULTS MEESE'S EFFORTS TO CURB HEROIN

text: IN THE law library at Rahway State Prison here is a three-inch-thick collection of brochures and newspaper and magazine articles about AIDS (acquired immune deficiency syndrome) published since last January.
title: PRISONERS PRESS FOR PROGRAM TO CURB AIDS SPREAD

text: They have been collected by, and belong to, a prisoner who works in the library. The inmate - call him Peter J. - makes them available to anyone who asks for information about AIDS. It is his way of helping to reduce the spread of the disease among inmates and guards.
title: PRISONERS PRESS FOR PROGRAM TO CURB AIDS SPREAD

text: Peter J. and another prisoner, Robert A. (the name also is fictionalized), have been trying to get the state to set up an AIDS education program in the prison system and to have the Department of Corrections guarantee confidentiality between inmates and institutional physicians.
title: PRISONERS PRESS FOR PROGRAM TO CURB AIDS SPREAD

text: The request for confidentiality was embodied in a civil complaint filed by Peter J. in Federal District Court in Newark last June. It names William H. Fauver, the state's Commissioner of Corrections; Alan C. Koenigsfest, health services coordinator for the Corrections Department, and John J. Rafferty, Superintendent of Rahway State Prison.
title: PRISONERS PRESS FOR PROGRAM TO CURB AIDS SPREAD

text: In an interview at the prison, Peter J. and Robert A. said that their concern had been aroused by the recent death, from AIDS, of an inmate acquaintance. Inmates who used or still use drugs intravenously, and who shared syringes with others, are especially worried, Peter J. said. (He also said he realized that the AIDS virus could be transmitted through homosexual activity, and that some inmates had requested information regarding oral-genital contact and its link to the disease.) According to James V. Stabile, public information officer for the Department of Corrections, 74 percent of all inmates in New Jersey prisons have used pills, marijuana, cocaine and drugs typically taken intravenously.
title: PRISONERS PRESS FOR PROGRAM TO CURB AIDS SPREAD

text: Peter J., who said he had spent 10 years behind state prison bars, estimated that about 10 percent of inmates used drugs while incarcerated.
title: PRISONERS PRESS FOR PROGRAM TO CURB AIDS SPREAD

text: How do drugs, syringes and needles get behind the sliding metal doors and past metal detectors and guards?
title: PRISONERS PRESS FOR PROGRAM TO CURB AIDS SPREAD

text: Despite the arrests of visitors trying to carry in contraband, syringes and needles may get through in packages mailed to inmates, said Mr. Stabile, and drugs can be carried in unnoticed in bodily crevices.
title: PRISONERS PRESS FOR PROGRAM TO CURB AIDS SPREAD

text: An outsider who has slipped contraband past the security system must then remove it from his or her body and pass it to the inmate. A prisoner, Peter J. said, then usually insert the syringe or drugs in his rectum.
title: PRISONERS PRESS FOR PROGRAM TO CURB AIDS SPREAD

text: Inmates are strip-searched after all contact visits, Mr. Stabile said, but usually only the exterior of the body is examined.
title: PRISONERS PRESS FOR PROGRAM TO CURB AIDS SPREAD

text: Although ''the scrutiny is intense,'' Peter J. said, ''there's no problem'' for anyone determined to bring in contraband.
title: PRISONERS PRESS FOR PROGRAM TO CURB AIDS SPREAD

text: The ratio of guards to visitors varies among the state's 35 correctional institutions. Five or six guards watch 300 visitors at some of the prisons, which makes it impossible to observe every move each person makes, Mr. Koenigsfest said.
title: PRISONERS PRESS FOR PROGRAM TO CURB AIDS SPREAD

text: Mr. Stabile said that increasing the guard force in visiting areas would not necessarily stop the passage of contraband.
title: PRISONERS PRESS FOR PROGRAM TO CURB AIDS SPREAD

text: The Department of Corrections has recorded 94 cases of AIDS among 13,400 convicts since its first diagnosed case in 1981. The 94 include 66 inmates who have since died, 12 patients at the department's unit in St. Francis Medical Center in Trenton, 15 parolees and one inmate who was granted clemency.
title: PRISONERS PRESS FOR PROGRAM TO CURB AIDS SPREAD

text: The state's Corrections and Health Departments both recorded higher-than-average proportions of deaths from AIDS - 70 percent and 62 percent, respectively - than the national average of 51 percent. (The Health Department reported 893 diagnosed cases and 555 deaths stemming from AIDS as of Oct. 22, the last date for which official data were available. Nationally, the Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta listed 14,519 diagnosed cases of the disease and 7,450 deaths as of Nov. 4.) In January, Peter J. said, he was a patient at St. Francis. A fellow patient, he said - one who had been diagnosed as an AIDS victim - told him that he had shared a syringe with other inmates before he learned he had AIDS. Peter J. said that the AIDS patient had asked him to encourage these men to request blood tests to determine if they were carrying the virus.
title: PRISONERS PRESS FOR PROGRAM TO CURB AIDS SPREAD

text: ''He told me about this one incident,'' Peter J. said. ''There was no water available, and no one really cleaned the syringe that well if they were using it.''
title: PRISONERS PRESS FOR PROGRAM TO CURB AIDS SPREAD

text: About five people shared the syringe to inject themselves with heroin.
title: PRISONERS PRESS FOR PROGRAM TO CURB AIDS SPREAD

text: Most inmates, Peter J. said, question the quality of medical care in prison and do not assume there is any confidentiality between inmates and staff members, including physicians.
title: PRISONERS PRESS FOR PROGRAM TO CURB AIDS SPREAD

text: This distrust is at the core of Peter J.'s demand for a general education program about AIDS, including ways to reduce the risk of contracting the disease and a counseling program for inmates with specific concerns about AIDS. This campaign, he said, would have to be administered by the Department of Health for prisoners to trust it.
title: PRISONERS PRESS FOR PROGRAM TO CURB AIDS SPREAD

text: He also urged the establishment of standards insuring that only medical personnel had access to a patient's medical records. Then, he said, inmates might seek medical help without fear of punishment for having done something prohibited in prison, such as using drugs intravenously.
title: PRISONERS PRESS FOR PROGRAM TO CURB AIDS SPREAD

text: Mr. Koenigsfest said in a telephone interview that in 1981, after its first case of AIDS, the Corrections Department began an AIDS training course for nurses and county-jail medical staff members.
title: PRISONERS PRESS FOR PROGRAM TO CURB AIDS SPREAD

text: Now, he said, the corrections staff has an AIDS team of two, including, to his knowledge, the nation's only full-time epidemiologist employed by a state department of corrections.
title: PRISONERS PRESS FOR PROGRAM TO CURB AIDS SPREAD

text: Mr. Koenigsfest said that the department trained prison staff members and inmates either directly or, when security measures did not allow that, through inmate representatives elected by members of prison housing units.
title: PRISONERS PRESS FOR PROGRAM TO CURB AIDS SPREAD

text: But Peter J. said that he recalled only two AIDS seminars having been held in Rahway State Prison since 1981. And inmate representatives, he added, unintentionally distort what they learn about AIDS when they report back to their housing units.
title: PRISONERS PRESS FOR PROGRAM TO CURB AIDS SPREAD

text: Inmates suspected of having AIDS are examined by a state epidemiologist in Trenton. If a diagnosis confirms AIDS, the prisoner is then sent to St. Francis and remains hospitalized until he dies or is paroled.
title: PRISONERS PRESS FOR PROGRAM TO CURB AIDS SPREAD

text: Asked whether the Corrections Department supplied inmates with information on reducing the risk of contracting AIDS, Mr. Koenigsfest said they were told that the disease could be transmitted through ''unclean needles and homosexuality.'' However, he added: ''You don't want to talk about safe drugs, you want to eradicate drugs. We have a trust. We can't return drug users to society.''
title: PRISONERS PRESS FOR PROGRAM TO CURB AIDS SPREAD

text: Alluding to incidents of sexual assault in prisons (the Corrections Department does not keep figures on sexual assaults), Mr. Koenigsfest said:
title: PRISONERS PRESS FOR PROGRAM TO CURB AIDS SPREAD

text: ''If we were to set up [an advocacy program] for people to use condoms, we would be setting up a victim.''
title: PRISONERS PRESS FOR PROGRAM TO CURB AIDS SPREAD

text: Peter J. agrees with Mr. Koenigsfest that the department should not provide items used in prohibited activities, such as intravenous drug use and homosexual activity.
title: PRISONERS PRESS FOR PROGRAM TO CURB AIDS SPREAD

text: The Department of Corrections administers its own health-care programs independent of the Department of Health, although health officials will intervene if their help is sought.
title: PRISONERS PRESS FOR PROGRAM TO CURB AIDS SPREAD

text: Dr. Jack Rutledge, a deputy commissioner of the Health Department, said that ''the biggest problem with AIDS in the whole state is education, information.''
title: PRISONERS PRESS FOR PROGRAM TO CURB AIDS SPREAD

text: ''Especially with prisoners about to be discharged,'' he said, ''it would be a shame to release them back into society without some information.''
title: PRISONERS PRESS FOR PROGRAM TO CURB AIDS SPREAD

text: ''It's in their interest and society's interest,'' he added.
title: PRISONERS PRESS FOR PROGRAM TO CURB AIDS SPREAD

text: Another Health Department official, Dr. Frances Taylor, said that the Corrections Department had ''not requested our help'' on AIDS, but that a program to counsel inmates about to be discharged was in ''the talking stage.''
title: PRISONERS PRESS FOR PROGRAM TO CURB AIDS SPREAD

text: THREE years ago the director of research and treatment at Regent Hospital in Manhattan, Dr. Arnold M. Washton, developed a curative program for cocaine abusers that he described as the first such specialized private drug-treatment program in New York City. Now he is duplicating that model here in Westchester, where, he says, there is considerable need for it.
title: PROGRAM FOR COCAINE-ABUSE UNDER WAY

text: The program, consisting primarily of outpatient services, is conducted at The Recovery Center, affiliated with and located at Stony Lodge Hospital in Ossining, a private psychiatric hospital recently re-opened under new leadership.
title: PROGRAM FOR COCAINE-ABUSE UNDER WAY

text: Dr. Washton is best known for his work with the National Cocaine Hotline, 800-COCAINE, which he helped to establish with Dr. Mark S. Gold. Dr. Gold is research director at Stony Lodge Hospital under the new team there.
title: PROGRAM FOR COCAINE-ABUSE UNDER WAY

text: Apart from its specific focus on cocaine abuse, The Recovery Center will serve people who want help in stopping any kind of drug abuse. Treatment is now being offered as part of Dr. Washton's outpatient psychiatric practice; Dr. Washton said he hoped the program would obtain full licensing from the state, which would allow it to expand, in the coming months. He added he has already been ''swamped'' with county residents requesting help.
title: PROGRAM FOR COCAINE-ABUSE UNDER WAY

text: ''We've received calls from several Westchester physicians seeking help, businessmen from some of the large corporations, owners of local businesses, and housewives,'' he said. Many calls have also come, he said, from parents of Westchester teenagers.
title: PROGRAM FOR COCAINE-ABUSE UNDER WAY

text: ''There appears to be increased 'polydrug' use among local teen-agers,'' he said, ''particularly from middle-class families. They often get sent to us because of marijuana use, but invariably these days that goes hand-in-hand with the use of hallucinogens, pills, cocaine and alcohol. Cocaine use, in particular, is on the rise.''
title: PROGRAM FOR COCAINE-ABUSE UNDER WAY

text: Teen-agers at The Recovery Center will be seen separately from adult patients, according to Ellen Morehouse, recently named director of outpatient adolescent services there. She said a broad range of mental health services would be offered drug-abusing teens, and agreed with Dr. Washton's observations about cocaine use among this age group.
title: PROGRAM FOR COCAINE-ABUSE UNDER WAY

text: ''There is a definite increase in cocaine use among county teen-agers,'' Mrs. Morehouse said, referring to statistics available through Student Assistance Services Inc. That is a school-based drug abuse prevention and counseling service begun by Mrs. Morehouse through the county's Department of Community Mental Health. She now heads Student Assistance Services privately.
title: PROGRAM FOR COCAINE-ABUSE UNDER WAY

text: ''Last year one-third of the students seen in the Student Assistance programs reported having tried cocaine,'' she said. ''That was considerably more than we'd seen in other years.'' Three teen-agers have sought this treatment already this year, she continued, for cocaine dependence resulting from the use of a new form of the drug called ''crack,'' or rock-like pieces of prepared ''freebase'' (concentrated) cocaine.
title: PROGRAM FOR COCAINE-ABUSE UNDER WAY

text: One of the advantages of The Recovery Center, Mrs. Morehouse said, will be the close monitoring of drug use among participants.
title: PROGRAM FOR COCAINE-ABUSE UNDER WAY

text: ''Screening urine samples for current use takes the guesswork out of how a teen-ager is doing,'' she said. ''I find the kids themselves don't even mind, because it helps them regain control. They know they simply can't use drugs anymore and get help, too.''
title: PROGRAM FOR COCAINE-ABUSE UNDER WAY

text: The biggest problem faced in treating drug abusers at any age, according to Dr. Washton, is the frequency of relapses. He believes the success of his approach owes in large part to what he has coined ''relapse prevention.''
title: PROGRAM FOR COCAINE-ABUSE UNDER WAY

text: ''The drug-abuse field in general has focused too much on getting the addict off drugs and too little on keeping him off,'' he said. ''It's wholly unrealistic to think that someone will never use drugs again as the result of a single detoxification or hospitalization.'' Few patients, in fact, will be hospitalized under his treatment approach, he said.
title: PROGRAM FOR COCAINE-ABUSE UNDER WAY

text: ''The overwhelming majority of people with drug-abuse problems do not need hospitalization,'' he said, ''though there are a few that do.''
title: PROGRAM FOR COCAINE-ABUSE UNDER WAY

text: Among those that could be referred for hospitalization, he said, are people addicted to drugs that require gradual weaning, those whose drug use is ''out of control'' or who are suicidal. Stopping cocaine use does not usually require hospitalization, he said.
title: PROGRAM FOR COCAINE-ABUSE UNDER WAY

text: ''That's not to say there's no withdrawal syndrome from cocaine,'' he added. ''But unlike heroin or alcohol or sleeping pills, cocaine can be stopped abruptly without medical risk or dramatic withdrawal symptoms. The best way to get off cocaine is to just stop using it - and be in treatment.''
title: PROGRAM FOR COCAINE-ABUSE UNDER WAY

text: Treatment at The Recovery Center involves teaching a patient how to remain drug-free. This, according to Dr. Washton, is accomplished by means of a ''very structured'' treatment plan requiring frequent individual and group counseling, drug screening tests at least three times weekly, and an agreement by the patient to remain drug-free.
title: PROGRAM FOR COCAINE-ABUSE UNDER WAY

text: ''When someone is out of control of their addictive behavior, one of the things they need most is limit-setting and structure,'' he said.
title: PROGRAM FOR COCAINE-ABUSE UNDER WAY

text: In addition to the patient's treatment, Dr. Washton believes family members must also be involved in the process through counseling and educational sessions.
title: PROGRAM FOR COCAINE-ABUSE UNDER WAY

text: ''Well-intentioned family members can unwittingly 'enable' an abuser to continue drug use,'' said Dr. Washton. ''They do this by covering up, giving the abuser money or sparing the abuser the negative consequences of his or her own drug use. That's why it's important for them to be educated.''
title: PROGRAM FOR COCAINE-ABUSE UNDER WAY

text: But it is the ''relapse prevention and recovery groups'' - the name Dr. Washton gives his group counseling sessions - that are most vital, he says, in helping patients stay drug-free. Through these groups, patients gain ''tools'' to avoid relapse. These include ways to avoid ''high-risk'' situation, such as ones where drugs are available; to cope with stress without resorting to drugs, and to keep a ''slip'' (an isolated incident of drug use) from becoming a complete relapse.
title: PROGRAM FOR COCAINE-ABUSE UNDER WAY

text: The drug treatment field, according to Dr. Washton, is split between those who view drug abuse as a symptom solely of a psychiatric disorder requiring psychotherapy, and those who see it as a behavioral ''disease'' responding only to community self-help groups such as found in the ''12-step'' programs, modeled after Alcoholics Anonymous. He said he felt there was truth in both views, and that he had built his model upon a ''marriage'' of both approaches.
title: PROGRAM FOR COCAINE-ABUSE UNDER WAY

text: ''I agree with those of the 'disease model' that unless you get the addictive behavior under control, there will be no treatment success anyway. That's why we require patients to stop all drug use and why we take frequent urine samples to monitor this.
title: PROGRAM FOR COCAINE-ABUSE UNDER WAY

text: ''Yet I also believe that sometimes - but not always - addiction is accompanied by psychological problems that must also be treated or that person will relapse. Our approach at The Recovery Center will be to treat both the addictive behavior and any psychological problems.''
title: PROGRAM FOR COCAINE-ABUSE UNDER WAY

text: Patients at The Recovery Center will be encouraged to participate in self-help ''12-step'' programs in conjunction with his work with them, he said. To this end, the first Cocaine Anonymous chapter in the county was begun recently at Stony Lodge, meeting Mondays 7:30 to 9:00 P.M. Cocaine Anonymous is a self-help group for cocaine users modeled after the well-known Alcoholics Anonymous group. Those attending meetings share only their first names.
title: PROGRAM FOR COCAINE-ABUSE UNDER WAY

text: ''Anybody is invited to those meetings,'' Dr. Washton said. ''The only prerequisite is a desire to stop cocaine or any other drug use.''
title: PROGRAM FOR COCAINE-ABUSE UNDER WAY

text: Dr. Richard Altesman is medical director of Stony Lodge Hospital. He pointed out that The Recovery Center was only one of a number of new services being offered in conjunction with the 61-bed hospital.
title: PROGRAM FOR COCAINE-ABUSE UNDER WAY

text: ''We are still primarily a psychiatric hospital,'' he said, ''though we are very glad to offer the expertise in drug treatment that we do.''
title: PROGRAM FOR COCAINE-ABUSE UNDER WAY

text: Psychiatric services there include two adolescent inpatient units, a neuropsychiatric evaluation unit where extensive diagnostic work is done, and an adult treatment unit. A program for people with eating disorders is also being developed and is expected to be open by late November. Admissions to the psychiatric units of the hospital are made 24 hours a day, Dr. Altesman said.
title: PROGRAM FOR COCAINE-ABUSE UNDER WAY

text: Additional information about The Recovery Center or other hospital services can be obtained by calling 941-6800.
title: PROGRAM FOR COCAINE-ABUSE UNDER WAY

text: Militant landowners of Kwajalein atoll in the central Pacific have occupied an island in the atoll that has played a central role in the Reagan Administration's space-defense program. They are protesting the terms offered by the United States for the continued use of their property as a billon-dollar missile testing range.
title: PACIFIC ISLANDERS OCCUPY 'STAR WARS' TEST SITE

text: Meck Island, to which a group of the landowners returned this week in a show of defiance to the military authorities in charge of Kwajalein, was the launch site for a missile that last year intercepted an incoming missile fired from Vandenberg Air Force Base in California, about 4,700 miles away.
title: PACIFIC ISLANDERS OCCUPY 'STAR WARS' TEST SITE

text: The feat, the first successful interception of an intercontinental ballistic missile in four tries from Meck, was hailed as a breakthrough in the Administration's Strategic Defense Initiative, popularly known as ''Star Wars.''
title: PACIFIC ISLANDERS OCCUPY 'STAR WARS' TEST SITE

text: According to Ataji Balos, the leader of the main landowners' organization, who disclosed the occupation of Meck, the islanders had moved onto two less important islands in the atoll several weeks ago after the expiration last Sept. 30 of the Defense Department's lease on their holdings.
title: PACIFIC ISLANDERS OCCUPY 'STAR WARS' TEST SITE

text: The corporation has refused to accept a payment of about $487,000 in rent due for October under the expired agreement, according to a Honolulu representative. Consequently, he said, a few dozen landowners returned to their farms on Meck and the other islands for food. They will remain unless forcibly evicted, he said.
title: PACIFIC ISLANDERS OCCUPY 'STAR WARS' TEST SITE

text: After Washington failed to respond to demands for a higher rental, a majority of the 5,600 landowners declared through their organization, the Kwajalein Atoll Corporation, that they would refuse to recognize a pending agreement between the United States and the Marshall Islands, of which Kwajalein is a part, making the Central Pacific archipelago independent except for continued American control of military affairs.
title: PACIFIC ISLANDERS OCCUPY 'STAR WARS' TEST SITE

text: The agreement, called the Compact of Free Association, was endorsed by the United States Senate Thursday. Similar legislation had been approved by the House of Representatives. The measures also apply to a group of islands west of the Marshalls, known as the Federated States of Micronesia, and may be extended later to include still another group, the Palau Islands in the western Pacific. All the groups, taken from Japan by United States forces in World War II, have been administered by Washington as a United Nations trusteeship since 1947. A fourth chain, the Northern Mariana Islands, have elected to become a United States commonwealth, like Puerto Rico.
title: PACIFIC ISLANDERS OCCUPY 'STAR WARS' TEST SITE

text: Senator Balos, the president of the Kwajalein Atoll Corporation and a member of the Marshall Islands legislature, said in Hawaii that the islanders occupying Meck had found that the electronic and other installations there had apparently been ''abandoned.'' But an Army spokesman in Honolulu said the center had merely been ''put in mothballs'' and ''would be used again in the near future.''
title: PACIFIC ISLANDERS OCCUPY 'STAR WARS' TEST SITE

text: Offer of $9 Million a Year
title: PACIFIC ISLANDERS OCCUPY 'STAR WARS' TEST SITE

text: A Honolulu attorney for the landowners, George M. Allen, said the group would stand by an earlier pledge to cooperate with the operation of the Kwajalein missile range while negotiations for a new lease are going on. Senator Balos said he had been tood that military security personnel on the island had not tried to interfere with the occupation.
title: PACIFIC ISLANDERS OCCUPY 'STAR WARS' TEST SITE

text: The compact approved by Congress, but still to be endorsed by President Reagan and accepted by the United Nations, gives the United States the right to Kwajalein for 15 years, with an option to extend the arrangement for 15 more years, at a rental of about $9 million a year, or $1 million more than the expired 1982 lease provides, plus additional development funds.
title: PACIFIC ISLANDERS OCCUPY 'STAR WARS' TEST SITE

text: The Kwajalein Atoll Corporation has asked for a payment of $6 million, to be spread over six months, in return for signing a new lease and dropping their opposition to the compact of free association.
title: PACIFIC ISLANDERS OCCUPY 'STAR WARS' TEST SITE

text: A Coast Guard cutter fired warning shots at a Colombian ship loaded with 28 tons of marijuana, boarded her and arrested the crew, then sank the vessel in international waters, officials said today. The cutter, the Gallatin, intercepted the 60-foot vessel Sunday 150 miles northwest of Colombia, Coast Guard officials said. They said the Coast Guard had approval to board the vessel from the Colombian Government.
title: Ship Carrying Drugs Is Sunk

text: Despite gains by other sports, and some problems of its own, major league baseball retains its status as America's pastime. Attendance passed 46.8 million last season and there is talk of expanding beyond the current 26 teams.
title: SHOULD BASEBALL HAVE MANDATORY DRUG TESTING?

text: But Peter Ueberroth, the baseball commissioner, recently warned that the sport has a ''cloud called drugs'' hanging over it. The failure to address the issue, he said, could jeopardize the game's support among advertisers and paying customers. Moreover, he predicted that, if left unchecked, drug use could result in a scandal where drug dealers blackmail players into compromising their efforts.
title: SHOULD BASEBALL HAVE MANDATORY DRUG TESTING?

text: Although there is little agreement about how many players use illegal drugs, a celebrated cocaine-trafficking trial in Pittsburgh last September showed that cocaine use was widespread a few years ago. Seven active and former players, testifying with immunity from prosecution, told how they and their teammates purchased, used, and, sometimes, sold cocaine in the late 1970's and early 80's. The commissioner has said he will determine over the winter whether to punish the players, who include Keith Hernandez of the Mets and Dale Berra of the Yankees.
title: SHOULD BASEBALL HAVE MANDATORY DRUG TESTING?

text: Meanwhile, Ueberroth had imposed mandatory drug testing on all baseball employees directly under his jurisdiction - office workers, owners and minor league players. His goal is to get major league players, who have union protection, to submit to the tests, which would seek users of cocaine, marijuana, morphine and heroin.
title: SHOULD BASEBALL HAVE MANDATORY DRUG TESTING?

text: The commissoner has twice asked the players to agree, first through their union and then through letters to individual players. They have declined, saying they want more information on the extent of drug use and more details from the commissioner. They have not rejected outright mandatory testing.
title: SHOULD BASEBALL HAVE MANDATORY DRUG TESTING?

text: Club owners, in response, have canceled the agreement with the union that provided for voluntary testing when clubs suspected a player of drug use. The union then filed a grievance with the National Labor Relations Board, charging the owners with an unfair labor practice. The grievance is pending.
title: SHOULD BASEBALL HAVE MANDATORY DRUG TESTING?

text: Until June 1984, the labor agreement between club owners and players was essentially silent on the subject of drug use. The cases of players found to be using illegal drugs were handled by Commissioner Bowie Kuhn after law enforcement matters had been settled.
title: SHOULD BASEBALL HAVE MANDATORY DRUG TESTING?

text: Kuhn, who served as commissioner from 1969 to October 1984, suspended eight players for drug use; five of those rulings were modified or overturned through arbitration.
title: SHOULD BASEBALL HAVE MANDATORY DRUG TESTING?

text: Both sides agreed that a formal agreement should be in place for handling drug cases, and negotiations produced one that stressed rehabilitation over punishment. If a club suspected a player was using drugs, it could call him in for talks and, with his permission, test him.
title: SHOULD BASEBALL HAVE MANDATORY DRUG TESTING?

text: If the player and the club disagreed, the case was to be submitted to a panel of three doctors appointed by the owners and the union. The panel had the right to recommend a course of diagnosis and, if necessary, treatment. If the player resisted, he was no longer protected by the agreement and the club could punish him. The player, in turn, could appeal through arbitration. .
title: SHOULD BASEBALL HAVE MANDATORY DRUG TESTING?

text: Ueberroth, who took office in October 1984, said he did not believe the drug agreement was working. Last May, as news began to spread of player testimony before the grand jury in Pittsburgh, he imposed mandatory testing on those without union protection and got the union representing umpires to go along.
title: SHOULD BASEBALL HAVE MANDATORY DRUG TESTING?

text: The tests, Ueberroth said, would be similar to those he used at the Summer Olympics in Los Angeles, where he was president of the Olympic Organizing Committee. Random urine samples would be collected three times a year and analyzed in laboratories, with the results reported to the players and their clubs. Positive tests would mean confirmation tests, followed by counseling and, if necessary, treatment. Punishment would be allowed if the player persisted in using drugs. Confidentiality was promised.
title: SHOULD BASEBALL HAVE MANDATORY DRUG TESTING?

text: In September, frustrated in his efforts to get the players' union to agree, Ueberroth wrote to each of the 650 major league players.
title: SHOULD BASEBALL HAVE MANDATORY DRUG TESTING?

text: ''Drugs are attacking the underbelly of our society,'' he wrote. ''Because of baseball's visibility, especially to youngsters, we in the game have a responsibility to provide leadership and a good example for others.''
title: SHOULD BASEBALL HAVE MANDATORY DRUG TESTING?

text: He added that, largely because of the Pittsburgh case, players were already guilty by association and that wholesale testing was the only way baseball could prove itself drug-free.
title: SHOULD BASEBALL HAVE MANDATORY DRUG TESTING?

text: The union, which has expressed annoyance at what it considers more a public relations gimmick by Ueberroth, has raised several questions about testing and Constitutional rights of privacy.
title: SHOULD BASEBALL HAVE MANDATORY DRUG TESTING?

text: ''To act as though all major league players are under suspicion because several have had a drug problem is an inappropriate way to do business,'' said Donald Fehr, the acting executive director of the union. ''The clubs are interested in testing Joe because Sam had a problem, or rather, in testing 1,000 Joes because three Sams had problems.''
title: SHOULD BASEBALL HAVE MANDATORY DRUG TESTING?

text: Fehr said players were willing to approve a survey to determine the extent of drug use, as provided for in the 1984 agreement, but that the commissioner's office had shown no interest. Without data showing the extent, he said, the union remained unconvinced that wholesale testing was necessary. If scientific data showed widespread use, he said, the union would have to re-evaulate its position.
title: SHOULD BASEBALL HAVE MANDATORY DRUG TESTING?

text: Fehr also said that the union wanted more information on who would conduct the tests, how confidentiality would be assured, what assurances there were of reliability, whether the tests were medically appropriate and whether testing really was a deterrent to drug use.
title: SHOULD BASEBALL HAVE MANDATORY DRUG TESTING?

text: ''They have been unwilling to provide us with any information, even the name of the tests they want to do,'' Fehr said of Ueberroth and his staff. ''The commissioner has to be willing to come to grips with the facts and the issues. You can't just say I want testing because I want testing.''
title: SHOULD BASEBALL HAVE MANDATORY DRUG TESTING?

text: The technology for highly accurate drug testing exists, according to Richard L. Hawks, chief of the Research Technology Branch of the National Institute on Drug Abuse. But he said strict guidelines must be followed.
title: SHOULD BASEBALL HAVE MANDATORY DRUG TESTING?

text: Like the military, more and more private companies are resorting to testing. One study, Hawks said, showed that about 25 percent of the nation's largest companies used drug testing as a condition of employment, with fewer using it among existing employees.
title: SHOULD BASEBALL HAVE MANDATORY DRUG TESTING?

text: Such a trend means that, if he wants to muster the information, the commissioner could probably answer many of the union's questions about testing. But less certain is whether he can persuade the players to set aside their basic doubts about the necessity of testing them.
title: SHOULD BASEBALL HAVE MANDATORY DRUG TESTING?

text: For now, neither side seems ready to make major concessions. Who blinks first may be determined by whether coming weeks and months produce any more Pittsburghs.
title: SHOULD BASEBALL HAVE MANDATORY DRUG TESTING?

text: CUTTING EDGES. Making Sense of the Eighties. By Charles Krauthammer. 221 pages. Random House. $17.95. IT is sad to live in present-day America, now that harvests have declined so precipitously, food rationing has been introduced and ''steak has become a memory.'' It must be even sadder to live in ''starvation-wracked Japan.'' Or rather it would be sad, if these particular prophecies of doom had been fulfilled. They were made by Paul Ehrlich in his 1968 book ''The Population Bomb''; they are cited by Charles Krauthammer in ''Cutting Edges'' in a passage that exemplifies one of Mr. Krauthammer's great strengths as a controversialist, his ability to seize on the giveaway quotation or the exquisitely revealing chink in his opponent's armor.
title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES

text: This is only one of the skills that have made him someone to look out for ever since he began publishing essays and columns in the late 1970's -initially in The New Republic (which is where most of the pieces reprinted in ''Cutting Edges'' first appeared), but latterly also in Time magazine and The Washington Post.
title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES

text: He is equally adept, for instance, at summoning up a happy (and unhackneyed) quotation to reinforce his own position, as when he calls in aid the 19th-century Irish radical who denounced negative revolutionaries -revolutionaries unwilling to describe the society they proposed to construct - as ''mere speculators in anarchy.'' He is a master of the crisp and compact formulation. And he knows how to get the most out of a comic analogy. Phil Donahue's show, with its procession of deviants and odd men out, reminds him of P. T. Barnum -except that ''in the old days, one merely gawked at these unfortunates. Donahue's genius is to get them to talk.''
title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES

text: Satisfying though his gifts are, he wouldn't be the serious commentator he is if he didn't put them at the service of a fairly consistent view of the world. Politically, he tells us, he belongs to the Democratic tradition ''whose pedigree stretches from Harry Truman through Henry Jackson'' - and if nowadays that makes him something of a displaced person, in his political essays he remains faithful to a philosophy that combines tough foreign policies and tender domestic ones.
title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES

text: A spokesman for the Militant Middle, he delivers a jab at Patrick Buchanan here and takes a smack at Jesse Jackson there. His internationalism sets him against neo-isolationists whether they are on the left, among Democrats who want to achieve internationalist ends without willing the means, or on the go-it-alone right. But though he is always worth listening to, he is at his best, I think, when he writes not so much about ''hard'' politics as about political culture - attitudes, fashions, assumptions - and beyond that about the contemporary social climate in general.
title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES

text: In the introduction to ''Cutting Edges'' he offers an interesting brief account of how he came to arrive at his own standpoint. As a graduate student, struggling with a thesis on the tension between John Stuart Mill's politics and his esthetics, he became mesmerized by a set of notebooks belonging to a friend who was studying medicine. They seemed to offer a certainty that was ''not found in the universe of politics,'' something that attracted him so much that he switched to medicine himself. (Eventually he became a psychiatrist.) But though he found many satisfactions in medicine, one thing he did not find was certainty. On the contrary, his experience as a doctor taught him that in this world there is no getting away from ambiguity.
title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES

text: Ambiguity, as he says, is one of the recurrent themes of his essays. Another, related one is the effort to see things as they really are, in all their untidiness. He argues repeatedly against oversimplification, the blurring of distinctions (between courage and survival, for instance), the glib or evasive assumption of ''moral equivalence'' where real differences exist - it can be seen at its simplest in Dr. Seuss's parable ''The Butter Battle Book,'' in which the world is endangered by a confrontation between the Yooks who like their bread butter-side up and the Zooks who like their bread butter-side down.
title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES

text: He is equally on his guard against the misuse of language. His objection to critics who at the time of Grenada kept complaining that America had forfeited ''the moral high ground'' is not merely that they were talking in cliches but that the cliche in question was an insidious one. A military metaphor, it carried yet one more suggestion of false equivalence (win a battle, lose a battle).
title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES

text: Even an essay on travel (written in 1984) quickly turns into a dissection of moral confusion. There is the psychic holiday, abetted by drugs. (''Marijuana lets you circumnavigate the land of schizophrenia; LSD parachutes you in for the day.'') Then there is the political holiday, for those who crave ''a whiff of social chaos.'' The then-current example cited is that of the carpenter from South Shields, England, evacuated from Tripoli with the PLO and announcing that he planned to stay with them for a year or two more before returning home. By chance this same carpenter was one of the group recently responsible for killing a party of Israeli holiday-makers in their yacht off Cyprus and starting the latest cycle of Middle East violence. Some holidays are more eventful than others.
title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES

text: Several essays - they are among the best in the book - gain in authority from Mr. Krauthammer's experience as a doctor (though he doesn't refer to it directly). There is a fine discussion of the true issue at stake in the Baby Fae heart-transplant case (the clash between ''the therapeutic imperative'' and ''the experimental imperative''), and an essay on homelessness that delicately and humanely makes the point that the plight of the homeless is to a large extent the plight of people who have been released from hospitals in the name of a liberty they are unable to enjoy.
title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES

text: For all his vigilance, even Mr. Krauthammer occasionally succumbs to the columnist's occupational disease and simplifies things for the sake of a debating point. But in general the standard of these pieces is exceptionally high; they were well worth collecting, and they remain as stimulating as they were when they first appeared.
title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES

text: Donna Moore stepped from the elevator at the Carter, her cheery hello ringing through the fifth-floor corridor, and one after another doors popped open, spilling toddlers who clambered at her knees and sad-eyed women who hung on her every word.
title: IN GLOOM OF WELFARE HOTELS, VOICE OF HOPE IS HEARD

text: Miss Moore patted the children, asked whether they were behaving and inquired after their progress in school. The mothers, meanwhile, peppered her with questions about how to find an apartment, how to fend off eviction, how to get their children immunized, how to find a methadone clinic, how to get through the days cooped up in a single room overlooking the streets off Times Square.
title: IN GLOOM OF WELFARE HOTELS, VOICE OF HOPE IS HEARD

text: The Carter, a hotel at 250 West 43d Street that is 1 of 55 housing 3,959 welfare families, is regularly visited by social workers, nurses and representatives of charitable organizations who try to guide the residents through the bureaucracy that serves New York City's growing homeless population.
title: IN GLOOM OF WELFARE HOTELS, VOICE OF HOPE IS HEARD

text: Few of them, however, can match Miss Moore as a Pied Piper of the hotel hallways, hallways that she knows intimately because of the five months she lived there, in room 1225, with her three sons.
title: IN GLOOM OF WELFARE HOTELS, VOICE OF HOPE IS HEARD

text: A Way Out of Welfare
title: IN GLOOM OF WELFARE HOTELS, VOICE OF HOPE IS HEARD

text: ''It's like going into a black hole when you're homeless,'' said Miss Moore, 35 years old, who wound up in the welfare system after giving up a banking job and a Brooklyn apartment to spend several months in North Carolina with her ailing mother. ''Unless you're scatching and clawing for information, you don't know nothing.''
title: IN GLOOM OF WELFARE HOTELS, VOICE OF HOPE IS HEARD

text: Miss Moore scratched and clawed, and applied her intelligence, pluck and enthusiasm to reordering life for herself and for her sons, Neil, now 16, Tony, 15, and Greg, 10. While some families languish for years in the hotels, Miss Moore found an apartment within a few months, the lower level of a two-family house in Corona, Queens, that had been rehabilitated for the homeless by the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development.
title: IN GLOOM OF WELFARE HOTELS, VOICE OF HOPE IS HEARD

text: Then, Miss Moore built a friendship with social workers from the Children's Aid Society into doing volunteer work and eventually a full-time job processing Medicaid claims, making hotel visits and spending three days a week at a new clinic for the homeless on West 46th Street.
title: IN GLOOM OF WELFARE HOTELS, VOICE OF HOPE IS HEARD

text: Meanwhile, she wrote a survival manual for women in the hotels, ''A Message of Hope For The Homeless,'' and was a speaker at the society's recent annual meeting. She is also a night student in the School of Social Work at Adelphi University, is sprucing up her six-room apartment with found objects and hand-me-downs, and placating her new husband, who finds himself doing more than his share of cooking and cleaning.
title: IN GLOOM OF WELFARE HOTELS, VOICE OF HOPE IS HEARD

text: ''Sometimes I don't know if I'm coming or going,'' Miss Moore said one recent afternoon as she scurried from appointment to appointment, black briefcase in one hand, soda bottle in the other. ''You see how my day goes. I live on Mountain Dew. If I had a whiny-type family, this wouldn't work.''
title: IN GLOOM OF WELFARE HOTELS, VOICE OF HOPE IS HEARD

text: There were moments, Miss Moore said, when the struggles of financial independence seemed daunting next to the ease of welfare. While she was in the hotel, her monthly welfare allowances totaled $2,551, including the $1,752 a month from the city, state and Federal governments for her shabby room. In her apartment - where her rent, food and other subsidies continued until she found work - her government support amounted to $740 a month. Now, earning $750 a month after taxes, Miss Moore is entirely self-supporting.
title: IN GLOOM OF WELFARE HOTELS, VOICE OF HOPE IS HEARD

text: ''When you're used to Medicaid and food stamps and you've got none of that, it's scary,'' she said. ''In actual, real money I was better off before, but now I have my mind clear. I don't have to worry that the computers are down, or somebody's going to close my case in error. I always looked at welfare as being like parents. They helped me when I couldn't help myself, but now I can.''
title: IN GLOOM OF WELFARE HOTELS, VOICE OF HOPE IS HEARD

text: ''Some people never ate so good until they were in that situation,'' she added, estimating that only 50 percent of the women in welfare hotels make a wholehearted effort to leave. ''It could be 75 percent, because some of them started out trying and gave up, thinking there was no hope.''
title: IN GLOOM OF WELFARE HOTELS, VOICE OF HOPE IS HEARD

text: Robert Jorgen, the deputy commissioner for crisis intervention services at the Human Resources Administration, applauded Miss Moore's efforts. He said that because of heavy caseloads, his agency, which supervises the welfare hotels and shelters, has not been as effective as he would like in educating the homeless.
title: IN GLOOM OF WELFARE HOTELS, VOICE OF HOPE IS HEARD

text: ''It's the responsibility of the family to seek and find its own housing,'' Mr. Jorgen said. ''But it might be an excellent idea to work up a housing pamphlet to encourage people.''
title: IN GLOOM OF WELFARE HOTELS, VOICE OF HOPE IS HEARD

text: Miss Moore's hallway preaching and her pamphlet, published by the Children's Aid Society, are a combination of inspirational exhortation and practical advice.
title: IN GLOOM OF WELFARE HOTELS, VOICE OF HOPE IS HEARD

text: She reminds the hotel mothers that the welfare system is not meant to be a permanent solution to their problems and that only the most rigorous discipline will keep them and their children out of the bogs of self-pity, laziness or drug addiction. Then she offers specific tips about the private and public sources of apartments and how to impress the agencies that control their allocation.
title: IN GLOOM OF WELFARE HOTELS, VOICE OF HOPE IS HEARD

text: ''I got doors slammed in my face, landlords saying, 'We don't want welfare people,' '' Miss Moore told the women at the Carter one recent afternoon. ''You have to dress in a way like you're a working person who just needs time to get back on the road. If you keep pounding, somewhere down the line they'll see you are the person you say you are.''
title: IN GLOOM OF WELFARE HOTELS, VOICE OF HOPE IS HEARD

text: Among those listening were a half-dozen glassy-eyed women, their rooms redolent with marijuana smoke and their youngsters running unsupervised through the corridors. One told Miss Moore that she had voluntarily given up her children to foster care. Another said that ''if we had participated harder, we'd be out of here.'' A third was slumped on the floor in a soiled nightgown.
title: IN GLOOM OF WELFARE HOTELS, VOICE OF HOPE IS HEARD

text: ''They came in here with minds like I got, but they're weaker than me,'' Miss Moore said later. ''It's hard for me to tell them they're wrong, but sometimes I get angry.''
title: IN GLOOM OF WELFARE HOTELS, VOICE OF HOPE IS HEARD

text: Over and over, to these women and others, Miss Moore described her discovery that applications for the city's rehabilitated housing were processed in Brooklyn, and her decision to trek from the Carter to Bergen Street each morning to wait outside the door.
title: IN GLOOM OF WELFARE HOTELS, VOICE OF HOPE IS HEARD

text: ''I was willing to take you all along,'' Miss Moore said, ''but anybody who wasn't ready, I went without them, because time waits for no one. You have to put yourself in a position to be picked. I really bothered those people. Maybe by getting rid of me they could take an extra coffee break.''
title: IN GLOOM OF WELFARE HOTELS, VOICE OF HOPE IS HEARD

text: ''It's really beautiful how she tries to help everyone,'' said Deborah Reese, a pregnant mother of five. ''Once she got out, she could have kept stepping.'' With newcomers to the hotel, Miss Moore must establish her credentials. ''When I meet a family I've never seen, they look at me as a worker, as somebody who never lost an apartment,'' she said. ''I let them talk, but when they say 'You can't do this' or 'You can't do that' I say 'Yes, you can' and then I tell them how I know.''
title: IN GLOOM OF WELFARE HOTELS, VOICE OF HOPE IS HEARD

text: Miss Moore traces her determination to her childhood in North Carolina, where her parents were sharecroppers and reared 14 children. ''I was taught that if you don't know something, you ask,'' Miss Moore said. ''If you don't have a table, you sit on the floor. If you're hungry, you beg. You don't let pride get in the way, because you can't live off pride.''
title: IN GLOOM OF WELFARE HOTELS, VOICE OF HOPE IS HEARD

text: By way of illustration, she tells a story about a Children's Aid Society outing to Yankee Stadium in 1984 when she barged into the public-relations office to declare herself a ''homeless mother'' and demand caps for the children. And another about scavenging in the streets for abandoned furnishings for the apartment and finding a 19-inch color television that she jiggled into working order.
title: IN GLOOM OF WELFARE HOTELS, VOICE OF HOPE IS HEARD

text: ''I was taught survival,'' Miss Moore said, ''and that's how we survived.''
title: IN GLOOM OF WELFARE HOTELS, VOICE OF HOPE IS HEARD

text: Those days are now a memory for Miss Moore, a lesson for her children, who chide her for watching television while she does her homework in a tiny living room that is decorated with pictures she swiped from the walls of the Carter.
title: IN GLOOM OF WELFARE HOTELS, VOICE OF HOPE IS HEARD

text: ''Coming from living around 42d Street, this is like a dream,'' she said. ''At night, there's nobody out. I can hear a dime drop on the sidewalk from inside the house. The day I brought the boys out here for the first time, the little one kept asking, 'Did we get rich, ma?' Walking home after work, I couldn't be more proud than the man who went to the moon.''
title: IN GLOOM OF WELFARE HOTELS, VOICE OF HOPE IS HEARD

text: The stakes in the Mexican Government's war against illegal drugs destined for the United States were raised substantially last weekend with the killing of 17 police officers and five other members of an anti-drug group who were on a night mission in a remote region of the Gulf Coast state of Veracruz. They were apparently killed by a large band of drug traffickers armed with high-powered automatic weapons after the police discovered a cache of marijuana.
title: THE MEXICAN DRUG WAR GETS RED HOT

text: ''This is the answer of the drug traffickers to the permanent campaign against drug trafficking,'' said Francisco Fonseca Nortario, official spokesman for Mexico's Federal Attorney General, who oversees the Government's campaign against illegal drug traffic. ''The traffickers were making a statement. They were saying, 'This is what we are going to do if you come in against us.' ''
title: THE MEXICAN DRUG WAR GETS RED HOT

text: United States diplomatic sources here echoed that assessment. ''This could mean the rules of the game are changing here,'' one diplomat said. ''If the drug traffickers raised the ante by killing that many police, they have to expect retaliation. It puts an impetus on the Mexican Government for revenge.''
title: THE MEXICAN DRUG WAR GETS RED HOT

text: Last fall, Mexican officials raided a large operation in the northern state of Chihuahua, near the United States border, and confiscated 10 tons of marijuana, one of the largest seizures they had ever made. They found a highly mechanized farm that provided clear evidence of the organizational abilities and resources available to Mexican drug traffickers.
title: THE MEXICAN DRUG WAR GETS RED HOT

text: Then in February, an agent of the United States Drug Enforcement Agency and his Mexican pilot were kidnapped in Guadalajara. Their bodies were found in March, showing signs of torture. The Reagan Administration reacted angrily, temporarily closing border crossing points with Mexico and placing heavy pressure on President Miguel de la Madrid to get tough.
title: THE MEXICAN DRUG WAR GETS RED HOT

text: Rafael Caro Quintero, described as a Guadalajara drug chief, is now in jail in Mexico City, accused of the abduction and murder of the drug agent and pilot and awaiting trial.
title: THE MEXICAN DRUG WAR GETS RED HOT

text: Subsequent investigation by Mexican officials also uncovered evidence of considerable corruption among the police agencies involved in combating drug traffic. Through the spring and summer, there were wholesale dismissals and transfers of federal police officers and a reorganization of the campaign against drug trafficking.
title: THE MEXICAN DRUG WAR GETS RED HOT

text: United States officials in both Washington and Mexico City have said they are pleased with the effort the Mexican Government is making both in increasing its overall effort and in cracking down on corruption. Relations between the two countries on the drug question, the officials say, are greatly improved.
title: THE MEXICAN DRUG WAR GETS RED HOT

text: ''There is no question about the commitment at the highest levels of the Government,'' an American official said. ''I think the Mexicans have a very good team in place at the very top in their anti-drug campaign. They work well together. They are committed. They are accessable to us.'' But what happened in the remote area of southern Veracruz state, a rugged and fertile region ideally suited for marijuana cultivation, has sent shock waves of fear through Mexican drug agents and revealed the extent to which they are ill-equipped to deal with the apparent strength and financial resources of the drug groups.
title: THE MEXICAN DRUG WAR GETS RED HOT

text: Although the precise events in the early morning hours of Nov. 1 still are not clear, Mexican officials say there are indications that the 17 police officers and five other men who worked for the police as informants and guides were drawn into a trap, then massacred.
title: THE MEXICAN DRUG WAR GETS RED HOT

text: Two survivors were reported to be under intense interrogation last week as investigators tried to learn what happened and why. Enough seems to be known to cause Mexican officials to reassess their operational methods. Often, Mexican drug agents have preferred to capture illegal drugs, but avoid confrontation with traffickers. Diplomatic sources say federal judicial policemen, from whose ranks the Attorney General's drug agents are taken, carry only a few rounds of ammunition for their weapons.
title: THE MEXICAN DRUG WAR GETS RED HOT

text: The policemen who were killed were not in communication with their headquarters and could not summon help. Moreover, they apparently switched their plans in the middle of an operation without telling anyone.
title: THE MEXICAN DRUG WAR GETS RED HOT

text: Beyond the presumed failings of the agents, Mexican authorities pose a problem of financial resources. A senior official in the Interior Ministry said last week that the problem is growing too rapidly for the Mexican Government to cope with it on its own.
title: THE MEXICAN DRUG WAR GETS RED HOT

text: ''I think we are going to need more help than we are at present getting,'' he said, indicating that it should come from the United States. In the last fiscal year, Washington contributed $10 million to controlling the Mexican drug traffic.
title: THE MEXICAN DRUG WAR GETS RED HOT

text: THE Easton Police Department has started a program in which parents anonymously submit drugs that they suspect their children are taking for analysis by the police.
title: POLICE HELP PARENTS IDENTIFY NARCOTICS

text: The program was started by Police Chief Gerard J. Hance in response to a recent study on drug use. The chief, who is on the board of the United Way of Eastern Fairfield County, cited a study by the agency that indicated that drugs and alcohol are prevalant among students in the seventh through 12th grades in six towns in Fairfield County, including Easton.
title: POLICE HELP PARENTS IDENTIFY NARCOTICS

text: ''I was quite astonished by the results of this study and wanted to do something to combat this problem,'' he said. ''It caused me to re-examine the police approach to this.''
title: POLICE HELP PARENTS IDENTIFY NARCOTICS

text: Chief Hance said that the police are usually the last to know of drug problems among teen-agers, and they have been unable to make an impact.
