title: POLICE HELP PARENTS IDENTIFY NARCOTICS

text: His program, which began three months ago, encourages parents to call the police department if they have found an unknown drug that they believe their child is taking. So far two families have used the program. The chief attributes this to lack of public awareness about the program.
title: POLICE HELP PARENTS IDENTIFY NARCOTICS

text: ''We're a conduit between the agencies that help drug abusers and the kids who need it,'' Chief Hance said.
title: POLICE HELP PARENTS IDENTIFY NARCOTICS

text: The executive director of Connecticut Civil Liberties Union, William Olds, said he was skeptical about the police department's involvment in such a program. He suggested the State Department of Health as an alternative.
title: POLICE HELP PARENTS IDENTIFY NARCOTICS

text: ''They're not in the same compromising position as the police,'' he said. ''The laws do say that possession of drugs is a criminal act.''
title: POLICE HELP PARENTS IDENTIFY NARCOTICS

text: The structure of the program, however, gives the parents, and thus the child, anonymity, the Police Chief said. When parents call the police department, they are given a number, no names are taken, and instructed to mail a sample of the drug to the department. Parents use the same number to get the test results 10 days later.
title: POLICE HELP PARENTS IDENTIFY NARCOTICS

text: Detective Les Eckert of the police department tests such drugs as marijuana, cocaine and heroin. Pharmaceutical drugs are analyzed by Stepney Pharmacy in Monroe.More complex drugs like LSD are sent to state agencies.
title: POLICE HELP PARENTS IDENTIFY NARCOTICS

text: ''We do not make any arrests or use any findings for evidence based on these submissions,'' said Chief Hance. ''We want parents to know we're not in the business of arresting their children. We want to help them get help for their children.'' If parents notify the police that their child who is taking drugs refuses to stop, however, he said then an investigation might be started, which could lead to an arrest.
title: POLICE HELP PARENTS IDENTIFY NARCOTICS

text: ''I think it's risky for parents to have the police do that kind of research for them,'' said Mr. Olds. ''Even though the policy of the program is not to make an arrest that could change later and their findings could be used as evidence against the child.''
title: POLICE HELP PARENTS IDENTIFY NARCOTICS

text: He said if he had a teen-ager at home with a drug problem he would not use the program.
title: POLICE HELP PARENTS IDENTIFY NARCOTICS

text: Chief Hance said that 67 percent of the inmates in Connecticut prisons have committed drug-related crimes and that it costs $15,000 each a year to maintain them.
title: POLICE HELP PARENTS IDENTIFY NARCOTICS

text: ''By making an early identification we can catch it and get the kids in a facility or to a psychologist before they get into crime,'' he said. ''It's the most economical way.''
title: POLICE HELP PARENTS IDENTIFY NARCOTICS

text: Chief Hance, who said there were no other drug programs like his in the country, cited two possible causes for the growing incidence of drug abuse among teen-agers: Acceptance of the drug culture by society and a lack of parental supervision in the home. He said that 22 percent of the households in the nation are run by single parents who have to go to work.
title: POLICE HELP PARENTS IDENTIFY NARCOTICS

text: ''Parents know by the general demeanor of their children - personality changes, problems at school -that something is wrong,'' he said. ''Often these problems are drug-related. When the parents are not home it's hard to detect these changes.
title: POLICE HELP PARENTS IDENTIFY NARCOTICS

text: The effectiveness of the program, however, depends on public support, he said. If parents are hesitant to let the police know that they suspect their children are on drugs, then the program is useless.
title: POLICE HELP PARENTS IDENTIFY NARCOTICS

text: THE first signs may be sudden furtiveness or tardiness on the job. Or frequent trips to the bathroom, or denial -denial of the theft of a co-worker's money or of such behavior as outbursts of temper followed by complacency.
title: COMPANIES ACT TO AID COCAINE ADDICTS

text: These are common signs of a developing cocaine addiction, and the Xerox Corporation's 60,000 employees - everyone from the president on down - will soon be alerted to them. The Stamford-based company is developing a mandatory drug-abuse education program largely in reponse to what experts are calling a cocaine epidemic.
title: COMPANIES ACT TO AID COCAINE ADDICTS

text: The Xerox program is the most recent step taken in Connecticut work places amid a growing realization not only that cocaine abuse has mushroomed in the state, but also that problems with the drug have reduced the productivity of tens of thousands of workers.
title: COMPANIES ACT TO AID COCAINE ADDICTS

text: ''It wasn't something we saw very much in the work place 5 or 10 years ago,'' said Mary Bernstein, manager of employee assistance programs for G.T.E. in Stamford. ''Now we do.''
title: COMPANIES ACT TO AID COCAINE ADDICTS

text: ''It isn't just the big people in the world who are in trouble,'' said Chester Griffith, who is helping develop the Xerox program. ''It's all of us. The word being used now is epidemic. We want to get people sooner. People on drugs are not particularly safe people to have around.''
title: COMPANIES ACT TO AID COCAINE ADDICTS

text: The Xerox program, according to Mr. Griffith, will reach employees in all Xerox offices nationwide and inform them - ''in a nonthreatening way'' - of the drug's dangers. Each employee will receive a copy of ''800-COCAINE,'' a book published last year by Dr. Mark Gold, the founder of a nationwide telephone hot line for cocaine abusers. Xerox will also show a classroom film about drug abuse.
title: COMPANIES ACT TO AID COCAINE ADDICTS

text: In addition, the company is training managers to identify early signs of problems in order to apply company-run assistance programs.
title: COMPANIES ACT TO AID COCAINE ADDICTS

text: Identifying problems is the key to Connecticut companies' remedies. An employee relations director from one Connecticut company told of a recent case in which an employee's cocaine addiction came to light after he was caught stealing large amounts of money from co-workers to finance his habit.
title: COMPANIES ACT TO AID COCAINE ADDICTS

text: Most major and middle-sized companies have instituted programs in recent years to work confidentially with employees having family, alcohol or, increasingly, cocaine problems.
title: COMPANIES ACT TO AID COCAINE ADDICTS

text: These days more than 75 percent of the drug-related problems facing Pitney-Bowes involve cocaine, according to the manager of employee relations, Connie Murphy. She said Pitney-Bowes was working on a general companywide abuse education program like the one at Xerox, except that it would be voluntary, not mandatory.
title: COMPANIES ACT TO AID COCAINE ADDICTS

text: Like other such programs, Pitney-Bowes's works privately with employees whose supervisors say have developed problems on the job. Supervisors are told not to search for drug or alcohol problems. Instead, the program works with troubled employees to identify the source of problems, refer drug abusers to area clinics, and follow up with them when they return to work.
title: COMPANIES ACT TO AID COCAINE ADDICTS

text: The promise of confidentiality is crucial in seeking out cocaine abusers and employees with other drug problems, said Mrs. Bernstein of G.T.E. The company instituted its program a year ago. It has found, she said, that it also often pays to draw on community services, outside the work place, in helping employees fight off addiction.
title: COMPANIES ACT TO AID COCAINE ADDICTS

text: Connecticut companies are only gradually learning that lesson, partly because the companies themselves are often just beginning to confront the dangers of cocaine use by employees, said Dr. Peter Jones, coordinator of the cocaine program at Liberation Clinic in Stamford.
title: COMPANIES ACT TO AID COCAINE ADDICTS

text: Several major corporations in town refer employees to his clinic, and about 30 percent of his patients now are such referrals, he said. But he said other companies still rely on less effective methods.
title: COMPANIES ACT TO AID COCAINE ADDICTS

text: ''They have a tendency to send an executive to a hospital in the country for 28 days and call it a leave of absence,'' Dr. Jones said. But such an artifical setting removes the abuser from the stressful circumstances that may have led him to drugs in the first place, he said. Out-patient community programs, he said, enable a worker to free himself from addiction while confronting those circumstances at the same time.
title: COMPANIES ACT TO AID COCAINE ADDICTS

text: Informing employees about cocaine's dangers is crucial because of its image as a safe drug that symbolizes success, assistance program administrators agree.
title: COMPANIES ACT TO AID COCAINE ADDICTS

text: ''Until recently, people had forgotten how addictive it is,'' said Charlie Williams, acting director of the prevention and intervention division of the State Alcohol and Drug Abuse Commission. ''It was a glamour drug for a number of years. But it's difficult, if not impossible, to control. If you continue to use it regularly, all you want to do is cocaine.''
title: COMPANIES ACT TO AID COCAINE ADDICTS

text: The story of white-collar cocaine abuse is not new. Rather, the signs of that increased use are just now becoming widely visible in the work place.
title: COMPANIES ACT TO AID COCAINE ADDICTS

text: Cocaine use may have become epidemic several years ago, but it has taken until now for a large percentage of those users to fall into enough trouble to seek help, said Dr. Herbert J. Kleber, a Yale psychiatrist who runs the A.P.T. Foundation. The foundation, which operates drug-treatment programs in New Haven, treats about 40 patients at a time in its cocaine clinic. Three years ago, the demand was too limited to justify a clinic.
title: COMPANIES ACT TO AID COCAINE ADDICTS

text: Jerome Mattioli, supervisor of the Federal Drug Enforcement Agency office in Hartford, applauded the increased efforts to combat cocaine problems in the work place as perhaps the most effective prevention.
title: COMPANIES ACT TO AID COCAINE ADDICTS

text: ''That's where the abuser spends the majority of his time,'' Mr. Mattioli said. ''The most important place that has the biggest impact on him is the work place.'' Approaching an office drug-abuse program can also offer the abuser the prospect of less embarrassment than seeking out a family member or clergyman, he noted.
title: COMPANIES ACT TO AID COCAINE ADDICTS

text: He and others portrayed the problem in two different but equally dramatic ways: through statistics and through anecdotes.
title: COMPANIES ACT TO AID COCAINE ADDICTS

text: According to a Federal report released last month, about 20 million Americans use cocaine at least once a month. Between 3 and 7 percent of the work force uses illegal drugs on a given workday and functions at 67 percent of its work potential. Society at large is losing between $50 billion and and $100 billion a year in sick leave, lost productivity and other costs as a result, the agency reported.
title: COMPANIES ACT TO AID COCAINE ADDICTS

text: Mr. Mattioli estimated that in Connecticut, while the number of heroin users has stayed at about 10,000, the number of cocaine users has shot up to three or four times that number in the last two years. He attributed the rise to a false sense that cocaine was not addictive, and to an influx of South American cocaine lowering prices.
title: COMPANIES ACT TO AID COCAINE ADDICTS

text: ''Now it seems like you can get cocaine anywhere, any time you want it,'' he said. ''Every walk of life has the cocaine problem in Connecticut, from the slums to bankers and lawyers.''
title: COMPANIES ACT TO AID COCAINE ADDICTS

text: Meanwhile, the State Alcohol and Drug Abuse Commission announced last month that the percentage of clients seeking help for cocaine problems at state-financed centers shot up far higher - 83.9 percent - than the percentage of clients grappling with other drug problems. And another study dampens officials' hopes of slowing that increase: a recent survey showed that marijuana use had leveled among high school seniors but that cocaine use continued to climb.
title: COMPANIES ACT TO AID COCAINE ADDICTS

text: The National ''800-COCAINE'' hot line, set up in 1983, now receives more than 1,200 calls a day. About three-quarters of the abusers calling in say they take the drug while at work, according to Dr. Arnold Washton, the hot line's research director.
title: COMPANIES ACT TO AID COCAINE ADDICTS

text: Dr. Washton said Connecticut ranks in the top four states - the other three are New York, California and New Jersey - according to the number of cocaine abusers calling in. He attributed this to the state's proximity to ''the cocaine capital of the country,'' meaning New York City, and because of its demographics. Many Connecticut executives commute to Westchester or New York City and have especially easy access to the drug, he said. He also said Connecticut has a high concentration of the primary risk group: middle- and upper-class ''upwardly mobile baby boomers who have switched from marijuana in the 60's and 70's to cocaine in the 80's.''
title: COMPANIES ACT TO AID COCAINE ADDICTS

text: ''It's gone from being the drug of choice of the wealthy to the drug of choice of middle-class America,'' Dr. Washton said.
title: COMPANIES ACT TO AID COCAINE ADDICTS

text: After a while, Dr. Washton said, some users become so addicted that they visit the bathroom every half-hour at work for another infusion. He has seen repeated cases of people losing friends, growing socially withdrawn, disappearing during work hours, and piling up sick days, especially after ''binge'' weekends and holidays.
title: COMPANIES ACT TO AID COCAINE ADDICTS

text: He told of managers and executives who turned down corporate promotions and raises. They feared they would simply spend salary increases on more cocaine, he said, speeding their physical deterioration.
title: COMPANIES ACT TO AID COCAINE ADDICTS

text: THE REGIONPRO AND CON: TESTING FOR DRUGS IN THE SCHOOLS
title: AN INVASION OF PRIVACY

text: THE Carlstadt-East Rutherford Regional High School District operates only one rather small institution, the Henry P. Becton Regional High School, which until recently went about its business quietly in suburban Bergen County, N. J., just seven miles west of Manhattan. But in August, members of the board of education, concerned about student alcohol and drug abuse, took an extraordinary step, voting to require all of the school's 500 students to take blood and urine tests, which, among other things, would be used to detect drug use and alcohol abuse. Under the new policy, believed to be the first of its kind in the country, the physical exam would be mandatory, and any student who refused to undergo one would be excluded from school. The results of the tests would be confidential and would not be turned over to the police, school officials said.
title: AN INVASION OF PRIVACY

text: The American Civil Liberties Union of New Jersey challenged the policy in court, and a State Superior Court judge temporarily barred the school from beginning the tests until the suit could be decided. A hearing is scheduled for Tuesday.
title: AN INVASION OF PRIVACY

text: Alan Finder, an editor of The Week in Review, last week asked Alfred L. Marbaise, the superintendent of the school district, and Jeffrey E. Fogel, the executive director of the New Jersey A.C.L.U., to discuss their positions. Excerpts of their remarks follow.
title: AN INVASION OF PRIVACY

text: We have challenged the Becton testing program because of our concern for rights under the Fourth Amendment. Many historians believe that the catalyst for the American Revolution was the disrespect for privacy rights by King George III. The people who framed the Bill of Rights believed that we had a right to be secure in our homes, our persons and our papers and effects, and that the Government had no right to intrude on that area of privacy without probable cause, a determination usually to be made by a judge.
title: AN INVASION OF PRIVACY

text: We're also concerned about the rights of young people and in particular young people in an institutional setting. There has been a long struggle over the extent to which - some would say whether or not - the Constitution even applies behind the schoolhouse doors.
title: AN INVASION OF PRIVACY

text: The only United States Supreme
title: AN INVASION OF PRIVACY

text: Court decision on the rights to search students in public schools involved a Piscataway, N.J., student. The court held in January of this year that the Fourth Amendment clearly does apply to searches of students by school officials, but that it applies in a watered-down form. School officials don't have to get warrants, they don't have to have probable cause, but they do have to have reasonable grounds to suspect that a search will uncover evidence of either a violation of law or of school rules. And one of the sine qua nons of the Fourth Amendment is individualized rather than group suspicion.
title: AN INVASION OF PRIVACY

text: The arguments that have been advanced to support generalized group searches of students without individual suspicion have been premised on a concern about drug use or violence.
title: AN INVASION OF PRIVACY

text: Those same arguments could be advanced in other settings. For example, why not frisk all citizens who enter the subway or walk down the streets of our cities because of our concern about crime and drugs? That is obviously a frightening proposition.
title: AN INVASION OF PRIVACY

text: Becton school officials have also argued that their approach to the problem has been: ''We treat drugs like an illness, not like a criminal matter.'' They're playing semantic games, because under existing school policy, any student found to be under the influence of an intoxicating substance in school is disciplined and referred to the police. They do not in fact treat drug usage as a medical problem. The rest of the society still treats it like a criminal problem, and there is a certain stigma attached to people who are identified as using drugs.
title: AN INVASION OF PRIVACY

text: You have a right to an education under our State Constitution. You cannot be deprived of that right without some compelling interest on the part of the state. Becton is saying that as a condition of going to school, you must give up a portion of your bodily fluids for a drug analysis. If you don't, you don't go to school. If a student refused to be analyzed for a drug which had a potential for contaminating other students or refused to be vaccinated for a contagious disease, then, yes, there would be a reasonable and compelling state interest to exclude that person until they complied. But that is hardly the case with respect to drug usage.
title: AN INVASION OF PRIVACY

text: It's ironic, I think, that Becton does not even claim to have a serious drug problem. When confronted about it they identified one, as they characterized it, one ''marijuana-related incident'' all of last year. The weight of the school board's evidence is against them.
title: AN INVASION OF PRIVACY

text: What they're saying to students in this policy is: ''Prove that you don't use drugs.'' Everybody has to disprove the suspicion that they might be using drugs. It certainly turns the notion of innocent until proven guilty on its head.
title: AN INVASION OF PRIVACY

text: Becton's approach is particularly disturbing in light of the obligation of our schools to inculcate basic civil values. What lesson about our Constitution is being taught by the conduct of these school officials? On the one hand, students are taught that in America you are innocent until proven guilty and that we all have certain rights to personal privacy and individual dignity. On the other hand, the conduct of school officials suggests that neither of those propositions is true in reality.
title: AN INVASION OF PRIVACY

text: I'm not prepared to give up the Bill of Rights simply because somebody says it gets in the way of our being able to solve a social problem. The attitude that some of the school officials have is that students belong to them and have no rights that are bound to be respected by school administrators. That's a very disturbing proposition. That argument was made in the Piscataway case and was unanimously rejected by the Supreme Court. As Justice Byron White said, ''We are not yet ready to hold that the schools and the prisons need be equated for purposes of the Fourth Amendment.''
title: AN INVASION OF PRIVACY

text: HOW American schools teach English to students who do not speak it fluently depends on the state, school district, school, instructor and the needs of the students. In most cases, though, schools use variations of three approaches:
title: THE 3 TEACHING METHODS IN BILINGUAL CLASSES

text: MAINTENANCE: This method is typically employed with students who have recently arrived in the United States and understand no English at all. A bilingual teacher teaches them fundamental math and reading skills, for example, in their native language first then begins teaching the same curriculum in English, using the native language to fall back on. The method aims to foster parallel learning development in both languages.
title: THE 3 TEACHING METHODS IN BILINGUAL CLASSES

text: TRANSITIONAL: With this method, bilingual instructors teach classes in both languages, principally in the native language at first and then increasingly in English as students' proficiency in it increases.
title: THE 3 TEACHING METHODS IN BILINGUAL CLASSES

text: Both methods are designed to teach students of all abilities, from beginners to advanced English speakers, but individual districts select which approach best suits its goals. To start maintenance or transitional programs, school districts or individual schools must enroll a minimum number of limited-English-speakers. That minimum varies from state to state and from district to district.
title: THE 3 TEACHING METHODS IN BILINGUAL CLASSES

text: ENGLISH AS A SECOND LANGUAGE: This method is taught at several levels, depending on how much English a student can speak and write. In school districts that do not have enough students to form bilingual classes, students may take extra periods of E.S.L., as it is commonly called, to improve their English. For schools that offer transitional or maintenance methods, which are more comprehensive, E.S.L. is usually a component of the broader program to reinforce the English taught in the bilingual classes.
title: THE 3 TEACHING METHODS IN BILINGUAL CLASSES

text: In the E.S.L. method students usually attend one or two E.S.L. classes a day to supplement the English they learn in subjects taught in English the rest of the day. Because a potpourri of languages are represented in E.S.L. classes, the teachers usually do not know all languages spoken. But they are trained to be sensitive to students' native languages and cultures, which can have an influence on how quickly they learn English. E.S.L. teachers stress fundamental speaking and comprehension skills in English first, then develop proficiency in reading and writing.
title: THE 3 TEACHING METHODS IN BILINGUAL CLASSES

text: In a less widely used fourth approach, the immersion method, students attend classes that are taught in English, though instructors are also certified in a second language. The method has provoked controversy among educators; some characterize it as a ''sink-or-swim'' method that is detrimental to the non-native-speaker's learning and language development. However, a few school districts around the country have successfully operated immersion programs; one example is in Elizabeth, N.J., where beginning this month the State of New Jersey will finance a three-year pilot immersion program for 200 kindergarteners and first-graders in eight schools.
title: THE 3 TEACHING METHODS IN BILINGUAL CLASSES

text: The following articles represent examples in the New York metropolitan area of each of the three bilingual methods of teaching English.
title: THE 3 TEACHING METHODS IN BILINGUAL CLASSES

text: IN Louise O'Neill-Mejia's classroom, the children are learning to live in two worlds: the familiar Spanish-speaking setting of their ancestry and the new English-speaking milieu of their adopted home.
title: THE 3 TEACHING METHODS IN BILINGUAL CLASSES

text: Using the maintenance method like a tennis match, with rallies in Spanish, then English, the third-, fourth- and fifth-graders in her mixed-grade classroom at Thomas Edison Elementary School in Port Chester, N.Y., learn academic subjects in both languages.
title: THE 3 TEACHING METHODS IN BILINGUAL CLASSES

text: The class is part of a bilingual program operated with state funds. The 18 children in Mrs. O'Neill-Mejia's class are classified as limited-English-speakers; many came to the United States only recently, from countries such as Guatemala, Ecuador, Peru, Mexico and Colombia.
title: THE 3 TEACHING METHODS IN BILINGUAL CLASSES

text: In the maintenance method, Mrs. O'Neill-Mejia teaches the children primarily in Spanish, building up their comprehension and confidence before using it to teach them English. In addition, the children receive special instruction in English and in United States culture through English as a Second Language classes. Throughout the program, however, students maintain and improve their ability to speak and learn academic subjects in Spanish.
title: THE 3 TEACHING METHODS IN BILINGUAL CLASSES

text: The Edison program also includes a parallel class of native-English-speaking students who are learning Spanish by the same maintenance method, receiving all their instruction in both languages. The goal of the three-year program, which started last November, is for both groups to attain proficiency in the two languages.
title: THE 3 TEACHING METHODS IN BILINGUAL CLASSES

text: Some educators have criticized the maintenance method, suggesting that since many children come from poor countries and are illiterate in their native language, they should be taught strictly in English to begin with. Mrs. O'Neill-Mejia's answer is that the children are still oriented to their native tongue in nonverbal ways, despite their lack of proficiency in it. ''Many of these kids didn't even know how to read in Spanish when they came here,'' said Mrs. O'Neill-Mejia. ''But they still think conceptually in Spanish. So if concepts are solidly formed in their first language, then we can transfer them more easily into English.''
title: THE 3 TEACHING METHODS IN BILINGUAL CLASSES

text: Indeed, her airy classroom is a study in bilingualism. Number charts, calendars, vocabulary lists and instructions on the chalkboard are written in both English and Spanish. And like all maintenance-method instructors, Mrs. O'Neill-Mejia is herself bilingual. One morning recently, she sat with six fifth-graders in a tight semicircle and conducted a weekly English lesson. She had the children read, then quizzed them in both languages to test their comprehension.
title: THE 3 TEACHING METHODS IN BILINGUAL CLASSES

text: Mrs. O'Neill-Mejia discounted the argument that the maintenance method retards a foreign student's development in English, ''As soon as we see someone flourishing in English,'' she said, ''we push them and do everything we can to improve their skills.'' A year ago five students in the group knew no English at all. Now, like most of their classmates, they read at second-grade levels or better and are improving rapidly. ''I like reading and I like to work,'' said Mariana Suarez, one of the five, a 9-year-old whose family moved from Bolivia two years ago.
title: THE 3 TEACHING METHODS IN BILINGUAL CLASSES

text: Children are tested once in the fall and again in the spring to monitor their progress, and to determine how many English-support classes they should take.
title: THE 3 TEACHING METHODS IN BILINGUAL CLASSES

text: Educators have seen academic and linguistic progress in the classroom, and they say that the program has also reaped social benefits on the playground. ''When these kids first came here, many were timid and withdrawn,'' said Frank Napolitano, the school principal. ''Now you can't measure their change in attitude and self-esteem. They're able to communicate, they're thriving and they're accepted by their peers.''
title: THE 3 TEACHING METHODS IN BILINGUAL CLASSES

text: PEDRO MEDINA finished typing a series of commands for a computer program he would use to review arithmetic and algebra problems.
title: THE 3 TEACHING METHODS IN BILINGUAL CLASSES

text: The program bade him ''adios,'' then displayed his results in English.
title: THE 3 TEACHING METHODS IN BILINGUAL CLASSES

text: For Pedro, a 17-year-old student at John Bowne High School in Queens, the switch from the farewell in Spanish to a list of printed results marked a transition to English that typified not only his course work in the computer math class but also in special classes he attends as part of the school's transitional bilingual program.
title: THE 3 TEACHING METHODS IN BILINGUAL CLASSES

text: Sixteen months ago, when Pedro moved from the Dominican Republic, he knew little English. Now he is learning English in the computer math class, as well as in science and history classes, which are taught in both English and Spanish. He also takes two special classes of English for non-native-speakers.
title: THE 3 TEACHING METHODS IN BILINGUAL CLASSES

text: As with other transitional bilingual programs, the aim at Bowne is for the non-native-speaker to achieve English proficiency as quickly as possible. In the early stages of a class, bilingual instructors teach subjects in the student's first language and then use progressively more English as students' proficiency increases.
title: THE 3 TEACHING METHODS IN BILINGUAL CLASSES

text: ''We want them to keep their foreign language but they have to succeed and master English if they want to make it in this country,'' said Patricia Kobetts, Bowne's principal.
title: THE 3 TEACHING METHODS IN BILINGUAL CLASSES

text: Like many large urban schools that use the transitional approach, Bowne is a melting pot. Its 3,200 students come from 67 countries and speak 28 languages.The school has identified about 500 students as limited-English-speakers. Of those, about 250 are Hispanic and 90 are Chinese, large enough blocs to warrant the formation of parallel bilingual curriculums. For them the school offers bilingual math and science courses in Spanish and Mandarin Chinese. A bilingual social studies class for Hispanic students is also taught. The remaining limited-English students receive special instruction in English as a Second Language classes.
title: THE 3 TEACHING METHODS IN BILINGUAL CLASSES

text: In addition, Bowne offers literature classes in Spanish and Mandarin as a way for those students to maintain their cultural and educational development in their first language. Students also take an English as a Second Language class to supplement the English they learn in other courses.
title: THE 3 TEACHING METHODS IN BILINGUAL CLASSES

text: One day recently, 10th-grade students in Pearl Shum's biology class listened to her instructions in English on how to use a microscope to examine onion-skin cells. For reinforcement, Mrs. Shum repeated some instructions and answered questions in Mandarin.
title: THE 3 TEACHING METHODS IN BILINGUAL CLASSES

text: Similarly, in Carmen Wojnarowski's life-sciences class, Spanish-speaking students followed instruction sheets printed in both Spanish and English to test the carbohydrate content of various foods. Both teachers said that as the term progressed they would use English more in lectures, experiments and tests.
title: THE 3 TEACHING METHODS IN BILINGUAL CLASSES

text: The transitional approach employs teachers who are fluent in English and, in Bowne's case, Chinese or Spanish. They are also certified in their specialties.
title: THE 3 TEACHING METHODS IN BILINGUAL CLASSES

text: Bowne tests students' English skills twice a year to determine placement in bilingual classes. Most students can read, write and speak well in English after two years in the bilingual program, Mrs. Kobetts said. They are then placed in mainstream classes.
title: THE 3 TEACHING METHODS IN BILINGUAL CLASSES

text: While many of the school's top students started in the bilingual programs, school administrators identified areas where their program could improve. ''Our feeling is that the kids need more practice writing,'' said Mrs. Kobetts, echoing a general concern among educators nationwide who often lack the funds or smaller class sizes to teach the way they would prefer. ''They have to cope with English to fill out job applications, college applications,'' she said.
title: THE 3 TEACHING METHODS IN BILINGUAL CLASSES

text: ENGLISH AS A SECOND LANGUAGE
title: THE 3 TEACHING METHODS IN BILINGUAL CLASSES

text: AROUND the table they sat: the Russian, the Thai, the Italian, the Chinese and the Spaniard, giggling about their work and speaking in English. It's a typical scene in Mary Ann Sacks's English as a Second Language classes at Countrywood Elementary School in Huntington Station, L.I. ''It's little America sitting here,'' said Mrs. Sacks of one class of 7- and 8-year-olds.
title: THE 3 TEACHING METHODS IN BILINGUAL CLASSES

text: E.S.L., as the classes are called in education circles, provide instruction in speaking and writing English to students who understand or speak little or none. Studies in such classes also often deal with material studied in other subject areas such as arithmetic and science. Unlike bilingual programs, however, an E.S.L. class may be attended by students from many foreign-language backgrounds. The instructor teaches in English and often does not speak a child's first language.
title: THE 3 TEACHING METHODS IN BILINGUAL CLASSES

text: To compensate for this, E.S.L. teachers, like Mrs. Sacks, are specially trained to use methods and materials designed to aid the non-native speaker. For example, teachers often use word games and rhymes to teach such lessons as parts of the body, terms English-speaking children would already know. Teachers are also trained to be sensitive to the customs and cultures of their foreign students, many of whom have survived war-torn countries. ''Some of their stories would make your hair stand on end,'' she said. ''Many have never had what we think of as a teacher. They had someone in a classroom who watched to make sure the kids avoided the gunfire outside.''
title: THE 3 TEACHING METHODS IN BILINGUAL CLASSES

text: To be certified to teach E.S.L., most states require teachers to complete such college courses as linguistics, psychology, sociology, anthropology, counseling and bilingual education. Many teachers continue these studies to earn a master's degree equivalent in E.S.L.
title: THE 3 TEACHING METHODS IN BILINGUAL CLASSES

text: Mrs. Sacks, who is certified in E.S.L. and also speaks Spanish, French and Hebrew, has taught the method for eight years. She is the senior member of the five E.S.L. teachers who shuttle among the seven schools, grades kindergarten through 12th grade, in the South Huntington Union Free School District.
title: THE 3 TEACHING METHODS IN BILINGUAL CLASSES

text: The district's E.S.L. program is small compared with some in large cities. Of the district's 6,000 students, about 135, speaking 21 different languages, qualify for the classes. The class at Countrywood, while smaller and able to afford more individual instruction, illustrates the approach used in E.S.L. classes elsewhere.
title: THE 3 TEACHING METHODS IN BILINGUAL CLASSES

text: With younger children, for instance, who have recently arrived in the United States and are just learning English, Mrs. Sacks begins with rhymes and word games to improve their speaking and comprehension skills, and to increase their self-confidence in the new idiom. Those who know little or no English spend more time in E.S.L. classes in proportion to their subject classes, she said, where they get additional help with both the language and their academic classes. The E.S.L. teachers also give teaching aids and suggestions to the subject teachers of a child whose English is very weak.
title: THE 3 TEACHING METHODS IN BILINGUAL CLASSES

text: Before Halloween the children cut out paper skeletons, giving Mrs. Sacks an opportunity to teach them the verbs associated with the activity, such as bending, folding, cutting, stapling and pasting. She also taught them the names of body parts.
title: THE 3 TEACHING METHODS IN BILINGUAL CLASSES

text: In intermediate grades Mrs. Sacks drills students on grammar, vocabulary and pronunciation using state textbooks, a manual she wrote and tape recordings. She integrates the exercises with lessons in American culture and history. Students of high-school age receive special career guidance and college preparatory help.
title: THE 3 TEACHING METHODS IN BILINGUAL CLASSES

text: Grade-schoolers receive about 30 minutes of E.S.L. instruction every day. Older students may receive 45 minutes daily. Depending on their progress, some children may spend more time each day in their E.S.L. class.
title: THE 3 TEACHING METHODS IN BILINGUAL CLASSES

text: CONSUMERS were awarded nearly $2 million from January 1984 to February 1985 under a car-repair arbitration program administered by the Better Business Bureau of Metropolitan New York.
title: HELPING UNHAPPY CAR OWNER

text: The program was begun under a 1983 consent order between General Motors and the Federal Trade Commission. It allows Better Business Bureaus nationwide to seek reimbursement or repairs from General Motors for people dissatisfied with certain components of the company's cars or light trucks.
title: HELPING UNHAPPY CAR OWNER

text: The order settled a 1980 complaint charging that General Motors failed to notify customers about serious problems with the following components in some cars: THM 200 transmissions (1976 to 1983 models); camshafts and lifters in 305- and 350-cubic-inch Chevrolet gasoline engines (1974 to 1983 models), and fuel injection pumps and fuel injectors in 350-cubic-inch Oldsmobile diesel engines (1978 to 1983 models).
title: HELPING UNHAPPY CAR OWNER

text: A study released by the trade commission shows that the bureau mediated and arbitrated 4,470 cases during that period, and $1,915,000 was awarded. In addition to the cash awards, 1,157 consumers were awarded repairs. The sum obtained by the bureau was the highest of any Better Business Bureau, the report said. In all, consumers were awarded 70 percent of the amounts they requested at the outset of arbitration.
title: HELPING UNHAPPY CAR OWNER

text: Information about the arbitration program is available through Better Business Bureaus. In New York City the number is 212-533-7500; on Long Island, 516-420-0597; in Bergen, Passaic and Rockland Counties, 201-845-4044; in Westchester, Putnam and Dutchess Counties, 914-297-6550, and in the Newark area, 201-643-3067.
title: HELPING UNHAPPY CAR OWNER

text: N EARLY a million people between the ages of 14 and 21 live in New York City, and the Community Council of Greater New York has just completed a booklet for them.
title: HELPING UNHAPPY CAR OWNER

text: Called ''Help Yourself - A Guide for Young People in New York City,'' it was prepared by teen-agers and covers such subjects as preparing for the work world, getting help with alcohol and drug problems and finding free and low-cost health services, counseling and suicide-prevention programs and recreational programs.
title: HELPING UNHAPPY CAR OWNER

text: The list of telephone numbers is lengthy and diverse. It includes, for example, the Covenant House runaway number (212-354-4323, 24 hours a day, 7 days a week) and numbers for the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau (212-397-8222) and the Homework Hotline (718-780-7766, 5 P.M. to 8 P.M. on days when city public schools are open).
title: HELPING UNHAPPY CAR OWNER

text: The booklet answers questions of interest to teen-agers, with detailed, straightforward information that adults may consider common knowledge but teen-agers may not know about.
title: HELPING UNHAPPY CAR OWNER

text: These are examples of the questions and answers:
title: HELPING UNHAPPY CAR OWNER

text: ''At what age can I get married?'' In New York, people under 14 cannot legally be married; those 14 to 16 can be married only with the consent of their parents and Family Court; those 16 to 18 need only parental permission, and those over 18 need no permission at all.
title: HELPING UNHAPPY CAR OWNER

text: ''Can I sign a lease? What rights do I have under the lease?'' Under a lease, a tenant agrees to pay rent, and the landlord agrees to provide a safe, livable apartment or room, plus heat and hot water. Many landlords will not sign a lease with anyone under 18, and others require the signature of a parent or another adult.
title: HELPING UNHAPPY CAR OWNER

text: ''When do I have to pay taxes?'' In general, anyone earning more than $2,300 a year must pay some taxes. Employers usually deduct some money from each paycheck for taxes; often, too much money is taken out, and the Government may owe you money at the end of the year. To receive the amount owed, you must file a tax return by April 15.
title: HELPING UNHAPPY CAR OWNER

text: ''Is marijuana legal?'' Possession of more than seven-eighths of an ounce is illegal; smoking marijuana in public carries a penalty of up to three months in jail.
title: HELPING UNHAPPY CAR OWNER

text: ''At what age can I get a driver's license, and how do I get it?'' People 16 to 18 need a parent's permission to get a learner's permit, which allows them to take the test for a junior license. Those 17 can take the test for an adult license, but only if they have completed a certified drivers' education course. For more information call the State Department of Motor Vehicles at 212-587-4620.
title: HELPING UNHAPPY CAR OWNER

text: ''What if I get arrested?'' Remain silent until you can speak with your parents or lawyer. Do not argue with the police officer, because you may be charged with a more serious offense. If you cannot afford a lawyer, you should be assigned one the first time you go before a judge.
title: HELPING UNHAPPY CAR OWNER

text: The booklet is available in English and Spanish and can be obtained by sending a self-addressed, stamped envelope with 39 cents' postage to ''Help Yourself,'' Community Council of Greater New York, 275 Seventh Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10001. Indicate English or Spanish edition.
title: HELPING UNHAPPY CAR OWNER

text: Penalties for college athletes who test positive for drugs at Division I bowl games and championships will range from a warning to the loss of a year's eligibility under a program expected to gain the approval of the National Collegiate Athletic Association in January, the chairman of a special committee said today. Drug testing is being performed independently at 96 of the N.C.A.A.'s 283 Division I schools and is under consideration at 45 others.
title: Drug-Penalty Proposals

text: Under the program developed by the committee headed by John Toner, a former N.C.A.A. president, mandatory tests would be conducted at selected bowl games and championships.
title: Drug-Penalty Proposals

text: A positive test result for any of about 200 banned drugs or chemicals except marijuana would result in a 90-day eligibility suspension.
title: Drug-Penalty Proposals

text: Repeat offenders would lose eligibility for one year. Only a confidential warning would be issued for an athlete's first positive test for marijuana. Toner said this is because marijuana is the most prevalent ''street drug'' and because an athlete could test positive from just being ireet the same room with marijuana smoke. But if athletes test positive for marijuana twice, they will be subjected to the first-offender sanctions.
title: Drug-Penalty Proposals

text: There was some excitement in Bremen, Ind., (pop. 3,500) yesterday. ''I ran home for lunch to watch the national news,'' said Dee Martin, the office manager of the weekly Bremen Enquirer.
title: FAMILY DOCTOR FOR CABINET

text: What Mrs. Martin and just about everybody else in Bremen found out was that Dr. Otis R. Bowen, 67 years old, the family doctor to most of Bremen, had been nominated by President Reagan to be the new Secretary of Health and Human Services.
title: FAMILY DOCTOR FOR CABINET

text: ''Now isn't that something,'' Mrs. Martin said in a voice that combined amazement and satisfaction. ''I don't think he ever condsidered himself a politician. He was just common, ordinary. You said 'Hi Doc' and that was it. You just knew that he was a nice, honest man.''
title: FAMILY DOCTOR FOR CABINET

text: Dr. Bowen, as a general practitioner, treated Mrs. Martin, her five children, and the rest of Bremen (pronounced BREE-men) for anything from sniffles to broken arms in the more than 26 years he practiced there. But in that time he also built a political career that led him, step by step, to the Governor's mansion and finally to Washington.
title: FAMILY DOCTOR FOR CABINET

text: Steady in Outlook, They Say
title: FAMILY DOCTOR FOR CABINET

text: Those who knew him said yesterday that Dr. Bowen's rise up the political ladder never changed his outlook.
title: FAMILY DOCTOR FOR CABINET

text: Ruth Gattman, a longtime friend from Elkhart, Ind., described him as ''a quiet person who didn't create a flap when he entered a room, even as Governor.''
title: FAMILY DOCTOR FOR CABINET

text: Mrs. Guttman remembered Dr. Bowen's stepping aside to hold the door for her. ''I'd say, 'But, Otis, you're the Governor,'' Mrs. Gattman said. ''And he would reply, 'I'm still a man and you're still a woman.' ''
title: FAMILY DOCTOR FOR CABINET

text: Otis Ray Bowen was born in Richland Center, Ind., near Rochester, on Feb. 26, 1918. His father, Vernie, and his mother, Pearl, moved from town to town for the father's jobs as a teacher, and Otis graduated from Francisville High School. He went on to Indiana University, where he was graduated in 1939 and that year married Elizabeth A. Steinmann. The couple eventually had four children, three boys and a girl.
title: FAMILY DOCTOR FOR CABINET

text: Dr. Bowen received his medical degree from Indiana Medical School in 1942 and set up his practice in Bremen. He left to serve in the Army Medical Corps from 1943 to 1946 and then returned to his practice in Bremen.
title: FAMILY DOCTOR FOR CABINET

text: By 1952 his political career had begun. He was elected Marshall County coroner. Then, in 1956, he was elected to the Indiana House of Representatives, where he served for seven terms. He became Speaker of the House in 1967, holding that post for four sessions, longer than anyone until then.
title: FAMILY DOCTOR FOR CABINET

text: Running on a platform calling for major revison of the state tox program, Dr. Bowen was overwhelmingly elected Governor in 1972. His program, which called for a reduction in property taxes and a rise in sales taxes, was easily enacted in the first legislative session of his administration. The popularity of the tax revision was credited with helping him to win a second term in 1976.
title: FAMILY DOCTOR FOR CABINET

text: He Gave Wife Medicine for Pain
title: FAMILY DOCTOR FOR CABINET

text: On Jan. 1, 1981, as his second term was ending, his wife died of the bone cancer she suffered for years. Shortly after he stepped down as Governor, Dr. Bowen told a meeting of the Americxan Medical Association that, to ease her pain, he had treated his wife with dimethyl sulfoxide and marijuana capsules that had not been approved for cancer victims by the Food and Drug Administration.
title: FAMILY DOCTOR FOR CABINET

text: ''Why can't a dying person with severe pain have easy prescription access to it?'' Dr. Bowen said. ''The only excuse I could find was that after prolonged use and heavy dosage, it caused an occasional cataract in dogs only. The container said 'For Horses Only.' We laughed about it, but it really wasn't funny.''
title: FAMILY DOCTOR FOR CABINET

text: Dr. Bowen went on to criticize the Food and Drug Administration, part of the department he has now been named to head, for its rules and other Government interference in medicine.
title: FAMILY DOCTOR FOR CABINET

text: Dr. Bowen gave up his medical practice when he was first elected Governor, but he returned to medicine, teaching at the Indiana University Medical School, after his second term.
title: FAMILY DOCTOR FOR CABINET

text: ''I was so impressed that he quickly got back in the swing, updated his medical knowledge and was also seeing private patients,'' said Dr. Alan Fischer, chairman of the medical school's Department of Family Medicine. ''He's been very effective on the faculty. He mingled with all, took his weekly turn being on call and sat with students when their patients were in labor.''
title: FAMILY DOCTOR FOR CABINET

text: Dr. Fischer described Dr. Bowen as ''clear-thinking'' with ''impeccable integrity.''
title: FAMILY DOCTOR FOR CABINET

text: ''He certainly didn't come out here pounding the desk like some ex-governor or politician,' Dr, Fischer said. ''He was just, what shall I say, Dr. Bowen.''
title: FAMILY DOCTOR FOR CABINET

text: For the first time in the nearly five years he had been teaching at the medical school, Dr. Bowen missed the regular 7:30 A.M. faculty meeting yesterday because he was on a plane to Washington.
title: FAMILY DOCTOR FOR CABINET

text: Dr. Bowen married Rose May Hochstetler in late 1981 and they have a home in Bremen. In his spare time Dr. Bowen likes to work in the woods he has developed behind the house.
title: FAMILY DOCTOR FOR CABINET

text: Dick Glant runs the hardware store in Bremen where Dr. Bowen shops. ''When he comes in, he's a guy off the street,'' Mr. Glant said. ''You see him in blue jeans and an old ratty T-shirt. He likes to putter. He'd putter with his lawnmower and sometimes get a little over his head, and we'd go out to help.''
title: FAMILY DOCTOR FOR CABINET

text: Leroy Hirstein, a friend of Dr. Bowen's in Bremen for 35 years, said: ''Nothing goes to his head. You're as apt to see him in a drive-in restaurant as a big steak house.''
title: FAMILY DOCTOR FOR CABINET

text: Cocaine use in America rose sharply in 1984 and supplies of the drug were so plentiful in many major cities that the wholesale price for a kilogram dropped, a Government study said today.
title: U.S. SAYS USE OF COCAINE ROSE SHARPLY IN '84

text: Marijuana use was down 3 percent, the study, the Drug Enforcement Agency said, mainly because fewer young people were using it.
title: U.S. SAYS USE OF COCAINE ROSE SHARPLY IN '84

text: The agency's annual ''Narcotics Intelligence Estimate,'' a detailed analysis of drug use, supplies, trafficking and money in 1984, also said the most significant factor on the international cocaine market was the expansion of all phases of trafficking: cultivation, processing and distribution.
title: U.S. SAYS USE OF COCAINE ROSE SHARPLY IN '84

text: While still dominated by Colombia, with Peru and Bolivia also large factors, trafficking and production had moved substantially into other South American nations, such as Ecuador and Brazil, the report said.
title: U.S. SAYS USE OF COCAINE ROSE SHARPLY IN '84

text: Cocaine use in the United States rose 11 percent in 1984, the study said. Taking cocaine with heroin intravenously, which caused the death of the comedian John Belushi in 1982, was also on the increase, with the number of hospital emergencies because of this use up 37 percent.
title: U.S. SAYS USE OF COCAINE ROSE SHARPLY IN '84

text: The report said that in early 1984 cocaine was so plentiful that there were large wholesale price drops in many U.S. cities. Kilogram prices were as low as $16,000 in south Florida and $30,000 in New York, although by the end of the year prices rose to $33,000 to $38,000 in Miami and $40,000 to $45,000 in New York.
title: U.S. SAYS USE OF COCAINE ROSE SHARPLY IN '84

text: While marijuana use was down in 1984, supplies were stable but prices were high, particularly for the stronger domestic varieties.
title: U.S. SAYS USE OF COCAINE ROSE SHARPLY IN '84

text: The use of more dangerous illegal drugs increased 15 percent over 1983, the report said, largely because of a greater use of the stimulant methamphetamine and the hallucinogen PCP. All the PCP, nearly all the methamphetamin and 80 percent of injectable amphetamine were produced in clandestine laboratories in the United States, the report said. In 1984, 312 clandestine laboratories were seized and closed down, a 38 percent increase over 1983.
title: U.S. SAYS USE OF COCAINE ROSE SHARPLY IN '84

text: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d, in a statement with the report, said the study showed the fight against illegal drugs was ''long and difficult.''
title: U.S. SAYS USE OF COCAINE ROSE SHARPLY IN '84

text: Study of Seniors Made Public
title: U.S. SAYS USE OF COCAINE ROSE SHARPLY IN '84

text: He cited an ''encouraging'' decrease in the use of marijuana and a 1 percent decrease in heroin use. But he said: ''The battle against drug use and abuse in this country can and will be won. But this battle is a marathon, not a sprint.''
title: U.S. SAYS USE OF COCAINE ROSE SHARPLY IN '84

text: A University of Michigan study made public today said the nation's high school seniors tried cocaine in greater numbers this year.
title: U.S. SAYS USE OF COCAINE ROSE SHARPLY IN '84

text: The university's 11th nationwide survey of 16,000 high school seniors at 132 schools found that marijuana smoking had stabilized and was no longer declining and that the use of some drugs increased among the class of 1985.
title: U.S. SAYS USE OF COCAINE ROSE SHARPLY IN '84

text: The annual survey, ''Monitoring the Future: A Continuing Study of the Life Styles and Values of Youth,'' found that a five-year decline in the use of drugs, alcohol and tobacco did not carry into 1985.
title: U.S. SAYS USE OF COCAINE ROSE SHARPLY IN '84

text: More than 600 policemen, soldiers and farmers converged today on a remote marijuana-growing area of southern Mexico to search for drug traffickers that the authorities believe tortured and killed 22 officers.
title: Mexico Intensifies Its Search For Killers of 22 Policemen

text: Comdr. Florentino Ventura, director of Interpol in Mexico, who is coordinating the hunt for the suspects, said three people were arrested in connection with the case.
title: Mexico Intensifies Its Search For Killers of 22 Policemen

text: Two police officers survived the ambush Friday.
title: Mexico Intensifies Its Search For Killers of 22 Policemen

text: By William Stockton, Special To the New York Times
title: MEXICO SEEKING KILLERS OF 21 POLICEMEN

text: Mexican policemen and soliders searched a remote region 300 miles southeast of here today seeking a band of drug smugglers who ambushed and killed 21 policemen after the police discovered a large cache of marijuana.
title: MEXICO SEEKING KILLERS OF 21 POLICEMEN

text: Reports reaching the capital from the area along the border between the states of Veracruz and Oaxaca said the ambush occurred before dawn Friday. Mexican officials said some of the policemen were captured by the smugglers, taken to a nearby farm and tortured and killed.
title: MEXICO SEEKING KILLERS OF 21 POLICEMEN

text: High-level Mexican officials who are supervising Mexico's efforts to combat drug smuggling directed the search from the town of Minatitlan on the Gulf of Mexico coast, which is about 60 miles from the area of the killings.
title: MEXICO SEEKING KILLERS OF 21 POLICEMEN

text: They included the Mexican head of Interpol and the federal assistant attorney general in charge of Mexico's campaign against drug trafficking.
title: MEXICO SEEKING KILLERS OF 21 POLICEMEN

text: Killings a Setback for Mexico
title: MEXICO SEEKING KILLERS OF 21 POLICEMEN

text: The killings are a setback in Mexico's efforts to control a substantial traffic in illegal drugs destined for the United States.
title: MEXICO SEEKING KILLERS OF 21 POLICEMEN

text: They came a week after a major Mexican drug figure escaped from a jail in Tijuana, on the United States-Mexican border south of San Diego. Jose Contreras Subias was being held in connection with the killing in 1984 of a Mexican federal police officer in an ambush.
title: MEXICO SEEKING KILLERS OF 21 POLICEMEN

text: Mr. Contreras was an associate of Caro Quintero, who is in a Mexico City jail awaiting trial on charges that he kidnapped and killed a United States Drug Enforcement Agency agent and his Mexican pilot in Guadalajara last winter.
title: MEXICO SEEKING KILLERS OF 21 POLICEMEN

text: Diploamtic sources here confirmed that 21 police officers had been killed, including 17 members of the Federal Judicial Police. The sources also confirmed that some of the police were captured and later tortured and killed.
title: MEXICO SEEKING KILLERS OF 21 POLICEMEN

text: According to Mexican officials, the battle between the policemen and the drug smugglers took place near the town of Hidalgotitlan in southern Veracruz near the border with Oaxaca. It is a remote region reachable by launch via a river.
title: MEXICO SEEKING KILLERS OF 21 POLICEMEN

text: It was in this area that the police and Mexican army units from garrisons in Matia Romero in Oaxaca and Minitatlan in Veracruz were concentrating their search.
title: MEXICO SEEKING KILLERS OF 21 POLICEMEN

text: According to Mexican officials and diplomatic sources, the Mexican drug agents surprised a band of drug smugglers taking about six tons of marijuana from trucks to a launch on the Rio Coachapa. A fight ensued.
title: MEXICO SEEKING KILLERS OF 21 POLICEMEN

text: Two policemen escaped. Reporting from Minatitlan, the Mexico City newspaper Excelsior quoted the two survivors as saying that the smugglers collected the bodies of the dead policemen and lined them up along the river bank after the battle. Then they moved back up the river to their camp, taking along the arms and trucks of the police.
title: MEXICO SEEKING KILLERS OF 21 POLICEMEN

text: Mexican officials said the surviving policemen were taken to a farm at the village of Cahuapan near Hidalgotitlan and tortured and killed. Their bodies were later dumped in Cahuapan.
title: MEXICO SEEKING KILLERS OF 21 POLICEMEN

text: Mexico is believed to be the source of 20 percent of the marijuana that reaches the United States, about 2,500 to 3,000 metric tons. Some officials think the number might be higher, in light of the seizure in the state of Chihuahua in the fall of 1984 of nearly 10,000 metric tons of marijuana apparently destined for the United States.
title: MEXICO SEEKING KILLERS OF 21 POLICEMEN

text: Mexico is also believed to be the source for between 18 and 35 percent of the cocaine that reaches the United States and 32 percent of the heroin.
title: MEXICO SEEKING KILLERS OF 21 POLICEMEN

text: The United States Government frequently has urged the Mexican Government to work harder at intervening in the highly lucrative drug traffic.
title: MEXICO SEEKING KILLERS OF 21 POLICEMEN

text: Relations between the two countries regarding illegal drug trafficking reached a critical point last winter when the American drug agent, Enrique Camarena Salazar, and his Mexican pilot were kidnapped off the streets of Guadalajara. Their bodies, showing signs of torture, later were found buried on a ranch.
title: MEXICO SEEKING KILLERS OF 21 POLICEMEN

text: The Reagan Administration reacted angrily and placed heavy restictions on traffic into the United States at border crossings with Mexico.
title: MEXICO SEEKING KILLERS OF 21 POLICEMEN

text: But State Department officials in Washington have said in recent months that the Mexican Government had strengthened its campaign against drug traffic as a result of the agent's killing and the United States reaction.
title: MEXICO SEEKING KILLERS OF 21 POLICEMEN

text: Early elections in the Philippines will be held, President Ferdinand E. Marcos announced. He said that he intended to call for a presidential election in January to settle what he called a ''silly claim'' that his Government is inept. [Page A1, Col.6.]
title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, NOVEMBER 4, 1985

text: A covert plan aimed at weakening the regime of the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, has been approved by President Reagan, according to Congressional sources and Administration officials. [A1:4.]
title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, NOVEMBER 4, 1985

text: 2 French secret agents pleaded guilty at their trial in Auckland, New Zealand, to manslaughter in the July 10 sinking of the Rainbow Warrior, flagship of the Greenpace environmental group, in which a Greenpeace photographer was killed. The reduction of the charge from murder came as a surprise. [A1:5.]
title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, NOVEMBER 4, 1985

text: Nicaragua's rebel leaders are divided by politically damaging disagreements over the objects and tactics of the rebel movement, according to rebel and American officials and Congressional sources. Despite new civilian directors, renewed American financing and advice from the Central Intelligence Agency, the guerrillas have not begun to make the political impact in Nicaragua or abroad that rebel and American officials say they had hoped for. [A1:3.]
title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, NOVEMBER 4, 1985

text: The killers of 21 Mexican policemen were sought by the police and soldiers. Drug smugglers are believed to have slain the policemen when they found a cache of marijuana. [A3:4.]
title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, NOVEMBER 4, 1985

text: A national election in Guatemala brought out voters in large numbers hoping that the new government would be free of military influence. The Christian Democratic candidate for President, Marco Vinicio Cerezo Arevalo, appeared to be running ahead, but election officials doubted any presidential candidate would win the required majority, making a runoff election likely. They said results should be known by Tuesday. [A3:1.]
title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, NOVEMBER 4, 1985

text: Parts of Moscow's arms plan could possibly provide a basis for eventual progress, a senior American official said in a briefing for reporters as Secretary of State George P. Shultz concluded his strategy talks for his meetings in Moscow Monday and Tuesday. The official said that although the United States had rejected last month's Soviet proposals as a whole, it saw ''seeds'' or ''nuggets'' in four ideas introduced by the Russians. He said it was now decided that they needed to be ''nurtured.'' [A1:4.]
title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, NOVEMBER 4, 1985

text: A Soviet soldier who ran into the United States Embassy in Kabul on Thursday and has remained there met with the Soviet Ambassador to Afghanistan and will see him again on Monday, United States officials said. The 19-year-old soldier, who had refused repeated requests for a meeting with the Soviet envoy, changed his mind, the officials said. [A14:1.]
title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, NOVEMBER 4, 1985

text: Some Federal scientists are selling their research on President Reagan's proposed Strategic Defense Initiative with the encouragement of the Reagan Administation. Hundreds of their colleagues are expected to do the same. White House officials strongly defend the practice, which is permitted under law and has grown rapidly since Mr. Reagan took office. [A1:3.]
title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, NOVEMBER 4, 1985

text: The tailored suit's effectiveness in helping women up the corporate ladder is being questioned. One problem: Everybody is wearing a suit because suits are in fashion. [A1:1.] A review of seismic data challenges the scientific basis of accusations by the Reagan Administration that Soviet underground nuclear tests may have violated the Threshold Test Ban Treaty of 1974. The review was made by a panel of scientists chosen by the Defense Department. [A13:1.]
title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, NOVEMBER 4, 1985

text: Bodies of miners killed in a fire at the Wilberg coal mine in Utah last December have been recovered by a team that included government investigators. The first recovery effort brought out the bodies of five of the 27 miners who died. [A16:2.]
title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, NOVEMBER 4, 1985

text: Rules requiring certain hospitals to offer free care to the poor would be eliminated under a change proposed by the Reagan Administration. Officials say the change would eliminate unnecessary administrative burdens imposed on publicly owned and operated facilities. [B6:3.]
title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, NOVEMBER 4, 1985

text: There will be few close races in tomorrow's election. Most will be decided by the dominance of Democrats in New York City and of Republicans in its suburbs. In New York City, where most contests were decided in the Sept. 10 primary, the pre-election weekend was the busiest for Mayor Koch and the other candidates in their seven-week campaign. [A1:2.]
title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, NOVEMBER 4, 1985

text: New Jersey's election will show whether Governor Kean has been successful in his campaign for a second term and in his attempt to gain Republican control of the State Assembly. Opinion polls gave him a comfortable lead over the Essex County Executive, Peter Shapiro, the Democratic challenger. [A1:1.]
title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, NOVEMBER 4, 1985

text: Dr. Irving S. Cooper, one of the world's top brain surgeons, died of cancer Oct. 30 in Naples, Fla. He developed techniques for treating Parkinson's disease and other neurological disorders. Most of his work was accomplished in New York area hospitals. He was 63 years old. [D14:1.] Page D1
title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, NOVEMBER 4, 1985

text: A few years back the Municipal Assembly banned all alcohol sales on this craggy island in the western Pacific.
title: IN MICRONESIA, A GNAWING DOUBT AMID THE PALMS

text: Prohibition has worked about as well as it did in the United States 60 years ago. Now people break the law to drink.
title: IN MICRONESIA, A GNAWING DOUBT AMID THE PALMS

text: Moen's police chief decided he would not even pretend to enforce the rules. His defiance so upset Mayor Fichita Bossy that he opened his own jail for liquor violators. Unfortunately for the Mayor, Truk state officials closed down his operation for sanitation-code infractions.
title: IN MICRONESIA, A GNAWING DOUBT AMID THE PALMS

text: This might be dismissed as mere comedy were it not for the seriousness of alcohol abuse, not only in Truk but throughout the vast, 2,000-island Pacific chain known as Micronesia. From the highest official on down, Micronesians list drinking as one of their most debilitating social problems and the chief cause of nearly all violent crime.
title: IN MICRONESIA, A GNAWING DOUBT AMID THE PALMS

text: Trukese say that Moen's liquor ban has cleared the streets of many drunkards prone to knife fights. But it has also created a new category of lawlessness and has basically failed, they say. Can Aid Be Habit-Forming? Some people then add as a postscript: just like so many other ideas borrowed from the United States.
title: IN MICRONESIA, A GNAWING DOUBT AMID THE PALMS

text: Having spent the last 38 years as an American trust territory, Micronesia is now an assortment of young governments looking for limited political autonomy. The transition process has been arduous, bogged down in disputes with Washington over conditions for home rule.
title: IN MICRONESIA, A GNAWING DOUBT AMID THE PALMS

text: But even if the wrangling vanished overnight, Micronesians agree, with little dissent, that long American rule has failed to prepare them to stand on their own. It is not just that they have come to expect United States aid, totaling more than $110 million a year for about 135,000 people; they are no longer able to survive without it.
title: IN MICRONESIA, A GNAWING DOUBT AMID THE PALMS

text: Stories are similar on most of the 100 or so inhabited islands. Planned fisheries somehow never open. Copra mills open, but quickly close. Chicken-raising projects fail because necessary feed cannot be flown in on time.
title: IN MICRONESIA, A GNAWING DOUBT AMID THE PALMS

text: The only growth industry is politics. The only significant employers are the many national, state and municipal governments, whose budgets consume most of the American aid.
title: IN MICRONESIA, A GNAWING DOUBT AMID THE PALMS

text: At least half the salaried workers throughout Micronesia hold government jobs, which pay far better than the relatively few private sector positions that are available. In a sense, Micronesians say, government employment itself is a form of welfare.
title: IN MICRONESIA, A GNAWING DOUBT AMID THE PALMS

text: ''The Americans have been successful at making us politicians,'' Ignacio Anastacio, a member of the Palauan Congress, said. ''But in terms of giving us economic development, I would give them a big F.''
title: IN MICRONESIA, A GNAWING DOUBT AMID THE PALMS

text: On the island of Ponape, a longtime American resident agreed: ''We just don't make very good colonialists.''
title: IN MICRONESIA, A GNAWING DOUBT AMID THE PALMS

text: A few people look back almost wistfully to the 30 years of Japanese domination that ended with Japan's defeat in World War II. Japanese troops had plans to execute entire island populations, older people recall, but at least they ran thriving sugar-cane plantations and built roads.
title: IN MICRONESIA, A GNAWING DOUBT AMID THE PALMS

text: Some places appear to have given up entirely. Were it not for its palm trees and tranquil lagoon, much of Moen, the main island in the Truk group, could easily be mistaken for the South Bronx.
title: IN MICRONESIA, A GNAWING DOUBT AMID THE PALMS

text: The Old Skills Are Lost
title: IN MICRONESIA, A GNAWING DOUBT AMID THE PALMS

text: Everywhere the walls are covered with graffiti, occasionally obscene. Stores and small buildings lie abandoned. Dozens of rust-eaten cars litter the roadside. A once-vibrant church-affiliated school, Mizpah, has sat empty for a dozen years, gone to tall weeds.
title: IN MICRONESIA, A GNAWING DOUBT AMID THE PALMS

text: What worries both Micronesians and Americans is that a permanent ''dependency mentality'' may have developed. Yet the same people who complain that the United States flooded the islands with welfare programs, starting in the 1960's, also fret that American funds might decline.
title: IN MICRONESIA, A GNAWING DOUBT AMID THE PALMS

text: Micronesians have lost basic skills that enabled them to survive for centuries. They live on lush islands, surrounded by waters thick with tuna, yet they prefer canned fish and fruit brought in from abroad.
title: IN MICRONESIA, A GNAWING DOUBT AMID THE PALMS

text: Exports are negligible. According to a study by the Rev. Francis X. Hezel, a Jesuit priest who has lived in Micronesia for many years, fishermen in Palau hauled in an average of 8.9 million pounds of tuna a year during Japanese rule in the 1930's. The official figure for 1983 was 930,000 pounds. Why Go Fishing? ''People have been taken care of for so many years that they're used to it,'' said Bernard Helgenberger, a Ponapean who is Secretary for Resources and Development in the Federated States of Micronesia, one of four governments within the trust territory.
title: IN MICRONESIA, A GNAWING DOUBT AMID THE PALMS

text: ''For fishing,'' Mr. Helgenberger said, ''you've got to get up at 2 or 3 A.M. and stay out there in the heat and rain all day long. You've got people saying, 'Why do this?' It's easier to eat breadfruit and coconut.''
title: IN MICRONESIA, A GNAWING DOUBT AMID THE PALMS

text: Unhappiness with Micronesia's plight is hardly new. Some Micronesians say that if they could only export the many reports churned out by consultants and analysts over the years, they would enjoy a healthy trade surplus.
title: IN MICRONESIA, A GNAWING DOUBT AMID THE PALMS

text: The trust territory contains the Marshall Islands, Palau, and the Federated States, an association of the Caroline island groups of Truk, Ponape, Yap and Kosrae. A fourth element of the trusteeship, the Northern Mariana Islands, elected in 1976 to become a commonwealth.
title: IN MICRONESIA, A GNAWING DOUBT AMID THE PALMS

text: For the last six years, the non-commonwealth states have formed their own governments. But the trust territory cannot be dissolved until they and Washington settle a long-negotiated arrangement that would continue United States aid in exchange for American military primacy in the region.
title: IN MICRONESIA, A GNAWING DOUBT AMID THE PALMS

text: United States officials do not agree that their stewardship of Micronesia has been as bleak as island leaders say. On Saipan, Janet McCoy, the Trust Territory High Commissioner, points to new airports and communications equipment, and to American-fostered health programs, schools and police training.
title: IN MICRONESIA, A GNAWING DOUBT AMID THE PALMS

text: Equally important, Mrs. McCoy says, is political development. ''It is a feather in our cap,'' she said. ''They all came out as democracies, and there are not many places you can say that about.''
title: IN MICRONESIA, A GNAWING DOUBT AMID THE PALMS

text: But many Micronesians see, instead, few paved roads, unreliable power systems and indoor plumbing that tends to be a wishful thought.
title: IN MICRONESIA, A GNAWING DOUBT AMID THE PALMS

text: Somehow, even the best plans often seem to go wrong.
title: IN MICRONESIA, A GNAWING DOUBT AMID THE PALMS

text: Water mains laid on Ponape sprang leaks, and the only way to locate cracks without tearing up a newly paved road was to hire American specialists in sonar detection. But the experts arrived during a severe drought two years ago, so there was no leaking water to detect.
title: IN MICRONESIA, A GNAWING DOUBT AMID THE PALMS

text: ''Forty years is a long time to take pride in a small thing like a new airport,'' President Lazarus Salii of Palau said. ''What we are recommending is that you give us the money. We will do a better job than you have shown yourself to be capable of.''
title: IN MICRONESIA, A GNAWING DOUBT AMID THE PALMS

text: Drug traffickers in remote southern Mexico ambushed and killed 21 policemen who had found a marijuana cache Friday, torturing some of the officers before shooting them dead, Mexican officials said tonight.
title: 21 MEXICAN POLICE REPORTED SLAIN IN AMBUSH

text: The army sent soldiers to take charge of the site, a settlement in the mountains along the border between the states of Veracruz and Oaxaca, the Veracruz state government said in a release from its press office.
title: 21 MEXICAN POLICE REPORTED SLAIN IN AMBUSH

text: The Mexican Attorney General, Sergio Garcia Ramirez, and Gov. Agustin Acosta Lagunes of Veracruz were meeting in the state capital to oversee the investigation.
title: 21 MEXICAN POLICE REPORTED SLAIN IN AMBUSH

text: Earlier reports said the ambush occurred early Saturday, but the Veracruz government statement said it took place at about 4:30 A.M. Friday. The federal Attorney General's office had earlier identified 17 of the victims as policemen.
title: 21 MEXICAN POLICE REPORTED SLAIN IN AMBUSH

text: However, the Veracruz government statement said all 21 killed were state and federal officers. The statement did not say how word of the killings was received from Cahuapan, a village of 200 families situated on along a river about 90 minutes by boat from the nearest large town.
title: 21 MEXICAN POLICE REPORTED SLAIN IN AMBUSH

text: However, Arturo Reyes Isidoro, spokesman for the Veracruz government, said that two agents had escaped during the ambush and contacted authorities at about 9 A.M. today.
title: 21 MEXICAN POLICE REPORTED SLAIN IN AMBUSH

text: According to the Veracruz government account, the agents of the Federal Judicial Police and the Veracruz state police were patrolling the area for marijuana plantations as part of the federal anti-narcotics campaign, and came upon a load of marijuana that appeared ready for shipment.
title: 21 MEXICAN POLICE REPORTED SLAIN IN AMBUSH

text: The group returned to the site before dawn Friday to collect the marijuana and was fired on by drug traffickers who were waiting in hiding.
title: 21 MEXICAN POLICE REPORTED SLAIN IN AMBUSH

text: Some of the officers were killed immediately, the Veracruz government statement said. It said others were captured and, with their hands bound behind their backs, taken to a nearby ranch where they were tortured and shot.
title: 21 MEXICAN POLICE REPORTED SLAIN IN AMBUSH

text: All of the bodies were later dumped in the village of Cahuapan, the statement said.
title: 21 MEXICAN POLICE REPORTED SLAIN IN AMBUSH

text: Mexican drug agents have said that most of the country's marijuana crop, estimated at 700 tons a year, is grown in the mountains along the Veracruz-Oaxaca border.
title: 21 MEXICAN POLICE REPORTED SLAIN IN AMBUSH

text: Mexico intensified its anti-drug campaign after a United States narcotics agent, Enrique Camarena Salazar, and his pilot were kidnapped in February within a few yards of the United States consulate in Guadalajara and later slain.
title: 21 MEXICAN POLICE REPORTED SLAIN IN AMBUSH

text: A dispatch from the United Nations Oct. 27 on marijuana fields in Belize gave an incorrect site for the sentencing of Eligio Briceno, a former Belizean Cabinet minister, on charges of conspiring to smuggle drugs into the United States. Mr. Briceno was tried in Wilmington, N.C., and sentenced in Raleigh, N.C.
title: CORRECTION

text: Only seven times in the past 50 years has Congress passed a controversial question down to the states in the form of a proposed Constitutional amendment, but the states are increasingly passing various questions and propositions down to their voters. On Tuesday, 53 such issues will be on the ballot for resolution in nine states and the District of Columbia; that compares with 50 ballot propositions in 1983 and 48 in 1981, comparable off-year elections.
title: THE BOUNTIFUL BALLOT

text: These statistics have been compiled by Patrick B. McGuigan, editor of Initiative and Referendum Report, a Washington newsletter.
title: THE BOUNTIFUL BALLOT

text: A good many of this year's propositions involve authorizing spending or borrowing for construction projects, topped by $980 million for water development in Texas. A Maine referendum concerns radioactive waste disposal. One of seven New Jersey questions would permit horseplayers at one track to bet on races at another and watch the outcome on television. Pennsylvanians will decide whether absentee voting should be permitted adherents of a religion when an election falls on their religious holiday.
title: THE BOUNTIFUL BALLOT

text: In addition to the statewide questions, city and county voters will consider hundreds of local ballot propositions.
title: THE BOUNTIFUL BALLOT

text: In Bristol, Conn., and Dover, N.H., they will agree or disagree with the 1973 Supreme Court decision on abortion. In Tucson, Ariz., they will vote on banning smoking in workplaces and restricting it in restaurants.
