In San Francisco, they will decide whether to spend $150,000 in public funds in support of a statewide proposal to decriminalize marijuana.
title: THE BOUNTIFUL BALLOT

text: THE UNFINISHED JOURNEY: America Since World War II. by William H. Chafe. Illustrated. 516pp. New York: Oxford University Press. Cloth, $24.95, Paper, $14.95.
title: MIGHT-HAVE-BEENS

text: William Chafe's vigorous book is another try at imposing coherence on America's last four decades. His narrative get dramatic juice out of familiar data and his grasp of the material is professional - a commendable, and recommendable, combination.
title: MIGHT-HAVE-BEENS

text: Much of ''The Unfinished Journey'' develops by describing what successive Presidents did and did not do - a latter-day Mount Rushmore as pillory, for the net effect is inevitably depressing. Yet, except for bits of amateur psychiatry, the story Mr. Chafe tells proves useful and on the whole not unfair. Eisenhower is allowed sometimes to have shown savvy and balance. Mr. Nixon is credited with the odd seizure of shrewd responsibility. But beyond such individual case histories, cautionary comment is needed.
title: MIGHT-HAVE-BEENS

text: The thematic framework obligatory in such studies is based on ''it-might-have-been'' and goes like this: the sociocultural shakeups that resulted from World War II might have enabled the liberal politics of good will to round out what the New Deal began. The cold war plus minor diversions stifled that. Toward the end of his life John F. Kennedy seemed to put the progressive house in order, and assassination did not interfere with this, for Johnson eagerly took up the torch, But flaws in his temperament, entaglement in Indochina and consequent turmoil diverted liberal energies. Eventually, the emergence of the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr., the Presidential candidacy of Robert F. Kennedy and (marginally) the women's movement promised a troika of seismic disturbances that could produce a site on which to build the liberals' Jerusalem. Assassinations did thwart that.
title: MIGHT-HAVE-BEENS

text: Wisely, the author, a professor of history at Duke Univeristy, does not define his ''liberal.'' The nearest he comes is when he calls Henry Wallace a ''classic liberal.'' which is invidious. What he really has in mind, one surmises, is a cross between Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas and Eleanor Roosevelt.
title: MIGHT-HAVE-BEENS

text: As such scenarios go, this one is recognizable enough. But the full treatment sometimes seems precariously based. The book discusses the World War II migration of blacks to Northern cities and propaganda uses of war-bond campaigns as though they had no World War I precedents. It describes suburban and occupational pressure toward conformity as if the Wall Street of the 1920's had not teemed with prototypes of the Organization Man already well tucked in to Westchester County.
title: MIGHT-HAVE-BEENS

text: In accounting for the liberals' disappointments, the author neglects momentous new departure. Thus the cultural effects of television are more or less convered but television's cataclysmic warping of politics gets only a few by-the-way sentences. Since without television neither John Kennedy nor Ronald Reagan would probably ever have gained the White House, that is like tipping one's hat to the steam engine when discussing the Industrial Revolution. Only one-and-a-quarter sentences for the heart-stopping moment when Moscow came up with an atom bomb and turned the cold war into a dizzily tenuous peace. No comment on the economic, social and physical results of the increasing use of marijuana, and more recently cocaine, by all social groups. Nor on the flood of Latin Americans now peacefully redressing the Mexican War.
title: MIGHT-HAVE-BEENS

text: Some crucial figures are mere walk-ons. Jacqueline Kennedy who, as the focus of Camelot did more than her husband to persuade the media that King Arthur was at the helm, is mentioned only twice. Only two sentences on the Hiss case that was so powerful a catalyst for the national mood. Only a few references to Joseph McCarthy, Hiss's inadvertent collaborator in skewing the political forces in which Mr. Chafe is properly interested.
title: MIGHT-HAVE-BEENS

text: Reviewers should beware of reproaching an author for not having written the book they might wish he had. But the subtitle ''America Since World War II'' is sweepingly inclusive, and such omissions do make one uneasy. Nevertheless, studies such as these, done in good faith by scholars of good will relatively free of re-re-revisionsim,, are valuable in setting the reader to pondering crosslights. That especially applies to the author's admirable accounts of the legal struggle for desegregation; and of Martin Luther King, Robert Kennedy, Eugene McCarthy - and Ronald Reagan as a symbol of what went wrong.
title: MIGHT-HAVE-BEENS

text: By Arthur Bonner, Special To the New York Times
title: AFGHANISTAN'S OTHER FRONT: A WORLD OF DRUGS

text: Soviet soldiers in Afghanistan use drugs extensively, and some Russians sell gasoline, ammunition and stolen guns to support their habits, according to several Russian defectors living with Afghan rebels.
title: AFGHANISTAN'S OTHER FRONT: A WORLD OF DRUGS

text: In addition, several rebel commanders say that they have captured Russians while the soldiers were drugged or while they were trying to buy hashish or heroin from village merchants.
title: AFGHANISTAN'S OTHER FRONT: A WORLD OF DRUGS

text: According to Western diplomats and analysts of the Afghan situation in Pakistan and elsewhere, Russian troops in Afghanistan have turned to drugs for the same reasons that many Americans did in Vietnam: They are young, away from home constraints, bored, frightened and under fierce pressure to prove themselves. And many of the Russian soldiers in Afghanistan are said by the defectors to have a 10th-to-12th-grade education.
title: AFGHANISTAN'S OTHER FRONT: A WORLD OF DRUGS

text: Afghanistan is one of the world's major production centers for opium and its derivatives, according to American narcotics agents in Pakistan and elsewhere in Asia. It is part of the so-called golden crescent extending from Iran to Pakistan and Afghanistan, an area that the agents said accounts for more than half of the world's opium output.
title: AFGHANISTAN'S OTHER FRONT: A WORLD OF DRUGS

text: Afghanistan is also a major producer of marijuana-based drugs like hashish that are consumed throughout South Asia and the Middle East. The profits from these drugs are great; according to the narcotics agents, Afghan hashish can be smuggled out of Pakistan, where it costs $25 a pound, for sale in Saudi Arabia at $1,500 a pound.
title: AFGHANISTAN'S OTHER FRONT: A WORLD OF DRUGS

text: Rahmatullah, a Soviet defector interviewed in Afghanistan who was previously named Aleksei Ivanovich Olenin, discussed the drug situation among Soviet soldiers. He said that at the Soviet base at Qiligai, Afghanistan, where he worked as a truck driver before his defection, ''there are 10,000 Russian soldiers there, and a lot of times they have nothing to do.
title: AFGHANISTAN'S OTHER FRONT: A WORLD OF DRUGS

text: ''Half of them smoke hashish,'' he said. ''The officers get drunk on vodka.''
title: AFGHANISTAN'S OTHER FRONT: A WORLD OF DRUGS

text: ''The soldiers are paid in rubles and never have enough money to even buy cigarettes,'' he said. Referring to the afghani, the Afghan currency, he added that if the Russians ''want to buy from the Afghans, they need afghanis, and so they sell gas and ammunition and anything else they can.''
title: AFGHANISTAN'S OTHER FRONT: A WORLD OF DRUGS

text: Naik Mohammed, another Russian who has defected to the rebels, said in a separate interview, ''That is true.''
title: AFGHANISTAN'S OTHER FRONT: A WORLD OF DRUGS

text: ''They sell gas and ammunition,'' said Mr. Mohammed, who said he was previously known as Gennadi Anatolyevich Tsevma.
title: AFGHANISTAN'S OTHER FRONT: A WORLD OF DRUGS

text: ''They steal guns from a storeroom and sell them,'' he said. ''They use the money to buy hashish.''
title: AFGHANISTAN'S OTHER FRONT: A WORLD OF DRUGS

text: Another report came from Ahmed, a Russian who said he defected from the Soviet base at Abadan and was formerly called Aleksandr Yuryevich Levenets. ''They sell gas and ammunition to get money to buy hashish,'' he said. ''If a soldier is killed, someone would try to steal his rifle to sell it for money for hashish.''
title: AFGHANISTAN'S OTHER FRONT: A WORLD OF DRUGS

text: There are many opium poppy fields in northern Afghanistan. Generally, there are about 50 poppy plants in a small plot mixed with plots of other crops such as tomatoes and okra. Tall marijuana plants grow everywhere.
title: AFGHANISTAN'S OTHER FRONT: A WORLD OF DRUGS

text: The rebels say they are opposed to both alcohol and drugs because the Koran is against them. They say they are fighting a religious war and will do nothing to violate Islamic teachings. When questioned about drug use, rebel commanders refuse to comment other than to say that their men do not use drugs.
title: AFGHANISTAN'S OTHER FRONT: A WORLD OF DRUGS

text: The reason for this appears to be that the commanders do not want to divert attention from fighting the Russians and do not want to do anything that might hurt their relationships with Afghan villagers, on whom they depend for food, shelter and information.
title: AFGHANISTAN'S OTHER FRONT: A WORLD OF DRUGS

text: All rebel sources acknowledge, however, that groups of heavily armed men who travel the same routes they rebels travel may well be smugglers or drug dealers. Drug dealers can roam freely in much of Afghanistan, calling themselves rebels, and can hire bodyguards with Kalashnikovs and horses and camels for transport.
title: AFGHANISTAN'S OTHER FRONT: A WORLD OF DRUGS

text: In traveling with rebel convoys from Pakistan into Afghanistan, armed groups pass each other on trails and will not ask questions; to do so might mark a person as a spy either for the Russians or for some other hostile group.
title: AFGHANISTAN'S OTHER FRONT: A WORLD OF DRUGS

text: Sulfi Finder, a rebel commander in northern Afghanistan, said he had heard many reports of rebels' catching Russians while they were drugged.
title: AFGHANISTAN'S OTHER FRONT: A WORLD OF DRUGS

text: About two years ago, he said, a platoon of Russians was making a sweep through villages, mostly deserted, near a highway. Some rebels from his group were hidden in one of the houses to prepare for an ambush, he said, and ''eight Russians came in looking for food.''
title: AFGHANISTAN'S OTHER FRONT: A WORLD OF DRUGS

text: ''They put their guns in a corner and began smoking hashish,'' Mr. Finder said. ''After a while our men took their guns and captured them. There were so many of them and so many other Russians in the area they could not take them away, so they killed them.''
title: AFGHANISTAN'S OTHER FRONT: A WORLD OF DRUGS

text: Mohammed Salim, a rebel commander in the area of the Qiligai base, recalled the story of one Russian seized by the rebels. He ''would not listen,'' to the rebels, ''and was alway trying to get hashish from the villagers.''
title: AFGHANISTAN'S OTHER FRONT: A WORLD OF DRUGS

text: Mohammed Sabir is a rebel commander at Ghurband, in Parwan Province, about 20 miles west of the Russian base at Pul-i-Mattak and some 50 miles north of Kabul. He was asked what he knew of Russian transactions for hashish. He said he did nothing to discourage such sales because the sales helped demoralize the Russians.
title: AFGHANISTAN'S OTHER FRONT: A WORLD OF DRUGS

text: ''There is a shop near the Pul-i-Mattak base where they go to say they want to buy hashish,'' he said.
title: AFGHANISTAN'S OTHER FRONT: A WORLD OF DRUGS

text: Young boys make the exchange, he said, because the Russians feel it is safer to deal with them than with adults. ''One boy has done this so often he has learned some Russian,'' he said.
title: AFGHANISTAN'S OTHER FRONT: A WORLD OF DRUGS

text: In another incident, Mr. Finder said, ''We captured a Russian near Kenjan who was wandering around out of his mind because of hashish.''
title: AFGHANISTAN'S OTHER FRONT: A WORLD OF DRUGS

text: Mr. Finder said he had made an arrangement with sympathetic shopkeepers in the area that if Russians come to them seeking to buy hashish, the shopkeepers would tell him.
title: AFGHANISTAN'S OTHER FRONT: A WORLD OF DRUGS

text: ''About nine or ten months ago,'' he went on, ''a Russian who could speak some Persian asked for heroin. He was sent to one of our men.''
title: AFGHANISTAN'S OTHER FRONT: A WORLD OF DRUGS

text: This man, Mr. Finder said, did not wear a beard like the rebels and looked like an ordinary person in the bazaar, although he had a pistol under his shirt.
title: AFGHANISTAN'S OTHER FRONT: A WORLD OF DRUGS

text: He told the Russian that the heroin could be obtained in another village, and the two got into a truck.
title: AFGHANISTAN'S OTHER FRONT: A WORLD OF DRUGS

text: The rebel ''tried to take out his pistol to capture the Russian, but the Russian fought him,'' Mr. Finder said. ''Other mujahedeen came and pulled the Russian to the ground. They took his Kalashnikov and pointed it at him.
title: AFGHANISTAN'S OTHER FRONT: A WORLD OF DRUGS

text: ''He shouted: 'Why are you doing this? I am your friend.' They shot and killed him right there and left his body for the Russians to find.''
title: AFGHANISTAN'S OTHER FRONT: A WORLD OF DRUGS

text: More recently, Mr. Finder said, a Russian officer asked for heroin in the bazaar. ''We decided we would capture him alive to use in exchange for some of our men who had been taken prisoner,'' he said.
title: AFGHANISTAN'S OTHER FRONT: A WORLD OF DRUGS

text: But the Russian became suspicious and reached for his gun, Mr. Finder said, and the rebels shot him dead.
title: AFGHANISTAN'S OTHER FRONT: A WORLD OF DRUGS

text: A former prosecutor with the New England Organized Crime Strike Force was indicted today on charges of selling information to drug dealers about investigative plans and pending indictments.
title: EX-U.S. PROSECUTOR INDICTED

text: According to the indictment filed in Federal District Court, the suspect, David P. Twomey of Westwood, now is in private law practice, received at least $200,000 for information he gave a convicted drug dealer.
title: EX-U.S. PROSECUTOR INDICTED

text: Mr. Twomey was not at his law office and could not be reached immediately for comment. William Weld, a Federal prosecutor, could not immediately be reached to discuss whether Mr. Twomey had been taken into custody.
title: EX-U.S. PROSECUTOR INDICTED

text: Mr. Twomey, who joined the Federal Attorney's office as an assistant prosecutor in the 1970's and for three years served as a special attorney on the organized crime project, was accused of six counts of conspiracy and bribery. Conviction on a bribery charge, the most serious, could be punished by up to 15 years in prison and a $20,000 fine.
title: EX-U.S. PROSECUTOR INDICTED

text: According to the indictment, Mr. Twomey received the money from Frank Lepere, who recently pleaded guilty to smuggling 145 tons of marijuana into the United States. Mr. Lepere gave the Federal Government much of the information that led to the indictment, according to the document.
title: EX-U.S. PROSECUTOR INDICTED

text: The Federal Government said that Mr. Twomey gave the drug dealers information ''concerning the identity of cooperating Government informants; the locations of telephones on which wiretaps had been installed; the nature of evidence being provided to the Government; the status of ongoing grand jury investigations; the likelihood and date of secret indictments brought against criminal defendants; and the places where and the means by which Federal agents were conducting investigations.''
title: EX-U.S. PROSECUTOR INDICTED

text: A Chinese gang leader who is serving a life term in Taiwan for killing a Chinese-American writer in San Francisco helped direct a New York drug deal from prison last month, according to the Federal Bureau of Investigation.
title: IMPRISONED TAIWAN GANG LEADER IS LINKED TO NEW YORK DRUGS DEAL

text: The allegation against the prisoner, Chen Chi-li, the head of the United Bamboo gang, has been denied by the Taiwanese. It was contained in an affidavit filed by an F.B.I agent in the indictment of 10 Asians in New York on racketeering charges. According to the affidavit, Mr. Chen approved a deal to import 660 pounds of heroin, as well as an attempt to buy a casino in Las Vegas, and was to benefit from both the transactions.
title: IMPRISONED TAIWAN GANG LEADER IS LINKED TO NEW YORK DRUGS DEAL

text: The affidavit, which is said to be based on taped conversations between gang members and undercover officers, does not explain how Mr. Chen could have given permission from a jail cell in Taiwan. Taiwan is under martial law and prisoners are normally strictly guarded.
title: IMPRISONED TAIWAN GANG LEADER IS LINKED TO NEW YORK DRUGS DEAL

text: But Anne T. Vitale, the Assistant United States Attorney in Manhattan in charge of the case, said it was correct to conclude that the Federal Government believed the 41-year-old Mr. Chen had participated from jail.
title: IMPRISONED TAIWAN GANG LEADER IS LINKED TO NEW YORK DRUGS DEAL

text: If the charges are correct, they raise new questions about relations between the gang and Taipei, particularly Taipei's involvement in the murder of the writer Henry Liu. Mr. Liu, who was shot to death in the garage of his home in California Oct. 15, 1984, had written a critical biography of Taiwan's President, Chiang Ching-kuo.
title: IMPRISONED TAIWAN GANG LEADER IS LINKED TO NEW YORK DRUGS DEAL

text: ''If the affidavit is accurate, it is a deeply disturbing development that could have grave consequences for Taiwan-U.S. relations,'' said Representative Stephen J. Solarz, a Brooklyn Democrat who is chairman of the House Subcommittee on Asian and Pacific Affairs.
title: IMPRISONED TAIWAN GANG LEADER IS LINKED TO NEW YORK DRUGS DEAL

text: ''It suggests the authorities on Taiwan have moved from complicity in efforts to intimidate and even kill an American to efforts to poison the American people with narcotics,'' Mr. Solarz said. ''The ordinary prisoner in Taiwan doesn't have access to a telephone. It is inconceivable that the authorities on Taiwan were not listening in to any conversation Chen had.''
title: IMPRISONED TAIWAN GANG LEADER IS LINKED TO NEW YORK DRUGS DEAL

text: An official of the Coordination Council for North American Affairs, Taiwan's unofficial mission in the United States, said in reply to questions that Mr. Chen was being held at a major prison operated by the Ministry of Justice in a suburb of Taipei. ''It is highly impossible,'' the official said, that Mr. Chen could be involved in a drug deal in New York.
title: IMPRISONED TAIWAN GANG LEADER IS LINKED TO NEW YORK DRUGS DEAL

text: Another Chinese knowledgeable about the Bamboo gang said he believed Mr. Chen had communicated with gang members in the United States through his wife, who has visited him in prison. The source asserted that many gang members, in a traditional Chinese way, still feel a strong sense of obligation to Mr. Chen as their leader.
title: IMPRISONED TAIWAN GANG LEADER IS LINKED TO NEW YORK DRUGS DEAL

text: Mr. Liu's death frightened many Asian-Americans, who said it was a terrorist act by a foreign government on United States soil. At a memorial service in San Francisco on the recent first anniversary of the death, Representative Norman Y. Mineta, Democrat of California, charged that the Reagan Administration was reluctant to pursue the case, contrasting it with Washington's reaction to terrorism in the Middle East.
title: IMPRISONED TAIWAN GANG LEADER IS LINKED TO NEW YORK DRUGS DEAL

text: After Mr. Liu's death, Mr. Chen and another Bamboo gang leader fled to Taiwan where they were later convicted and sentenced to life in prison for the murder. But Mr. Chen left a taped confession in California that accused the head of the Military Intelligence Agency in Taiwan's Defense Ministry, Adm. Weng Hsi-ling, of directing the murder.
title: IMPRISONED TAIWAN GANG LEADER IS LINKED TO NEW YORK DRUGS DEAL

text: After gang members in the United States turned the tape over to the F.B.I., Taiwan arrested Admiral Weng, a former aide to the late Chiang Kai-shek, and then sentenced him to life in prison also.
title: IMPRISONED TAIWAN GANG LEADER IS LINKED TO NEW YORK DRUGS DEAL

text: But in the hurried trials, in which few witnesses were called and little evidence was introduced, it was not clear whether Admiral Weng had planned the murder himself or had been acting under orders from a more senior official. Taiwan has refused to extradite any of the men to the United States.
title: IMPRISONED TAIWAN GANG LEADER IS LINKED TO NEW YORK DRUGS DEAL

text: Widow Sues for $250 Million
title: IMPRISONED TAIWAN GANG LEADER IS LINKED TO NEW YORK DRUGS DEAL

text: Earlier this month, Mr. Liu's widow, Helen Liu, filed a $250 million lawsuit against the Chinese Nationalist Government on Taiwan and the convicted men, charging them with murder, racketeering and deprivation of civil rights.
title: IMPRISONED TAIWAN GANG LEADER IS LINKED TO NEW YORK DRUGS DEAL

text: In the suit, filed in Federal District Court in San Francisco, Mrs. Liu contended that the killing was part of a ''terrorist conspiracy'' to intimidate critics of the Nationalists.
title: IMPRISONED TAIWAN GANG LEADER IS LINKED TO NEW YORK DRUGS DEAL

text: Drawing on Mr. Chen's taped confession and the scant evidence at the trials, the suit said President Chiang's brother, Gen. Chiang Wego, a senior Defense Ministry official, attended a meeting with Mr. Chen and Admiral Weng in July 1984, three months before Mr. Liu was killed. At the meeting the men discussed ''plans for representatives'' of the Bamboo gang ''to engage in illegal activities in the United States'' on behalf of the Nationalist Government.
title: IMPRISONED TAIWAN GANG LEADER IS LINKED TO NEW YORK DRUGS DEAL

text: One of President Chiang's sons, Chiang Hsiao-wu, who is 40 years old, holds an important though not publicly acknowledged post in Taiwan's intelligence apparatus and was also a close friend of Mr. Chen, according to accounts in Chinese newspapers in the United States. The younger Mr. Chiang, however, has denied any connection with the murder.
title: IMPRISONED TAIWAN GANG LEADER IS LINKED TO NEW YORK DRUGS DEAL

text: Under Mr. Chen's leadership, the Bamboo gang grew rapidly in the late 1970's from a local teen-age street group to an international organization with 40,000 members in Taiwan, Hong Kong, the Philippines, Japan, Saudi Arabia and the United States, according to former members now living in the United States and the F.B.I. affidavit. Because many of its members were the sons of Nationalist officials who fled to Taiwan from the mainland in 1949 with Chiang Kai-shek, the gang operated with relative impunity, combining extortion, gambling and prostitution with some legitimate businesses such as a gossip magazine and a recording company, the former members report. A number of prominent movie actors and directors also joined the organization.
title: IMPRISONED TAIWAN GANG LEADER IS LINKED TO NEW YORK DRUGS DEAL

text: U.S. Aide Speculates on Case
title: IMPRISONED TAIWAN GANG LEADER IS LINKED TO NEW YORK DRUGS DEAL

text: An American Government official familiar with the indictment of the 10 Bamboo gang members in New York said they were expected to contend that their plans to import heroin, cocaine and marijuana to New York and buy a casino in Las Vegas were at the behest of officials on Taiwan, as in the murder of Mr. Liu. The American official said the men might argue that they were raising funds for Taiwan's intelligence work against the Chinese Communists in the United States.
title: IMPRISONED TAIWAN GANG LEADER IS LINKED TO NEW YORK DRUGS DEAL

text: Mr. Chen was named an unindicted co-conspirator in the New York case.
title: IMPRISONED TAIWAN GANG LEADER IS LINKED TO NEW YORK DRUGS DEAL

text: A potential key witness to both the murder and the New York case, Tung Kuei-sen, was arrested last month in Brazil at the request of Washington after he was charged in the New York complaint. Mr. Tung, who the authorities in California say actually shot Mr. Liu, also returned to Taiwan last year after the murder but fled before he could be arrested and was rumored to be in the Philippines.
title: IMPRISONED TAIWAN GANG LEADER IS LINKED TO NEW YORK DRUGS DEAL

text: The State Department has begun the formal process of seeking his extradition. One of the many unresolved questions is why, if the F.B.I. knew he was in Brazil, did not the Federal Government press for his arrest on the murder charge sooner.
title: IMPRISONED TAIWAN GANG LEADER IS LINKED TO NEW YORK DRUGS DEAL

text: The F.B.I affidavit asserts that on Aug. 20, a gang member in Houston, Chen Chih-yi, known as Yellow Bird, called Mr. Tung and directed him to arrange for the importing of 660 pounds of heroin from a gang contact in Thailand. On Sept. 14 Yellow Bird and two other gang members met with F.B.I. and New York City police undercover agents to discuss purchasing the heroin, the affidavit says.
title: IMPRISONED TAIWAN GANG LEADER IS LINKED TO NEW YORK DRUGS DEAL

text: The next day, according to the affidavit, Yellow Bird told the undercover agents ''that Chen Chi-li had approved of the narcotics transaction and was to benefit from it.''
title: IMPRISONED TAIWAN GANG LEADER IS LINKED TO NEW YORK DRUGS DEAL

text: The scene was disturbingly familiar: United States marines in battle gear with camouflage blacking on their faces, moving along a jungle trail and carrying M-16 rifles.
title: U.S. WORRIES ABOUT SECURITY OF 2 BASES IN PHILIPPINES

text: It was a routine patrol within the perimeter of this vast base, with no enemy and no war. But the symbolism did not escape the soldiers themselves.
title: U.S. WORRIES ABOUT SECURITY OF 2 BASES IN PHILIPPINES

text: ''Charlie's out there somewhere,'' one of them joked, using the terminology of the Vietnam War.
title: U.S. WORRIES ABOUT SECURITY OF 2 BASES IN PHILIPPINES

text: With increasing anxiety in Washington about the stability of the Philippine Government, and plans under way to invest $1.3 billion to upgrade America's two big bases here, the long-term security of the installations has become a growing issue.
title: U.S. WORRIES ABOUT SECURITY OF 2 BASES IN PHILIPPINES

text: Two recent intelligence studies for Congress have warned that the political and military situation in the Philippines is deteriorating, adding to concern about the future of the bases, Subic Bay Naval Base and Clark Air Base.
title: U.S. WORRIES ABOUT SECURITY OF 2 BASES IN PHILIPPINES

text: Assistant Secretary of Defense Richard L. Armitage has estimated that if present trends in the Philippines continue, the Communist insurgency could reach a ''strategic stalemate'' with the armed forces in three to five years.
title: U.S. WORRIES ABOUT SECURITY OF 2 BASES IN PHILIPPINES

text: As an indication of the Administration's concern about the situation in the Philippines, President Reagan sent a personal envoy, Senator Paul Laxalt, on an informal diplomatic mission here recently. Senator Laxalt met with President Marcos and later said he had agreed to permit American observers at the Philippine election in 1986 and 1987 and to relax his controls over the Philippine military.
title: U.S. WORRIES ABOUT SECURITY OF 2 BASES IN PHILIPPINES

text: ''We now have a base line from which future reforms can be assessed,'' said Mr. Laxalt, a Nevada Republican.
title: U.S. WORRIES ABOUT SECURITY OF 2 BASES IN PHILIPPINES

text: An agreement allowing the United States to use the two bases in the Philippines expires in 1991, and negotiations to renew the pact are expected to begin before then.
title: U.S. WORRIES ABOUT SECURITY OF 2 BASES IN PHILIPPINES

text: American officials say categorically that there are no plans to move the bases. But they have also been talking publicly about contingency plans for a move, which they say are a normal part of military analysis.
title: U.S. WORRIES ABOUT SECURITY OF 2 BASES IN PHILIPPINES

text: It is a move that Philippine opponents of President Marcos are increasingly demanding. Even Mr. Marcos's Government is finding it politically expedient these days to make disparaging remarks about the bases. But it is a move would pose severe difficulties for the Americans.
title: U.S. WORRIES ABOUT SECURITY OF 2 BASES IN PHILIPPINES

text: In their strategic location, in the facilities they are able to provide, and in the economy of their operation, Subic Bay and Clark Air Base are acknowledged by American officials to be irreplaceable.
title: U.S. WORRIES ABOUT SECURITY OF 2 BASES IN PHILIPPINES

text: Estimates of the cost of moving them, if the need arises, have ranged from $2 billion to $8 billion.
title: U.S. WORRIES ABOUT SECURITY OF 2 BASES IN PHILIPPINES

text: Analysts say it is probable that no one site could duplicate the complex of services the two bases provide, and therefore it is likely that some operations would be scattered among more than one location.
title: U.S. WORRIES ABOUT SECURITY OF 2 BASES IN PHILIPPINES

text: The alternative sites usually mentioned are the Pacific islands of Guam, where the United States now has a smaller base, and Tinian. Both are in the Marianas.
title: U.S. WORRIES ABOUT SECURITY OF 2 BASES IN PHILIPPINES

text: Subic Bay Naval Base, which covers 450 square miles of land and ocean in one of the world's great natural harbors, and Clark Air Base, with a 150,000-acre target range that is unmatched in any other overseas facility, are the biggest American bases of their kind outside United States territory.
title: U.S. WORRIES ABOUT SECURITY OF 2 BASES IN PHILIPPINES

text: They are strategically placed on air and sea routes to control and supply a broad sweep of Asia, from the American base at Diego Garcia in the Indian Ocean through the vital Strait of Malacca into the South China Sea and the Pacific.
title: U.S. WORRIES ABOUT SECURITY OF 2 BASES IN PHILIPPINES

text: They guard what the military calls ''choke points'' for one-half of the oil supplies that travel from the Persian Gulf to Western markets.
title: U.S. WORRIES ABOUT SECURITY OF 2 BASES IN PHILIPPINES

text: Just 70 minutes by jet fighter from the huge Soviet base at Cam Ranh Bay in Vietnam, the bases in the Philippines have grown in strategic importance as the Soviet naval presence in the Pacific has grown.
title: U.S. WORRIES ABOUT SECURITY OF 2 BASES IN PHILIPPINES

text: No alternative site offers either strategic location or natural facilities that would come near to duplicating the advantages of the two bases, American officials say.
title: U.S. WORRIES ABOUT SECURITY OF 2 BASES IN PHILIPPINES

text: Relocation to Guam and Tinian, which lie more than 1,500 miles east of the Philippines, would move the key American centers some three to four hours' flying time, or several days' sailing time, farther from the vital areas they defend.
title: U.S. WORRIES ABOUT SECURITY OF 2 BASES IN PHILIPPINES

text: Military officers say such a move would give the Russians geographical dominance over the sea lanes from the Indian Ocean to the Pacific.
title: U.S. WORRIES ABOUT SECURITY OF 2 BASES IN PHILIPPINES

text: It would also mean the loss of a skilled and inexpensive work force that could not be found on small Pacific islands.
title: U.S. WORRIES ABOUT SECURITY OF 2 BASES IN PHILIPPINES

text: The two bases employ 44,000 local workers, many of them experienced tradesmen whose families have worked in specialties such as ship repair for generations. That many workers would equal half the population of Guam and more than the total population of Tinian.
title: U.S. WORRIES ABOUT SECURITY OF 2 BASES IN PHILIPPINES

text: The wages now paid are estimated to be about one-seventh of what Americans would receive if they were needed to replace the Filipinos. Some of the Filipinos, for example the Negrito tribesmen who build bamboo models of airplanes for Clark's target range, are paid in rice.
title: U.S. WORRIES ABOUT SECURITY OF 2 BASES IN PHILIPPINES

text: On the naval base, where an average of 9,000 sailors come ashore each day, a move seems far away.
title: U.S. WORRIES ABOUT SECURITY OF 2 BASES IN PHILIPPINES

text: The base bustles with activity, in its 200 acres of warehouses, along its runways and roads, and in some of the most lavish recreational sites the American military offers. There are auto hobby shops and sites for horseback riding and skeet shooting.
title: U.S. WORRIES ABOUT SECURITY OF 2 BASES IN PHILIPPINES

text: Western diplomats here suggest that with the attention that has now been aroused over the future of the bases, it would be politically difficult for the United States to draw back from plans to improve them.
title: U.S. WORRIES ABOUT SECURITY OF 2 BASES IN PHILIPPINES

text: Any move such as a public search for alternative sites, they say, would shake confidence in America's commitment to the bases and would further complicate its political difficulties.
title: U.S. WORRIES ABOUT SECURITY OF 2 BASES IN PHILIPPINES

text: These difficulties, which include recent suggestions by the Government that the Philippines could live very well without the bases, may in part be preliminary maneuvering over the renewal of the bases agreement.
title: U.S. WORRIES ABOUT SECURITY OF 2 BASES IN PHILIPPINES

text: Under the current five-year contract, which was signed in 1983, the United States is required to pay $900 million as compensation for use of the bases, about half of it in military aid and half in economic assistance.
title: U.S. WORRIES ABOUT SECURITY OF 2 BASES IN PHILIPPINES

text: The Marcos Government is expected to demand a large increase in this sum under any new agreement.
title: U.S. WORRIES ABOUT SECURITY OF 2 BASES IN PHILIPPINES

text: The $1.3 billion that the Pentagon has earmarked for improvements would go primarily into upgrading the physical plant, including the runways and housing. But Major Thomas J. Boyd, public affairs director for Clark Air Base, said security improvements would also be included.
title: U.S. WORRIES ABOUT SECURITY OF 2 BASES IN PHILIPPINES

text: These improvements would presumably address serious breaches reported last month by a delegation from a Senate subcommittee. It found empty guard towers and missing fencing around much of the perimeter of Clark, which, like Subic Bay, is patrolled by the Philippine military.
title: U.S. WORRIES ABOUT SECURITY OF 2 BASES IN PHILIPPINES

text: Most dramatically, the subcommittee reported evidence of Communist guerrilla presence within the perimeter of the Subic installation, which includes miles of fields and hilly jungle that are used for gunnery practice and training exercises.
title: U.S. WORRIES ABOUT SECURITY OF 2 BASES IN PHILIPPINES

text: The subcommittee report found the signs of guerrilla presence in these outer parts of the base ''nothing short of incredible.''
title: U.S. WORRIES ABOUT SECURITY OF 2 BASES IN PHILIPPINES

text: The potential for a clash between guerrilla groups and the American marines who tramp the jungle trails with their M-16 rifles, the report said, ''is all too apparent.''
title: U.S. WORRIES ABOUT SECURITY OF 2 BASES IN PHILIPPINES

text: By David Pitt, Special To the New York Times
title: BELIZE WARILY CONSIDERS MARIJUANA HERBICIDE

text: The leader of the Central American nation of Belize said today that he was ready to accede to United States wishes to resume aerial spraying of his tiny country's vast marijuana fields, but only if it posed no environmental hazard.
title: BELIZE WARILY CONSIDERS MARIJUANA HERBICIDE

text: Aerial spraying of paraquat, a herbicide that can produce severe lung damage in humans, was suspended by Belize after 1983, when the herbicide's environmental hazards became a political issue in national elections, the first since the former British Honduras became independent in 1981.
title: BELIZE WARILY CONSIDERS MARIJUANA HERBICIDE

text: ''While we share the American concern about the drug problem, because it is our problem as well, we feel that we have an obligation to proceed responsibly,'' Prime Minister Manuel Esquivel said in an interview at the Belizean Mission. ''If you say that aerial eradication is the only efficient way to do it, O.K. We just want to make sure that whatever we do will not be to our detriment.''
title: BELIZE WARILY CONSIDERS MARIJUANA HERBICIDE

text: United States officials have said that Belize, an economically battered nation of fewer than 160,000 people, is the most important narcotics trafficking center in Central America and the fourth largest supplier of marijuana to the United States, after Colombia, Mexico and Jamaica. Authorities say about 85 percent of each year's crop is smuggled to the United States, much of it aboard small planes flown from clandestine airstrips.
title: BELIZE WARILY CONSIDERS MARIJUANA HERBICIDE

text: Mr. Esquivel said paraquat spraying in 1983 had been ''very successful,'' eradicating more than 80 percent of the 700 tons of marijuana grown that year. But he said he had ''serious reservations'' about paraquat's safety.
title: BELIZE WARILY CONSIDERS MARIJUANA HERBICIDE

text: The Prime Minister said the Drug Enforcement Administration recently proposed that Belize try an alternative herbicide, glyphosate, which D.E.A. officials have said is less risky to the environment. The Prime Minister said he told United States officials that Belize wanted to run its own tests on glyphosate first.
title: BELIZE WARILY CONSIDERS MARIJUANA HERBICIDE

text: ''For example,'' Mr. Esquivel said, ''we have a growing honeybee industry, and it is felt that if we were to spray paraquat over a wide area, particularly in the north, where we have a lot of honeybees, that we run the risk of destroying that industry. We're told that glyphosate in tests has not affected honeybees. Well, we'll see.''
title: BELIZE WARILY CONSIDERS MARIJUANA HERBICIDE

text: The Prime Minister said that since January, the country's 500-member police force had destroyed more than 80,000 marijuana plants and 7,000 pounds of harvested marijuana. In the same period, he said, 375 people, from the United States as well as Belize, were arrested for drug trafficking, and 288 were convicted.
title: BELIZE WARILY CONSIDERS MARIJUANA HERBICIDE

text: ''We also confiscated four U.S.-registered aircraft and 10 motor vehicles,'' Mr. Esquivel said. ''In fact,'' he added with a laugh, ''most of my ministers drive around'' in vehicles confiscated from marijuana dealers.
title: BELIZE WARILY CONSIDERS MARIJUANA HERBICIDE

text: Mr. Esquivel said an ''alarming'' side effect of the marijuana industry was growing use of cocaine among Belizeans.
title: BELIZE WARILY CONSIDERS MARIJUANA HERBICIDE

text: Mr. Esquivel said that, with help from a private United States group financed by the Agency for International Development, he had embarked on a ''massive public education campaign'' to try to make Belizeans more aware of the dangers of marijuana trafficking.
title: BELIZE WARILY CONSIDERS MARIJUANA HERBICIDE

text: ''I have been trying to drive home the concept that this business, aside from its social effects, is politically very dangerous,'' Mr. Esquivel said. ''If we allow this to continue, we could lose our Government - our independence.''
title: BELIZE WARILY CONSIDERS MARIJUANA HERBICIDE

text: Last month, Eligio Briceno,a former Cabinet official in the left-of-center Government defeated last December by Mr. Esquivel's conservative party, was sentenced in Miami to seven years in prison for conspiring to smuggle more than 1,000 pounds of marijuana and cocaine into the United States.
title: BELIZE WARILY CONSIDERS MARIJUANA HERBICIDE

text: ''As the case with Mr. Briceno shows,'' the Prime Minister said, ''you will always reach a stage where it becomes necessary for the people in the United States or Colombia or wherever to feel that they need to influence the Government. And to a large extent, they certainly have influenced Belize already.''
title: BELIZE WARILY CONSIDERS MARIJUANA HERBICIDE

text: In 1948, Tony Tarracino elected to go to Florida for his health. The risk to his health was the strong arm of some hoods in Elizabeth, N.J., who had decided that Mr. Tarracino's bets with them on horses were costing them too much money.
title: 'OLD PIRATE' TAKES A POLITICAL PLUNGE

text: The bookmakers' pursuit carried some resentment after they discovered that Mr. Tarracino had devised a system of getting the race results from faraway tracks before the information was put on the sports betting wire.
title: 'OLD PIRATE' TAKES A POLITICAL PLUNGE

text: ''I was betting horses that already had won,'' said Mr. Tarracino with a deep growl of a chuckle, twisting his weathered face in a crinkled smile that seems to invite the listener to decide whether the story was true.
title: 'OLD PIRATE' TAKES A POLITICAL PLUNGE

text: More improbable than the story is the fact that Captain Tony, as he has been known since his days as a fishing boat skipper, has got himself in the middle of a new horse race. Ribald raconteur and now proprietor of Key West's best-known saloon after Sloppy Joe's, this whisky-drinking, Lucky Strike-smoking father of 13 children, with one more on the way at the age of 69, has emerged as a strong contender in the Key West Mayoral race.
title: 'OLD PIRATE' TAKES A POLITICAL PLUNGE

text: The bizarre has become commonplace in this old pirates' haven, which has gone from rum-running to drug smuggling and from a casual beer-stained seediness to a rebirth of its 19th-century architectural splendor. This week, thousands of costumed revelers have added to the unrestrained atmosphere in Key West's seventh annual around-the-clock Halloween celebration, the ''Fantasy Fest.''
title: 'OLD PIRATE' TAKES A POLITICAL PLUNGE

text: Like the old wooden clapboard houses that have been rescued from decay by wealthy outsiders who admired their charm, Captain Tony himself is being viewed in a new light by very respectable people who see behind his deck-hand's vocabulary and barroom squint a decent and upright man.
title: 'OLD PIRATE' TAKES A POLITICAL PLUNGE

text: ''I'm going to vote for him,'' said Molly Wylly, who moved to Key West from New York City, where she owned an art gallery. ''He's a kind, lovable old pirate, and an honest one to boot.''
title: 'OLD PIRATE' TAKES A POLITICAL PLUNGE

text: As for himself, Captain Tony harbors no doubts.
title: 'OLD PIRATE' TAKES A POLITICAL PLUNGE

text: ''I can't miss,'' he declared as he held forth on the first barstool just inside the doorway at Capt. Tony's Saloon. ''I'll be the greatest ambassador this city has ever had. I'll bring in another $10 million tourist-wise just being me.''
title: 'OLD PIRATE' TAKES A POLITICAL PLUNGE

text: In the wake of a series of problems, Key West could use a restorative.
title: 'OLD PIRATE' TAKES A POLITICAL PLUNGE

text: The AIDS scare, with more than 30 cases of acquired immune deficiency syndrome reported in the island's large homosexual population, has put a strain on tourism, a major element in the island's economy.
title: 'OLD PIRATE' TAKES A POLITICAL PLUNGE

text: Organizers of the four-day festival have worked hard to increase tourism before the winter season gets under way, and the Fest has been toned down and cleaned up enough to be billed as suitable for families.
title: 'OLD PIRATE' TAKES A POLITICAL PLUNGE

text: ''They've taken all the horror out of Halloween and gone for the glitz,'' lamented a three-headed man, Mark Cline of Natural Bridge, Va., who motorcycled down for the weekend wearing his costume and drawing more than a few curious stares on I-95.
title: 'OLD PIRATE' TAKES A POLITICAL PLUNGE

text: Mayor Richard Heyman was out of town for the weekend, attending the funeral of a friend in Ohio. Mr. Heyman, a homosexual who owns a Key West art gallery, has been credited with changing the tone of Key West politics, shifting power from the native islanders to the newcomers.
title: 'OLD PIRATE' TAKES A POLITICAL PLUNGE

text: Until recently, the natives, who are known as Conchs after the hardshell mollusk that inhabits local waters, ran the 28,000-resident island like a political clubhouse, Mr. Heyman said in a telephone interview. The leadership was known as ''the Bubbas,'' a heavily accented regionalism for ''the brothers.''
title: 'OLD PIRATE' TAKES A POLITICAL PLUNGE

text: Drug money and other forms of corruption brought the Bubbas hard times. One of the best known was a fire chief who raced around in red clothes and rose-tinted glasses until he was convicted for dealing in cocaine and marijuana. Before beginning a jail term, he mysteriously disappeared.
title: 'OLD PIRATE' TAKES A POLITICAL PLUNGE

text: A former city attorney has served a prison sentence for conspiracy to smuggle marijuana, a former county attorney was convicted in a drug bribery case, and his wife, a former Mayoral candidate, was convicted of selling cocaine.
title: 'OLD PIRATE' TAKES A POLITICAL PLUNGE

text: More recently, the city's deputy police chief went to prison after he was convicted of protecting drug smugglers, and a police lieutenant and sergeant were convicted of drug smuggling.
title: 'OLD PIRATE' TAKES A POLITICAL PLUNGE

text: The major opposition in the Mayor's race comes from a local banker named Tom Sawyer, 37 years old, and Steve McDaniel, Key West Redevelopment Agency chief. Mayor Heyman, who decided not to seek another two-year term, has not endorsed any of the candidates.
title: 'OLD PIRATE' TAKES A POLITICAL PLUNGE

text: Captain Tony's campaign slogan is ''Fighting for the Future,'' based on his pledge to lower taxes and not let big-money interests push the working people off the island.
title: 'OLD PIRATE' TAKES A POLITICAL PLUNGE

text: ''Right now they've got 4,000 more luxury condos on the drawing boards and they can't find any labor to build them because working people can't afford to live in Key West anymore,'' he rumbled.
title: 'OLD PIRATE' TAKES A POLITICAL PLUNGE

text: As Captain Tony outlined his views, he was interrupted by a tall, rubicund man dressed as a 19th-century undertaker and a woman dressed in a nurse's uniform, who popped in the front door and embraced the candidate. ''I am Dr. Seltzer from Myrtle Beach, South Carolina, and I am here to proclaim my support for Captain Tony,'' he announced to the bar patrons, who noted his appeareance with a lift of head or rolling of eye.
title: 'OLD PIRATE' TAKES A POLITICAL PLUNGE

text: ''Captain Tony won't go around illegalizing anything that's fun,'' the red-faced man boomed. ''His motto should be if it's fun once, it'll be fun again! Isn't that right, nurse?''
title: 'OLD PIRATE' TAKES A POLITICAL PLUNGE

text: As the nurse tittered Captain Tony shook his head with a twinkle of amusement. ''I love my bar,'' he said. ''It's the best preparation for higher office.''
title: 'OLD PIRATE' TAKES A POLITICAL PLUNGE

text: RICHARD HAMILTON is forever in art history books as the father of British pop art, which many contend preceded the American version. In America, not much is known of Mr. Hamilton's doings since. The current exhibition at the Yale Art Gallery, an exhilerating retrospective of his prints from 1952 to 1982 called ''Image and Process,'' brings us up to date.
title:
ART;

AT YALE, WORKS OF A LEADER OF BRITISH POP ART

text: The exhibition is curated, and the catalogue authored, by Richard S. Field of the gallery. Mr. Hamilton says he often consults Mr. Field for insights into his own ideas and motivations. One of the main ideas of the exhibition is the link with Marcel Duchamp, especially significant to Yale, which has Katherine Dreier's large Duchamp collection.
title:
ART;

AT YALE, WORKS OF A LEADER OF BRITISH POP ART

text: Mr. Hamilton begins with ''Found Images'' and applies his dizzyingly thorough knowledge of printmaking techniques, both artistic and commercial, to transform an image we already know, if only dimly, into an elucidation of a wide range of human experience. In this he resembles Jasper Johns and Robert Rauschenberg, but Mr. Hamilton is more raw, he is more of guerrilla.
title:
ART;

AT YALE, WORKS OF A LEADER OF BRITISH POP ART

text: Even early on when he was more modest, questioning was the central theme of a work.
title:
ART;

AT YALE, WORKS OF A LEADER OF BRITISH POP ART

text: An etching of three bottles in the Cubist style is entitled ''Still Life?'' Picasso has remained as a hero to Mr. Hamilton. His prints are never dry exercises; often a work is suffused with emotion. ''My Marilyn'' is a collage of photographs of Marilyn Monroe on a beach. All of the images are crossed out, save one. ''Hamilton steadfastly maintains Marilyn's own marks of acceptance and rejection,'' said Mr. Field.
title:
ART;

AT YALE, WORKS OF A LEADER OF BRITISH POP ART

text: Throughout his career, Mr. Hamilton's colors have been ethereal. Soft colors can transform the most hard reality into a kind of dream.
title:
ART;

AT YALE, WORKS OF A LEADER OF BRITISH POP ART

text: Certainly that happens with Mr. Hamilton's investigation of Bing Crosby in the film ''Holiday Inn.'' Besides the more-pale-than-pale coloration of ''I'm Dreaming of a White Christmas,'' Mr. Hamilton makes frequent inversions, parts of the print that look as though they belong to the film were drawn by the artist and vice versa. And the artist creates a mega-inversion when he comes up with ''I'm Dreaming of a Black Christmas,'' which is rather chocolate in tone.
title:
ART;

AT YALE, WORKS OF A LEADER OF BRITISH POP ART

text: For Mr. Field, Mr. Hamilton's transformations here mean ''Bing becomes a modern Wandering Jew condemned to journey forever through life, unable to be fully a part of the present but remaining to all a reminder of man's spiritual insufficiency and blindness.''
title:
ART;

AT YALE, WORKS OF A LEADER OF BRITISH POP ART

text: One is tempted to say that many of Mr. Hamilton's machinations resemble conventional but ineffable portrayals of ''acid trips,'' images so prevalent in the late 1960's and early 1970's. Therefore it is ironic when he works with a newspaper image of Mick Jagger, identified with counterculture, handcuffed and under arrest for marijuana possession. The singer and the journalist that he was arrested with both have their hands over their faces to avoid the blinding flashbulbs. We are prevented from identifying this famous face.
title:
ART;

AT YALE, WORKS OF A LEADER OF BRITISH POP ART

text: Many of the images Mr. Hamilton works with are a lot less compelling than those. He takes an odyssey through interiors, cinematic and actual. The artist favors a construction mode made up of collaged blocks, which has a triumph in ''Putting on de Stijl'' in which the square wooden forms of Rietveld chairs are echoed by bright red, yellow, blue and black squares the color of de Stijl painting that here animates the furniture.
title:
ART;

AT YALE, WORKS OF A LEADER OF BRITISH POP ART

text: One thinks that Mr. Hamilton has really hit upon a subject that is not only innocuous but also cloying when he transforms that stock subject, a vase of flowers. Then one notices, however, something that neatly symbolizes the latent brashness in all of his work: dog excrement sits in front of the vase. But this insertion is not just nastiness. The brown color results from mixing the colors of the separate plates, so it is part of the printmaking process. But also, as explained by Mr. Field, ''What can produce such splendour also produces the opposite - again the theme of reversal.''
title:
ART;

AT YALE, WORKS OF A LEADER OF BRITISH POP ART

text: One of the most recent series and also one of the densest as well as one of the most visually bizarre is ''In Horne's House'' based on an episode from James Joyce's ''Ulysses.'' In his masterpiece, Joyce aped other writing styles, and here in Mr. Hamilton's gathering an Easter Island head sips a drink along with an Egyptian figure. Rembrandt and Cezanne are in the company, too. The print has the dynamism of the Cubist style, with which Mr. Hamilton began his investigations.
title:
ART;

AT YALE, WORKS OF A LEADER OF BRITISH POP ART

text: The artist has worked many times with his own self-portrait. In 1974 he did ''Palindrome,'' which is a Polaroid taken of himself daubing paint on a mirror - perhaps the most clear example of reversal. His face is captivating here: The way his beard frames his balding head and his trimmed mustache make him uncannily resemble Shakespeare. By the supple way he understands the movements of the contemporary universe, he is entitled to the resemblance.
title:
ART;

AT YALE, WORKS OF A LEADER OF BRITISH POP ART

text: Another set of prints far different from Mr. Hamilton's but spectacular in their own right are the panoramas in ''Gilded Scenes and Shining Prospects'' at the Yale Center for British Art through Dec. 15. The overview of a place, most commonly of London, was an art that flourished from 1575 to 1900.
title:
ART;

AT YALE, WORKS OF A LEADER OF BRITISH POP ART

text: This survey convinces the viewer that in the days before scientific mapping by airplane, the view of a city from on high had something celestial about it. Angels can sometimes be spotted at the top margin. As late as 1845, St. Paul's Cathedral could be said to be the center of the universe, at least in a circular composition that rather resembles the blue orb that astronauts see.
title:
ART;

AT YALE, WORKS OF A LEADER OF BRITISH POP ART

text: One's enjoyment of this show will be doubled if one knows London. The detailed views will make for enjoyable ''then and now'' comparisons.
title:
ART;

AT YALE, WORKS OF A LEADER OF BRITISH POP ART

text: By William R. Greer, Special To the New York Times
title: WILMINGTON POLICE CRACK DOWN ON GANG VIOLENCE

text: On North Market Street in the northeast part of Wilmington is a string of sandwich shops, liquor stores and corner groceries called the Strip. Under the street lights, hundreds of young men gather at night. They lounge on corners and lean in doorways and call themselves Yeayo boys.
title: WILMINGTON POLICE CRACK DOWN ON GANG VIOLENCE

text: ''I see them go by in groups and they all got something in their hands, like broom poles,'' said Gary Linton, who works behind a 24-hour dining counter on the Strip. ''When I'm in my car, I roll up my windows and lock my doors.''
title: WILMINGTON POLICE CRACK DOWN ON GANG VIOLENCE

text: On some Friday and Saturday nights as many as 40 of these men in their late teens and early 20's mill in front of the ''no loitering'' sign at the 7-Eleven. Others crowd the entrance to Angela's Pizza across the street. Sometimes they grow restless and violent. When a 7-Eleven clerk refused to let one of the young men use the store's bathroom three weeks ago, he slammed a bottle in her face, cutting a gash above her eye that was treated at a hospital.
title: WILMINGTON POLICE CRACK DOWN ON GANG VIOLENCE

text: 'Like You See On the Movies'
title: WILMINGTON POLICE CRACK DOWN ON GANG VIOLENCE

text: ''One night, it was really bad,'' said Lawrence Stansbury, another clerk at the 7-Eleven. ''The cops were here and the kids were throwing bottles at the cops. I just stood here watching and I couldn't believe it. It was like you see on the movies.''
title: WILMINGTON POLICE CRACK DOWN ON GANG VIOLENCE

text: For several months the 251-member Wilmington police force has been combating its worst outbreak of gang violence since the 1950's, according to a police spokesman, Sgt. William E. Jennings. The turmoil came to a head recently when one youth died and 20 others were arrested for beating him with baseball bats and chains.
title: WILMINGTON POLICE CRACK DOWN ON GANG VIOLENCE

text: A group of residents said enough was enough. The group, the Concerned Citizens Task Force, whose members include a minister, a high school mathematics teacher and two police officers, has asked Mayor Daniel S. Frawley to put more police officers on the Strip and to create social programs to counsel the gang members.
title: WILMINGTON POLICE CRACK DOWN ON GANG VIOLENCE

text: Mayor Frawley, who has been in office since January, says the violence has received more attention from newspapers and television than warranted. ''We have had several assaults related to groups' beating up on one another,'' he said. ''But it's not wholesale gang violence.''
title: WILMINGTON POLICE CRACK DOWN ON GANG VIOLENCE

text: The Mayor said the city had ''progressive programs'' to help the city's young people, among them a summer employment program that he said served 800 young men and women this year. ''It's very frustrating,'' he said. ''Some of these young people, despite our best efforts, defy institutional support.''
title: WILMINGTON POLICE CRACK DOWN ON GANG VIOLENCE

text: The district where much of the violence has occurred, among the rundown two-story row houses in the northeast, stands in sharp contrast both to the rows of new luxury condominiums being built a few blocks away along the Brandywine River and to the office building boom taking place downtown.
title: WILMINGTON POLICE CRACK DOWN ON GANG VIOLENCE

text: Out-of-state banks like Chase Manhattan, Morgan Guaranty and Citibank are setting up offices on block after block in a city that has become the nation's credit card capital because of more liberal lending laws.
title: WILMINGTON POLICE CRACK DOWN ON GANG VIOLENCE

text: A Park, a Dispute, a Death
title: WILMINGTON POLICE CRACK DOWN ON GANG VIOLENCE

text: A park along the Brandywine where the du Pont family first built its gunpowder mills in the 18th century is now often used by Yeayo boys as a hangout. Some of the people on the Strip the other day said the argument that led to the death of Michael L. Brown earlier this month started there.
title: WILMINGTON POLICE CRACK DOWN ON GANG VIOLENCE

text: North Market Street had been popular with young people for decades, the police said. After a series of purse snatchings last year, the police in April added a foot patrol to the neighborhood and three other areas seen as having high crime rates.
title: WILMINGTON POLICE CRACK DOWN ON GANG VIOLENCE

text: In June, a group of young men from New Castle, south of Wilmington, tangled with the Yeayo boys. Several young men were arrested, the police increased their patrols on North Market Street, and after a while calm returned, according to Officer Michael E. Maggitti, who patrols North Market.
title: WILMINGTON POLICE CRACK DOWN ON GANG VIOLENCE

text: Earlier this month, though, a group of Yeayo boys piled into cars and headed down to the Lower East Side, Officer Maggitti said. At least one of the Yeayos had been assaulted in Brandywine Park earlier, apparently by some men connected with a group from the Lower East Side.
title: WILMINGTON POLICE CRACK DOWN ON GANG VIOLENCE

text: ''There was bad blood between the the kids from the Lower East Side and the kids from the Upper East Side, the Yeayo boys,'' the officer said. ''It's probably a case of the kids just didn't like each other and it got out of hand.''
title: WILMINGTON POLICE CRACK DOWN ON GANG VIOLENCE

text: In the ensuing fight, Mr. Brown was severely beaten. Wilmington Hospital, where he was initially examined, has been criticized for sending him home without discovering he had two skull fractures and a broken arm. He lapsed into a coma the next day and died 10 days later.
title: WILMINGTON POLICE CRACK DOWN ON GANG VIOLENCE

text: ''It stunned everybody,'' Officer Maggitti said as he walked his beat the other day. ''Fights can go on and on, but here you had a death and several kids are facing a murder conviction.''
title: WILMINGTON POLICE CRACK DOWN ON GANG VIOLENCE

text: Just what led to the slaying remains unclear. The Mayor and the police say most of the violence stems from arguments over territorial rights to drug sales. The name of the gang, Yeayo, was what the drug dealers in the movie ''Scarface'' called cocaine. The Police Department's vice squad has been sent into the area to crack down on drug operations.
title: WILMINGTON POLICE CRACK DOWN ON GANG VIOLENCE

text: ''The big problem in this area is drug traffic, marijuana, cocaine and heroin,'' said Officer Maggitti, who said he has made ''30 to 35'' drug arrests since April.
title: WILMINGTON POLICE CRACK DOWN ON GANG VIOLENCE

text: Several residents, however, say the problem is more a traditional rivalry between neighborhoods.
title: WILMINGTON POLICE CRACK DOWN ON GANG VIOLENCE

text: One young man noted that Mr. Brown, 19 years old, was known locally for his performance of ''rap'' music, in which the artist speaks the rhyming lyrics in a rhythmic patter. ''It ain't about drugs or my territory or your territory,'' the man said. ''It's about rapping and who raps the best. That's what it's really about.''
title: WILMINGTON POLICE CRACK DOWN ON GANG VIOLENCE

text: A woman standing nearby with her son said, ''They're fighting about drugs and gold and hats.''
title: WILMINGTON POLICE CRACK DOWN ON GANG VIOLENCE

text: ''What starts it,'' said Mr. Stansbury, the store clerk, ''is when somebody comes in here from somewhere else and tries to act badder than the guys here. With 40 people hanging out and doing nothing, you get a fight.''
title: WILMINGTON POLICE CRACK DOWN ON GANG VIOLENCE

text: After Daniel Ortega Saavedra jogged through Central Park, his aides joked that the Nicaraguan President needs to stay in shape because, if the Reagan Administration gets its wish, the Sandinistas may have to resume the rough life of guerrillas some day.
title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: ORTEGA CHIC

text: If the revolutionary leader does return to the hills, he will do so with a full supply of designer eyewear.
title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: ORTEGA CHIC

text: His motorcade of 17 cars pulled up to the Cohen's Fashion Optical store on the Upper East Side the other morning. The store's manager, Noel Cottington, said he helped Mr. Ortega pick out something sophisticated and yet simple, lightweight and yet bulletproof.
title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: ORTEGA CHIC

text: After an eye examination, the Sandinista leader bought six pairs, at $300 apiece, of Silhouette frames with lenses made of polycarbonate - a sturdy plastic that is familiar to New Yorkers as the material used for many of the panels that protect taxidrivers and passengers from each other. ''It's indestructible, so it must be bulletproof,'' Mr. Cottington said, adding that the dark, conservative glasses gave Mr. Ortega ''the usual Wall Street look.''
title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: ORTEGA CHIC

text: Rosario Murillo, Mr. Ortega's wife, chose three pairs of Gucci frames, as well as three Fiorucci frames for the couple's daughter back home.
title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: ORTEGA CHIC

text: The bill was more than $3,500. Mr. Ortega paid with a Diner's Club card from the Nicaraguan Mission.
title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: ORTEGA CHIC

text: At President Reagan's cocktail party Thursday night at the Waldorf-Astoria, Mr. Ortega also received some fashion advice from the Mayor of New York. Surveying the Sandinista's black suit, Mayor Koch remarked: ''You look better in civilian clothes than you did in your uniform. You look more peaceful.''
title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: ORTEGA CHIC

text: Harlem holds a fascination for many of the European dignitaries visiting New York for the first time. ''They want to know if the Cotton Club still exists, and about segregation and poverty in the area,'' said Adam Sterling of the city's Commission for the United Nations and for the Consular Corps.
title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: ORTEGA CHIC

text: But even Mr. Sterling was surprised when Prince Philippe Leopold Louis Marie of Belgium asked him to arrange a trip to a Harlem shelter for the homeless.
title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: ORTEGA CHIC

text: The 25-year-old Prince and his bodyguard, a Belgian Army colonel, drove up to 155th Street in their limousine and toured the shelter with William E. Gould, a Human Resources Administration deputy administrator. Mr. Gould confessed that he was quite nervous during the tour. ''It was my first time meeting foreign royalty, and we Americans don't always know how to act or what to say,'' he said.
title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: ORTEGA CHIC

text: Other dignitaries also moved beyond the usual visits to museums and theaters and couturiers to seek out the city's less glamorous side.
title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: ORTEGA CHIC

text: A group of Danish Members of Parliament and national officials who are visiting as special delegates to the General Assembly were eager to compare their country's social services with those available in New York. They asked Mr. Sterling to arrange tours of Rikers Island jail, police headquarters, the Spofford Youth Center in the South Bronx, and Covenant House, the Times Square center for troubled youth. They also explored on their own.
title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: ORTEGA CHIC

text: Taking a stroll on East 53d Street one night, Tage Nielsen, the head of the Danish Youth Council, surprised a young male prostitute when he began asking him about his motivations. ''Do you know what kind of a risk you run with AIDS and all that?'' the diplomat demanded.
title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: ORTEGA CHIC

text: ''I try to protect myself but I need the money,'' the 18-year-old replied.
title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: ORTEGA CHIC

text: Touring Times Square one afternoon, Mr. Nielsen walked up 42d Street past the erotic movie theaters, drug paraphernalia shops and kung fu festivals. He watched a derelict with a pink feather in his hair singing in a falsetto and executing an Egyptian-style dance as he smoked marijuana.
title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: ORTEGA CHIC

text: ''This is worse than I expected,'' Mr. Nielsen said of the neon neighborhood. ''I thought at least there were some rules, but there aren't. There's a lot of un-behavior, people fighting, taking drugs. It looks like you could be shot there without anyone taking care of it.''
title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: ORTEGA CHIC

text: Henry Yurek, the principal of Junior High School 143 in the Bronx, was more excited than his students. He bounced around on the edge of the crowd at the Asia Society reception for Sonia Gandhi, the wife of Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi of India.
title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: ORTEGA CHIC

text: ''How often do you get to meet a president's wife in your life?'' he asked Tyisha McClarity, a seventh grader, and Neal Block, an eighth grader, who were standing rather phlegmatically by his side. ''I'll tell you - zero!''
title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: ORTEGA CHIC

text: Mr. Yurek bustled around, making sure that Mrs. Gandhi had received his present, a copy of the book ''The Beautiful Bronx.''
title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: ORTEGA CHIC

text: ''Franklin D. Roosevelt came through the Bronx when I was 5 years old,'' the principal said. ''He was in an open car. I think he saw me waving but I don't know for sure. From F.D.R. in 1940 to Mrs. Gandhi in 1985!''
title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: ORTEGA CHIC

text: Mrs. Gandhi came to the Asia Society to meet some students and teachers from Harlem, Brooklyn and the Bronx who had won an art competition and visited India. The Italian-born First Lady, an elegant woman wearing a homespun silk flowered sari, smiled often but spoke little - only to ask the children how they had liked her country's food and people. By the end of the reception, the children were as enchanted as Mr. Yurek.
title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: ORTEGA CHIC

text: ''She's smart, she's pretty,'' Neal Block, 13 years old, said. ''She and her husband seem to be handling the country good.''
title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: ORTEGA CHIC

text: Capitol Hill in the Federated States of Micronesia is a wing of an old one-story hospital that was condemned long ago. The President's office used to be the pediatrics ward.
title: MICRONESIA RESENTS A FAR LAND CALLED WASHINGTON

text: There are plans to build a new Government center in a more choice location a few miles away in Kolonia, but money is scarce and the necessary water mains and power lines exist only in blueprints.
title: MICRONESIA RESENTS A FAR LAND CALLED WASHINGTON

text: So President Tosiwo Nakayama and the 14-member Congress make do in aging tin-roofed buildings by the coconut trees, hoping for the situation to improve. But then, they have become good at waiting, they say. When the United States is involved, they are prepared to wait without end.
title: MICRONESIA RESENTS A FAR LAND CALLED WASHINGTON

text: Since 1947 Micronesia has been a United States trust territory, dependent on American dollars and, often enough, the whims of Washington bureaucrats who decreed what Federal programs were best for the 135,000 Ponapeans, Trukese, Palauans and other western Pacific people in the long Micronesian chain.
title: MICRONESIA RESENTS A FAR LAND CALLED WASHINGTON

text: Slowly over the last 16 years, Micronesian leaders and American administrations put together an agreement to end the trusteeship, the last one to survive from 11 that were created under postwar United Nations mandates. The agreement, officially referred to as the Compact of Free Association, divided the roughly 2,000 islands and atolls forming the territory into new political entities with appreciable autonomy but hardly full independence.
title: MICRONESIA RESENTS A FAR LAND CALLED WASHINGTON

text: Critical complications still had to be ironed out, but a basic deal had been struck, ready to be approved by the United States Congress this fall. Now Micronesians wonder if all their work is about to fall apart. They are concerned, a bit confused and, in less guarded moments, bluntly resentful over what some regard as merely the latest backhanded blow from Washington.
title: MICRONESIA RESENTS A FAR LAND CALLED WASHINGTON

text: The House of Representatives approved the compact in late July, but it amended it radically in a burst of tax-revision fervor. The House removed tax incentives that islanders - rich in lush scenery and poor in just about every other way - consider essential if they are to have any hope of luring business investment.
title: MICRONESIA RESENTS A FAR LAND CALLED WASHINGTON

text: Perhaps more important to the Micronesians, the House restricted their right to license American tuna boats operating in their waters, creating a potential revenue loss of a few million dollars a year. In Micronesia, that is real money. Domestic Issues in U.S. The Senate has yet to act, but one version under consideration risks a Presidential veto. It contains an irrelevant textile-protection rider, added to the compact amid the jockeying between lawmakers and the White House over trade legislation.
title: MICRONESIA RESENTS A FAR LAND CALLED WASHINGTON

text: Suddenly, this string of dots on the Pacific map, probably unknown to most Americans, is swept along by two of the hotter domestic issues in the United States - tax revision and protectionism. On Ponape, which has few exportable products worth worrying about let alone protecting, people are trying to figure out what hit them.
title: MICRONESIA RESENTS A FAR LAND CALLED WASHINGTON

text: ''We negotiated in good faith for 16 years,'' President Nakayama said. ''To run into these last-minute developments - you can imagine how frustrated we feel. It never dawned on me that a textile rider was going to be attached. We cannot explain to our people why this is happening.''
title: MICRONESIA RESENTS A FAR LAND CALLED WASHINGTON

text: Mr. Nakayama said that if the amendments survive, Micronesians, who supported the original compact in a 1983 referendum, may have to vote again on a new document. They might not go along a second time, he warned.
title: MICRONESIA RESENTS A FAR LAND CALLED WASHINGTON

text: The Federated States consist of four far-flung Caroline Island groups - Ponape, Truk, Yap and Kosrae. Their peoples speak nine languages, and they differ dramatically in appearances and customs.
title: MICRONESIA RESENTS A FAR LAND CALLED WASHINGTON

text: ''There is no guarantee that they will hold together if the compact doesn't make it,'' an American living on Ponape said.
title: MICRONESIA RESENTS A FAR LAND CALLED WASHINGTON

text: Micronesia's green mountains and shimmering lagoons do not disguise the many remnants of casual neglect from long United States rule. The few paved roads give way quickly to cratered lanes. On Ponape, poor distribution requires rationed water hours, even though the densely vegetated island gets an average of 200 inches of rain a year. Power blackouts are common. Toilets are not. Small stores exist, but no big business or industry worthy of the name. According to official figures, at least half the workers on salary hold government jobs, and without help from Washington, there might be no government at all.
title: MICRONESIA RESENTS A FAR LAND CALLED WASHINGTON

text: In a typical recent year, 1983, revenues in the Federated States totaled $78.3 million. More than $63 million of this came from the Interior Department and assorted Federal programs. Barely 10 percent was raised locally. ''In terms of economic development, we are really starting at the bottom,'' said Daniel Twum-Barimah, an adviser to the Department of Resources and Development in Kolonia.
title: MICRONESIA RESENTS A FAR LAND CALLED WASHINGTON

text: The compact guarantees that the islands will remain an American ward through this century.
title: MICRONESIA RESENTS A FAR LAND CALLED WASHINGTON

text: Three Micronesian governments would gain the status of ''freely associated states,'' meaning semi-independence and an assured flow of $2.4 billion in American aid over the next 15 years. Some Micronesians say they prefer full independence, but most people rule that out, given the islands' inability to sustain themselves.
title: MICRONESIA RESENTS A FAR LAND CALLED WASHINGTON

text: For its money, the United States retains military authority, and it reserves the right to deny other countries any military presence in the strategically sensitive region.
title: MICRONESIA RESENTS A FAR LAND CALLED WASHINGTON

text: Both American and Micronesian officials express concern about a recent agreement under which Soviet trawlers will be able to enter the waters of Kiribati, the former Gilbert Islands, to the east. The United States has long asserted that the Soviet Union uses such fishing ships for surveillance purposes.
title: MICRONESIA RESENTS A FAR LAND CALLED WASHINGTON

text: Besides the Federated States, the governments involved are the Marshall Islands and Palau, which is due west. But Palau's drive toward home rule has been further stalled by an antinuclear Constitution that keeps the compact from going into effect.
title: MICRONESIA RESENTS A FAR LAND CALLED WASHINGTON

text: A fourth group in the Micronesian trusteeship, the Northern Mariana Islands, has been an American commonwealth, like Puerto Rico, for the last nine years.
title: MICRONESIA RESENTS A FAR LAND CALLED WASHINGTON

text: While the compact talks drag on, the Micronesian States have acted as though they truly are on their own, with constitutions, congresses and full political agendas. The chief American delegate to the region, Fred M. Zeder, holds the rank of ambassador.
title: MICRONESIA RESENTS A FAR LAND CALLED WASHINGTON

text: But as long as agreement with Washington languishes, the islands cannot move forward and the trusteeship, though scaled down steadily since 1979, cannot end.
title: MICRONESIA RESENTS A FAR LAND CALLED WASHINGTON

text: Mr. Zeder and Micronesian leaders have talked of possible ways to get around the House of Representatives' bill with special payments to make up for lost tax revenue.
title: MICRONESIA RESENTS A FAR LAND CALLED WASHINGTON

text: Officials here say they are especially adamant about their right to license foreign fishing boats operating in their tuna-thick waters. Last year such licenses produced $3.5 million in badly needed revenue for the Federated States, most of it from Japanese fishermen.
title: MICRONESIA RESENTS A FAR LAND CALLED WASHINGTON

text: Some American boats are also willing to pay the fees, but the United States insists that in the case of highly migratory fish like tuna, countries have exclusive economic rights only up to 12 miles from their shores, not the 200 miles claimed by the Government in Kolonia. By way of emphasis, the House required that any Micronesian fines levied against American boats for violating territorial waters would be deducted from United States payments under the compact.
title: MICRONESIA RESENTS A FAR LAND CALLED WASHINGTON

text: American negotiators say the Micronesians will probably bargain on this issue, as they have on many others, but a Ponapean Government official said, ''This is an insult.''
title: MICRONESIA RESENTS A FAR LAND CALLED WASHINGTON

text: Others talks of a ''David and Goliath'' situation, only in this case it is Goliath who carries the slingshot.
title: MICRONESIA RESENTS A FAR LAND CALLED WASHINGTON

text: To catch American ''tuna pirates,'' Kolonia maintains a coast guard consisting of one tired ship built in 1916 and chartered from a company in San Francisco. On good days, she manages eight knots.
title: MICRONESIA RESENTS A FAR LAND CALLED WASHINGTON

text: Claudell Washington, the Atlanta Braves' outfielder who was arrested in California last February and charged with possession of marijuana, was allowed yesterday to enter a drug-diversion program rather than stand trial on the misdemeanor charge, which carries a penalty for conviction of up to a year in prison and a $1,000 fine. Details of the diversion program were not immediately available, according to court authorities in Walnut Creek, Calif., where Washington was arrested on Feb. 19 after being stopped for a traffic check. Washington, who lives in the nearby town of Orinda, about 30 miles from San Francisco, was treated for drug dependecy after the 1983 season.
title: Help for Washington

text: MORE THAN 1,000 LOCAL COORDINATORS OF THE Interdenominational Peace Council of the Netherlands gathered early on a Sunday morning at a high school in Utrecht to begin planning their fall demonstrations. The high school was on a street called Amerikalaan, America Street. That seemed appropriate to the Dutch organizers, because their marches, meetings and petitions would be an attempt to stop the deployment of United States cruise missiles in their country.
title: THE PERMISSIVE DUTCH

text: It seemed appropriate to me, too, but for a different reason. Walking through the workshops and discussion groups that May morning, by a sign that said ''Give Peace a Chance,'' it all looked like America to me. America at the end of the 1960's. Except for the language, I could have been in California 15 years ago. The people were the same: earnest elderly couples with their gray hair a little longer than most, matrons with their hair pulled sensibly back in buns, younger women in earth-mother dresses and sandals, and their men looking as if they were waiting for tenure at a university. On the fringes of the crowd were a few leftover hippies, looking like a lost road show of ''Hair.''
title: THE PERMISSIVE DUTCH

text: After that meeting, they went out and collected almost three million signatures - the equivalent of one from every four adults in the nation - on antimissile petitions, which will be presented to Prime Minister Ruud Lubbers this week.
