On Nov. 1, Lubbers is expected to recommend to Parliament that the Netherlands allow 48 cruise missiles to be brought onto Dutch soil. THE NETHERLANDS IS THE PLACE WHERE THE 60'S NEVER ended, or where they are just ending, as utopian dreams of compassionate antiauthoritarianism are being interrupted by such realities as budget deficits and drug overdoses. But the Dutch are not a people who give up easily. Otherwise, they would have long ago lost their vulnerable lowlands to the ceaseless attacks of the North Sea. And there is just as stubborn a commitment to a tolerant, egalitarian, participatory democratic welfare state where the Government still distributes official publications containing such statements as:
title: THE PERMISSIVE DUTCH

text: ''The Dutch think that little real purpose is served by locking prisoners up with fellow criminals to serve out long sentences in resentment and misery.''
title: THE PERMISSIVE DUTCH

text: ''Although pot-smoking is officially illegal, the Amsterdam council has accepted that it is better to let it go on in a controlled and regulated way in clubs which are partly subsidized by the city.''
title: THE PERMISSIVE DUTCH

text: ''Young people who wanted to change the present competitive society liberated houses which had stood empty for a long period of time, making them available to families who had looked in vain for a place through official channels.''
title: THE PERMISSIVE DUTCH

text: The Government's response to that last situation has been to buy the buildings, renovate them and then give them to the squatters -krakers in Dutch - at minimal rents.
title: THE PERMISSIVE DUTCH

text: ''Amsterdam Is Building for Our Young People'' read the official yellow sign over five 18th-century homes along the Keizersgracht, perhaps the most beautiful of the canals that make the city's center an urban art work. Inside, Government workmen were converting the homes into 33 apartments, carefully restoring the ornate floor-to-ceiling fireplaces and curved doors that once must have been the pride of a prosperous merchant. One of the last things the crew did was to plaster and paint over the obscene graffiti of skulls and knives and the legend: ''Destroy the Government Anywhere.''
title: THE PERMISSIVE DUTCH

text: The squatters who broke into those five buildings will pay $50 a month rent for the apartments, which the city will maintain for the next 10 years.
title: THE PERMISSIVE DUTCH

text: ''The job will cost more than a million guilders'' -more than $300,000 - says a city housing official. ''I suppose you could say it's an expensive way to deal with a little social unrest. But it's a Dutch way.''
title: THE PERMISSIVE DUTCH

text: T HE DECENT, STUB-born, self-righteous and contradictory ways of the Dutch have been perplexing, offending and amusing foreigners for centuries. Not that outsiders have ever much noticed the Dutch, until they do such things as harbor Pilgrims fleeing England for the New World, or defy Arab boycotts to share their oil with Israel, or charge police lines chanting, ''Kill the Pope! Kill the Pope!''
title: THE PERMISSIVE DUTCH

text: It was, in fact, the angry Dutch ''welcome'' for Pope John Paul II last May that made many foreigners realize that the Netherlands wasn't all windmills and wooden shoes. That poor and orderly agricultural country, where some children under the age of 30 could not marry without the written permission of their parents, had been destroyed forever by World War II and its aftermath. In its place, the Dutch, deter-mined that their people would never again suffer as they had under German occupation, built a dazzling modern welfare state.
title: THE PERMISSIVE DUTCH

text: The earned wealth of hard work and the new riches of giant natural gas fields under the marshy land of the north have subsidized schemes that add up to guaranteed lifetime support for everyone, whether they work or not. Dutch egalitarianism is now such that at great multinational corporations, such as Royal Dutch/Shell and Philips, average earnings of top management are only five times the take-home pay of the lowest laborer. And combined welfare, unemployment and disability payments can add up to much more than working people earn. ''It's a bit ridiculous, I know,'' said a clerk in an Amsterdam bookstore, without any trace of resentment. ''But, of course, we must do it, because it would be wrong not to.''
title: THE PERMISSIVE DUTCH

text: The Government, determined to do the right thing, assumed the financing, but not control, of almost all ''private'' functions: schools, hospitals, religious charities, home construction corporations, local jazz bands. There is even a program to encourage artists in the most practical way: if no one will buy their work, the Government does, and then builds warehouses in which to store it. So buying houses for squatters seemed a natural Dutch way to deal with a problem Americans would call breaking and entering.
title: THE PERMISSIVE DUTCH

text: ''People needed houses and the Government was failing to provide suitable housing. What else were they to do?'' says Klaas de Vries, an influential Labor Party (socialist) member of Parliament. ''This is a self-regulatory society, it is not governed by speeches from above. We allow as many people as possible to be themselves. Some call that anarchy; we call it civilization.''
title: THE PERMISSIVE DUTCH

text: The view from further to the right of Dutch politics is a variation on the same theme. ''We believe in democracy, not only in terms of methods, but in result,'' said Prime Minister Lubbers, leader of the centrist Christian Democratic Party, as we talked in his paneled office, about the size assigned to assistants to deputy under secretaries in Washington. ''Our word is 'solidarity,' the conception that every citizen is integrated into all things. You have to ban poverty, and we were relatively successful with that in our welfare state.''
title: THE PERMISSIVE DUTCH

text: Lubbers's Christian Democrats govern in parliamentary coalition with the Netherlands' most conservative major party, the People's Party for Freedom and Democracy, known as the V.V.D. Liberals. Since their slogans emphasize, ''Less government, more free enterprise,'' I assumed they would be bitterly opposed to a system where nearly two-thirds of the gross national product each year was distributed and redistributed by the Government. I guessed wrong. ''In the 70's we went too far,'' says the party's spokesman, Ferry Houterman, ''but we can live with welfare where it is now.''
title: THE PERMISSIVE DUTCH

text: ''We were too ambitious, financially,'' says Prime Minister Lubbers, whose coalition has initiated such austerity measures as reducing unemployment benefits from an average of 75 percent of a worker's last salary for two years, to 70 percent for one year; in either case, many ex-workers are also getting as much, or more, from extremely generous disability benefits.
title: THE PERMISSIVE DUTCH

text: ''We learned that Government can only spend what is earned in the country,'' Lubbers said. ''Balance is the problem of every free society. You have the American risk: pockets of poverty. You have the Dutch risk: too many people outside the system of production.''
title: THE PERMISSIVE DUTCH

text: At the time we talked, more than one out of every three people in the Dutch work force was apparently producing nothing. Unemployment, as in most of Europe, was high - 18 percent - but that was only the beginning of the Dutch problem. All employees are entitled to more than 30 days a year of holidays and vacations and virtually unlimited paid sick days. It is something of a tribute to Dutch Calvinism that two-thirds of the country's six million able-bodied adults still go to work every day.
title: THE PERMISSIVE DUTCH

text: The biggest problem of all, though, turned out to be the ''disablement list,'' which provides that Dutch workers who become ill or are injured, whether on or off the job, are entitled, at public expense, to up to 80 percent of their previous pay for a year and then 70 percent until they are 65. Then, they become eligible for a public pension plan that pays retirees the minimum wage - 75 percent of the national average wage - plus generous vacation allowances. This year, the disablement list reached 800,000 people. Many of them are men in their 20's and 30's being paid for a working lifetime for having had an accident.
title: THE PERMISSIVE DUTCH

text: Even with natural gas revenues, low inflation and a very favorable trade balance, the Netherlands soon began to run out of money. Income taxes took 70 percent of national earnings in 1983, but the budget deficit climbed above 10 percent of G.N.P.
title: THE PERMISSIVE DUTCH

text: ''The gay 70's are over,'' says Finance Minister H. Onno Ruding, a blunt former banker who took over when Lubbers's center-right Government replaced a center-left Government in 1982. ''There is apparently something in the Dutch character -'solidarity' - which dictates that the Government must support economically and socially weak people. I don't like that, but I accept it.
title: THE PERMISSIVE DUTCH

text: ''We think we can make people understand that lower unemployment benefits means that each man has a better chance to get a job,'' he continued. ''But there are limits on what we can do; where they are remains to be seen. We will see at election time. You pay a price for democracy.''
title: THE PERMISSIVE DUTCH

text: E LECTION TIME WILL COME in May. National polls indicate the elections will produce a sweeping victory for a coalition of the left led by the Labor Party. The issues of the left are dissatisfaction over unemployment, the very moderate austerity of the past year or so and the scheduled deployment of the missiles in the Netherlands early next year in Woensdrecht, near the Belgian border.
title: THE PERMISSIVE DUTCH

text: The Labor Party has carefully avoided promising to restore the small welfare cuts of the Lubbers Government. But politicians of the left seem to have no doubt that economic adversity will not diminish the fundamental Dutch drive toward guaranteed individual security. I sat at dinner one night while two young Amsterdam aldermen - Walter Etty, 36, of the Labor Party, and Gerrit Jan Wolffensperger, 40, of the more centrist Democrats '66 - argued cordially about what would happen next in the Netherlands.
title: THE PERMISSIVE DUTCH

text: ''We believe you must give people a basic wage, and let them choose whether or not to work,'' Wolffensperger said. ''Our friends, the socialists, will argue for cutting the number of hours in the work week, from 38 to 36, then to 30 and 25. On the right, they will call for less of the same.''
title: THE PERMISSIVE DUTCH

text: It is difficult to find a Dutchman to challenge that. Even Finance Minister Ruding, who doesn't like it one bit, must pay lip service to that consensus.
title: THE PERMISSIVE DUTCH

text: The issue that does divide the Netherlands is missile deployment. The cruise missiles, pointed at the Soviet Union, would be part of a total deployment of 572 Pershing 2 and cruise missiles - weapons approved by the North Atlantic Treaty Organization in 1979 to counter new installations of Soviet SS-20 missiles aimed at Europe. In the simplest terms, Labor and most of the Dutch left is opposed to the deployment on their soil. The Liberal Party favors deployment. Lubbers's Christian Democrats are divided, but the Prime Minister himself has been trying to find a way to begin deployment in the face of repeated antinuclear street demonstrations involving upwards of a half-million of the Netherlands' population of 14.5 million.
title: THE PERMISSIVE DUTCH

text: The next Government attempt to go along with NATO and the Americans will be Nov. 1. That date was set in June 1984, when Parliament voted to delay deployment to see if there might be an arms limitation agreement in Geneva and whether the Soviets would continue to activate new SS-20's aimed at Europe. Either could have been used to get the Dutch off the nuclear hook.
title: THE PERMISSIVE DUTCH

text: Now, Lubbers is preparing to argue that cruise deployment should proceed because there has been no Geneva agreement, and because Western intelligence surveys have reported new SS-20 activation. But Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev, an interested observer of the cruise debate, made a point of insisting in Paris three weeks ago that the total number of missiles able to hit European targets has been reduced to ''the June 1984'' level, an obvious attempt to persuade Dutch decision-makers and demonstrators that the Soviets have met one Dutch condition for refusing cruise deployment.
title: THE PERMISSIVE DUTCH

text: The organizational meeting I attended in Utrecht was the beginning of the principal antideployment effort, the petition drive of the peace council, the joint operation of the Dutch Roman Catholic Church and the country's eight largest Protestant denominations. Mient Jan Faber, the peace council's general secretary, talked of the current movement as a product of both the faded optimism of the 1960's and of Dutch aspirations to be acknowledged as a world moral power.
title: THE PERMISSIVE DUTCH

text: They are righteous and self-righteous. The Dutch set aside a generous 1.1 percent of their gross national product for aid to poor countries, and for centuries they have been known as ''the people of the finger,'' because of their penchant for wagging fingers in people's faces, preaching to the world and to each other.
title: THE PERMISSIVE DUTCH

text: ''There was an expectation here in the late 1960's that we could identify possibilities to give our people more power than they had within our parliamentary democracy,'' said Faber, a former mathematician who is now a full-time organizer and preacher. ''Then came the frustration when we realized we really had no power, no influence on nuclear issues.
title: THE PERMISSIVE DUTCH

text: ''We did not want to be forced to choose between the positions of others, of NATO, which we consider ourselves part of, or of the Soviets,'' Faber continued. ''We wanted to create a new position ourselves, from the Dutch way. Before World War II, we looked to the sea, to other colonies. We had a place, an important place. Now where are we? Who are we?''
title: THE PERMISSIVE DUTCH

text: W HAT THE DUTCH WERE before World War II were dutiful, cautious thrifty, moderate farmers and traders, dominated by Calvinist ideas of the connections between work, success and salvation.
title: THE PERMISSIVE DUTCH

text: It was a wonder of hard work and calculating ingenuity that they had once controlled much of the world -from the islands of the East Indies (Indonesia) to Nieuw Amsterdam (Manhattan). But the economic depressions of the 1930's crippled world trade and Dutch prosperity. In 1940, the Netherlands was poor but tidy, in every sense. Dutch society was organized and ordered by a system called ''The Pillars.'' Protestants, Roman Catholics and nonbelievers lived tolerantly separate lives, each group with its own ''pillar'' of villages, schools, political parties, newspapers, radio stations and labor unions, even football leagues.
title: THE PERMISSIVE DUTCH

text: The pillars were cracked by the German occupation of the Netherlands, when Protestants from the north, Catholics from the south and agnostic and atheistic socialists from the cities got to know each other and worked together for the first time in resistance to the brutal invaders.
title: THE PERMISSIVE DUTCH

text: Then the pillars were smashed by two great blows in the late 1940's and the 1960's. First, the country rebuilt itself as a rich industrial power -with per capita income comparable to that in the United States - and people flocked from the flat countryside of windmills to the cities along the sea, leaving behind parents, preachers and priests. Then, in the 60's the Protestant and Catholic political parties, eventually merged as the Christian Democratic Appeal, moved to hold onto the loyalties of relocated villagers by creating a new religion for them - the welfare state. The Dutch actually use the phrase Vadertje Staat, or Dear Father State.
title: THE PERMISSIVE DUTCH

text: The new religion, sanctified by the agony of the Nazi occupation and appealing to ''atheistic socialists,'' united Dutchmen as never before. Tolerance, which had always been among the highest of proclaimed Dutch virtues, became even more vital in the secularizing society of one of the world's most crowded countries - 1,002 people live on each of the Netherlands' flat, watery square miles, compared with 64 in the United States, or 252 in France.
title: THE PERMISSIVE DUTCH

text: ''We believe,'' said socialist Alderman Etty as he and I talked one night. ''We have a mission. We believe people are good and that there's something to be done in this city, in this country, in this world.''
title: THE PERMISSIVE DUTCH

text: ''We were so old-fashioned that when things began to move, everything just burst out,'' says Harry Mulisch, a novelist and essayist whose last novel sold 280,000 hardcover copies - an indication of Dutch literacy and literary enthusiasm. ''Sure it went too far, but would I change this system for the old one? Would anyone? Never.''
title: THE PERMISSIVE DUTCH

text: With Puritan determination, the Dutch began in 1965 to enthusiastically explore the possibility that all of them were entitled to indulge themselves in any behavior that didn't physically injure someone else. Offensive or expensive had nothing to do with it.
title: THE PERMISSIVE DUTCH

text: ''Some people say 'permissive,' some say 'tolerant,' '' says Prime Minister Lubbers. ''What is tolerant about alcohol to you or me may be permissive to a Saudi Arabian. But tolerance in itself is a good thing. If you let people express their differences you will have less violence.''
title: THE PERMISSIVE DUTCH

text: ''We thought we could be tolerant and still control hard drugs. We were very naive,'' says Eduard van Thijn, the Burgomaster (Mayor) of Amsterdam. In 1984, in his city, 73 young people died of drug overdoses. ''We did not see it as a police problem, but a public health problem. We wanted to deal humanely with the junks - we still do -and thought we could concentrate them without affecting life in the rest of the city and the country.''
title: THE PERMISSIVE DUTCH

text: That, too, is the Dutch way: tolerate anything, but contain it where it can be controlled, and keep it out of the mainstreams of Dutch life. For more than 200 years, well into the 19th century, the practice of Catholicism was officially prohibited in the Netherlands, although masses were regularly said in elaborately decorated chapels in attics, inns and barns throughout the country. The ''clandestine'' church, as it is called, was an important factor in establishing a determined localism and independence among Dutch Catholics, including independence from Popes far away in Rome.
title: THE PERMISSIVE DUTCH

text: Legal prohibition and practical tolerance. The Dutch have taken the same hypocritical - or civilized -attitude toward sex for pleasure or profit since at least the 17th century. The red light district of Amsterdam, with prostitutes of both sexes displaying their wares in windows, is not new - and has generally succeded in keeping prostitution in what the Dutch would call its proper place.
title: THE PERMISSIVE DUTCH

text: D ISSENT HAS ALSO been contained pretty effectively in the Netherlands with the same kind of aggressive tolerance. There is something very tidy about channeling the emotions of hundreds of thousands of antinuclear demonstrators into a day or a week of marches. The Government being protested against cooperates, indeed effectively subsidizes them. And, if the world press occasionally focuses on punk provocation or violence on the fringes, that unpleasantness is at least where it belongs, on the fringes.
title: THE PERMISSIVE DUTCH

text: Such Dutch ways have, however, failed to contain the use and public abuse of drugs. Amsterdam, in particular, which absorbed the use of marijuana and hashish with relative ease beginning in the late 1960's, essentially welcomed thousands of ''drug tourists'' with indulgent toleration - until last year, when officials finally responded to the fact that thievery on the streets had increased tenfold in 10 years.
title: THE PERMISSIVE DUTCH

text: ''We are not concerned with anything unless it has a connection with heroin and cocaine,'' says Jan Winkel, the commander of the city's central police district. ''And we have never found any connection between soft and hard drugs.'' So, grass and hash are sold everywhere in the city at cafes marked by a marijuana leaf on their signs. Local guides - the ''Mellow Pages'' - rate the quality of the decor and the menu of the stock from Pakistan, Syria, Mexico, Indonesia, the world. The ''Casa Blanca,'' says one guide, accepts American Express.
title: THE PERMISSIVE DUTCH

text: With heroin and cocaine, the Dutch way was to try to concentrate dealing to one short central street, the Zeedijk, a 500-yard canyon between buildings going back to the 14th century, where hundreds of dealers and addicts mingled desperately in a grimy bazaar. The true sign that Amsterdam finally meant to do something about hard drugs came this spring when the city began closing down the Zeedijk. In the Dutch way, the city bought all the buildings on the street to begin development of a new luxury hotel.
title: THE PERMISSIVE DUTCH

text: ''So far, the problem is only being moved to other places,'' says Barry de Koning, former head of the city narcotics brigade and recently promoted to commander in Bijlmermeer, a new city on the outskirts of Amsterdam. More than 1,500 of the 75,000 people living in Bijlmermeer are junks, as the Dutch call addicts. At the center of town, next to the children's animal farm, is ''The Shed,'' a two-room structure decorated with magazine photos of Tina Turner and Prince, where the junks go to smoke heroin and snort cocaine, under police supervision.
title: THE PERMISSIVE DUTCH

text: When I was there, 20 blank faces looked up slowly from the tin-foil chocolate wrappers which they use to inhale cooking heroin. They were Surinamese, born in the former Dutch Guiana of South America. About half the Surinamese, 130,000 people, took the Dutch citizenship that was offered at independence in 1975.
title: THE PERMISSIVE DUTCH

text: ''It's not easy to decide what's best for them,'' the police commandant said as we left The Shed. ''At least here we know where they are.''
title: THE PERMISSIVE DUTCH

text: T HE POLICE ALSO know exactly where to find krakers, beginning at the headquarters of the hard core of the squatters movement, an aptly named cafe called Rioolrat, or the Sewer Rat. It's a grungy place with a Hell's Angels look about it, even if it is just bicycles stacked outside.
title: THE PERMISSIVE DUTCH

text: On the day I visited, the red entrance door was framed by posters used to organize the demonstration against the Pope in Utrecht, 30 miles away. One of them read: ''Stop Making Sense. Make Terror.''
title: THE PERMISSIVE DUTCH

text: The attempt to make terror the day the Pope came to Utrecht involved only a few hundred krakers but in their crude way they represented many, many more of their countrymen. It was interesting to me that almost no one in the Netherlands, from Queen Beatrix on down, spoke out to condemn the rioters. Several of the people I interviewed - officials, writers and intellectuals - said they believed John Paul was a force for evil in the world, urging women in poor countries to have babies, infants condemned to starvation. The most prominent Catholic layman in the country, Prime Minister Lubbers, told me: ''We do not believe in holy men. The Pope came here as a man higher than others. That is not the Dutch way.'' The Utrecht demonstraters were drawn from the 3,000 or so hard-core krakers now in Amsterdam. The number is apparently declining, not because the squatters are leaving the buildings they have been occupying, but because they are being ''legalized.''
title: THE PERMISSIVE DUTCH

text: Under the legalization program, Piet, a 37-year-old unpublished writer who lives on $278-a-month ''student'' grant from the Government, will get the apartment he has been illegally occupying for $56 a month sometime in 1986. The first floor of the large building on the Vredenburger Alley will be converted into studios and a small theater, which Piet and the five friends who have been squatting with him, can rent to aspiring artists and performers. ''I was very firm,'' Piet told me. ''I refused to settle unless some provision was made for art and expression.''
title: THE PERMISSIVE DUTCH

text: Piet, whose own book-lined rooms struck me as Greenwich Village with a canal view, does not give his last name ''for my own legal protection.'' This anonymity is parody, because he and I were standing with the Amsterdam housing official who negotiated the turnover of the building.
title: THE PERMISSIVE DUTCH

text: Why don't you just throw the squatters out? I asked the question many times and got many answers.
title: THE PERMISSIVE DUTCH

text: ''I can't do that, it's against the law,'' said Burgomaster van Thijn, who seemed surprised by the question. ''If we catch them in the act of breaking in, we can do something. Otherwise, they have rights.''
title: THE PERMISSIVE DUTCH

text: As police commander Winkel explained it, ''We had this idea that every youngster of 18 was entitled to their own housing, but there really was no housing for them. They began moving into empty houses, and it became very complicated because our law says property has to be 'in use' to give an owner full rights.''
title: THE PERMISSIVE DUTCH

text: Alderman Etty pursued the point: ''If you leave a building empty for five years in a housing shortage, you can't then claim property rights. The squatters had a moral right to do what they did.''
title: THE PERMISSIVE DUTCH

text: That last view was repeated frequently during interviews around the country. The moral claim of the squatters is principally based on the fact that hundreds of buildings in central Amsterdam were being held empty by speculators, many of them from Britain, hoping to cash in on spectacular increases in city real-estate prices.
title: THE PERMISSIVE DUTCH

text: The speculators moved into Amsterdam in the middle of a series of Government decisions that proved, at least in hindsight, to be almost as foolish as they were humane. Bombed-out, the Netherlands had a tremendous housing shortage after World War II and immediately instituted strict rent-control laws. The laws, of course, were popular and, as in other European cities, and New York City too, they long survived the crisis. By the end of the 1950's, many of the four-story, four-apartment buildings that make up most of Amsterdam were in deteriorating disrepair. Owners couldn't get enough rent to maintain their properties. But, at the same time, there was a boom in the prices of fancier houses along the canals in the heart of the city. The hard-pressed owners in surrounding middle-class neighborhoods were delighted to sell out to the speculators. Then world interest rates rose and the real-estate market collapsed, leaving buildings abandoned in bankruptcy.
title: THE PERMISSIVE DUTCH

text: The squatters came in waves beginning in the 1960's. First, they moved into old empty factories, then the empty speculation buildings, and then into similar buildings that the Government purchased for urban renewal but left standing empty because there was not enough money to build new public housing.
title: THE PERMISSIVE DUTCH

text: ''The inevitable happened to us,'' says Jos Paardekooper, Amsterdam's director of housing distribution. ''People saw them empty and they renewed them themselves.''
title: THE PERMISSIVE DUTCH

text: The krakers, in fact, did more than that. They actually set up an alternative government with its own bureaucracy and radio and television stations. More than 1,000 apartments then under squatter control - the number is somewhat smaller now -were distributed from headquarters at the Rioolrat and a pirate radio station, still operating, broadcast from a storefront three blocks away. The television station, which was eventually jammed by city engineers, broadcast by splicing into the city's cable system. At the same time, workmen from the Rioolrat answered calls to illegally connect their constituents to the city's water, gas and electricity lines.
title: THE PERMISSIVE DUTCH

text: In addition to daily programming that includes such items as daily drug prices, Staatsradio - named for the principal squatter neighborhood, Staatslieden - is part of the elaborate radio-telephone alarm network the squatters used to produce a demonstration when the police dared to attempt an eviction. But after a number of violent confrontations, the police don't really try anymore. The rioting peaked two years ago in a two-day rock-and-club battle between police and squatters over an apartment building near the Rijksmuseum, with its great collection of the works of Amsterdam's most famous son, Rembrandt van Rijn. The police were losing the fight when they were forced to call in the Army, which brought in a tank to move the crowd, and the confrontation ended only when the city agreed to renovate the building for its illegal tenants.
title: THE PERMISSIVE DUTCH

text: ''We have the squatters under control now,'' says Alderman Wolffensperger, whose living-room window has been broken 21 times by rock-throwers. ''Legalization will make it past history.'' Perhaps, but the squatters still see themselves as a political movement contending for public approval, and for continued control over part of the city's housing stock.
title: THE PERMISSIVE DUTCH

text: ''We represent the people who don't want to live the way everybody else lives,'' says Marcel, a 28-year-old squatter living on student grants. ''We're trying to find alternatives. We need them because there's never going to be enough work again.''
title: THE PERMISSIVE DUTCH

text: ''Money shouldn't be tied to work,'' interrupted another squatter, Eveline, a 24-year-old univerity graduate in political science. ''I see my social security as a basic right. Anyway, the work I do is more important than paid work. I take complaints against the police.''
title: THE PERMISSIVE DUTCH

text: ''Right,'' Marcel said. ''You have to get up in the middle of the night to answer eviction alarms. You're not paid well for saving the inner city.''
title: THE PERMISSIVE DUTCH

text: I asked Marcel why he became a squatter and he answered like a teen-ager: ''I had to commute to the university every day back and forth from my parent's house in Haarlem. It was awful. When there were parties, I had to leave at 11:30 for the last train home.''
title: THE PERMISSIVE DUTCH

text: Then I asked about the Pope's visit in May. But Marcel had not demonstrated, probably because he has not yet served a one-month sentence he received when he was convicted of stoning a policeman at the demonstration near the Rijksmuseum. ''I was there,'' Eveline said. ''It was a gay day. A good day. I demonstrated for my way of life. And the police flipped out.''
title: THE PERMISSIVE DUTCH

text: ''When you demonstrate,'' Marcel said, ''aren't you just part of the system? I don't like committing violence and I hardly every do it. But it's the only thing that gets attention in Holland.''
title: THE PERMISSIVE DUTCH

text: ''Right,'' says Eveline. ''It's the iron fist in the velvet glove here. They'll give in on little things, like renovating your houses. But if you go too far, they'll smash you down.''
title: THE PERMISSIVE DUTCH

text: No, they won't. For almost 20 years, the Dutch have been testing whether anything at all is too far. That is the Dutch way. Perhaps it has always been. In the Amsterdam Historical Museum there is a life-size display of a man begging in the streets of the city 400 years ago.
title: THE PERMISSIVE DUTCH

text: ''Between 1560 and 1650 the population of Amsterdam grew by leaps and bounds,'' the legend on the display reads. ''The city's mounting prosperity attracted many people. Large numbers of them were poor. Crime increased. At the end of the 16th century, the municipal public assistance system was reorganized. In addition, the city attempted to control crime by establishing two houses of correction. Although this solution was very advanced for its time, it did not solve the problems.''
title: THE PERMISSIVE DUTCH

text: On a sunny morning in August 1984, Giuseppe Palazzolo met under the leafy portico of the Doney cafe on the Via Veneto in Rome with a bearded young American he had met several months earlier in New York.
title: U.S.-ITALIAN TEAMWORK BRINGING ORGANIZED-CRIME CHIEFS TO TRIAL

text: Over espresso, Mr. Palazzolo said two kilograms of heroin were waiting in Palermo, Sicily, an hour's flight away, and would cost $240,000. He did not know that the American, who was wearing a hidden listening device, was, in fact, Special Agent Louis A. Caprino Jr. of the Federal Bureau of Investigation - the first F.B.I. agent to work undercover in Italy.
title: U.S.-ITALIAN TEAMWORK BRINGING ORGANIZED-CRIME CHIEFS TO TRIAL

text: Agent Caprino's surreptitious role in Italy was approved by the Italian judiciary with an enthusiasm that American prosecutors say would have been unthinkable only a few years ago. It symbolized a new turn not only in the level of cooperation between American and Italian law-enforcement officials but also in a wide-ranging campaign now being waged in both countries against the leadership of organized crime.
title: U.S.-ITALIAN TEAMWORK BRINGING ORGANIZED-CRIME CHIEFS TO TRIAL

text: The effectiveness of this new round in an old battle that has often been attended by premature pronouncements of success remains to be seen, and skeptics abound.
title: U.S.-ITALIAN TEAMWORK BRINGING ORGANIZED-CRIME CHIEFS TO TRIAL

text: G. Robert Blakey, a Notre Dame Law School professor who helped formulate the current attack, says he is doubtful of its ultimate success ''unless there is a sustained follow-up that breaks up the structure and financial assets and the very activity'' of organized crime.
title: U.S.-ITALIAN TEAMWORK BRINGING ORGANIZED-CRIME CHIEFS TO TRIAL

text: But today, according to F.B.I. officials, there are more high-ranking members or associates of the Mafia or other organized-crime groups under Federal indictment than at any time previously.
title: U.S.-ITALIAN TEAMWORK BRINGING ORGANIZED-CRIME CHIEFS TO TRIAL

text: In New York alone, which they said was home to half the national membership of the Mafia, the number facing trial is well over 100. Other major cases are being tried now in Boston and Kansas City, Mo.
title: U.S.-ITALIAN TEAMWORK BRINGING ORGANIZED-CRIME CHIEFS TO TRIAL

text: The prosecutions have several foundations: a substantially increased use of electronic surveillance during the Reagan Administration; a growing reliance on a 1970 racketeering statute that, for years, was little understood even by prosecutors; the entry of the F.B.I. in 1982 into the ever-shifting war against international drug trafficking, and a decision by the Justice Department and the F.B.I. a half-dozen years ago to change their strategy against organized crime in general and the Mafia in particular.
title: U.S.-ITALIAN TEAMWORK BRINGING ORGANIZED-CRIME CHIEFS TO TRIAL

text: ''We've almost totally reversed a theory that you knock off La Cosa Nostra by the prosecution of single acts by individuals, by a numbers game of convictions,'' said Thomas Sheer, deputy assistant director in charge of the New York office of the F.B.I. ''We're going after the enterprise itself, and shredding the hierarchy. We've matured.''
title: U.S.-ITALIAN TEAMWORK BRINGING ORGANIZED-CRIME CHIEFS TO TRIAL

text: ''What you're seeing in court now is the culmination of five, six, seven years of effort,'' said Rudolph W. Giuliani, the United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York. ''We're not going to end crime, but I think it's realistic to expect that we can crush the Mafia.''
title: U.S.-ITALIAN TEAMWORK BRINGING ORGANIZED-CRIME CHIEFS TO TRIAL

text: Edward A. McDonald, the Federal prosecutor who heads the Organized Crime Joint Strike Force in Brooklyn, said that, because of the time lag between indictments and the resolution of appeals stemming from convictions, the impact of the current attack on the Mafia would ''not be clear at first. But there will be an impact,'' he said, ''because of the number in the hierarchy who will go down in the same period.''
title: U.S.-ITALIAN TEAMWORK BRINGING ORGANIZED-CRIME CHIEFS TO TRIAL

text: Thomas Puccio, who preceded Mr. McDonald in Brooklyn and is now a lawyer in private practice, took issue with an often-stated proposition that the Mafia will always regenerate itself.
title: U.S.-ITALIAN TEAMWORK BRINGING ORGANIZED-CRIME CHIEFS TO TRIAL

text: ''Someone who takes the place of a Mafia leader who is convicted is not necessarily someone of equal influence,'' Mr. Puccio said. Close Teamwork Between 2 Nations In Brooklyn, Charles E. Rose, an assistant United States attorney who prosecuted the Palazzolo case, keeps near his desk a bottle of Amaro Corleone, a liqueur that he bought on an official trip to Italy, and a snapshot of himself and others in a small Palermo restaurant. Seated next to Mr. Rose in the photograph is Giovanni Falcone, perhaps the best-known of the Italian magistrates who are engineering the assault on the Mafia in Sicily.
title: U.S.-ITALIAN TEAMWORK BRINGING ORGANIZED-CRIME CHIEFS TO TRIAL

text: ''These personal contacts we've developed count for a lot,'' said Mr. Rose. ''It matters that you can pick up the phone and call Palermo and know who you're talking to. You've had dinner with them, a glass of wine with them, and they know you can be trusted. The preliminaries are taken care of.
title: U.S.-ITALIAN TEAMWORK BRINGING ORGANIZED-CRIME CHIEFS TO TRIAL

text: ''Whether it's a matter of setting up surveillance on somebody getting on a plane or something else,'' Mr. Rose said, ''you know they'll get right to it and give it their best shot, as we do for the Italians. It's not the same with telexes and diplomatic notes.''
title: U.S.-ITALIAN TEAMWORK BRINGING ORGANIZED-CRIME CHIEFS TO TRIAL

text: In the Palazzolo case, Italian police officers posing as tourists walked up and down the sidewalk during the meeting with Agent Caprino at the Doney. And from a cafe across the broad Via Veneto, Italian police photographers recorded the scene.
title: U.S.-ITALIAN TEAMWORK BRINGING ORGANIZED-CRIME CHIEFS TO TRIAL

text: Mr. Palazzolo, who lived in Brooklyn and in Cinisi, Sicily, and several confederates were believed to be responsible for the monthly shipment of multi-kilogram quantities of heroin into the United States. All are now serving prison terms in this country. They are expected to be tried in absentia in Italy, at a trial of five other people accused of illegal drug dealings with Agent Caprino.
title: U.S.-ITALIAN TEAMWORK BRINGING ORGANIZED-CRIME CHIEFS TO TRIAL

text: American law-enforcement officials have traveled to Italy to aid the prosecution there, just as Italian officials have come here twice to gather further evidence in the case.
title: U.S.-ITALIAN TEAMWORK BRINGING ORGANIZED-CRIME CHIEFS TO TRIAL

text: Mr. Giuliani in Manhattan said American prosecutors and their Italian counterparts had long been confused by each other's legal system and requirements and had long been reluctant to share intelligence.
title: U.S.-ITALIAN TEAMWORK BRINGING ORGANIZED-CRIME CHIEFS TO TRIAL

text: ''We now have with Italian law-enforcement people about as close a working relationship as we have anywhere,'' he said. ''I must meet once a week with a representative of the Italian Government, and one of my assistants has probably spent more time in Italy in the last year than he has here.''
title: U.S.-ITALIAN TEAMWORK BRINGING ORGANIZED-CRIME CHIEFS TO TRIAL

text: This month, the Anti-Mafia Commission of the Italian Parliament received briefings in Washington and New York from American officials, including the staff of the President's Commission on Organized Crime. And the Italian-American Working Group on Organized Crime, established by the two Governments last year, is planning a computer link between law-enforcement officials in Washington and Rome.
title: U.S.-ITALIAN TEAMWORK BRINGING ORGANIZED-CRIME CHIEFS TO TRIAL

text: ''All this activity represents a relationship between people who have come to realize they're looking for many of the same people and doing many of the same investigations,'' said Pino Arlacchi, Italy's leading academic expert on the Mafia. ''It's not friendship; it's real collaboration.'' An Array of Cases On the Docket Among the major organized-crime cases now under way in the Southern District of New York, or scheduled to start shortly, are a half-dozen in which a total of more than 70 defendants face racketeering, drug conspiracy or other charges.
title: U.S.-ITALIAN TEAMWORK BRINGING ORGANIZED-CRIME CHIEFS TO TRIAL

text: In one of those cases, nine men, including the ''bosses or acting bosses of the five New York crime families,'' according to prosecutors, are accused of regulating the activities of a ''commission'' that governs the families. William H. Webster, the director of the F.B.I., described this indictment as ''historic,'' saying that it exposed ''the structure and leadership of organized crime on a scale never done before.''
title: U.S.-ITALIAN TEAMWORK BRINGING ORGANIZED-CRIME CHIEFS TO TRIAL

text: In the so-called ''pizza connection'' case in the Southern District, which includes Manhattan, the Bronx and seven upstate counties, 22 defendants are accused of operating a Mafia-connected drug ring that smuggled at least $1.65 billion in heroin from Sicily.
title: U.S.-ITALIAN TEAMWORK BRINGING ORGANIZED-CRIME CHIEFS TO TRIAL

text: A defense attorney in the ''pizza connection'' case said the quality of the cooperation marshaled by American and Italian authorities in that and other recent cases he was familiar with was ''fabulous and unprecedented.''
title: U.S.-ITALIAN TEAMWORK BRINGING ORGANIZED-CRIME CHIEFS TO TRIAL

text: ''Italy and the United States have been talking cooperation for a decade,'' he said, ''but now they're doing it, and it's going to make a difference. Does the Mafia know this? It's beginning to dawn on them.''
title: U.S.-ITALIAN TEAMWORK BRINGING ORGANIZED-CRIME CHIEFS TO TRIAL

text: In two pending cases in the Eastern District of New York, which includes Brooklyn, Queens, Staten Island and Long Island, 28 defendants face charges of labor racketeering in the moving and storage or air-freight industries. In another case, 25 reputed members and associates of a crime ''crew'' said by prosecutors to have been headed by three sons of ''the late Colombo family boss Joseph Colombo'' were indicted for a pattern of racketeering that included murder, attempted murder, extortion, narcotics trafficking, numerous home robberies, postal theft, mail and wire fraud, and interstate transportation of stolen property.
title: U.S.-ITALIAN TEAMWORK BRINGING ORGANIZED-CRIME CHIEFS TO TRIAL

text: In Boston, five reputed leaders of organized crime are on trial after what has been depicted as possibly the most extensive investigation of its kind ever conducted in New England, involving more than 850 hours of conversations secretly recorded by the F.B.I. Among the defendants is Gennaro J. Angiulo, whom law-enforcement officials have identified as the head of the Boston crime family.
title: U.S.-ITALIAN TEAMWORK BRINGING ORGANIZED-CRIME CHIEFS TO TRIAL

text: In Kansas City, a five-year investigation by Federal agencies in a half-dozen cities has led to the trial of nine reputed organized-crime figures who are accused of diverting profits from Las Vegas, Nev., casinos in which they were said to have maintained a hidden interest. Prosecutors have said the trial would disclose close ties between the underworld and officials of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters in the late 1970's.
title: U.S.-ITALIAN TEAMWORK BRINGING ORGANIZED-CRIME CHIEFS TO TRIAL

text: Scheduled to testify as a key Government witness is Anthony A. Lonardo, who for years was regarded as the second-in-command of the Cleveland crime family. Mr. Lonardo received a life sentence in 1983 after his Federal conviction in Cleveland on drug-conspiracy charges. He is now believed to be in protective custody.
title: U.S.-ITALIAN TEAMWORK BRINGING ORGANIZED-CRIME CHIEFS TO TRIAL

text: Mr. Lonardo, whom F.B.I. officials have portrayed as one of the most senior Mafia figures ever to cooperate with the Government, may also testify at the ''commission'' case trial in New York next spring.
title: U.S.-ITALIAN TEAMWORK BRINGING ORGANIZED-CRIME CHIEFS TO TRIAL

text: In interviews with the F.B.I., Mr. Lonardo has already linked Anthony Salerno, the reputed head of the Genovese crime family in New York, to the selection of Roy L. Williams and, later, Jackie Presser, as president of the teamsters' union. Mr. Salerno is a defendent in the ''commission'' case.
title: U.S.-ITALIAN TEAMWORK BRINGING ORGANIZED-CRIME CHIEFS TO TRIAL

text: A major Government witness in the ''pizza connection'' case will be Tommaso Buscetta, a well-connected Sicilian Mafioso who, after his arrest in Brazil in 1984, decided to cooperate with both Italian and American authorities. Mr. Buscetta is also scheduled to be a central witness in a trial of 800 Italians on Mafia charges that is expected to begin in a new high-security courthouse in Palermo early next year.
title: U.S.-ITALIAN TEAMWORK BRINGING ORGANIZED-CRIME CHIEFS TO TRIAL

text: ''We've got the sort of people testifying that were unheard of l0 years ago,'' said Oliver B. Revell, the F.B.I.'s executive assistant director for investigations. ''We've got bosses and underbosses testifying, and their knowledge of the entire national apparatus is extensive.'' In Italy and U.S., A Changing Mafia Sicilian Mafiosi have been privately providing the authorities with information on their rivals since at least the end of the 1960's. But as viewed by Professor Arlacchi, who is a consultant to the Italian parliamentary commission, Mr. Buscetta's willingness to speak out in a public forum was a rare exception to omerta, the code of silence.
title: U.S.-ITALIAN TEAMWORK BRINGING ORGANIZED-CRIME CHIEFS TO TRIAL

text: It illustrates, he said, the demoralized state of a violent but only moderately rich Italian Mafia that has, in recent years, been transformed from traditional, rural-based ''men of honor'' into ''modern entrepreneurs'' allied with businessmen. For a variety of reasons, including the urbanization of Sicily and the money available from narcotics even during the Corsican-dominated ''French Connection'' days in the early 1970's, the professor said, ''the search for wealth'' became the paramount goal.
title: U.S.-ITALIAN TEAMWORK BRINGING ORGANIZED-CRIME CHIEFS TO TRIAL

text: After the Italian Mafia came under ''some real investigations'' in the late l970's, Professor Arlacchi said, it resorted to killing scores of public officials in an effort at ''general intimidation.'' But that ''rational calculation from their point of view,'' he said, only elicited a backlash from the Government, church, intellectuals and young people who demanded the crackdown now in process and set the stage for the present cooperation with American officials.
title: U.S.-ITALIAN TEAMWORK BRINGING ORGANIZED-CRIME CHIEFS TO TRIAL

text: The existence of the Mafia as a coordinated, powerful organized-crime alliance in the United States was questioned for years. As recently as 1983, in a much-publicized trial in Chicago, a defense lawyer sought to portray it as a myth perpetrated by Hollywood, news organizations and the Government.
title: U.S.-ITALIAN TEAMWORK BRINGING ORGANIZED-CRIME CHIEFS TO TRIAL

text: Federal officials estimate there are now 1,700 to 2,000 formal members of American Mafia families, with as many as 10 associates for each member. A 1983 listing of Mafia members in New York City, by the city's Police Department, showed it as a relatively aged group, with few having been born after 1940.
title: U.S.-ITALIAN TEAMWORK BRINGING ORGANIZED-CRIME CHIEFS TO TRIAL

text: In testimony, also in 1983, before the President's Commission on Organized Crime, headed by Judge Irving R. Kaufman of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, William French Smith, then the Attorney General, traced the origins of a ''syndicate'' of 24 families to Prohibition and observed that it was not until the 1950's that Federal law-enforcement officials began to give organized crime ''sustained attention.''
title: U.S.-ITALIAN TEAMWORK BRINGING ORGANIZED-CRIME CHIEFS TO TRIAL

text: ''We - all of us as citizens - are paying the price for the late response of the Government to the nature and threat of organized crime,'' Mr. Smith said. ''And it is only in the last 15 years that the Government has been able to make much headway against the crime cartels.''
title: U.S.-ITALIAN TEAMWORK BRINGING ORGANIZED-CRIME CHIEFS TO TRIAL

text: Others have criticized the F.B.I. as being slow, even into the 1970's, to cope with what was increasingly regarded as a sophisticated, multibillion-dollar, illicit confederation that had moved with ease from bootlegging and gambling and prostitution to spread its tentacles into labor unions and legitimate businesses throughout the nation.
title: U.S.-ITALIAN TEAMWORK BRINGING ORGANIZED-CRIME CHIEFS TO TRIAL

text: Moreover, many law-enforcement officials have warned of a steady growth in the number and strength of ''non-traditional'' organized-crime groups in this country, ranging from black narcotics traffickers to motorcycle gangs to the Japan-based Yakuza and the Taiwan-based United Bamboo. Such groups, the Kaufman Commission said this month, threaten to become ''fixtures in America's mainstream economy in much the same fashion as the Mafia has become.'' New Weapons For Prosecutors The major weapons now being employed against organized crime date to 1968, when the Justice Department obtained authority under a new Federal law to seek court orders for wiretapping and bugging to investigate suspected criminal offenses.
title: U.S.-ITALIAN TEAMWORK BRINGING ORGANIZED-CRIME CHIEFS TO TRIAL

text: In 1970, Congress approved the Racketeer-Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act, or RICO, which makes it illegal to conduct an ''enterprise'' through a ''pattern of racketeering'' and provides a basis for forcing people connected with those enterprises to forfeit to the Government the ''ill-gotten gains'' from the racketeering.
title: U.S.-ITALIAN TEAMWORK BRINGING ORGANIZED-CRIME CHIEFS TO TRIAL

text: The RICO act was drafted by Professor Blakey of Notre Dame but, a decade after its passage, he wrote in a private analysis that the Justice Department was still not going after organized crime with the means at its disposal. He goaded the F.B.I. in Washington and lectured to agents in New York. He remembers his arguments being dismissed out of hand by some prosecutors.
title: U.S.-ITALIAN TEAMWORK BRINGING ORGANIZED-CRIME CHIEFS TO TRIAL

text: ''The Department of Justice has had an organized-crime program, which has been primarily focused on La Cosa Nostra, since about 1960, yet it has not eliminated one family,'' he wrote in 1980. ''All that has been accomplished has been to change the names of the players.''
title: U.S.-ITALIAN TEAMWORK BRINGING ORGANIZED-CRIME CHIEFS TO TRIAL

text: Professor Blakey complained that law-enforcement officials had ''failed to attack the structure of the LCN syndicate itself'' and said that, while there had been ''some significant convictions'' - although fewer significant sentences - ''the sources of the LCN economic power remain untouched.'' In short, he wrote, ''there has been no comprehensive strategy.''
title: U.S.-ITALIAN TEAMWORK BRINGING ORGANIZED-CRIME CHIEFS TO TRIAL

text: Today, with RICO being used in virtually all major prosecutions, the Federal strategy to destroy the ''apparatus'' of organized crime owes much to Professor Blakey. The professor said last week that, while the Goverment was still gravely ''underutilizing'' the act's forfeiture provisions, it now had ''the prospect of success. That's not to say Valhalla is around the corner.''
title: U.S.-ITALIAN TEAMWORK BRINGING ORGANIZED-CRIME CHIEFS TO TRIAL

text: Professor Blakey said the ''commission'' case in New York - a city where the smallest crime family is believed to be larger than the largest crime family anywhere else in the country - ''is what the Standard Oil case was to the Sherman Anti-Trust Act of 1890, and that took 20 years to do.''
title: U.S.-ITALIAN TEAMWORK BRINGING ORGANIZED-CRIME CHIEFS TO TRIAL

text: For some years law-enforcement officials and some courts divided over the question of whether the RICO forfeiture provisions applied to a wholly illegal enterprise - such as a crime family - as opposed to the more limited ''ill-gotten gains'' from, say, organized-crime infiltration of a legitimate business.
title: U.S.-ITALIAN TEAMWORK BRINGING ORGANIZED-CRIME CHIEFS TO TRIAL

text: Even Mr. Angiulo, the reputed head of the Boston crime family, seemed taken with the issue. In a conversation overheard by the F.B.I., he told an associate: ''Our argument is that we're illegitimate business.''
title: U.S.-ITALIAN TEAMWORK BRINGING ORGANIZED-CRIME CHIEFS TO TRIAL

text: ''We're a bookmaker,'' he said. ''We're selling marijuana. We are illegal here, illegal there. Arsonists. We are everything.''
title: U.S.-ITALIAN TEAMWORK BRINGING ORGANIZED-CRIME CHIEFS TO TRIAL

text: But in 1983, the United States Supreme Court interpreted the statute very broadly in the Government's favor.
title: U.S.-ITALIAN TEAMWORK BRINGING ORGANIZED-CRIME CHIEFS TO TRIAL

text: In non-narcotics organized-crime RICO prosecutions in 1984, according to the F.B.I., the Government sought or obtained $8.5 million in forfeitures, including a Lear jet and a number of French Gazelle helicopters. In the first half of 1985, the F.B.I. said, the figure was $35 million, including several aircraft and a large Texas ranch where prize-winning appaloosas are raised. Figures like these are regarded as too low by some staff members of the President's Commission on Organized Crime.
title: U.S.-ITALIAN TEAMWORK BRINGING ORGANIZED-CRIME CHIEFS TO TRIAL

text: The marked increase in the use of electronic surveillance in recent years is borne out by Federal court statistics. During the Carter Administration, the annual number of authorized installations of bugs and wiretaps nationally averaged slightly more than 80, about one-third fewer than in the preceding four years.
title: U.S.-ITALIAN TEAMWORK BRINGING ORGANIZED-CRIME CHIEFS TO TRIAL

text: In 1981, the figure increased to 106; in 1982, 129; in 1983, 205; and in 1984, 277. In New York alone, the figure rose from 74 in 1982 to 184 in 1984 and stood at 140 for the first eight moinths of 1985.
title: U.S.-ITALIAN TEAMWORK BRINGING ORGANIZED-CRIME CHIEFS TO TRIAL

text: Mark Summers, a defense attorney who was a Federal prosecutor in Brooklyn until last spring, remarked that, since the use of videotapes in the Abscam prosecutions, many jurors expected to see the results of electronic surveillance and ''are suspicious'' of the Government's case if such evidence is not available.
title: U.S.-ITALIAN TEAMWORK BRINGING ORGANIZED-CRIME CHIEFS TO TRIAL

text: A number of defense attorneys and civil libertarians today say the dominance of prosecutions under RICO casts an unwarranted, ''malevolent'' light on defendants who, they say, should be judged on their individual acts alone.
title: U.S.-ITALIAN TEAMWORK BRINGING ORGANIZED-CRIME CHIEFS TO TRIAL

text: ''RICO has become a law unto itself,'' said Stanley M. Meyer, who represents Alphonse Persico in a current New York case involving the Colombo crime family. ''It allows the Government to do whatever it wants and, with 30 or 40 defendants, nobody can get a fair trial.''
title: U.S.-ITALIAN TEAMWORK BRINGING ORGANIZED-CRIME CHIEFS TO TRIAL

text: But, in the larger framework of the Government's campaign against organized crime, even a RICO conviction may not have the kind of lasting impact Washington wants.
title: U.S.-ITALIAN TEAMWORK BRINGING ORGANIZED-CRIME CHIEFS TO TRIAL

text: Two cities in which organized-crime leaders were successfully prosecuted under RICO in recent years were Cleveland and Los Angeles. But, last week, Federal prosecutors in both cities said the effect had been more one of disruption than destruction.
title: U.S.-ITALIAN TEAMWORK BRINGING ORGANIZED-CRIME CHIEFS TO TRIAL

text: ''It created a bit of a vacuum at the top,'' said James Henderson, who prosecuted the case in Los Angeles. ''But now we've got all sorts of hoods coming in here.''
title: U.S.-ITALIAN TEAMWORK BRINGING ORGANIZED-CRIME CHIEFS TO TRIAL

text: ''See the stars! Fifty cents! Three for a dollar!'' Enchanted by the cosmos and perchance smelling a profit, Dwayne Reed, street vendor, has abandoned his career in the sale of counterfeit Gucci handbags and set up his telescope on the sidewalks of New York.
title: THE SELLING OF THE COMET, 1985

text: ''Comet-mania,'' Mr. Reed explained, ''the space age. Everyone's getting all excited about Halley's comet.
title: THE SELLING OF THE COMET, 1985

text: ''Things are looking up,'' he said, rubbing his hands together. Mr. Reed is selling glimpses of Saturn and Jupiter right now, but will begin marketing the first views of Halley's comet within a few days.
title: THE SELLING OF THE COMET, 1985

text: The comet nears. A city stands at the ready. Halley's comet has returned to earth every 76 years since the first recorded passing in 240 B.C. The earth is never quite the same from one visit to the next.
title: THE SELLING OF THE COMET, 1985

text: This time, mankind has evolved to the point where the comet will finally have an agent. Owen Ryan, president of General Comet Industries Inc., in Manhattan, is the self-proclaimed ''official representative of Halley's comet.'' And what's more, it's working.
title: THE SELLING OF THE COMET, 1985

text: He has drawn up a Halley's comet logo, and has sold licensing rights to manufacturers of such things as caps and jackets, necklaces and bracelets, tote bags, cocktail glasses, night shirts, balloons, T-shirts, a fast-food chain's ''Adventure Meals'' and stock certificates for shares in the comet.
title: THE SELLING OF THE COMET, 1985

text: ''At first people looked at us like we were from the planet Mongo,'' said Ted Donahue, who works with Mr. Ryan, explaining the reception they received when they tried to sell rights to the comet. Other deals they are pursuing include ''Comet Creepers'' shoes, Comet Cereal, Comet Cocktails, wristwatches and thermos jugs.
title: THE SELLING OF THE COMET, 1985

text: Calls pour into the office on Broadway at 20th Street from people who want to put the logo on hard hats to protect people from comet debris, on a book entitled ''Thinner Thighs In 76 Years'' and on other products. Odd things are arriving in the mail for consideration, such as: a ''moon rock,'' a rock with a bare derriere carved on the back; a comet doll, and Scotch whisky in a commemorative comet bottle.
title: THE SELLING OF THE COMET, 1985

text: There is a sense that the earth is better prepared for the coming of the comet this time. Scientific experiments are under way. Special programs are planned at museums and planetariums.
title: THE SELLING OF THE COMET, 1985

text: New York entrepreneurs have begun to market ''Halleyscope'' telescopes, ''Pin the Tail on the Comet'' games, ''Comet Rock'' candy, comet-watching excursions to southern climes - where the viewing is better - from Key West, Fla., to Peru, luxury comet cruises led by the likes of astronauts and Carl Sagan, and a trip to the heart of Australia, where 80,000 Japanese visitors are to set up a tent city for comet watching.
title: THE SELLING OF THE COMET, 1985

text: At stores selling telescopes, elbowing at the counters has already begun, even though the comet does not come closest to the earth until April 11 and should be visible by telescope until August.
title: THE SELLING OF THE COMET, 1985

text: Several of the stores report telescope sales up 100 percent from last year. ''My husband asked for a telescope for his birthday,'' said Miriam Fletcher, walking through a thicket of 40 different models in a variety of decorator colors on display at Brothers Cameras at Lexington Avenue and 45th Street. ''He has never shown the least interest in astronomy. It is either Halley's comet or an attractive young woman has moved into one of the buildings out our window.''
title: THE SELLING OF THE COMET, 1985

text: Indeed, other shoppers noted that telescopes and binoculars have long been standard equipment for high-rise dwellers. Abe Hakim, manager of the store, said yesterday that sales of telescopes were up more than 100 percent this year.
title: THE SELLING OF THE COMET, 1985

text: Mr. Hakim said the crunch is yet to come, with some people still not aware of the comet's coming. Asked what he thought about Halley's comet, Louis Carbone, a taxi driver said, ''Oh yeah, I remember that.
title: THE SELLING OF THE COMET, 1985

text: ''One o'clock, two o'clock, three o'clock rock,'' he said, reciting lyrics sung by Bill Haley and the Comets.
title: THE SELLING OF THE COMET, 1985

text: Burt Rubin, founder of the Halley Optical Corporation, on Third Avenue, said yesterday that those buying his ''Halleyscope'' telescopes would be able to see the comet in about two weeks and that the scopes can be used for voyeurism, among other things, long after. He is selling the telescopes, which retail for about $180, as fast as they can be manufactured.
title: THE SELLING OF THE COMET, 1985

text: Mr. Rubin, who became a multimillionaire marketing E-Z Wider rolling papers for marijuana cigarettes, read about the comet craze that occurred in 1910 and he began this company five years ago.
title: THE SELLING OF THE COMET, 1985

text: He read that telescope sales had boomed in 1910, that comet lounge chairs were sold, that comet-watching parties and picnics were held in parks and on rooftops throughout the world and that some people feared the comet's arrival.
title: THE SELLING OF THE COMET, 1985

text: After intensive research on the 1910 visit, both Mr. Rubin and Mr. Ryan say they have come to believe that the world has not changed as much in the last 76 years as one might think.
title: THE SELLING OF THE COMET, 1985

text: ''There was a story in a 1910 newspaper,'' Mr. Rubin said, ''that quoted a woman who had seen the comet in 1835 as saying the world was better then and that there were too many divorces in 1910. Stories next to the comet stories told of serious concerns about environmental problems and inflation, and about Congress arguing over an appropriations bill.''
title: THE SELLING OF THE COMET, 1985

text: In 1910 ''comet pills'' to ward off the effects of feared poisonous cyanogen vapors from the comet were being sold. This time around, the comet pills are new and improved, with a yogurt coating, and there are products heretofore unimagined such as Comet Dust hair glitter.
title: THE SELLING OF THE COMET, 1985

text: Both Mr. Ryan and Mr. Rubin said they have developed an awe and reverence for the comet through research for their products. They would both like for the coming of the comet to remind earthlings that they are all citizens of the same planet.
title: THE SELLING OF THE COMET, 1985

text: ''You can't help thinking about it sometimes,'' said Dwayne Reed, looking skyward.
title: THE SELLING OF THE COMET, 1985

text: ''See the stars! Fifty cents!''
title: THE SELLING OF THE COMET, 1985

text: By Francine Du Plessix Gray
title: No Headline

text: ON FEB. 6, 1934, MY uncle Andre Monestier joined my father and 40,000 other Frenchmen at the barricades to preserve the honor of France and overthrow a government which they thought inept and corrupt. Like most other patriots of their time, they looked on their nation as supreme unto all others in the glory of its culture and its political and military might, ''Mother of arms, of arts and of laws'' (a phrase drummed into them since infancy). And in the winter of 1934 that image was being sullied by a number of political scandals which had culminated in the Stavisky affair, a heist brought off by a foreign adventurer who had robbed France of billions of francs, implicating some of the country's most prominent men.
title: No Headline

text: At the cost of several dead and many wounded, most of the militants confronted the police at the Pont de la Concorde, near the Chamber of Deputies, and forced the resignation of the Daladier Government. My uncle and father, however, belonged to a quixotic right-wing organization called Croix de Feu, ''Fiery Cross,'' which had decided to avoid all physical violence. They remained in front of the restaurant Lasserre, just off the Champs-Elysees, and were satisfied to tear out the metal pickets that surrounded Lasserre's lawn, brandishing them as symbolic weapons. When policemen asked them the purpose of this singular gathering, my two relatives cried out: ''We are here to shout subversive words! We are shouting 'Vive la France!' ''
title: No Headline

text: ''Vive la France, subversive words!'' my uncle repeated with relish as he related the incident to me this past summer. ''I've always been proud of that answer, one barely hears those words anymore. . . .''
title: No Headline

text: We were seated on the terrace at La Croze, his summer property in the Gorges du Tarn, a savage, mountainous site in southern France where I've been visiting him since early childhood. My uncle Andre, now 90 years old, is the only relative I have left who has witnessed the changes that have swept France in our century. And I had returned this time to gauge the shifts in France's national consciousness by immersing myself in his quintessentially French family.
title: No Headline

text: Six foot two and massively built, my uncle is as lucid, vigorous and idealistic as ever. He was born in this very region, the Lozere, and traces his ancestry to 13th-century Albigensian dissenters who were forced to flee their ancestral village of Monestier (close to Albi; a map appears opposite page). And earlier that day I'd teased him with the notion that he had been made a true patriot by his more heretical traits - Utopian optimism, audacity, rebelliousness.
title: No Headline

text: ''Right,'' he'd quickly answered, ''too much passivity these days, people are always waiting for a leader . . . never wait, just vote for the least imbecile of the lot and continue griping and create whatever microcosm of perfection you can in your own life. . . .''
title: No Headline

text: Below us, as poplars gleamed on the sunny bank, a large wooden crate, strung on cables, was slowly traveling above the river Tarn, carrying Le Figaro and a load of groceries from the nearby village. My uncle's summer reteat, which he bought in 1935, had struck me since childhood as a microcosm of romantic perfection. La Croze is a complex of rustic gray stone buildings that can only be reached by boat, perched on that steep, rocky side of the Tarn canyon on which there is no road for many miles. And the region itself, the Lozere, is one of France's most untamed, close to where the Wild Boy of Aveyron is said to have been raised by wolves, the only part of the country in which wolves are said occasionally still to roam.
title: No Headline

text: ''The age of leaders may be over,'' my uncle was saying. ''It already was over in 1914. Do you realize that World War I was the first major war in history which did not bring forth one great man? Not one military genius? Led by total dunces who wasted men left and right? I was there, in the Somme. . . .'' I HAD ORIGINALLY STARTED visiting La Croze because Uncle Andre's wife, Aunt Simone, was a cousin of my father's, and the three had become inseparable by the time I was born. They shared interests in philosophy, maverick politics and exotic places thought bizarre by their conventional, provincial relatives. After being wounded and highly decorated in World War I, Uncle Andre had graduated from a competitive grande ecole - Polytechnique. He had settled in the Paris region, and, with a fairly modest capital investment -the equivalent of $6,000 in 1985 - he had started a small chemical factory that provided him with a comfortable living for some decades. Every few winters, he and my aunt set out on audacious trips considered outlandish by habitually cautious French travelers - they descended the Amazon into the wilds of Brazil, skied in the Carpathians, sailed through the Norwegian fjords.
title: No Headline

text: Aunt Simone was an indefatigable, high-spirited redhead with a vigorous need to nurture, shelter, spread cheer. The Monestiers had yearned for 10 children but had never been able to bear more than one daughter, Claude, a decade my senior. During my summer vacations at their eccentric hamlet, La Croze, they treated me as a second child, putting me to bed in their own room when the house was overcrowded with guests. Their boldness and largess remained unabated with the decades. During the years of the Nazi occupation, after my father had died with the Free French and I had immigrated to the United States, the Monestiers repeatedly risked their lives to shelter whatever underground fighters came their way. After the liberation, my uncle was elected mayor of La Malene, the impoverished village closest to La Croze. During his decade as mayor, he organized the first boatmen's union in the region, and lobbied relentlessly in Paris to provide his constituents with their first public water system.
title: No Headline

text: Two decades later, when he and Aunt Simone were close to 70 and their own finances were decimated by the forced sale of their chemical factory, they persuaded the Alliance Francaise to back their several trips to India where they gave lectures on Teilhard de Chardin. They lived in an ashram in Pondicherry for several months of the winter, rising at 5 A.M. to work and pray with the rest of the community. And, back in Paris, my uncle published a book entitled ''Teilhard or Marx?'' My aunt busied herself with Jungianism and graphology, supplementing income by analyzing handwriting samples at $30 a shot.
title: No Headline

text: By the age of 10, in the middle of the war, I had settled in the United States with my mother. But the deep love I had for the Monestiers, and theirs for me, remained undiminished by time or distance. After the war, returning to France every few years for a summer visit, I was increasingly fascinated by their views, which were as quirky and original as their avocations. Devout Catholics and Gaullists, they had come to believe that ''Communism is a manifestation of the Devil, a Satanic event''; yet they declared themselves to be Christian Socialists because ''capitalism is based on usury, which is forbidden by the Gospel.''
title: No Headline

text: Despite their love of travel and their great admiration for American character and customs, they never came to the United States because they judged it to be ''too similar to France, equally part of the materialistic West.'' Radically ecumenical, my uncle could write and publish the hazardous opinion that ''Christ has been present, through His Holy Ghost, in each religion since the world's beginnings,'' yet defend every Pope that came to power.
title: No Headline

text: In the last decade, the Monestiers' longing for a large family has been amply fulfilled. By 1980, the five children of their daughter Claude, who had married during the war, had given them 21 great-grandchildren. Claude's husband, Jean de Laromiguiere, had spent two years in Dachau for his work in the Resistance, suffered many nervous breakdowns and was frequently absent from home, leaving the Monestiers all the more in charge. Every summer the entire clan congregated loyally at La Croze, which teemed with little ones. And as I watched my adopted parents aging amid proliferating youth, I feared that I was seeing an aspect of France threatened with extinction. They belonged to a generation infused with the unquestioned authority of travail, famille, patrie, yet they also exemplified that spirit of idealism and risk that, until World War II, had constantly revitalized the nation, inspired its mavericks and visionaries, from the Curies to de Gaulle, from Cousteau to Teilhard.
title: No Headline

text: Could this balance of rootedness, daring and chivalry be maintained by their progeny? How did the sense of ''being French'' differ in 1985 from what it had been in 1934, when my father and uncle took to the streets to help overthrow a corrupt government? What are the French thinking today about such issues as religion, family, French-American relations, the threat of Communism, the atomic bomb? How has France's traditional sense of superiority been affected by its diminished status as a great power? These are some of the questions I'd set out to explore as I stood by the Tarn river on a July afternoon this year, waiting to be ferried across to La Croze.
title: No Headline

text: I had driven up from Montpellier, some three hours south, and parked my car in the family lot that lies below the D907 bis, the tortuous public road across the river from La Croze. I'd given my decades-old shout, ''Traversez!'' and been answered with the traditional ''On arrive!'' I inhaled the thyme and lavender on the hot air, stared at the gray garland of houses that lies nestled on the rock-crested mountain like a nation unto itself. I looked at the site with particular sadness and urgency, for my beloved Aunt Simone had died of a heart attack just five weeks before, aged 87. And my uncle, so I'd been told the day before on the phone, was in his bed at La Croze, suffering from bronchitis and a fever of 102.
title: No Headline

text: T WO BIKINI-CLAD beauties, Claude's 14- and 17-year-old granddaughters, whom I had last seen when they were 6 and 9, pole across the Tarn to fetch me, the wooden rods thudding softly against the stony river bed. My cousin Claude stands on the other side and runs for-ward to hug her welcome, a large, exuberant woman who has inherited her mother's tumultuous vitality and warmth. This particular afternoon she wears a green-and-white T-shirt inscribed with the words ''Tupperware-France,' ' the American company for whose Paris branch she has worked for over two decades. My uncle, she immediately reassures me, is improved today, and I can see him for a very short visit.
title: No Headline

text: In residence at La Croze, she adds as we climb the steep path to the house, are 27 members of the family -four of her five children, 14 of her grandchildren, several cousins. ''It's a great disappointment,'' she says. ''We'd planned to be 35.'' Missing from the reunion is her husband Jean, who ''is again in crisis.'' ''It's been a very sad summer,'' she sums up as we reach the house, ''but a wonderfully quiet one. Imagine, none of us has crossed the river more than once, on Sundays, to go to mass!''
title: No Headline

text: ''Oh well, the very best times are those when there is a priest vacationing here,'' says one of her granddaughters, ''and then we can spend weeks without crossing, except to fetch guests!''
title: No Headline

text: ''C'est ici qu'on se ressource,'' gravely adds her 15-year-old cousin - ''We're renewed, refueled here.'' And I sense that the mysterious force of tribal roots is exerting itself as fully as ever on the new generation.
title: No Headline

text: U NCLE ANDRE greets me from his bed, a biography of Pope John Paul II in hand, effusive and lucid despite his illness. Do I notice that he's wearing the red bathrobe I'd sent him for Christmas a decade ago, which he hasn't gotten out of since? No one must worry about this silly fever, don't we know what powerful stock he comes from? His 92-year-old sister, the retired nun, is playing bridge tournaments in Lyons, having lied about her age to get into the tournaments. . . . The room, sparsely furnished with rustic chairs and chests of fruitwood, left almost cave-dark by the narrow 17th-century windows that pierce the walls of rough-hewn stone, has barely changed since I slept in it as a child. I'd been determined to remain stoic about Aunt Simone's death, but at the sight of the half-empty bed my eyes flood with tears.
title: No Headline

text: ''Come come,'' my uncle says gently, touching my cheek. ''It's sad but not so sad. What's life but a passage to more important things?'' The faith of the phrase threatens to set me off again, so I hasten downstairs to the terrace, where the immense family always congregates when it isn't pouring rain, the one indoor public room being constantly used as a bedroom by some member of the clan.
title: No Headline

text: As I join my cousins, they are finishing Sunday lunch, a frugal, American-style meal prescribed long ago by Aunt Simone so that no one would have to cook on the Sabbath: a self-service buffet of hot dogs, rolls and red wine, a selection of popsicles for dessert. After the emotional mayhem of greetings, the queries about the health of my family back in the United States, the introduction to each child born since my last visit, my relatives sink into their ''chaises relax'' to take their coffee. From now until 5, when everyone will descend to the Tarn for the ritual late-afternoon swim, the air hums with the clicking of knitting needles and the snipping of scissors. Most of the women are making a garment for another member of the family - evening dress for a 16-year-old niece, bloomers for a 4-year-old nephew - while the rest of us sit on the lawn, stringing beans for supper. Yves de Laromiguiere, Claude's youngest son, sits apart with his brothers-in-law and nephews, planning next morning's work. All the upkeep of the property is done by the men of the family - there is always a leaking roof to be repaired, a generator to be serviced, brush to be cleared in many fields.
title: No Headline

text: As the shadows lengthen and everyone prepares for the evening swim, a 5-year-old passes his cousins and siblings the basket holding the afternoon gouter - dark chocolate nestled in thick chunks of white bread. I follow the clan down the steep path to the Tarn, and we all wade into mid-river to a small, pebbly island some 20 feet wide and 40 feet long that I find strikingly uncomfortable and claustrophobic. The family favors it because it offers shallow water on one side for the little ones, more adventurous depths on the other side for the adults. They remain there until close to suppertime and continue the family banter started over lunch, two-dozen relatives supremely content with each other, seeking out for the evening hours an enclave even more intimate and crowded than the one they have spent the day in. As I watch this tribal spectacle, it strikes me that they might be recreating, in these compulsive yearly gatherings, a micro-France of bygone years, indulging in a nostalgic fantasy of that superior, united, self-sufficient nation that their patriarch had already battled to preserve a half-century ago.
title: No Headline
