text: Of the adults gathered on that crowded island, I have chosen six who might express how that sense of France has changed.
title: No Headline

text: Chantal de Bussac, Claude's second-oldest daughter, a very handsome, outgoing woman of 42, has amply inherited her grandparents' forthright warmth and intellectual gifts. Before her marriage she taught mathematics and physics to the senior class of a girls' school in Paris. For the last 14 years she has lived in Clermont-Ferrand, her husband's native city, which she prefers to the capital because ''it provides better quality of life for the children.'' Soon after the last of her four offspring was born, she began to feel restless and became interested in the theories of personality development formed in the United States by the psychologist and author Carl Rogers. For two years, she spent part of each week in Lyons, leaving her husband in charge of the children, learning ''la methode Rogers.'' Using its techniques of consciousness-raising, she now runs group seminars in which she teaches women to ''fulfill their identities, express themselves more eloquently, abolish their sense of powerlessness.''
title: No Headline

text: Although Chantal is still uncomfortable with the ''feminist'' label, she admits that her work involves ''a quintessence of nonconfrontational feminism.'' She has also been active in a nationwide organization, Accueils des Villes Francaises, which helps women adapt to their surroundings when they move to a new city. Chantal feels that a recent blossoming of volunteer organizations is one of the most striking developments in contemporary France, and that it has to do with a great loss of faith in the state as an agent of change. She heartily welcomes this new public-mindedness. ''We're at last crawling out of our traditional shell, the home, and reaching out to others.'' The de Bussacs also do a great amount of volunteer work for their parish, including a weekly counseling session for couples who are about to be married. (''Can you imagine, some of them tell us they've already been living together . . . that would have sounded very startling 10 years ago!'') Pierre de Bussac, Chantal's husband, is the most cosmopolitan of my cousins. A slight, pensive man approaching 50, he is a graduate of a competitive grande ecole - Ecole des Mines. He spent a year in the Soviet Union in the 1960's, overseeing the installation of French machinery in Soviet chemical plants. He speaks and writes Russian fluently and speaks English well, though he is very shy about using it. After a stint with the American firm Armco, he now directs a small company that makes computer printout paper in Clermont-Ferrand.
title: No Headline

text: ''Etre Francais, c'est etre contre,'' Pierre says - ''To be French is to be against.'' But he senses that his compatriots are dissatisfied with a larger variety of issues than ever before, and that they are engaging in an unprecedented amount of self-criticism. Pierre's particular obsession is the ''downright pathetic state'' of France's scientific research, which lacks any systematic or adequate funding. ''Americans might seem overly specialized to us, but you're the ones getting the Nobels.''
title: No Headline

text: Pierre feels that the French are undergoing a crisis of identity that was originally triggered by the student uprisings of 1968, when all forms of traditional authority were put into question. Like every member of the Monestier-Laromiguiere clan, he is militantly opposed to Mitterrand's Socialist Government and to all forms of leftism. Yet he does not totally share his in-laws' condemnatory views of the 1968 rebellion and believes it was a great benefit to French family structure. ''It made better parents of us, it finally taught us to listen to children's opinions as the most interesting and precious we can hear, it transformed the table talk of French families . . . it is at table that everything happens.''
title: No Headline

text: In Clermont, Pierre's favorite recreation is to see American films, particularly those of Woody Allen. He dismisses all allegations of American cultural imperialism abroad as ''more misguided leftist nonsense.'' He believes that French culture ''needs to turn outward in every possible way, and would benefit by emulating American models of business management, scientific research and philanthropic funding.''
title: No Headline

text: Catherine de Maistre, Chantal's younger sister, is a delicate, elegant woman with a striking resemblance to the young Zizi Jeanmaire. Her sinuous, feline charm is ill-matched to her grimly disciplinarian views. During a short walk we took together, she said that ''1968 was a watershed year for me because I was in the last year of school and my brother Bruno and I were tempted to join our classmates and go to some demonstrations. But mother put her foot down and said, 'I've worked my heart out to support you, don't you dare go out there or you can't come home.' It was blackmail on her part, virtual blackmail, but I've always been grateful to her for it. . . . She taught us then and there the supremacy of family duty and patriotic values, of order, order above all . . . and I've tried to instill the same values in my children.''
title: No Headline

text: For a decade Catherine had fervently hoped to bear a son who might continue her husband's illustrious name: Alain de Maistre is a direct male descendant of Joseph de Maistre (c.1753-1821), the prominent archconservative thinker whose writings opposed les philosophes of the Enlightenment, deplored the progress of science and acclaimed public executioners as the guardians of social order. Catherine and Alain bore four daughters in a row, and a few years ago rejoiced at the birth of their first son.
title: No Headline

text: The de Maistres shun their local parish in fashionable Neuilly because it is ''close to being Communist,'' and travel a distance to attend mass at which they listen to ''marvelously old-fashioned authoritarian sermons which hold even the youngest children spellbound.'' Catherine has recently stopped reading Elle magazine because of its support of legalized abortion and switched her loyalties to Madame Figaro, which she consders the most ''B.C.B.G.'' - bon chic, bon genre - publication in France. Catherine says she would be ''deeply shocked'' if one of her daughters admitted to having sex before marriage. Like her sister Chantal and her brother Bruno, Catherine came to spend some weeks with me in the United States in the mid-1960's. She was ''overwhelmed by Americans' hospitality and warmth.'' And, notwithstanding her qualms about the permissiveness of our mores (''one intake of marijuana in school and you get hooked for life on stronger stuff like cocaine and heroin''), she wishes fervently that each of her children might enjoy a similar stay in the States when they come of age.
title: No Headline

text: Alain de Maistre, lanky, 6 foot 2, did his military service in France's most elite paratroop corps, stayed on a few extra years, and almost decided to make a career of it. He is the director of an advertising agency that handles financial accounts, including that of the Banque Nationale de Paris. He is more publicly active than his home-loving wife, and his great cause is the Boy Scout movement. He recently spent seven years as Scoutmaster, giving the movement a dozen hours a week. He trained for the paratroop corps in several different countries and the happiest times of all were spent in Germany, the country for which his generation and that of his children feel the most sympathy.
title: No Headline

text: ''I found no difference whatsoever in human values, in any point of view, between our group and our German colleagues.'' The most unhappy days of Alain's paratrooper training were spent in England, which my cousins unanimously agree is that country in the world which the French dislike the most. ''The British forced our unit into total isolation. The British will never become Europeans; they'll always remain insular, a culture of their own.''
title: No Headline

text: Like every one of my relatives, Alain and Catherine have intense admiration for Ronald Reagan, as they had for Richard Nixon. (''How lucky you are to still have such great leaders! Magnificent men!'') Alain says that he inherited a negative view of the United States and only began to admire it in his late teens, when his Scout troop was taken to the World War II museum in Normandy. ''I learned there to my total amazement that the U.S. forces had participated in the liberation of France - in all our history courses we were taught that the Free French alone had liberated the country.''
title: No Headline

text: Yves de Laromiguiere, Claude's fifth and youngest child, is the family's political activist. For the first five years of his marriage, he lived near Amiens, where he ran for the Chamber of Deputies on Valery Giscard d'Estaing's ticket. He is tall and heavyset, like his grandfather, with a ready smile and a voluble gift for conversation. He now lives in Brussels, where he directs the Belgian branch of a French wallpaper concern.
title: No Headline

text: One of Yves' favorite political topics is the need for a united European community. ''France can't go it alone any more than Great Britain or Italy can. If we don't destroy our outdated boundaries and create Europe, the decline of Western civilization will be as total as that of Egypt or other ancient cultures. The first step is to create one single European monetary unit; but like other tasks in building Europe it can't be done through the political system.
title: No Headline

text: ''The notion of abandoning French currency is an abomination for the average French deputy and his constituents. So we have to lobby for it, create a massive grass-roots movement which will impose the notion on our politicians. The situation is already serious, dangerous; Europe is becoming poorer by the day. . . .''
title: No Headline

text: Yves enjoys Brussels because ''it's marvelous to live in a country which has no complex of superiority.'' He looks upon that particular trait of his countrymen as ''an escapist delusion kept alive for too many decades by de Gaulle and not yet eroded enough.'' His devout Catholicism is an interesting mixture of liberal and conservative. He shares his grandfather's belief in the equal sanctity of all religions, and finds it abominable that the Church of Rome still retains the word ''Catholic'' in the Nicene Creed: ''One Holy, Catholic and Apostolic Church.'' ''The word 'Catholic' should immediately be dropped to make a statement of universal salvation,'' Yves says. Yet like most every member of the family, he and his wife go to confession once a month. And last fall the couple accompanied Yves' mother, Claude, on a pilgrimage to a site in Yugoslavia where the Virgin Mary is said to be appearing daily to six young peasants.
title: No Headline

text: As with the rest of his kin, the central priority of Yves' life is his children's education. He is very critical of both the Belgian and the French educational system. ''They cram you with facts and don't teach you how to use them,'' he says. So, notwithstanding his profound dislike of the British, Yves is sending his oldest son, Louis, 9, to a Jesuit boarding school in England. During one of our lunch conversations, Yves said that if he were doomed with some illness and had only a few months to live, he would spend all his time writing letters to each of his four children, ''a fundamental letter for each year of their growing up until they reach the age of 21.'' Every member of the assembled family enthusiastically agreed that they could not conceive of a better way to spend their last days on earth.
title: No Headline

text: ''What do you think of Allen Ginsberg's 'Howl'? '' Yves' wife, Sybille, asked me in her near-perfect English on one of my mornings at La Croze. She is a seductive, green-eyed redhead with a spunky sense of humor and has graduate degrees in British and American literature from the University of Amiens. She taught her subject in a private school while bringing up four children. Her reading in contemporary American literature, which seems to go up to 1960, includes Henry Miller, Arthur Miller and Truman Capote. She yearns to return to the United States, where she once spent a summer on Long Island.
title: No Headline

text: Unlike my other relatives, Sybille thinks it wrong for Catholics to impose their views against abortion on the population at large and is opposed to the growing movement to repeal legal abortion in France. Sybille is militant, however, on the issue of preserving the freedom of private church schools. She and Yves traveled from Brussels twice in 1984 to attend rallies protesting government legislation that threatened to curtail that freedom and which drew unprecedented crowds of a million and a half people. Sybille is also adamant on the issue of premarital sex. ''I'm particularly disturbed when unmarried teachers have sex together. Il faut avant tout ne pas choquer'' - ''Above all, one must never shock.''
title: No Headline

text: B OTH THE AMERICAN television imports ''Dallas'' and ''Dynasty'' are unanimously shunned and derided by the family (''C'est pour les ploucs'' - ''It's for the simple-minded'';) and the children are forbidden to view them because of their ''low moral caliber.''
title: No Headline

text: My relatives have not read, or seen, and have barely heard of: Roland Barthes, Jacques Derrida, Marcel Ophuls, Marguerite Duras or most other persons who have recently served as cultural bridges between France and the United States. Being little aware of discussions about the mediocrity of current French culture and its consequent colonization by foreign talent, they are indifferent to the fact that a Chinese-American architect is about to build a pyramid in the courtyard of the Louvre, that an Italian has been commissioned to design the interior of the new Quai d'Orsay museum and that a Canadian architect is designing the new opera house at the Place de la Bastille.
title: No Headline

text: My relatives' names sound ancient and romantic but their means are modest, and their talk seems totally centered on Confucian concerns for family and on issues of immediate survival - how best to take care of grandfather Monestier now that he is widowed; the threat posed to Pierre de Bussac's business, where production has been cut by 30 percent because of several strikes by the C.G.T., France's largest union; the precarious finances of Yves' older brother, Bruno, who must support six children on the meager salary he earns from an American automotive company whose French branch has fallen on bad times; how to pool the money direly needed to maintain La Croze, the upkeep of which they finance jointly.
title: No Headline

text: Along with their obsession with the children's education, they are, above all, immersed in the cultivation of harmonious family bonds; their concept of ''self'' seems virtually nonexistent outside of the communal context of their extended family. These dutiful, cautious lives may strike Americans as constrained, class-conscious, tradition-bound. Yet one cannot help but admire the remarkable cordiality, tenderness and deference that is maintained between siblings and cousins, parents and children, and, most striking of all, between husbands and wives. It is a family in which women have considerable influence and power and often express themselves in strong language, as they did on a recent summer afternoon:
title: No Headline

text: A young married couple, only vague acquaintances, had waded across the Tarn for a visit. The aggressive, loquacious husband sat by my uncle talking of the abandoned shepherd's house he had just bought on one of the neighboring causses, the barren stony plateaus that dominate the gorges of the Tarn and of other neighboring rivers. He planned to live there with his bride five months of the year. He was rebuilding the walls and roofs of the house with his own hands. He had just started his own lumber business in the area; no more of the capital's ''metro, boulot, dodo'' -roughly ''subway, the office grind, and off to bed'' - current shorthand for the hassle of Parisian life.
title: No Headline

text: ''And do you have any employment, Madame . . . '' my uncle courteously asked the waifish, very silent young wife. ''Hell no, I wouldn't let her,'' the husband interrupted with a lewd wink. ''Who'd want a wife who's all tired out at night?''
title: No Headline

text: ''That man is a walking phallus!'' Sybille exclaimed as soon as the uninvited guests had started wading back to the opposite bank.
title: No Headline

text: ''Must be a beast in bed,'' my cousin Claude remarked.
title: No Headline

text: ''Poor pretty girl,'' my 90-year-old uncle said; ''she'd be better off with me.''
title: No Headline

text: D U VIN FIN A dejeuner,'' uncle Andre called out from his bedroom as his lunch tray was about to be brought, ''none of our local everyday swill! And a poire with my coffee!''
title: No Headline

text: By the third day I was at La Croze, my uncle's fever had abated and I was able to visit with him for a few hours of the afternoon. He sat in his armchair by a window that overlooked the Tarn, shoes impeccably shined, the Legion of Honor rosette blazing in the lapel of his tweed jacket. He had discovered my predilection for serious talk when I was about 6 years old, and, as in our meetings of past decades, he began with a little theme that he wished me to ponder. This time, it had to do with the 20th century as analogous to the Book of Job.
title: No Headline

text: ''It is simply not normal,'' he began, ''for God to send us as many plagues as he has since 1914. At just about that time, as I see it, God and the Devil had one of their big executive meetings, and the Devil said, 'You think they're worthy down there? Let's test them out with some real trouble and we'll find out.' And sure enough the Lord sent all those plagues to test our faith, the decimation of World War I, Hitler, Stalin. . . .''
title: No Headline

text: ''My heretic ancestry!'' he pointed his cane toward the windows and mountains. ''You've always thought that's my source. . . . Well, I do grow increasingly Manichaean as I get older. I sense that a force of Evil has been pitted against Good since the Creation. And in 1985 God sits up there, still challenged by the Devil, pretending He's dead, pretending He's abandoned us, testing us, testing. . . .''
title: No Headline

text: He paced the room slowly, his eyes benign under the bushy black brows even when he wished to look threatening. ''Well, we deserve His abandonment, we asked for it. Pope John Paul put it best, Christians have failed the Gospel, capitalism is totally unjust toward the working class. But we might just be able to come out of it. I feel we're at the end of the Great Temptation. Mind my words, the 21st Century will be the spiritual century, or it will not be at all. . . .''
title: No Headline

text: It had been two hours since the younger generations had been in the patriarch's room. They had been admonished to respect his afternoon rest. Now they started crowding in as they do every midafternoon, bringing their hugs and kisses, their presents of butterflies and leaves, their admonitions to him to avoid ''courants d'air'' and to move about less. Tea was brought in, and somehow we all fell to talking about heroes. Which public figures did we particularly admire or uphold as heroes, either past or present?
title: No Headline

text: ''Dear God, all the heroes I was brought up to revere as a schoolboy!'' uncle Andre exclaimed. ''Archetypes of patriotic valor: Vercingetorix, Roland at the pass, Napoleon. Later on I also adulated Clemenceau, Poincare, Teilhard, and still later Gandhi, the great pacifist Lanza del Vasto. . . .''
title: No Headline

text: ''Well those of us who came of age during the last war never admired military men,'' my cousin Claude said. ''My heroes are Renoir and Berthe Morisot, those passionate, sensual artists who can fill our lives with joy and warm colors. Oh, I'd crawl through the Sahara on all fours to own one. . . .''
title: No Headline

text: ''I admire most those who work above and beyond politics,'' said Claude's daughter, Chantal. ''Like Mother Teresa.''
title: No Headline

text: ''Mozart, Bach, Chopin,'' said Anne, Claude's silent, pensive daughter, who seldom participates in group conversation.
title: No Headline

text: I turned to the generation of my uncle's great-grandchildren, who were gathered together in the back of the room. ''I balk at the very notion of heroes,'' said 17-year-old Arnaud, Chantal's eldest child. ''Well . . . perhaps Einstein.''
title: No Headline

text: ''The only heroes I have are fictional,'' said Cristelle, his 17-year-old sister, ''like Julien Sorel.''
title: No Headline

text: ''But why have heroes?'' exclaimed her 17-year-old cousin from Tours, Valerie. ''Our generation refuses heroes! That's our motto, no more heroes! We've all seen the obverse side of the coin, we all know the shoddy seamy side of geniuses and public men!''
title: No Headline

text: ''We don't even have any more leaders,'' she added defiantly. ''Et je trouve ca tres bien,'' - ''I think it's all to the good.''
title: No Headline

text: Claude exclaims, lifting up her Tupperware plastic rolling pin for everyone to see. ''Impeccable pie crust in 60 seconds without a moment of sticking! And now I transfer my dough into the pie plate . . . see, even the rolling surface is intact!''
title: No Headline

text: Claude joined the Tupperware corporation some two decades ago, shortly after it had opened its first office in Paris. She was the 11th dealer in France. ''Tupperware of America!'' she exclaims to anyone not acquainted with the company: ''An enterprise of genius, branches in 33 countries!'' Today she is giving me a Tupperware demonstration on the terrace of La Croze, and a score of her progeny have assembled for the umpteenth time to watch her. ''Here's the secret!'' she continues. ''A hollow plastic rolling pin which we fill with ice-cold water to avoid any sticking!''
title: No Headline

text: The very way in which Claude joined Tupperware seems providential. It was in 1962, and her husband, Jean de Laromiguiere, had just undergone the second of the major nervous breakdowns that he would suffer after his return from Dachau. With five children to support, Claude's finances were desperately strained. She economized by going to Les Halles at 5 every Thursday morning to do the entire week's marketing. A friendly merchant expressed concern that Claude's groceries might spoil, and showed her a streamlined new kind of plastic container which, she claimed, insured weeklong garden freshness. Claude immediately coveted the containers and was dismayed to learn that ''le Tupperware'' is sold only ''en salon'' - at demonstrations in private homes.
title: No Headline

text: But the merchant promised to arrange such an event, and within a fortnight my cousin was watching a Comtesse de Chambure (''proprietor of a splendid chateau in the Somme'') sell several hundred dollars' worth of the American miracle in one after-noon. Broke and energetic, Claude immediately decided to join the circle of Parisian women making independent incomes through the plastic wonder. She found her first clientele through her hairdresser, who invited Claude to perform in an apartment building of a working-class suburb.
title: No Headline

text: ''All the women there were members of the C.P.,'' Claude recalls. ''They launched me, and I owe them eternal gratitude. With the Communist ladies, I'd doubled my sales quota in a fortnight. The secret? Communists love presents, and Tupperware offers a free gift with each purchase.''
title: No Headline

text: Twenty years later, Claude directs a Tupperware concession that covers a few hundred miles miles north and west of Paris and supervises more than 400 sales personnel. In the last two decades, she has ''seen the world thanks to Tupperware,'' attending conferences and visiting branch offices in 19 countries, including Ireland, Senegal, Indonesia and the United States, where she spends most of her time at the company headquarters in Orlando, Fla. She speaks no more than a few words of English. She admires, above all our other institutions, Thanksgiving holiday, ''a sign of the profound religiosity of the American people.''
title: No Headline

text: In the 1970's, when Claude's deranged husband began to leave home for months at a time, she drew strength from still another American import - the ''speaking in tongues'' manifestation of the charismatic movement, which had recently migrated from United States churches to those of Europe and was making spectacular inroads into French Catholicism. (It is also called Le Mouvement du Renouveau, somewhat analogous to our term ''born again.'') Claude learned about it from a colleague at Tupperware's office in Nantes and discovered ''a form of prayer which is all the deeper because it abandons logical linguistic symbols.''
title: No Headline

text: In the last few years, this daughter of the country gentry has become one of the charismatics' most active street evangelists. On Saturday mornings, she meets a dozen colleagues in front of a prosperous branch of the Felix Potin grocery chain in Neuilly. The group stands on the sidewalk, reading and chanting texts to a guitar accompaniment and urging any passerby who approaches them to ''read and spread the Gospel.'' Claude sees the charismatic movement as one more way in which staid, conservative French adults are joining in voluntary organizations, taking to the streets to fulfill their needs and aspirations.
title: No Headline

text: ''And wait till you see our new Ultra 21 line,'' Claude says as she brandishes a souffle mold at the end of her Tupperware demonstration. ''Tupperware for the 21st century! A revolutionary new brand of plastic that can go straight from the freezer into a 350-degree oven!''
title: No Headline

text: ''Formidable!'' Even the athletic teen-age grandsons applaud. ''Mother is so persuasive,'' Catherine says proudly. ''She could sell you a bag of rusty nails even if she'd told you they were rusty.''
title: No Headline

text: But Claude's oldest daughter, 43-year-old Anne, has knitted dourly throughout the performance, her eyes cast down on her clicking needles, as she sits through most of her days at La Croze. She is a brooding woman with a great gift for music, which she was never able to fulfill, and a broken marriage. And, as she angrily knits on the terrace at La Croze, I am forced to recall that she is that child of the Monestier-Laromiguiere clan most profoundly marked by the traumas of World War II.
title: No Headline

text: Anne was a year old in 1942, when her mother and father, Jean de Laromiguiere, a brilliant and eccentric graduate of Saint-Cyr, undertook one of the most perilous tasks of the Resistance: they turned their small Paris apartment into a shelter whence Free French and other members of the underground were guided to the Spanish frontier. The resisters' hiding place was a small bedroom reached through Anne's nursery, its door hidden by a curtain. The Laromiguieres's escape network was eventually infiltrated by a Gestapo informer, and Jean was sent to Dachau. During the following months, Claude shifted homes every few days with her tiny daughters, Anne and Chantal, to avoid her own arrest.
title: No Headline

text: Anne was 4 when she saw her father return from Dachau, a dour, silent invalid weighing some 70 pounds. He had repeatedly suffered floggings and solitary confinement for agitating in behalf of fellow inmates. She was 12 when her father had his first total breakdown.
title: No Headline

text: For a decade, a series of French doctors, hardly known for their contribution to the field of mental health, tried to cure Jean with a combination of drugs and sleeping cures, which entailed being put to sleep for months at a time. During one such treatment, he fell off his bed while unattended and lay hours on a freezing hospital floor, contracting double pneumonia and suffering setbacks of mental illness.
title: No Headline

text: Lithium drugs were made available in France in the late 1960's, and these periodically enabled Jean to resume some kind of family life. I saw him at La Croze in 1974 and 1977. Plump and numbed by the drug, my once razor-witted cousin spent most of his time wandering about the property, keeping company with the youngest of his grandchildren, dusting their toys, pushing their swings. During periods when he refused treatment, he would leave home for stretches of up to two years, begging hospitality in different provinces from relatives and friends.
title: No Headline

text: Since his most recent cure he often comes to Paris to lunch with Claude. ''The independence I've gained through my Tupperware work has given me courage,'' she told me this summer. ''The charismatic movement has strengthened the faith I need to pray for his total healing.''
title: No Headline

text: ''And you know,'' she adds with her brave, luminous smile, ''they both came from the United States.'' ''HE IS THE CRUCIBLE for our memory.'' That is the phrase with which 17-year-old Arnaud de Bussac describes the missing member of the yearly family reunion, Jean de Laromiguiere, his recurringly ill, absent grandfather. ''He has forced us to remember the past, to a far greater degree than most of our generation. And one must remember in order not to start again; it is forgetfulness which could start another war. . . .''
title: No Headline

text: And yet, I note, Germany is the country for which he and his relatives feel the most affinity. Doesn't his grandfather's suffering, begun at Dachau, make it particularly difficult for his family to feel close to Germans?
title: No Headline

text: ''The first thing grandpapa said when he returned from camp is this,'' says Arnaud's 14-year-old brother, Nicolas. ''We must remember, but we must also forgive.''
title: No Headline

text: ''Anyhow, we must all outgrow our sense of national boundaries,'' says Arnaud, who is cramming for the admissions examination to his great-grandfather's school, the prestigious Polytechnique, and whose words are heeded with reverence by his peers. ''I feel just as 'European' as I feel 'French.' There is much more affinity these days between a French and a German than there is between a Breton and Parisian.''
title: No Headline

text: The six youngsters, whose ages range from 14 to 17, nod approvingly. Arnaud, two of his siblings and three of his cousins are dining with me at a small restaurant at La Malene, the village a few miles upstream from La Croze. In the first half-hour, they've already confronted me with two myths which I destroyed as well as I could. One, ''In the States everyone informs you of their annual salary the second they meet you.'' Two, ''Americans publish no news about France whatsoever in their newspapers; they don't even bother to study French anymore, everyone's learning Japanese.''
title: No Headline

text: I'd asked them about their future vocations. Arnaud is one of ''Les happy few'' whose scientific career would be assured by his admission into a grande ecole. His sister Cristelle would like to work in the business management of some international couture or perfume industry, ''ideally like Hermes.'' Valerie, 17, is studying at the Ecole du Louvre, aspires to be an art dealer and detests any art more recent than the Impressionists. Nicolas, 14, wishes to start his own business enterprise. (''Good luck, old man,'' the others jibe at him. ''It's not like the old days when great-grandfather could set up a factory on a pittance. These days the Government stifles all initiative.'') All of these youngsters fear that their schools' outdated curriculums, and the general rigidity of French society, could pose severe obstacles to their goals. ''We can't seem to succeed according to our gifts anymore, as you still can in the United States.'' ''Our country is too withdrawn into itself, our economic system seems unable to find any source of renewal.'' ''Our schools only cram us with facts with which to pass exams; we need a more complete formation which would include computer techniques, arts, sports.''
title: No Headline

text: If they were of age, how would they vote to remedy these ills in the legislative elections scheduled for the spring of 1986? They all shrug their shoulders indifferently. ''Raymond Barre seems O.K,'' Arnaud says. ''I'd vote for the right, to be sure,'' Valerie says, ''and probably for Jean-Marie Le Pen on the first round, as a protest.'' Do they feel threatened by the possibility of an atomic war? ''We're much more afraid of pacifists and demonstrations and protest movements than of the bomb,'' Nicholas says defiantly, and the group nods vehemently in assent.
title: No Headline

text: Their favorite musicians are Michel Sardou, Pink Floyd and Simon and Garfunkel. The only American actor they care for is Gregory Peck. Their favorite French stars are Isabelle Adjani, Miou-Miou and Marlene Jobert. They are in unanimous accord that their parents are ''absolutely fair and liberal'' in their ways of imposing discipline, and that their private schools, most of which are church schools, ''do not give a rigorous-enough religious formation.''
title: No Headline

text: And their favorite moments of the year are spent at La Croze, where there is nothing much to do beyond engage in family banter, do maintenance work on the property, take a daily swim in the Tarn and a weekly trip to La Malene to go to mass and enjoy many visits with great-grandfather Monestier (''The most extraordinary man we'll ever know.'' ''A magnetic force.'' ''A source of inspiration to each of us.'') ''It is uniquely serene here at La Croze.'' ''It is so romantic.'' ''We are renewed here,'' one of them says, as a cousin had said earlier that week. They have helped me to learn that of that once sacred triad, ''travail, famille, patrie,'' famille is the only one that remains undiminished and intact.
title: No Headline

text: For the sphere of travail has been made more precarious than ever by a society in which social mobility seems not to increase, by a Socialist experiment whose vision seems limited, whose consensus has failed, and whose very future seems uncertain. The issue of patrie is being increasingly blurred by the aspirations for a European community; by an unprecedented lack of faith in the central government; by a cosmopolitanization that is affecting the entire planet, but particularly affects the French because their identity so depended on their sense of superiority and uniqueness. So, amid the tarnished, tenuous concepts of work and nationhood, the narrow pleasures of family life may provide all the more seductive a refuge for the young. I could not perceive one chink in the reverence and admiration my young relatives have for every generation of their family, for its authority and rituals. Their docility struck me as downright scary.
title: No Headline

text: M ANY THINGS HAP-pen in France at lunchtime, if one allows the symbols to take over.
title: No Headline

text: Uncle Andre had fully recovered from his flu. And just before lunch one day he indulged in one of the yearly rituals, the bestowing of the Grand Ordre de La Croze. It is an honorary society whose ranks, from Chevalier to Grand-Croix, duplicate precisely those of the Legion of Honor. It has been awarded for decades by my aunt and uncle to those members of the family who ''with good humor and diligence'' (as one citation reads) ''have helped us to preserve this privileged site, La Croze, and contributed to its improvement.''
title: No Headline

text: We all stood in the sunlight to watch my uncle elevate the new Chevaliers. This year the decoration - a rustic metal cross hung on braided string - was awarded to 14-year-old Nicolas de Bussac ''for having completed the restoration of the wheat bin and the renovation of the boat.'' His 15-year-old cousin Alain was equally honored for having ''participated most efficiently in the clearing of the threshing floor and the collection of trout.'' The towering old man, wearing his own Legion of Honor rosette, beamed with pleasure as he kissed each youngster and hung the decorations around their necks. Everyone clapped. A few parents wiped tears. A regional aperitif, walnut wine, was served to all.
title: No Headline

text: W E WERE PIC-nicking on the causse above La Croze, and I asked to hear the words of a song Aunt Simone had taught me when I was a child. The loyal, loving couples, the loyal, handsome adolescents joyously burst into song, raising their glasses of red wine to the sun: ''Buvons un coup/Buvons en deux A la sante des amoureux, A la sante du Roi de France . . .''
title: No Headline

text: ''Let's drink a glass, let's drink two to the health of lovers, to the health of the King of France.''
title: No Headline

text: And then - I knew why I needed to hear it again: the refrain was ageless in its loyalties and hatreds: ''Et merde pour la Reine d'Angleterre Qui nous a declare la guerre.'' - Politely: ''And down with the Queen of England Who has declared war on us.''
title: No Headline

text: A NOTHER DAY, after the habitual Sunday lunch of hot dogs and popsicles, my uncle decided to ''celebrate a very beautiful day'' by setting off his cannon. The cannon stands at the edge of the terrace that overlooks the Tarn, a decrepit 17th-century specimen he'd bought decades ago in some local antique shop. Yves and Alain went to get the gunpowder, and we closed our ears. Off it went, a thunderous and meaningless explosion over the gorge, clouds of putrid fumes rising into the air, groups of amazed tourists stopping their cars on the road across the river to stare at the eccentric little nation wreathed in smoke.
title: No Headline

text: ''One of my patriotic fantasies,'' my uncle said with a mischievous smile. ''Just another of my little follies.''
title: No Headline

text: Some time later, one of my 4-year-old cousins, seated on her mother's lap, asked: ''Qu'est-ce que c'est, La Marseillaise?''
title: No Headline

text: Outbursts of indignation. ''Doesn't she know yet? What are they taught these days?'' ''Let's teach her right now.'' And a dozen voices sang again, right through to the last brutal verses: ''Marchons, marchons, qu'un sang impur abreuve nos sillons''-''Let us march, let us march, let impure blood drench our fields.''
title: No Headline

text: Everyone was quiet for a few seconds. Then Catherine spoke, softly: ''Comme c'est beau.''
title: No Headline

text: It was said with sadness, with emotion, with longing and regret, with a certain defiance.
title: No Headline

text: Three United States Customs Service supervisors were indicted Friday in a scheme to smuggle $17 million worth of marijuana from Colombia, according to the Federal authorities.
title: 3 CUSTOMS OFFICIALS INDICTED IN SCHEME TO SMUGGLE DRUGS

text: The supervisors gave smugglers access to secret information in Government computers, including the identities of undercover agents, said Edmund J. Pistey, special agent for the New Orleans office of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.
title: 3 CUSTOMS OFFICIALS INDICTED IN SCHEME TO SMUGGLE DRUGS

text: The three supervisors were in charge of intercepting drugs before they reached the United States, Mr. Pistey said.
title: 3 CUSTOMS OFFICIALS INDICTED IN SCHEME TO SMUGGLE DRUGS

text: He said their activities forced the authorities to abandon a plan to let a ship carrying 51,210 pounds of marijuana reach a customs dock at Dulac, La. Instead, the Coast Guard seized the vessel Aug. 20 in the Gulf of Mexico.
title: 3 CUSTOMS OFFICIALS INDICTED IN SCHEME TO SMUGGLE DRUGS

text: The indictment Friday superseded one that named 23 people arrested the day of the seizure.
title: 3 CUSTOMS OFFICIALS INDICTED IN SCHEME TO SMUGGLE DRUGS

text: The agents were identified as Keith Deerman, 30 years old, and Francis G. Kinney, 43, both of New Orleans, and Charles F. Jordan, 38, of Key Largo, Fla. Also indicted was a civilian identified as Michael Cerione of Miami.
title: 3 CUSTOMS OFFICIALS INDICTED IN SCHEME TO SMUGGLE DRUGS

text: Mr. Pistey said the three customs agents gave smugglers access to the computer systems of various law-enforcement agencies. He said this enabled them to learn which boats were under surveillance.
title: 3 CUSTOMS OFFICIALS INDICTED IN SCHEME TO SMUGGLE DRUGS

text: ''Most significantly in this case,'' Mr. Pistey said, ''they were able to gain access to the identities of our undercover agents. They were able to gain access to telephone numbers that had been called by our agents.''
title: 3 CUSTOMS OFFICIALS INDICTED IN SCHEME TO SMUGGLE DRUGS

text: An investigation is planned to learn if the agents might have been involved in other smuggling activities, said Ronald Bernhard, regional director of Customs' Internal Affairs Division.
title: 3 CUSTOMS OFFICIALS INDICTED IN SCHEME TO SMUGGLE DRUGS

text: All 27 people named in the indicment Friday face four counts of violating Federal narcotics laws. According to United States Attorney John Volz, the 27 face 60 years in prison and fines of $125,000 if they are convicted. ----Official Is 'Angry'
title: 3 CUSTOMS OFFICIALS INDICTED IN SCHEME TO SMUGGLE DRUGS

text: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (UPI) -Customs Commissioner William von Raab said Friday that he was ''both angry and disappointed that three officers of the United States Customs Service have allegedly breeched not only the integrity of the Customs Service but also the public's trust.
title: 3 CUSTOMS OFFICIALS INDICTED IN SCHEME TO SMUGGLE DRUGS

text: ''Over the past four years, Customs has taken strong measures to increase the policing of its internal security to both prevent and uncover any lapse of integrity,'' he said. ''Customs will continue to do everything possible to guard against and uncover breeches such as those charged by the grand jury.''
title: 3 CUSTOMS OFFICIALS INDICTED IN SCHEME TO SMUGGLE DRUGS

text: In recent months Stuyvesant Square, between 15th and 17th Streets on the East Side and considered one of the city's most handsome parks, has become a late-night sexual meeting place for young homosexual men and a locus for drug dealers.
title: AS NIGHT FALLS, CRIME MOVES INTO STUYVESANT SQUARE

text: ''It's been the place for awhile,'' said a man at the park on a recent night. ''You do your deal. You leave. Nobody knows who you are. Nobody cares. You get whatever you want here.''
title: AS NIGHT FALLS, CRIME MOVES INTO STUYVESANT SQUARE

text: Among the city's parks, few are as picturesque as Stuyvesant Square. On its western boundary, Rutherford Place, are significant 19th-century landmarks, including St. George's Episcopal Church and the Friends Meeting House. To the north and south are three-story town houses. Last spring the Department of Parks and Recreation completed a $770,000 renovation of Stuyvesant Square, which next year will be 150 years old.
title: AS NIGHT FALLS, CRIME MOVES INTO STUYVESANT SQUARE

text: During the day, the historic four-acre park is a pleasant recreation area used by schoolchildren, homemakers and workers on lunch breaks.
title: AS NIGHT FALLS, CRIME MOVES INTO STUYVESANT SQUARE

text: But after dark it undergoes a transformation. Behind the protective curtain of a seven-foot, cast-iron fence, some 15 to 40 young homosexual men cruise the park's stone walks, watched by several dozen others sitting on park benches. Around the park's perimeter, drug dealers armed with knives and small handguns sell marijuana, heroin and cocaine to a steady stream of customers.
title: AS NIGHT FALLS, CRIME MOVES INTO STUYVESANT SQUARE

text: ''You just can't imagine that this kind of behavior is happening around the corner from where you live and work,'' said Dr. Vladimir Svesko, an emergency-room physician at nearby Beth Israel Medical Center who lives on Second Avenue, which bisects the park. ''The square has always been used by the alcoholics and lately by homeless people. But this gay activity and the increasing number of drug dealers is something new. It's brought a sinister atmosphere to the neighborhood.''
title: AS NIGHT FALLS, CRIME MOVES INTO STUYVESANT SQUARE

text: Residents, police officers and city officials offer a variety of theories for the emergence of criminal activity in Stuyvesant Square. They say they believe that homosexuals seeking to engage in public oral sex, masturbation or exhibitionism, and drug dealers and prostitutes have migrated from nearby areas that have been the focus of greater police surveillance.
title: AS NIGHT FALLS, CRIME MOVES INTO STUYVESANT SQUARE

text: Last May the Parks Department completed a $3.6 million renovation of Union Square Park, just three blocks west, which once was a popular meeting place for dealers, addicts and prostitutes. Union Square is now closed at night and heavily patrolled by the police and officers from the Parks Department's enforcement patrol unit.
title: AS NIGHT FALLS, CRIME MOVES INTO STUYVESANT SQUARE

text: The Police Department also began Operation Pressure Point on the Lower East Side to reclaim streets between Avenues A and C from drug dealers and prostitutes.
title: AS NIGHT FALLS, CRIME MOVES INTO STUYVESANT SQUARE

text: At the same time, Stuyvesant Square was undergoing reconstruction. Two fountains were rebuilt. Bushes, trees and flowers were planted. More than 200 new benches were installed and walkways were rebuilt. Nighttime police patrols, however, were not increased.
title: AS NIGHT FALLS, CRIME MOVES INTO STUYVESANT SQUARE

text: The park's character begins to change at dusk. Alcoholics and homeless people are the first to arrive, seeking benches in dark corners to sleep. Later, young men move in, lounging on benches smoking marijuana and drinking from bottles in brown paper bags.
title: AS NIGHT FALLS, CRIME MOVES INTO STUYVESANT SQUARE

text: Before midnight, drug pushers begin to gather, advertising in the staccato whisper that has become familiar in parts of the city. ''Sinse. Sinse. Reds. Blues. Flake.'' They offer the powerful seedless marijuana known as ''sinsemilla'' as well as amphetamines, barbitu-rates and cocaine. Others offer ''works'' - syringes and needles - for those who use drugs intravenously.
title: AS NIGHT FALLS, CRIME MOVES INTO STUYVESANT SQUARE

text: In the hours after midnight, yet another group moves into Stuyvesant Square. Some pace along the stone paths. Others sit on benches smoking cigarettes. Screened by the fence and the trees, park gradually becomes the scene of public sex.
title: AS NIGHT FALLS, CRIME MOVES INTO STUYVESANT SQUARE

text: Often, a group of men appears to watch the encounter. Minutes later, the group dissolves into the darkness. The silent process resumes.
title: AS NIGHT FALLS, CRIME MOVES INTO STUYVESANT SQUARE

text: From midnight until near dawn, men pair and part. ''The word has been out for awhile,'' said one man. ''It's getting a little colder. There aren't so many people here now. You should have been here in the summer.''
title: AS NIGHT FALLS, CRIME MOVES INTO STUYVESANT SQUARE

text: In a short interview on 17th Street, the man explained he had been coming to Stuyvesant Square from his Manhattan apartment twice a week for a year. He said also that only a few of the men are active prostitutes. ''Nobody's getting rich out here,'' he said. ''Money's not the reason we're here. It's just a place to do it. A lot of people come just to watch.''
title: AS NIGHT FALLS, CRIME MOVES INTO STUYVESANT SQUARE

text: But Ron Najman, a spokesman for the National Gay Task Force, with headquarters in Manhattan, said this behavior is practiced only by a fringe group of younger homosexuals.
title: AS NIGHT FALLS, CRIME MOVES INTO STUYVESANT SQUARE

text: ''It's a mistake to suggest that public sex was ever the means for most gay men to pursue sexual activity,'' he said. ''We do not condone public sex. Public sex is illegal. It's dangerous. It's offensive. Clearly, if young gay men are engaging in this sort of activity, they haven't been educated about the danger of AIDS, and they have not been made aware of the many opportunities for gay people to socialize in this city.''
title: AS NIGHT FALLS, CRIME MOVES INTO STUYVESANT SQUARE

text: Police officials, who recently were made aware of the after-midnight activity in Stuyvesant Square, said they planned to increase the number of patrols in the area.
title: AS NIGHT FALLS, CRIME MOVES INTO STUYVESANT SQUARE

text: ''We've had one officer in the area on foot since last spring to watch during the day,'' said Sgt. Maureen Kirwan, supervisor of the Community Patrol Program for the 13th Precinct. ''We've had radio cars patrolling the area at night, but their major concern is emergency calls. The best way to address this is to schedule a police patrol for the park at night.
title: AS NIGHT FALLS, CRIME MOVES INTO STUYVESANT SQUARE

text: ''I also think it would help if we can get more lights in there. That park is like a tomb at night.''
title: AS NIGHT FALLS, CRIME MOVES INTO STUYVESANT SQUARE

text: Last week, two enforcement patrol officers from the Parks Department spent several hours after midnight in Stuyvesant Square to observe the activities.
title: AS NIGHT FALLS, CRIME MOVES INTO STUYVESANT SQUARE

text: In a report to Commissioner Henry J. Stern, the officers said they had witnessed public sex.
title: AS NIGHT FALLS, CRIME MOVES INTO STUYVESANT SQUARE

text: ''Our men saw this behavior Friday night and they were solicited to have sex,'' said Mr. Stern. ''It's my feeling the park should be closed after 11, at least for awhile. And then we'll see whether it can be reopened with closer supervision. We're working with the 13th Precinct on this plan.
title: AS NIGHT FALLS, CRIME MOVES INTO STUYVESANT SQUARE

text: ''It's clear some of the problems of Union Square Park, and maybe Washington Square Park, have migrated to Stuyvesant Square. But the park is not the place for antisocial behavior and it has to be routed out.''
title: AS NIGHT FALLS, CRIME MOVES INTO STUYVESANT SQUARE

text: Residents have held community meetings in recent weeks to discuss conditions in Stuyvesant Square. Proposals to close the park at night have been offered, but many residents reject the idea because they fear that the homeless people who stay in the park overnight will end up sleeping in building entrances.
title: AS NIGHT FALLS, CRIME MOVES INTO STUYVESANT SQUARE

text: ''It's a difficult problem,'' said Mr. Stern. ''We're going to be looking at it very carefully.''
title: AS NIGHT FALLS, CRIME MOVES INTO STUYVESANT SQUARE

text: ''I'm amazed these guys are still doing this stuff,'' said Dr. Svesko, who has witnessed the activity for more than a year. ''We know that the highest risk group for AIDS is sexually active homosexual men and intravenous drug users. And those are the guys out there every night in the square. What they're doing is nothing less than suicidal.''
title: AS NIGHT FALLS, CRIME MOVES INTO STUYVESANT SQUARE

text: The police here say they have seized three-quarters of a ton of marijuana from a plane that was forced to land at Greater Wilmington Airport when it began to run out of fuel. Four men who came to unload the drugs were arrested early Saturday by New Castle County officers and Federal agents.
title: Delaware Marijuana Seizure

text: As South Florida grew, so did its problems. Most were visible as the urban population swelled and crowded the world-famous beaches. Others, like the destruction of offshore reefs, were not.
title: OCEAN LIFE, AVIAN LOVE AND REPATTERNED PLATES

text: Pollution, dredging and countless individual assaults killed large sections of the reef chain until environmentalists and sportsmen helped get laws passed that brought an end to the destruction.
title: OCEAN LIFE, AVIAN LOVE AND REPATTERNED PLATES

text: Now the reefs, which provide a habitat for game fish and other marine life and lure divers to explore the depths, are being rehabilitated and augmented by the most ambitious artificial reef program in the nation. The tools are a gaudy array of castoff boats and nautical eyesores.
title: OCEAN LIFE, AVIAN LOVE AND REPATTERNED PLATES

text: The latest addition - and the biggest - plopped into 200 feet of clear water off the Fort Lauderdale beach last week. Three 50-foot offshore drilling platforms, each weighing 200 tons, and two 80-foot supporting towers were donated by the Tenneco Oil Company. Thus the instruments that many feared would cause pollution are now used to enhance the marine environment.
title: OCEAN LIFE, AVIAN LOVE AND REPATTERNED PLATES

text: Another recent addition to the reef-building program was the Mercedes I, the coastal freighter blown ashore by a storm last November on an exclusive section of Palm Beach. The ship, when she was finally pulled from the beach after languishing for three months, was purchased by neighboring Broward County and sunk in 97 feet of water about a mile off Fort Lauderdale.
title: OCEAN LIFE, AVIAN LOVE AND REPATTERNED PLATES

text: Meanwhile, Miami is also busy littering the bottom with wrecks, drawing on an ample supply of abandoned hulks rotting along the bilge-blackened docks of the Miami River. Most were once proud North Sea shallow-draft freighters that were pushed into service on banana trade routes until their rivets popped or, exhausted, they were enlisted as expendable marijuana transports.
title: OCEAN LIFE, AVIAN LOVE AND REPATTERNED PLATES

text: Palm Beach County, a little slow getting into the act, managed to get some attention two weeks ago when a local hairdresser donated his 1967 Rolls-Royce Silver Shadow for dumping at sea as a reef.
title: OCEAN LIFE, AVIAN LOVE AND REPATTERNED PLATES

text: Presumably, only kingfish or ladyfish will take up residence there.
title: OCEAN LIFE, AVIAN LOVE AND REPATTERNED PLATES

text: There were problems with the flamingos from the start at Hialeah Race Course. The first flock imported from Cuba 50 years ago to adorn the new track promptly took wing and flew back to Havana.
title: OCEAN LIFE, AVIAN LOVE AND REPATTERNED PLATES

text: The next group of birds had their wings clipped and learned to settle into their new habitat. Succeeding generations grew up accustomed to the thundering horses and screaming grandstands filled with $2 bettors.
title: OCEAN LIFE, AVIAN LOVE AND REPATTERNED PLATES

text: All was well until the 1970's, when declining attendance cost Hialeah the favored midwinter racing dates set by state racing officials. The new dates in the spring months conflicted with the flamingos' mating season and the birds, apparently confused or shy, failed to breed in full view of thousands of spectators.
title: OCEAN LIFE, AVIAN LOVE AND REPATTERNED PLATES

text: The results were disastrous. Females stopped ovulating and refused to build nests. No new birds were born for a decade and by 1980 the flamingo population dwindled to the point that the flock's survival was in doubt.
title: OCEAN LIFE, AVIAN LOVE AND REPATTERNED PLATES

text: The park's maintenance crew decided to interfere with nature and through several ruses managed to get the birds breeding again. They devised a sprinkling system that fooled the birds into believing the rainy season had started in the dry winter months and they constructed flamingo-style nests for them.
title: OCEAN LIFE, AVIAN LOVE AND REPATTERNED PLATES

text: The strategy was so successful that female flamingos fooled their nursemaids by producing a double hatching this year, increasing the flock to about 500, twice its size in the 1960's, according to Michael Mackey, vice president and general manager of Hialeah.
title: OCEAN LIFE, AVIAN LOVE AND REPATTERNED PLATES

text: The sprinklers will be turned off next mating season, Mr. Mackey said, adding that he hoped the flamingos would be, too.
title: OCEAN LIFE, AVIAN LOVE AND REPATTERNED PLATES

text: Founded on the proposition that it pays to advertise, Florida is taking to the road to bolster its image.
title: OCEAN LIFE, AVIAN LOVE AND REPATTERNED PLATES

text: Dissatisfied that its present automobile license plates, green numbers on a white background with an orange silhouette of the state, are not exciting enough, the Cabinet has invited the public to design a new look.
title: OCEAN LIFE, AVIAN LOVE AND REPATTERNED PLATES

text: So far, more than 2,000 submissions have been entered. Mickey Mouse is a favorite candidate as a symbol of Florida, as are palm trees, dolphins, alligators and, presumably a long shot, a cockroach.
title: OCEAN LIFE, AVIAN LOVE AND REPATTERNED PLATES

text: Though slogans were discouraged, several entries carried downbeat messages. One featured a skull and crossbones above the words ''The Latin Crime State.''
title: OCEAN LIFE, AVIAN LOVE AND REPATTERNED PLATES

text: Another entry, alluding to a law-enforcement practice in which the state ranks No. 1, depicted a gagged man in an electric chair, a palm tree, and the message: ''Florida Plays for Keeps.''
title: OCEAN LIFE, AVIAN LOVE AND REPATTERNED PLATES

text: The Cabinet will declare a winner this month.
title: OCEAN LIFE, AVIAN LOVE AND REPATTERNED PLATES

text: TQ 20 Twenty Years of the Best Contemporary Writing and Graphics From TriQuarterly Magazine. Edited by Reginald Gibbons and Susan Hahn. Illustrated. 668 pp. Wainscott, N.Y.: Pushcart Press. $28.
title: LASTING EPHEMERA

text: A MAGAZINE, even so fine a literary journal as TriQuarterly, is likely to be discarded after the journey or at spring cleaning. This handsome illustrated book proposes that some periodicals are worth putting on the shelf for future reflection.
title: LASTING EPHEMERA

text: There have been three editors at TriQuarterly, Charles Newman, Eliott Anderson and now Reginald Gibbons, who tells us that from the beginning it has sought ''to be a national magazine of international range,'' including poetry and criticism but emphasizing fiction. As with most little magazines, its circulation is under 5,000.
title: LASTING EPHEMERA

text: Mr. Gibbons believes that most important fiction is likely ''to look to the world outside the writer,'' that ''narrow, self-regarding, clever work always has some appeal to the small reader in us'' but that the larger reader ''responds to work that is free of self-indulgence . . . that binds us to others rather than asserting our solitariness.''
title: LASTING EPHEMERA

text: ''TQ 20's'' table of contents sparkles with well-known names from the dominant enthusiasms of the 1960's and early 70's - the Latin Americans and the postmodernists. This muster of writers from two factions that have had such influence (and are often considered as one entity) invites judgment.
title: LASTING EPHEMERA

text: The Latin Americans are represented by four eminences. The Jorge Luis Borges story is a short-short masterpiece about a knife fight between toughs from the north and south ends of town. The Gabriel Garcia Marquez selection pictures a mother grieving over the death of her thieving son. In the Carlos Fuentes story, a middle-aged narrator finds his playful nymphet of 14 years earlier has become a deformed, wretched adult. And in the story by Julio Cortazar, an eccentric family builds a gallows in its front yard, adopts a tiger and takes a Marx Brothers-ish romp through the post office.
title: LASTING EPHEMERA

text: All four stories rely on sensational situations. It is neither character nor plot that makes an impression but rather their apocalyptic mood. They seem to be early work, so it is surprising to find them so orthodox. The Borges story is capped with the exalting expectation that one day God will explain man's strange, destructive behavior, but otherwise these four selections are short on the supernatural, mythic elements attributed to the Latin American boom as well as the epater le bourgeois benchmarks of postmodernism.
title: LASTING EPHEMERA

text: Mr. Gibbons warns: ''The partisanship of the first two editors allows a reader of the whole bulk of TriQuarterly to see how an artistic trend like postmodern fiction appears both in the context of its contemporary excitement and comment, and in our own moment, which has made it seem more an experiment somewhat limited to a certain time and certain writers. Reprinting individual works from that period often shows too little of their context; thus deprived, many of them seem less readable now.''
title: LASTING EPHEMERA

text: The postmodern school is represented by selections from William H. Gass, Joyce Carol Oates, Robert Coover, Cynthia Ozick and John Hawkes. Their stories may accordingly be about fiction itself. If so, the disguise is so clever I cannot say how.
title: LASTING EPHEMERA

text: Mr. Gass's piece is a recollection and reverie, by its nature introspective. The Oates story is a one-way correspondence from a man serving time for possession of marijuana to the judge who sentenced him. The Hawkes, Ozick and Coover tales are flights into imaginative areas light-years from reality, while the Elkin story pushes absurdity to the brink.
title: LASTING EPHEMERA

text: ''Less readable now'' may be a cautious estimate. Completing this section, I had an imaginative flight of my own in which waggish American lit professors hauled fiction's smoothly worn bench from the park into the classroom, slathered it with Krazy Glue and glass shards and graded students for the good humor with which they endured a half hour on it.
title: LASTING EPHEMERA

text: Well, those of us who live in chronological time can hardly chide the postmodernists for ignoring Mr. Gibbons's warning about neglecting the actual world outside themselves to celebrate their isolation. They were simply too early.
title: LASTING EPHEMERA

text: One's own biases are crucial in juding this selection, and mine were reinforced by entering TriQuarterly's second decade. I was grateful to John Sayles for writing about a realistic Hollywood nursing home with credible geriatric patients and being able to convey the humor and pathos of their delusions. I
title: LASTING EPHEMERA

text: * WAS also touched by the deer hunters in Tobias Wolff's outdoorsman's farce, Robert Stone's heroine in an excerpt from ''A Flag for Sunrise,'' Andrew Fetler's feckless entrepreneur and his tacky roadside zoo, Raymond Carver's compassionate alcoholic and Richard Ford's sleazy women neatly conning a knavish nar-rator.
title: LASTING EPHEMERA

text: We are home again. The narrative voice levels with us. Clocks tell time. Characters have returned from vacation. Their behavior is motivated. Fantasy is intact but framed in reality so that it produces recognition rather than vertigo. The reader feels welcome. The reader feels.
title: LASTING EPHEMERA

text: Yet these writers of the beginning of the 80's are not suffering from cultural amnesia. They have borrowed from and reacted to the fashions of the 70's. ''TQ 20'' makes a good case for the postmodernist catharsis of a fiction suffering from exhaustion.
title: LASTING EPHEMERA

text: The work of 47 poets is represented here. The selections are short, often only epigrams, but the roster is impressive. Anne Sexton and Howard Nemerov open the 60's, while Richard Hugo, James Tate, W. S. Merwin and John Ashbery wind them up. Marvin Bell and Dennis Schmitz speak from the early 80's, while Linda Pastan and John Peck close the book with thoughts about moving on, wondering why and deciding it is in order not to be left behind.
title: LASTING EPHEMERA

text: Richard Gordon, the Mayor of this mountain-rimmed harbor city, puts it bluntly: ''Olongapo is a company town.''
title: FILIPINO QUANDARY: THE YES AND NO OF U.S. BASES

text: In Olongapo's case, the ''company'' happens to be the Pentagon. The town's nightclubs, bars, hotels, restaurants, massage parlors and 250,000 people are almost wholly dependent on the huge United States naval base at Subic Bay, whose grounds cover an area slightly larger than Manhattan and whose gates open onto the city's main street.
title: FILIPINO QUANDARY: THE YES AND NO OF U.S. BASES

text: Yet even in Olongapo, and even in the Mayor's office, there is a hint of the ambivalence Filipinos increasingly express toward the presence of two big American military bases on their soil, Subic Bay and the nearby Clark Air Base.
title: FILIPINO QUANDARY: THE YES AND NO OF U.S. BASES

text: Mayor Gordon recognizes that the American base is his town's lifeblood, and at a time when the Philippine economy is depressed and businesses are closing down, he notes with relief, ''No one is being laid off here, thanks to the U.S. Navy.''
title: FILIPINO QUANDARY: THE YES AND NO OF U.S. BASES

text: Mr. Gordon also speaks knowledgably of the Soviet buildup in Cam Ranh Bay, Vietnam, a 70-minute jet ride across the South China Sea, and of what he terms ''the need to balance Soviet power in the region.''
title: FILIPINO QUANDARY: THE YES AND NO OF U.S. BASES

text: Yet as a Filipino, the Mayor acknowledges that he has other feelings as well. ''As a principle, no one wants the foreign bases here,'' said Mr. Gordon, 40 years old, whose father, a former Mayor of Olongapo, fought for the town's independence. Until 1959, Olongapo, 50 miles northwest of Manila, was part of the Subic base and was run by an American administrator.
title: FILIPINO QUANDARY: THE YES AND NO OF U.S. BASES

text: American strategic interests in the Philippines are now confronting a rising wave of sentiment against the bases. The movement is partly a resurgence of Filipino nationalism and partly a reaction to continuing American economic and military support for the embattled Government of Ferdinand E. Marcos.
title: FILIPINO QUANDARY: THE YES AND NO OF U.S. BASES

text: To the left, including a fast-growing Communist insurgency, the military bases are a symbol of America's neocolonial influence and Washington's backing for President Marcos. At anti-Government demonstrations in Manila, the removal of the American bases is a rallying point, along with calls for the overthrow of the ''U.S.-Marcos dictatorship.''
title: FILIPINO QUANDARY: THE YES AND NO OF U.S. BASES

text: Moreover, as opposition to the Marcos Government has stepped up and the influence of the left has increased, more centrist politicians have also come out against the bases. Last December, a dozen prominent opposition leaders signed an agreement stating that ''foreign bases on Philippine territory must be removed and no foreign military bases shall hereafter be allowed.''
title: FILIPINO QUANDARY: THE YES AND NO OF U.S. BASES

text: The agreement between Manila and Washington permitting Amerihe health of Mr. Marcos, 67 years old, is uncertain, and the position of any successor government toward the bases is unpredictable. Accordingly, the United States Government is concerned about the future.
title: FILIPINO QUANDARY: THE YES AND NO OF U.S. BASES

text: ''The loss of the bases in the Philippines would be a body blow to Western strategic interests in the Pacific and globally,'' an American diplomat said.
title: FILIPINO QUANDARY: THE YES AND NO OF U.S. BASES

text: As a fallback, the United States is trying to lease possible alternative sites in Guam and on the islands of Micronesia and the Northern Marianas. Military estimates of the cost and time that would be required to replace Subic and Clark range from $2 billion and three years to $5 billion and eight years.
title: FILIPINO QUANDARY: THE YES AND NO OF U.S. BASES

text: Moreover, almost any replacement would be a significant loss militarily. It would be impossible to equal the location or the inexpensive, skilled workforce at Subic, the center of support operations for the 90 ships, 550 aircraft and 70,000 troops of the Seventh Fleet in the Pacific and Indian Oceans.
title: FILIPINO QUANDARY: THE YES AND NO OF U.S. BASES

text: Subic lies at the center of the vital ocean lanes running from the Sea of Japan to the east coast of Africa. The Marianas, by contrast, are far more peripherally situated, being four days steaming time from Subic. Guam, too, is far more remote.
title: FILIPINO QUANDARY: THE YES AND NO OF U.S. BASES

text: ''Take away Subic and you double and triple the distances and greatly reduce the time for operations in key areas,'' said Lieut. Comdr. James Van Sickle, a briefing officer at the base.
title: FILIPINO QUANDARY: THE YES AND NO OF U.S. BASES

text: The Philippines also offers the Pentagon skilled labor at bargain rates. The Navy estimates that a day's work shift at Subic costs about one-sixth the rate in Japan and one-seventh that in the United States.
title: FILIPINO QUANDARY: THE YES AND NO OF U.S. BASES

text: The central indictment of American foreign policy in the Philippines, heard from both Marcos opponents and Congressional critics, is that Washington is focused single-mindedly on the bases. Washington's fixation, they argue, undermines its efforts to press the Marcos Government for political and economic changes.
title: FILIPINO QUANDARY: THE YES AND NO OF U.S. BASES

text: Although opposition to the bases is vocal and growing, it does not yet appear to be the majority opinion. In an independent nationwide poll issued last month, 43 percent of Filipinos surveyed agreed that the American bases should ''kept or tolerated,'' and 23 percent disagreed. The movement against the bases has gained most among younger, better-educated Filipinos, the poll indicated.
title: FILIPINO QUANDARY: THE YES AND NO OF U.S. BASES

text: And even some of those who oppose the bases appear willing to compromise. Significantly, the call for their removal signed by opposition leaders in December was vague, leaving out such details as a timetable. Foreign diplomats suggested that the declaration was a harmless gesture of nationalism, which allowed the still-divided opposition to agree on a largely theoretical issue while sidestepping thornier matters, such as choosing a single candidate to run against President Marcos.
title: FILIPINO QUANDARY: THE YES AND NO OF U.S. BASES

text: ''I'm against the American bases, but there are practical considerations that must be taken into account,'' said Aquilino Pimentel, an opposition leaders who signed the declaration.
title: FILIPINO QUANDARY: THE YES AND NO OF U.S. BASES

text: Of these practical matters, the first Mr. Pimentel mentioned was employment. About 43,000 Filipinos work at Clark and Subic, and the American Government is the third largest employer in the country, after the Philippine Government and the San Miguel Corporation.
title: FILIPINO QUANDARY: THE YES AND NO OF U.S. BASES

text: ''Besides, not even Castro could kick the U.S. out of its base at Guantanamo,'' Mr. Pimentel said. ''There's not much chance we will get rid of these bases anytime soon.''
title: FILIPINO QUANDARY: THE YES AND NO OF U.S. BASES

text: Special to the New York Times
title: 15 ARE ARRESTED IN DRUG INQUIRY

text: The police said today that they had arrested 15 people, including five from the military, after a three-month undercover investigation of drug trafficking at Walter Reed Army Medical Center.
title: 15 ARE ARRESTED IN DRUG INQUIRY

text: Lieut. William Goulart of the police said that at least six more people would be arrested in the investigation, on charges including possession and distribution of cocaine, marijuana and the hallucinogens LSD and PCP.
title: 15 ARE ARRESTED IN DRUG INQUIRY

text: The police said undercover agents had bought more than $150,000 worth of illegal drugs and $7,500 worth of stolen hospital property, such as typewriters and dictating equipment, in an investigation at the 10,000-employee Army medical complex in northwest Washington. The police said another $45,000 worth of drugs and property were seized, including two vehicles and a handgun.
title: 15 ARE ARRESTED IN DRUG INQUIRY

text: Suspects Worked in Support Jobs
title: 15 ARE ARRESTED IN DRUG INQUIRY

text: Lieut. Goulart and a hospital spokesman, Peter Esker, said all of the hospital employees arrested were in support jobs, such as food preparation and inventory management.
title: 15 ARE ARRESTED IN DRUG INQUIRY

text: Lieut. Goulart said that the police found no evidence to implicate hospital employees who were directly involved in caring for patients. Mr. Esker said none of the drugs were believed to have come from hospital supplies except for a prescription diuretic called Lasix, which he said is mistakenly believed by drug users to help them pass urinalysis tests.
title: 15 ARE ARRESTED IN DRUG INQUIRY

text: Mr. Esker said the cases involved six distinct groups of suspects rather than a single drug ring. Five of the cases, he said, involved hospital employees buying drugs from dealers outside the hospital and retailing them inside. The sixth case involved stolen hospital property.
title: 15 ARE ARRESTED IN DRUG INQUIRY

text: Mr. Esker said that the military police at the hospital initially received a tip about the drug dealing, and they invited outside officers from the city police force and the Army Criminal Investigations Division to send in undercover agents.
title: 15 ARE ARRESTED IN DRUG INQUIRY

text: ''We're an open post in the city, and we have to deal with urban problems,'' Mr. Esker said. ''We just wanted to send out a signal that this sort of thing isn't going to go at Walter Reed.''
title: 15 ARE ARRESTED IN DRUG INQUIRY

text: By Jo Thomas, Special To the New York Times
title: THE BOBBY: FRESH LOOK AT HIS ROLE

text: Twice in five weeks the traditionally unarmed British police have shot an innocent member of a family during a raid on a house in search of someone else. Both shootings were described by the police as tragic accidents. Both touched off mob violence.
title: THE BOBBY: FRESH LOOK AT HIS ROLE

text: The shootings, now being investigated by the police, have raised serious questions among Britons about police training, weapons and procedures. The disturbances, which occurred in communities that were scarred by rioting four years ago and where there are many ethnic groups, have raised fundamental questions about what the British can or ought to do to bring peace to neighborhoods that residents describe as tinderboxes of unemployment and despair.
title: THE BOBBY: FRESH LOOK AT HIS ROLE

text: In Birmingham in August, John Shorthouse, a 5-year-old white child, was shot dead in his bed by policemen who broke into his family's apartment to search for his father in connection with an armed robbery. The police said the gun went off accidentally.
title: THE BOBBY: FRESH LOOK AT HIS ROLE

text: Hours later, a crowd wrecked two police cars and sent a constable to the hospital with head injuries. Two weeks later, in the Birmingham neighborhood of Handsworth, two days of riots followed a confrontation between onlookers and policemen.
title: THE BOBBY: FRESH LOOK AT HIS ROLE

text: On Saturday morning in Brixton, Cherry Groce, a black mother of six, was shot and seriously wounded in her bedroom. The police said it was an accident. A mob tried to burn down the police station, and a major riot ensued.
title: THE BOBBY: FRESH LOOK AT HIS ROLE

text: Although those involved in the violence in Birmingham and Brixton were whites, blacks and Asians, the question of race and racism inexorably turned up in the debate over why the riots occurred.
title: THE BOBBY: FRESH LOOK AT HIS ROLE

text: Enoch Powell, the Ulster Unionist Member of Parliament for Down South, said after the Handsworth riots that the presence of blacks and Asians in the inner cities would lead to a Britain ''unimaginably racked by dissension and violent disorder, not recognizable as the same nation it has been, or perhaps, a nation at all.'' He said they should be offered generous terms to leave the country.
title: THE BOBBY: FRESH LOOK AT HIS ROLE

text: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, when asked about this suggestion, tersely rejected it. Many community leaders pointed out that the vast majority of the young adults in this group were born in Britain and know no other home.
title: THE BOBBY: FRESH LOOK AT HIS ROLE

text: Britain's two million blacks and Asians make up 4 percent of the total population, but they are concentrated in the cities, where the unemployment and disadvantage are the worst. A report issued this month by the Policy Studies Institute concluded that at least a third of British employers discriminate against black job applicants.
title: THE BOBBY: FRESH LOOK AT HIS ROLE

text: Lord Scarman, who conducted an inquiry into the 1981 riots, concluded that unemployment was ''a major factor in the complex pattern of conditions which lies at the roots of the disorders.'' A year ago, after returning to visit Brixton, he warned that the problems and the dangers were still there.
title: THE BOBBY: FRESH LOOK AT HIS ROLE

text: Lord Scarman noted that the police had a critical part to play. ''If they neglect consultation and cooperation with the local community,'' he said, ''unrest is certain and riots become probable.''
title: THE BOBBY: FRESH LOOK AT HIS ROLE

text: Only one in ten British policemen carries a gun - one in five in greater London - but concern has been growing in recent years about the way in which the guns are used.
title: THE BOBBY: FRESH LOOK AT HIS ROLE

text: In 1980, Gail Kinchin, who was 16 years old, died after being hit by police bullets at the end of a siege in Birmingham. She was pregnant and the man holding her hostage had tried to use her as a human shield. Three years ago a Birmingham police bullet fired into a bed narrowly missed a 3-year-old girl.
title: THE BOBBY: FRESH LOOK AT HIS ROLE

text: Mistaken for Gunman and Shot
title: THE BOBBY: FRESH LOOK AT HIS ROLE

text: In 1983, Steven Waldorf, a television film editor who was mistaken for a gunman wanted for wounding a London policeman, was shot by the police and lived. His case raised a political storm and brought with it a tightening of police regulations.
title: THE BOBBY: FRESH LOOK AT HIS ROLE

text: Leon Brittan, who was then Home Secretary, said he would consider whether more revisions in the firearms guidelines were needed after the Shorthouse child was shot dead in August in what the police called an accident.
title: THE BOBBY: FRESH LOOK AT HIS ROLE

text: The officer who shot the boy is reported by his colleagues to be suffering from shock.
title: THE BOBBY: FRESH LOOK AT HIS ROLE

text: Last week, reporters who were taken to watch police firearms training were told that the standard police revolver has no safety catch. The 10-pound pressure needed to fire the weapon is considered a good enough ''safety margin.''
title: THE BOBBY: FRESH LOOK AT HIS ROLE

text: In Handsworth, where an arrest was enough to set off serious violence, almost everyone interviewed recently said the root cause of the tension is unemployment.
title: THE BOBBY: FRESH LOOK AT HIS ROLE

text: More than 55 percent of the work force in Handsworth, once a booming industrial community, has been out of a job for at least a year. Except for Asians who work in family businesses, 95 percent of the nonwhites leaving school cannot find work for two years, according to one school official. Elaine Foster, a high school deputy principal, said her former students, many of whom are 21 or 22 and still jobless, find themselves on a ''carrousel of depression.'' Three-quarters of the young black men in Brixton are said to be unemployed.
title: THE BOBBY: FRESH LOOK AT HIS ROLE
