text: While crime and the use of hard drugs have soared in Brixton in recent years, according to the police, in Handsworth the tension has centered on marijuana. Some residents, who blamed street crime on the marijuana, demanded that the police crack down. Rumors spread that a white vigilante group was forming, and residents say these added to the unease.
title: THE BOBBY: FRESH LOOK AT HIS ROLE

text: The police, who have been trying to improve relations with minorities, are in a difficult position. The number of officers from ethnic minorities is minuscule - 260 out of a force of 27,000 in greater London.
title: THE BOBBY: FRESH LOOK AT HIS ROLE

text: Since 1981, officers have been encouraged to cultivate contacts with community groups, schools, and sports teams in areas they police. At the same time, Guy Cumberbatch, a psychologist who has studied the police in Handsworth, said: ''Police officers tend to be more attracted to arrests than crime prevention. Promotion is based on that. In one study of 1,000 commendations, not a single one was for crime prevention.''
title: THE BOBBY: FRESH LOOK AT HIS ROLE

text: David Webb, who used to run Handsworth's community policing program, said: ''If you have young coppers who want to be Starsky and Hutch, they don't see going camping with black kids as what they joined the police force to do. A lot of policemen prefer not to get involved.''
title: THE BOBBY: FRESH LOOK AT HIS ROLE

text: From the building of the first railroads in the last century to the giant dams and water and energy projects of this century, the West has long depended on armies of outside workers to come in, build a project, and then depart.
title: BRAWLING AND CAROUSING GONE IN BOOM OUT WEST

text: Here in southwestern Wyoming, as in other parts of the region, those armies of outside workers have not always been welcome, either. Crowds of young construction workers, far from home and with money in their pockets have, in the past at least, spawned congestion, a colorful and often illegal nightlife, and sporadic violence in the normally placid farming and ranching towns nearest their job sites.
title: BRAWLING AND CAROUSING GONE IN BOOM OUT WEST

text: But as the Exxon Corporation's billion-dollar natural-gas treatment plant rises in a shallow desert valley 20 miles northeast of this little crossroads, many of those common complaints have been muted by new state laws controlling temporary workers and a chillier job climate for the workers themselves.
title: BRAWLING AND CAROUSING GONE IN BOOM OUT WEST

text: Instead of crowding into makeshift trailer camps or squatting in tents on public lands, as workers have in the past, many of the 3,800 men and women brought in to build the Exxon plant are staying in huge worker ''man camps'' built by the company at the job site in response to state siting laws aimed at reducing overcrowding in local communities.
title: BRAWLING AND CAROUSING GONE IN BOOM OUT WEST

text: And instead of carousing in the bars of downtown Rock Springs and Green River, the workers seem to be minding their manners and saving their money against the day next March when the job ends, and they all move on to the next job.
title: BRAWLING AND CAROUSING GONE IN BOOM OUT WEST

text: There are some local frictions. Some people here in Opal (pronounced Oh-PAL) resent the opening of a bar, the only one in town, and the importation of its weekend strippers that followed, while arrests for speeding and driving while intoxicated in Lincoln County have risen sharply.
title: BRAWLING AND CAROUSING GONE IN BOOM OUT WEST

text: But complaints are far fewer than when almost nightly brawls and open prostitution accompanied reconstruction of the huge Jim Bridger power plant east of Rock Springs nearly 10 years ago.
title: BRAWLING AND CAROUSING GONE IN BOOM OUT WEST

text: One of the conditions that have changed since the Jim Bridger project made Rock Springs synonymous with boom-town excesses is a changed labor market. Turnover then approached 40 percent in some months when labor was scarce and workers could jump from job to job, and employers tolerated behavior, notably drug abuse and arrests, that will get someone dismissed in today's softer job market.
title: BRAWLING AND CAROUSING GONE IN BOOM OUT WEST

text: ''Sure people are being more careful,'' said Ray Ahrens, an operating engineer from Riverton, Wyo. ''There's guys stacked up outside the gate every day looking for your job.''
title: BRAWLING AND CAROUSING GONE IN BOOM OUT WEST

text: Pat Daigle, a welder from Groves, Tex., agreed. ''Ten years ago I quit three jobs in one day and had a fourth by nightfall. Things aren't the same anymore.''
title: BRAWLING AND CAROUSING GONE IN BOOM OUT WEST

text: In the last two weeks, Frank Naify has managed the Exxon camp for workers at the Shute Creek gas-processing site 20 miles northwest of here, where 1,450 workers, including a handful of women, live. He has already dismissed 12 of them, he said, six for brawling and six found with marijuana in one of the company's surprise drug searches, which include the use of drug-sniffing dogs.
title: BRAWLING AND CAROUSING GONE IN BOOM OUT WEST

text: ''Can you imagine guys letting the company put sniffer dogs on them in the old days?'' a customer at the Bar-N saloon here declared. ''They'll do it today, though. Try to find another job where you can make this kind of money.''
title: BRAWLING AND CAROUSING GONE IN BOOM OUT WEST

text: The skilled workers who make up most of the Exxon work force, the welders, machinists, instrument fitters and iron workers, are the ones who do the best by the long hours and subsidized living arrangements at the job, however. For them, the hourly wage scale approaching $14 is only so-so, but the hours more than make up for that.
title: BRAWLING AND CAROUSING GONE IN BOOM OUT WEST

text: ''They're hiring in Salt Lake, but they're not working these hours,'' Mr. Ahrens said. ''We're working 12 days straight, 10 hours each with two days off every other weekend. That means one check for 70 hours and one for 50 hours, and you can't beat that.''
title: BRAWLING AND CAROUSING GONE IN BOOM OUT WEST

text: Anything over 40 hours a week is paid at time and a half, pushing wages close to $1,000 a week. With room and board at the worker camp costing a scant $12 a day and with little to spend money on but popcorn and video games in the camp mess hall, most of the workers are building savings accounts they know they will need when the Exxon plant is completed next March.
title: BRAWLING AND CAROUSING GONE IN BOOM OUT WEST

text: ''Why else would a man live in Wyoming if it wasn't to save some money?'' asked Les Thompson, an iron worker from Arkansas who figures he has saved $8,000 since July.
title: BRAWLING AND CAROUSING GONE IN BOOM OUT WEST

text: ''We're willing to rough it and do whatever it takes to save some money and pay off some land we own in Oklahoma,'' said Theresa Droste. She and her husband, who are both instrument fitters, live in the company trailer park next to the worker camp.
title: BRAWLING AND CAROUSING GONE IN BOOM OUT WEST

text: As grateful as she is for the long hours of work, she has some regrets about not leading a more settled life.
title: BRAWLING AND CAROUSING GONE IN BOOM OUT WEST

text: ''My garden,'' she said. ''I planted one this spring back home, got my hopes up, read all the books, got started early, and three days later we get a call to hit the road and come up here. So I decided that's it for gardens - until we can settle down, never again.''
title: BRAWLING AND CAROUSING GONE IN BOOM OUT WEST

text: An increasing number of drug-rehabilitation programs are beginning to recognize that narcotics abuse seriously affects the parents, spouses, children and close friends of abusers.
title: HELPING THE 'CO-DEPENDENTS' OF NARCOTICS ABUSERS

text: ''They become co-dependents, enmeshed in the addict's disease,'' said Barbara Cooper-Gordon, program administrator of the Stuyvesant Square Chemical Dependency Program at Beth Israel Medical Center in Manhattan. A private teaching hospital, Beth Israel includes a weeklong teaching and therapy program for family members of addicts enrolled in the center's 28-day recovery program. ''It gets to a point where an irrational endurance develops, you have a mad household, chaos as a result and the co-dependent becomes terribly irrational and very sick,'' Mrs. Cooper-Gordon said. ''Their thinking process becomes just like that of an addict.''
title: HELPING THE 'CO-DEPENDENTS' OF NARCOTICS ABUSERS

text: People close to the addict or members of the addict's family can exacerbate the cycle of drug abuse and, conversely, can be an important part of an addict's recovery, Mrs. Cooper-Gordon said.
title: HELPING THE 'CO-DEPENDENTS' OF NARCOTICS ABUSERS

text: ''There can be extreme cases where people are literally obtaining drugs or alcohol for family members,'' said Mrs. Cooper-Gordon. They are afraid if they don't, the patient will become sick or violent, she said, or they are afraid of being rejected. In more subtle cases, family members may be afraid to confront the addict or may even blame themselves for the drug problem.
title: HELPING THE 'CO-DEPENDENTS' OF NARCOTICS ABUSERS

text: Five years ago, only a handful of programs paid attention to the interaction between drug abusers and the people they live with. But now the families of at least 10 percent of those enrolled in rehabilitation programs are receiving ongoing therapy, said Dr. Alfred S. Friedman, director of research at the Philadelphia Psychiatric Center. And that number is increasing, he said, adding that the National Institute on Drug Abuse in Washington has financed three major studies, now in progress, to document the effect of addiction and treatment on nonusers.
title: HELPING THE 'CO-DEPENDENTS' OF NARCOTICS ABUSERS

text: While there are no exact statistics on how many people have serious drug problems, the National Institute on Drug Abuse said that there are about 500,000 heroin addicts in the United States, about half of them in New York State. The institute estimates almost 33 million, or 18 percent of all people in the United States older than 12, have at least tried narcotics stronger than marijuana.
title: HELPING THE 'CO-DEPENDENTS' OF NARCOTICS ABUSERS

text: In 1984, narcotics use was at least partially responsible for 102,843 visits to the emergency rooms of the 750 hospitals that responded to an institute poll. In addition, narcotics were involved in 3,486 deaths reported by 90 coroners who responded to the poll. For each drug abuser, there are often several co-dependents.
title: HELPING THE 'CO-DEPENDENTS' OF NARCOTICS ABUSERS

text: Ann went through the Stuyvesant Square program with her 25-year-old son, who had been using drugs since he was 16. She asked that she be identified by her middle name and, like others interviewed, that her last name be omitted. She now attends meetings of Families Anonymous, a group for families of drug abusers, truants and criminal offenders.
title: HELPING THE 'CO-DEPENDENTS' OF NARCOTICS ABUSERS

text: ''We knew he had a drug problem -he had trouble walking, talking and getting up and going to sleep,'' she said. ''But he said he could stop, and we believed him.'' She did not know just how bad the problem was, she said, until her son stood up in a group-therapy session at Stuyvesant Square and listed the drugs he was taking.
title: HELPING THE 'CO-DEPENDENTS' OF NARCOTICS ABUSERS

text: 'I Knew if I Slipped'
title: HELPING THE 'CO-DEPENDENTS' OF NARCOTICS ABUSERS

text: ''It was a very emotional thing,'' Ann said. ''We finally knew everything that was happening. And if we didn't go through that week, we still would be able to deny that.'' After the program, her son started using drugs again, but this time, she said, she did not let him come home. He soon enrolled himself at a halfway house. ''I knew if I slipped, if I let him come back, I'd be hurting both of us,'' she said. ''I wouldn't be helping him grow, not helping him get responsible for himself.''
title: HELPING THE 'CO-DEPENDENTS' OF NARCOTICS ABUSERS

text: Encouraging families to make the addict leave the home is not unusual, but it is also a last resort, according to counselors and others involved in self-help groups. Usually, if the drug abuser is making an effort to recover, families are encouraged to work together.
title: HELPING THE 'CO-DEPENDENTS' OF NARCOTICS ABUSERS

text: Pat, 34, is enrolled in Nar-Anon, a self-help program for people with family or friends who are abusing narcotics. It is cooperates with Narcotics Anonymous, a separate self-help group for addicts. Pat's husband belongs to that group. Nar-Anon, headquartered in the Los Angeles area, has about 300 groups that meet around the country and abroad. It also operates Nar-Anon Preteen and Narateen for children between the ages of 5 and 18. Nar-Anon maintains a list of local chapters; the address and phone number: P.O. Box 2562, Palos Verdes Peninsula, Calif. 90275; 213-547-5800.
title: HELPING THE 'CO-DEPENDENTS' OF NARCOTICS ABUSERS

text: ''I used to think my life was unmanageable because my husband was drugging,'' Pat said. ''And I thought if I were a better wife, cleaned house more, the problem would go away.''
title: HELPING THE 'CO-DEPENDENTS' OF NARCOTICS ABUSERS

text: When Pat's husband went to buy drugs in the South Bronx, she said she went with him, taking her daughter along. ''I thought that if I was there, we'd look like a family, and the cops wouldn't pull us over,'' she said. ''I was also right there giving him the money. I thought crazy things would happen to him if I didn't.''
title: HELPING THE 'CO-DEPENDENTS' OF NARCOTICS ABUSERS

text: Since Nar-anon, ''things still aren't easy,'' she said. ''But I'm lucky that I still have a home and my family is together.''
title: HELPING THE 'CO-DEPENDENTS' OF NARCOTICS ABUSERS

text: Gail, who attended at a recent Nar-anon meeting at Grace Episcopal Church in Brooklyn Heights, said that she had been involved with more than one addict. That is common, Mrs. Cooper-Gordon said, and it is also common for children of co-dependents to become co-dependents or addicts themselves. ''The fact that there is repetition is evidence that this, too, is a disease, in my opinion,'' she said.
title: HELPING THE 'CO-DEPENDENTS' OF NARCOTICS ABUSERS

text: Many friends and family members of people who abuse drugs are still not getting help, said Julio A. Martinez, director of New York State's division of substance abuse services. There are 3,000 co-dependents involved in New York City and State programs, but there are 37,000 addicts in recovery programs.
title: HELPING THE 'CO-DEPENDENTS' OF NARCOTICS ABUSERS

text: ''I believe we should treat the parents and families,'' he said. ''And I believe we should start drug education in kindergarten. But we have a lot to handle with just the drug abusers themselves. We don't have the resources, and we haven't touched the tip of the iceberg.''
title: HELPING THE 'CO-DEPENDENTS' OF NARCOTICS ABUSERS

text: After a year in use, New York City's padlock law has halted illegal narcotics, gambling and prostitution operations at more than 700 sites, according to officials.
title: 700 CRIME SITES SHUT DOWN BY POLICE UNDER NEW YORK CITY PADLOCK LAW

text: The law gives the Police Department the power to fight illicit activities by closing such places as betting parlors and shops where illegal drugs are sold.
title: 700 CRIME SITES SHUT DOWN BY POLICE UNDER NEW YORK CITY PADLOCK LAW

text: Of the operations halted, 417 had sold marijuana and 286 were involved in gambling, narcotics and prostitution.
title: 700 CRIME SITES SHUT DOWN BY POLICE UNDER NEW YORK CITY PADLOCK LAW

text: ''The general feeling is it has been very successful,'' said Lieut. Richard Valentine of the Brooklyn North Narcotics Unit, in whose territory are more than a third of the closed marijuana shops. ''The community sees the difference.''
title: 700 CRIME SITES SHUT DOWN BY POLICE UNDER NEW YORK CITY PADLOCK LAW

text: But some community leaders in neighborhoods where sites have been shut said the law had had mixed results.
title: 700 CRIME SITES SHUT DOWN BY POLICE UNDER NEW YORK CITY PADLOCK LAW

text: ''You close their doors, they operate from the street, from the roofs, from abandoned buildings,'' said Enid J. Ford, district manager of Community Board 9 in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn. ''It's just a matter of shifting them around.''
title: 700 CRIME SITES SHUT DOWN BY POLICE UNDER NEW YORK CITY PADLOCK LAW

text: Under the law, after two convictions and a third arrest for violations on the site within one year, the Police Commissioner can close such places as grocery stores that illegally sell narcotics or gambling parlors that pose as legitimate businesses. It eliminates the need for court prodceedings.
title: 700 CRIME SITES SHUT DOWN BY POLICE UNDER NEW YORK CITY PADLOCK LAW

text: But the law's main thrust is against the landlords who rent sites to lawbreakers. After a hearing presided over by a police lawyer, the Commissioner can decide to close a site and deprive the landlord of rental income for up to one year, declaring it a misdemeanor for anyone to be found on the site. Premises are not actually padlocked, but posters stating the Commissioner's ruling are mounted.
title: 700 CRIME SITES SHUT DOWN BY POLICE UNDER NEW YORK CITY PADLOCK LAW

text: One tenant challenged his eviction without a court proceeding, but the Commissioner was upheld in State Supreme Court, according to Lieut. Arthur Ilardi of the Police Department's legal bureau.
title: 700 CRIME SITES SHUT DOWN BY POLICE UNDER NEW YORK CITY PADLOCK LAW

text: A letter sent to landlords after each arrest on their site has been the best tool for the police, convincing many landlords to evict offenders on their own, said Inspector William Molinari of the narcotics division. ''The owners often come in to show they are in the process of evicting.''
title: 700 CRIME SITES SHUT DOWN BY POLICE UNDER NEW YORK CITY PADLOCK LAW

text: He said that about 3,600 arrests had been made on the targeted sites over the last year.
title: 700 CRIME SITES SHUT DOWN BY POLICE UNDER NEW YORK CITY PADLOCK LAW

text: Only 100 of the more than 700 sites closed since September 1984 reached the hearing stage, he said. The vast majority of the others halted illegal operations after landlords were notified.
title: 700 CRIME SITES SHUT DOWN BY POLICE UNDER NEW YORK CITY PADLOCK LAW

text: Sixty-six of the sites were ordered closed after hearings; 10 have since had the order vacated because of co-operation by the affected landlords and tenants, he said.
title: 700 CRIME SITES SHUT DOWN BY POLICE UNDER NEW YORK CITY PADLOCK LAW

text: The padlock law has helped the neighborhoods where drug dealers and so-called smoke shops have become a chronic problem.
title: 700 CRIME SITES SHUT DOWN BY POLICE UNDER NEW YORK CITY PADLOCK LAW

text: Since last February, the 71st Precinct in Crown Heights has combined the threat of padlocking with the Special Narcotics Abatement Program to fight the number of smoke shops in grocery stores and bars in the Nostrand Avenue area.
title: 700 CRIME SITES SHUT DOWN BY POLICE UNDER NEW YORK CITY PADLOCK LAW

text: Through the program, known as SNAP, undercover detectives try to buy drugs in targeted shops. If they succeed, they notify backup officers who make the arrest.
title: 700 CRIME SITES SHUT DOWN BY POLICE UNDER NEW YORK CITY PADLOCK LAW

text: ''It definitely has helped the community,'' said Capt. Edward J. King, the precinct's commanding officer. ''Now I ride down Nostrand Avenue, and I see groceries, and they're selling real groceries.''
title: 700 CRIME SITES SHUT DOWN BY POLICE UNDER NEW YORK CITY PADLOCK LAW

text: As has been the pattern around the city, the threat of padlocking, rather than the hearing process, has had the greatest effect, Captain King said.
title: 700 CRIME SITES SHUT DOWN BY POLICE UNDER NEW YORK CITY PADLOCK LAW

text: All 12 of the 23 targeted sites closed so far in the precinct shut down on their own, before reaching the hearing stage, Captain King said.
title: 700 CRIME SITES SHUT DOWN BY POLICE UNDER NEW YORK CITY PADLOCK LAW

text: To certify that illegal activities have stopped, detectives return to a targeted smoke shop five times and try to make a purchase. If they cannot, the site is listed as ''stabilized.''
title: 700 CRIME SITES SHUT DOWN BY POLICE UNDER NEW YORK CITY PADLOCK LAW

text: Captain King said word of the operation had spread, making it difficult for the detectives to buy drugs. Though drug dealing may not have stopped, Captain King still looks on the difficulty of purchasing as a good sign.
title: 700 CRIME SITES SHUT DOWN BY POLICE UNDER NEW YORK CITY PADLOCK LAW

text: ''It's curtailed the blatancy of drug dealing - it's not so much of an eyesore,'' he said.
title: 700 CRIME SITES SHUT DOWN BY POLICE UNDER NEW YORK CITY PADLOCK LAW

text: The padlock law has helped reduce the overall crime rate in the 71st Precinct, Captain King said. Murders, robberies and burglaries in the first seven months of this year were down 37.5 percent, 24.4 percent and 10.1 percent, respectively, compared with the same period in 1984, he said.
title: 700 CRIME SITES SHUT DOWN BY POLICE UNDER NEW YORK CITY PADLOCK LAW

text: While some residents agreed that the number of smoke shops on Nostrand Avenue had been reduced under the pressure, others said drug dealing had only moved over to Rogers Avenue and other areas.
title: 700 CRIME SITES SHUT DOWN BY POLICE UNDER NEW YORK CITY PADLOCK LAW

text: Dealers have adopted new tactics, they said, becoming more selective of their customers, or selling narcotics from cars, clubs and abandoned buildings.
title: 700 CRIME SITES SHUT DOWN BY POLICE UNDER NEW YORK CITY PADLOCK LAW

text: ''We have a whole lot of abandoned buildings, and these have become the rendezvous for the whole drug traffic,'' said Sidique Wai, president of the People's Alliance, a community group.
title: 700 CRIME SITES SHUT DOWN BY POLICE UNDER NEW YORK CITY PADLOCK LAW

text: ''Concentrating on stores will never clean up the problem because they'll find other ways of trading,'' he said.
title: 700 CRIME SITES SHUT DOWN BY POLICE UNDER NEW YORK CITY PADLOCK LAW

text: According to Inspector Molinari, the padlock law forces the police to define the targeted crime location narrowly. Drug or gambling arrests made near a site, or even on a site, do not count toward the two convictions needed to shut it down if the merchandise is exchanged elsewhere.
title: 700 CRIME SITES SHUT DOWN BY POLICE UNDER NEW YORK CITY PADLOCK LAW

text: Even in neighborhoods where illegal activities are limited to specific sites, the padlock law has had only mixed success.
title: 700 CRIME SITES SHUT DOWN BY POLICE UNDER NEW YORK CITY PADLOCK LAW

text: Three smoke shops located in small grocery stores on Manhattan's Upper East Side had been a nuisance for several years, making the neighborhood in the 90's along First Avenue a small drug market, authorities said.
title: 700 CRIME SITES SHUT DOWN BY POLICE UNDER NEW YORK CITY PADLOCK LAW

text: But when two of the shops were padlocked this year and a third vacated on its own, the dealers moved into the streets. A local bar owner said as many as 20 to 30 youths, some with warning beepers, could sometimes be seen roaming First Avenue offering drugs to passers-by.
title: 700 CRIME SITES SHUT DOWN BY POLICE UNDER NEW YORK CITY PADLOCK LAW

text: ''Padlocking actually worsened the problem by forcing everybody out on the street and getting the kids involved,'' said Tom Bush, the owner of Spudd's, a bar at 1754 First Avenue at 91st Street.
title: 700 CRIME SITES SHUT DOWN BY POLICE UNDER NEW YORK CITY PADLOCK LAW

text: Councilman Robert J. Dryfoos, who testified at one of the padlock hearings, disagreed.
title: 700 CRIME SITES SHUT DOWN BY POLICE UNDER NEW YORK CITY PADLOCK LAW

text: ''The padlock law has been very successful as a tool, not a panacea,'' said Mr. Dryfoos. ''It initially forced the problem to the street, but that's where the police can do their job.'' Two officers assigned to patrol the area and the temporary removal of pay phones that the dealers had used have ''substantially improved'' conditions, he said.
title: 700 CRIME SITES SHUT DOWN BY POLICE UNDER NEW YORK CITY PADLOCK LAW

text: Although the padlock law helps curb some criminal activities, police officials agreed it could not eliminate them.
title: 700 CRIME SITES SHUT DOWN BY POLICE UNDER NEW YORK CITY PADLOCK LAW

text: Anthony Ciffo, community affairs officer of the Upper East Side's 19th Precinct, blamed lenient penalties for the persistence of marijuana dealing on the street.
title: 700 CRIME SITES SHUT DOWN BY POLICE UNDER NEW YORK CITY PADLOCK LAW

text: ''The problem with marijuana is, while in this state we have harsh laws against harder drugs, marijuana has been practically decriminalized,'' Officer Ciffo said. ''A dealer can have up to 25 grams, enough for maybe 50 cigarettes, and we cannot presume sale.''
title: 700 CRIME SITES SHUT DOWN BY POLICE UNDER NEW YORK CITY PADLOCK LAW

text: Street dealers usually are fined $75 to $100, little compared to the $250 a night they earn, Officer Ciffo said.
title: 700 CRIME SITES SHUT DOWN BY POLICE UNDER NEW YORK CITY PADLOCK LAW

text: Only Federal action against the wholesalers and countries that supply drugs will eliminate Crown Height's narcotics problem, said Captain King of the 71st Precinct. Harsh sentences against street dealers make a dent, he said, but are not enough.
title: 700 CRIME SITES SHUT DOWN BY POLICE UNDER NEW YORK CITY PADLOCK LAW

text: Special to the New York Times
title: EX-FLORIDA LEGISLATOR SHAKEN BUY U.S. CHARGE

text: A former state legislator, once considered one of Florida's most powerful politicians, is on trial here, accused of helping drug smugglers hide their illicit profits.
title: EX-FLORIDA LEGISLATOR SHAKEN BUY U.S. CHARGE

text: The trial of the former lawmaker, Mallory Horne, the only man to serve as president of the Florida Senate and Speaker of the Florida House in this century, will enter its third week Monday. On trial with Mr. Horne, a 60-year-old Tallahassee lawyer and lobbyist, is his nephew and former law partner, Melvin Horne, 38.
title: EX-FLORIDA LEGISLATOR SHAKEN BUY U.S. CHARGE

text: 'I Don't Know Who I Am'
title: EX-FLORIDA LEGISLATOR SHAKEN BUY U.S. CHARGE

text: Mallory Horne, who described himself as a conservative on law-enforcement issues, said this week that the trial had led him to re-examine his political ideas. ''I just never believed anything like this would ever happen,'' he said. ''It has really wrecked me philosophically. I don't know what I am or who I am.''
title: EX-FLORIDA LEGISLATOR SHAKEN BUY U.S. CHARGE

text: Each of the Hornes is charged with 13 criminal counts involving conspiracy to impede collection of income taxes, mail and wire fraud and foreign travel in the furtherance of marijuana smuggling. If convicted, they could each be sentenced to prison for up to 65 years and be fined up to $76,000.
title: EX-FLORIDA LEGISLATOR SHAKEN BUY U.S. CHARGE

text: In opening arguments, the prosecutors said they would prove that both men were involved in a scheme with Robert J. Dugan, a pilot from Dunnellon, Fla., who was convicted of marijuana smuggling in Louisiana in 1979, to help hide the illegal gains from a drug operation. The prosecutors said Mr. Dugan began another drug operation after he got out of prison. They also said the Hornes, for tax purposes, had tried to help Mr. Dugan conceal the ownership of 160 acres in Levy County and an airplane.
title: EX-FLORIDA LEGISLATOR SHAKEN BUY U.S. CHARGE

text: Mr. Dugan, who is expected to testify as a Government witness, pleaded guilty last month to charges of racketeering and income tax invasion for his role in the case involving the Hornes. He is awaiting sentencing. Attorneys for the Hornes have told the jury in Federal District Court that their clients were entrapped by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation. The attorney asserted that the Federal agents were building a case against Mallory Horne to pressure him into working for them to uncover political corruption in the state capital.
title: EX-FLORIDA LEGISLATOR SHAKEN BUY U.S. CHARGE

text: Mallory Hornes's attorneys have also argued that their client never left the country to aid drug smuggling. Federal prosecutors conceded that Mr. Horne had not gone abroad, but they said he was part of a conspiracy that involved foreign drug smuggling.
title: EX-FLORIDA LEGISLATOR SHAKEN BUY U.S. CHARGE

text: Part of the Government's undercover operation included setting up an F.B.I. agent, Matthew Pellegrino, as a Tallahassee accountant and organized crime figure willing to help disguise the source of illeal money. Mr. Pellegrino was introduced to Melvin Horne by James Mark Stroud, a Tallahassee businessman described as a client and ''close friend'' of Mallory Horne.
title: EX-FLORIDA LEGISLATOR SHAKEN BUY U.S. CHARGE

text: Mr. Stroud, who has pleaded guilty to Federal racketeering charges and is awaiting sentencing, had been working as a Government informer since November 1980. On Thursday, Mr. Stroud described how he went to the Hornes' law office for a series of meetings in January 1981 and was told that Melvin Horne's client, Mr. Dugan, had an ''extremely large amount of cash,'' land and an airplane he needed to conceal from the Internal Revenue Service.
title: EX-FLORIDA LEGISLATOR SHAKEN BUY U.S. CHARGE

text: Some of the conversations in the office were picked up on a tape recorder the F.B.I. had Mr. Stroud conceal in a special briefcase. Excerpts of the tapes were played for the jury.
title: EX-FLORIDA LEGISLATOR SHAKEN BUY U.S. CHARGE

text: The trial is expected to continue for another three weeks.
title: EX-FLORIDA LEGISLATOR SHAKEN BUY U.S. CHARGE

text: Mallory Horne served as the Florida House Speaker in the early 1960's. He was later elected to the Florida Senate, where he was president in 1973-74.
title: EX-FLORIDA LEGISLATOR SHAKEN BUY U.S. CHARGE

text: In 1974 he ran unsuccessfully for a United States Senate seat. His last foray into politics was in 1980, when he was defeated in a bid for a state court judgeship.
title: EX-FLORIDA LEGISLATOR SHAKEN BUY U.S. CHARGE

text: Special to the New York Times
title: BAY STATE STARTING FIGHT ON DRUGS IN THE SCHOOLS

text: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis is planning an aggressive public education campaign against what surveys show is a substantial presence of drugs in Massachusetts classrooms.
title: BAY STATE STARTING FIGHT ON DRUGS IN THE SCHOOLS

text: The Governor's initiatives, which he and his staff described in interviews this week, include billboard and broadcast advertising, an increased emphasis on law enforcement, and the development of courses on drugs for students in kindergarten through 12th grade.
title: BAY STATE STARTING FIGHT ON DRUGS IN THE SCHOOLS

text: Roberta G. Leis, the executive director of the Governor's Alliance Against Drugs, said the new program would shift emphasis to grades four through six from earlier efforts that focused on high school students. The change, she said, reflects Mr. Dukakis's belief that younger children are easier to reach and increasingly likely to be exposed to drugs.
title: BAY STATE STARTING FIGHT ON DRUGS IN THE SCHOOLS

text: ''One of the reasons for starting early - fourth, fifth and sixth grades - is that parents and kids tend to communicate a lot better at that age,'' Mr. Dukakis said in an interview. ''And we want parents and kids to begin talking about this problem early.''
title: BAY STATE STARTING FIGHT ON DRUGS IN THE SCHOOLS

text: A number of states view the Massachusetts effort as a model drug program for students. State officials say representatives from Connecticut, Hawaii and Maryland have visited Massachusetts to inquire about the program, especially its increased efforts in law enforcement.
title: BAY STATE STARTING FIGHT ON DRUGS IN THE SCHOOLS

text: In 1983, Mr. Dukakis assigned 100 state troopers and some local police officers to the county district attorney offices. Their job was to coordinate drug investigations with local and county investigators.
title: BAY STATE STARTING FIGHT ON DRUGS IN THE SCHOOLS

text: ''But it really ended years of a lack of coordination on drug enforcement and intelligence,'' said Barbara Kopans, a spokesman for the state Department of Public Safety. Encouragement From D.E.A. The idea for broadening the drug campaign to drug education was encouraged by the Federal Drug Enforcement Administration.
title: BAY STATE STARTING FIGHT ON DRUGS IN THE SCHOOLS

text: In a private meeting two years ago with Mr. Dukakis, Robert M. Stutman, who then headed the drug agency's New England office, described how he had confronted a young girl in a Brookline High School classroom who was obviously under the influence of drugs. Mr. Dukakis is an alumnus of the high school, and one of his daughters is currently a student there.
title: BAY STATE STARTING FIGHT ON DRUGS IN THE SCHOOLS

text: ''He said to her, 'Why are you doing this,' '' Mr. Dukakis recalled. ''And she said, 'Nobody ever told me there was anything wrong with it.' ''
title: BAY STATE STARTING FIGHT ON DRUGS IN THE SCHOOLS

text: After the meeting, Mr. Dukakis instructed his Department of Public Health to conduct an in-depth survey of the schools to determine the extent of the problem. ''The Governor thought schools would deny they had a problem unless he substantiated it.'' Mrs. Kopans said.
title: BAY STATE STARTING FIGHT ON DRUGS IN THE SCHOOLS

text: The survey, covering more than 5,000 students and 73 public and private high schools, showed that 60 percent of the students reported using drugs once or more in their lives. Of these, 28 percent said they had first used drugs at the age of 12 or younger. Twenty percent said they had been under the influence of marijuana in school. #33% Say They Use Drugs About 50 percent had used marijuana and nearly 20 percent said they had experimented with cocaine. One in three reported they were current users.
title: BAY STATE STARTING FIGHT ON DRUGS IN THE SCHOOLS

text: A recent survey by the National Institute on Drug Abuse substantiated the state's figures. It also showed that Massachusetts was above the national average in nearly all categories of drug use.
title: BAY STATE STARTING FIGHT ON DRUGS IN THE SCHOOLS

text: After the survey was completed, Mr. Dukakis, accompanied by four teen-agers recovering from drug abuse, began touring high schools. Without sparing details, the youths described the havoc drugs had wreaked on their lives.
title: BAY STATE STARTING FIGHT ON DRUGS IN THE SCHOOLS

text: ''I as Governor can go in and give my little speech about this, that and the other thing,'' Mr. Dukakis said. ''But when those kids talked about their own experiences, believe me those auditoriums were quiet. It had an enormous impact.''
title: BAY STATE STARTING FIGHT ON DRUGS IN THE SCHOOLS

text: After the sessions, Mr. Dukakis would typically meet in a room with 30 students selected from the audiences. With no other adults present, the Governor listened as the students talked about drugs in their lives.
title: BAY STATE STARTING FIGHT ON DRUGS IN THE SCHOOLS

text: ''It confirmed for me that many of the kids didn't like it,'' Mr. Dukakis said. ''They didn't want it and they were very physically uncomfortable in an atmosphere in which there was a lot of it.''
title: BAY STATE STARTING FIGHT ON DRUGS IN THE SCHOOLS

text: Ray Williams, who played with the Celtics last season, has been signed to an offer sheet by the Los Angeles Clippers. . . Terry Donahue, the U.C.L.A. football coach, who had two years remaining on his contract, signed a three-year extension. . . . Chris Kotsopoulos, the defenseman who was turned away from the Hartford training camp after his suspension was lifted, is in limbo while the Whalers try to work out a trade for him. Kotsopoulos, who is involved in a contract dispute, was suspended after failing to attend a practice and scrimmage on Monday. . . . Mario Tremblay, a 31-goal scorer last season with Montreal, will miss 8 to 10 weeks after having surgery for a separated left shoulder. . . . Ferris Fain, the American League batting champion in 1951 and 1952, has been charged with growing marijuana and possession of marijuana for sale, both felonies, at his home in Placerville, Calif.
title: Comings and Goings

text: He was released on $5,000 bail and a hearing is set for Oct. 21. . . . Bill Yeoman, head football coach at the University of Houston, has charged that William Clements, a former Governor of Texas, aided the N.C.A.A. investigation of other schools in the Southwest Conference after Southern Methodist was given a strict probation. Clements, chairman of the board at S.M.U., denied any role in the investigation.
title: Comings and Goings

text: IN ''Nashville,'' the Robert Altman film that marked her graduation from television-sketch comedienne to actress, Lily Tomlin was just one of many vivid characters in a throbbing panorama of contemporary American life. To say that this artist has continued to grow in the decade since then is to abridge the story drastically. In Act II of ''The Search for Signs of Intelligent Life in the Universe,'' her new show at the Plymouth, we find that Miss Tomlin and her longtime collaborator, the writer and director Jane Wagner, are attempting what might well be considered their own theatrical update to Mr. Altman's epic. They treat the audience to an idiosyncratic, rude, blood-stained comedy about American democracy and its discontents - and, this time around, Miss Tomlin plays all the parts herself.
title: The Stage: Lily Tomlin In 'Search for Signs'

text: The results are something to see. While Miss Tomlin's chameleon-like ability to inhabit a wide range of personalities is not news to those who saw her previous Broadway recital, the 1977 ''Appearing Nitely,'' this time she knits her creations (almost all of them new) into what can rightly be called a play. What's more, the script is nearly as daring as Miss Tomlin's single-handed assault on it. As the star trails like a comet through a galaxy of characters - with no props, costume changes or scenery for artificial propulsion - so Miss Wagner attempts to sum up a generation of social history in a tightly compressed saga of a few representative lives. Even the occasional blurring of Miss Tomlin's characterizations and the fitful melodramatics of Miss Wagner's writing can't diminish the fact that Act II of ''The Search for Signs'' is original, not to mention absorbing, theater.
title: The Stage: Lily Tomlin In 'Search for Signs'

text: This post-intermission segment, which follows a relatively benign Act I assortment of vignettes, is also the most genuinely subversive comedy to be produced on Broadway in years. It's a radical critique not only of the national status quo but also of some activists who have fought (ineffectually, in the author's view) for change. In telling the story of a California feminist named Lynn over a period that begins with the birth of Ms. magazine and ends with Geraldine Ferraro's ascension to the Democratic ticket, Miss Tomlin and Miss Wagner make equal sport of men and women (hetero- and homosexual), liberals and reactionaries, rebellious multi-media peformance artists and middle-management corporate pawns. True, the bourgeois fashions of west Los Angeles and Marin County get hit particularly hard: Lynn and her husband live in a geodesic dome (built from a kit advertised in Mother Jones magazine) and enlist in every est-inspired training program going. But only the self-deceiving will fail to recognize Miss Wagner's play as an indictment of everyone who has spent the last decade either standing still or attempting ''to be politically conscious and upwardly mobile at the same time.''
title: The Stage: Lily Tomlin In 'Search for Signs'

text: For all the anger that underlies the piece, it is more seductive than abrasive in the watching. Miss Tomlin makes us care about the well-meaning Lynn, who discovers too late that it is impossible to ''change the system'' and be a ''total woman'' (replete with children, money, power, cosmic consciousness) while constantly doing all the cooking and produce shopping required to maintain a gourmet health-food kitchen. We also grow to like Lynn's best friends - Edie, a radical lesbian journalist whose newspaper is purchased by Rupert Murdoch, and Marge, who eventually discovers a most macabre outlet for her skill at macrame. Even Lynn's hypocritical husband, Bob, isn't a total loss. Like the title of Edie's forthcoming book, ''What's Left of the Left,'' the slogan on his favorite T-shirt - ''Whales save us'' - could well be the plaintive epitaph for an age.
title: The Stage: Lily Tomlin In 'Search for Signs'

text: Miss Tomlin shifts among the female personae so fast - with alterations of voice, posture and facial muscles - that Lynn's tale almost takes on the hallucinatory flow of consciousness as it spills about the black stage. Miss Wagner's lines rarely miss a witty trick, whether they're describing Lynn's preferred marijuana (''paraquat-free Panama Red'') or the products sold by Bob's raised-consciousness catalogue business (''New Age chatchkes''). Some of the dialogue has a shapeliness that circumscribes character while making us laugh: ''If I had known what it would be like to have it all,'' says a beleaguered Lynn, ''I might have settled for less.''
title: The Stage: Lily Tomlin In 'Search for Signs'

text: Lynn's Act II drama aside, ''The Search for Signs'' sometimes does settle for less. Although Miss Tomlin's energy never flags, Miss Wagner's writing is variable. Some of the show's many other characters go on too long. In Act I, the laughs and insights are outnumbered by preachy pronouncements (''God has Alzheimer's disease and forgot that we exist'') and maudlin sketches (an alienated teen-age punk rocker turns to her grandparents for solace). The woman who serves as the evening's unofficial narrator - Trudy, a nutty Manhattan bag lady who is conducting the metaphysical search of the title - is a treacly Ken Kesey-era cliche, stuffed with cute, curmudgeonly aphorisms that reek of Humanity and idiot-savant wisdom. Miss Tomlin, whose eyes squint into shifty half-moons when playing Trudy, is a little cloying in the role, too.
title: The Stage: Lily Tomlin In 'Search for Signs'

text: Much more convincing are such characters as Chrissy, a health-club devotee in doomed search of self-esteem and good-looking men (''If it weren't for false hopes, the economy would just collapse,'' she concludes); Brandy and Tina, a pair of prostitutes (one white, one black) living ''the life'' at 49th and Broadway, and, most hilariously, Kate, a trendy, jaded socialite who is bored by everything from ''uplifting theater'' to slick magazine articles about boredom. What Miss Tomlin and Miss Wagner don't do to differentiate among these and the others, their inventive lighting designer, Neil Peter Jampolis, does: The punk rocker is embalmed with the sallow fluorescent light of an all-night fast-food joint, while the drugged-out streetwalker is aglow with the reflected glare of Times Square's own nocturnal spectrum.
title: The Stage: Lily Tomlin In 'Search for Signs'

text: At the end of the show, after Lynn's story has been told, almost all the characters converge on stage at once, brought together by Miss Tomlin's masterful acting and a series of rapid-fire Dickensian coincidences. As they do, the tone turns abruptly sentimental. No longer are we being told that life is meaningless, that the contents of Middle American homes are ''garbage,'' that G. Gordon Liddy's ''Will'' is the self-help bible of our time or that ''evolution works on the Peter Principle.'' Instead, Trudy the bag lady offers comforting talk about life's awesome ''mysteries'' -among them ''the goose-bump experience'' of attending a play at which ''a group of strangers sitting together in the dark are laughing and crying about the same thing.''
title: The Stage: Lily Tomlin In 'Search for Signs'

text: Perhaps these final-curtain declarations of optimism are what the other characters - and their heretofore tough-minded creators - might cynically dismiss as ''false hopes'' or, worse, ''uplifting theater.'' But by then, Miss Tomlin has drawn her audience completely into the goose-bump experience, and who can stop tingling long enough to resist? Goose Bumps THE SEARCH FOR SIGNS OF INTELLIGENT LIFE IN THE UNIVERSE, written by Jane Wagner; production supervised by Charles Bowden; lighting and set design, Neil Peter Jampolis; sound design, Otts Munderloh; production stage manager, Janet Beroza; associate producer, Cheryl Swannack; produced by Lily Tomlin; directed by Miss Wagner. Presented by Tomlin and Wagner Theatricalz. At the Plymouth Theater, 236 West 45th Street. WITH: Lily Tomlin
title: The Stage: Lily Tomlin In 'Search for Signs'

text: A new State Department report on worldwide drug production says that most major drug-producing nations continue promising to eradicate their marijuana, coca or opium-poppy crops while actually doing little or nothing toward that end.
title: U.S. SAYS NATIONS ARE NOT DESTROYING DRUG CROPS

text: There are exceptions - notably Colombia, Ecuador and Jamaica - where, the report says, the Governments have eradicated significant marijuana or coca crops, used to make cocaine, in recent months.
title: U.S. SAYS NATIONS ARE NOT DESTROYING DRUG CROPS

text: But the report, a midyear update of the State Department's annual assessment of narcotics production, says coca crops continued to expand worldwide this year after increasing by one-third last year.
title: U.S. SAYS NATIONS ARE NOT DESTROYING DRUG CROPS

text: It says marijuana crops have increased slightly while opium-poppy crops, used to make heroin, dropped slightly, due largely to poor weather in Afghanistan last year.
title: U.S. SAYS NATIONS ARE NOT DESTROYING DRUG CROPS

text: Police Said to Aid Smugglers
title: U.S. SAYS NATIONS ARE NOT DESTROYING DRUG CROPS

text: ''The narcotics production issue is bad, particularly with coca,'' said Jon R. Thomas, assistant secretary of state for international narcotics matters.
title: U.S. SAYS NATIONS ARE NOT DESTROYING DRUG CROPS

text: In a related development, Federal drug enforcement officials today said they were investigating allegations that officers of the Mexican Federal Police, armed with pistols and machine guns, have begun escorting marijuana, cocaine and heroin traffickers across the border into Texas.
title: U.S. SAYS NATIONS ARE NOT DESTROYING DRUG CROPS

text: That charge first came in a letter to President Reagan and 13 members of Congress this month from an organization of current and retired officers of the United States Customs Service and the Drug Enforcement Admininistration.
title: U.S. SAYS NATIONS ARE NOT DESTROYING DRUG CROPS

text: Neil Lageman, director of the Customs Service's Office of Patrol, said the group, the Fraternal Order of Border Agents, ''is a very credible organization'' of 50 to 100 ''top, highly respected people who are quite knowledgeable about activities on the Mexican border.''
title: U.S. SAYS NATIONS ARE NOT DESTROYING DRUG CROPS

text: The group's letter cited one case in August in which, it said, Mexican authorities ''armed with machine guns and wearing .45-caliber pistols'' accompanied drug traffickers across the border into Starr County, Tex., between McAllen and Laredo. According to the letter they ''provided an armed escort'' and then ''set up a perimeter defense'' while the traffickers successfully unloaded a load of marijuana and cocaine.
title: U.S. SAYS NATIONS ARE NOT DESTROYING DRUG CROPS

text: The load was so large, the letter said, that 18 people were needed to carry it ''from trucks into boats on the Mexican side, across the Rio Grande'' and then ''to a house on the United States side.''
title: U.S. SAYS NATIONS ARE NOT DESTROYING DRUG CROPS

text: Mr. Lageman said the Customs Service has begun an investigation of the charges. A spokesman for the Drug Enforcement Administration said the agency ''is aware of those incidents'' but would not elaborate.
title: U.S. SAYS NATIONS ARE NOT DESTROYING DRUG CROPS

text: The letter said the border area is patrolled by few customs or drug drug agents. Representative Glenn English, an Oklahoma Democrat who heads the House Information Subcommittee, which has investigated the Customs Service, was one of those who received the letter. He said it ''illustrates the tremendous failings in drug interdiction.''
title: U.S. SAYS NATIONS ARE NOT DESTROYING DRUG CROPS

text: The group's president, John E. Van Diver, a former senior Drug Enforcement Administration official, could not be reached for comment today.
title: U.S. SAYS NATIONS ARE NOT DESTROYING DRUG CROPS

text: The State Department report, which does not mention the border incidents, notes that Mexico's marijuana crop, nearly all of which is sent to the United States, more than doubled last year. The Mexican opium crop increased by almost 25 percent, the report adds, and that nation also became ''a major transit route for cocaine'' smuggled from South America to the United States.
title: U.S. SAYS NATIONS ARE NOT DESTROYING DRUG CROPS

text: The report adds that with ''high narcotics production levels'' and ''widespread official corruption,'' Mexico ''will remain a major concern in the forseeable future.''
title: U.S. SAYS NATIONS ARE NOT DESTROYING DRUG CROPS

text: The report also criticizes Bolivia and Belize for failing to eradicate any of their large drug-plant crops - coca in Bolivia and marijuana in Belize.
title: U.S. SAYS NATIONS ARE NOT DESTROYING DRUG CROPS

text: Earlier this month, the Senate Foreign Relations Committee demanded to know by Sept. 25 whether Belize, formerly British Honduras, planned to eradicate its large marijuana crop, which is almost ready for harvest. If Belize does not spray its crop to destroy it, the committee wants the State Department to say whether it will recommend that Belize lose United States foreign aid, which will total about $25 million this fiscal year.
title: U.S. SAYS NATIONS ARE NOT DESTROYING DRUG CROPS

text: The report estimates that Belize has more than five square miles under marijuana cultivation, an area about one-quarter the size of Manhattan. A State Department official said Belize had not yet made any eradication plans known.
title: U.S. SAYS NATIONS ARE NOT DESTROYING DRUG CROPS

text: On the positive side, the report notes that in the United States and abroad, narcotics problems have become a higher-priority foreign policy matter in the last year.
title: U.S. SAYS NATIONS ARE NOT DESTROYING DRUG CROPS

text: ''There has been a significantly stepped-up awareness in the world of this problem in 1985,'' Mr. Thomas said.
title: U.S. SAYS NATIONS ARE NOT DESTROYING DRUG CROPS

text: The report points out that President Reagan discussed narcotics control problems with other heads of state at the seven-nation economic summit in Bonn last May.
title: U.S. SAYS NATIONS ARE NOT DESTROYING DRUG CROPS

text: The report also notes that although Burma, the world's largest producer of opium poppies, has not eradicated much of its huge crop, it has for the first time promised to do so.
title: U.S. SAYS NATIONS ARE NOT DESTROYING DRUG CROPS

text: Peru, the largest producer of coca, has continued trying to eradicate the crop but with only limited success because of terrorist attacks against American-financed narcotics workers, according to the report.
title: U.S. SAYS NATIONS ARE NOT DESTROYING DRUG CROPS

text: And Panama discovered for the first time this year that it has nearly 2,000 acres under marijuana cultivation and began eradicating it last week.
title: U.S. SAYS NATIONS ARE NOT DESTROYING DRUG CROPS

text: ''Given how difficult it has been to get any kind of progress in narcotics control,'' a State Department official said, ''even these incremental changes are important.''
title: U.S. SAYS NATIONS ARE NOT DESTROYING DRUG CROPS

text: Peter Ueberroth, saying ''a cloud hangs over baseball,'' urged all major league players yesterday to submit voluntarily to drug tests.
title: UEBERROTH ASKS ALL PLAYERS TO UNDERGO TESTS FOR DRUGS

text: Mr. Ueberroth, the commissioner of baseball, also announced that he was ''wrestling'' with the issue of possible penalties against the seven active and former players who recently testified in Pittsburgh to having purchased cocaine from a man later convicted of drug trafficking.
title: UEBERROTH ASKS ALL PLAYERS TO UNDERGO TESTS FOR DRUGS

text: He said he was postponing any decision on the seven, who include Keith Hernandez of the Mets and Dale Berra of the Yankees, until he could review transcripts of the testimony, talk to each player and, possibly, hold hearings.
title: UEBERROTH ASKS ALL PLAYERS TO UNDERGO TESTS FOR DRUGS

text: ''A cloud hangs over baseball,'' Mr. Ueberroth said at a news conference at the Waldorf Astoria Hotel. ''It's a cloud called drugs and it's permeated our game.''
title: UEBERROTH ASKS ALL PLAYERS TO UNDERGO TESTS FOR DRUGS

text: Many players said yesterday that they did not oppose testing but that it should be done in conjunction with the Major League Baseball Players Association. The Mets, for instance, voted unanimously to participate in a testing program, but want to work out the details through the union, according to Dave Johnson, the manager of the team. The Yankees also voted to refer the matter to the union. [Page B5.] Donald Fehr, the acting executive director of the Players Association, said of Mr. Ueberroth's request: ''Am I in favor of it? No. I think it's silly, I think it's counterproductive, and I think it's likely to provoke confrontation.''
title: UEBERROTH ASKS ALL PLAYERS TO UNDERGO TESTS FOR DRUGS

text: At his news conference, Mr. Ueberroth said, ''Testing is the only way to show our public and the fans that baseball is clean. The players could take that cloud and just throw it away, remove it.''
title: UEBERROTH ASKS ALL PLAYERS TO UNDERGO TESTS FOR DRUGS

text: Otherwise, the commissioner said, baseball ran the risk of losing fan support and advertising dollars. He also said he had been warned by public officials that there was a possibility of congressional investigations and legislation if baseball did not address its drug problems. He declined to say which officials had made those warnings or to be more specific about what action they were contemplating.
title: UEBERROTH ASKS ALL PLAYERS TO UNDERGO TESTS FOR DRUGS

text: Staff members of Congressional committees who would normally be involved in legislation concerning cocaine abuse said in Washington yesterday that they knew of no pressure on Capitol Hill to investigate the scandal.
title: UEBERROTH ASKS ALL PLAYERS TO UNDERGO TESTS FOR DRUGS

text: Mr. Ueberroth's request for testing was contained in a letter that asked each player on the 26 teams to agree to three unscheduled tests for illegal drugs next season, beginning in the spring. A copy of the letter was to be hand-delivered to each player before yesterday's games by a management official from each team, with the players asked to respond, yes or no, by Friday.
title: UEBERROTH ASKS ALL PLAYERS TO UNDERGO TESTS FOR DRUGS

text: George Steinbrenner, principal owner of the Yankees, said ''I think it's tremendous. I will lobby with them.''
title: UEBERROTH ASKS ALL PLAYERS TO UNDERGO TESTS FOR DRUGS

text: That the players were asked to submit to the tests, rather than being ordered to do so, reflects the fact that, under an agreement with the Players Association, no player can be required to take drug tests. However, minor league players and office personnel are covered by a mandatory drug testing program that Mr. Ueberroth started last month.
title: UEBERROTH ASKS ALL PLAYERS TO UNDERGO TESTS FOR DRUGS

text: The announcement marked the first time the commissioner has commented publicly on the testimony in Pittsburgh, which showed widespread cocaine use among players.
title: UEBERROTH ASKS ALL PLAYERS TO UNDERGO TESTS FOR DRUGS

text: In addition to Mr. Hernandez and Mr. Berra, others who admitted under oath to buying and using cocaine, often with teammates, in recent years were Enos Cabell of the Los Angeles Dodgers, Jeff Leonard of the San Francisco Giants, Dave Parker of the Cincinnati Reds and Lonnie Smith of the Kansas City Royals. John Milner, a former player who is out of baseball, has testified at two trials about his, and other players', use of cocaine.
title: UEBERROTH ASKS ALL PLAYERS TO UNDERGO TESTS FOR DRUGS

text: Five other players testified before the grand jury in the case, which resulted in the indictment of seven men, but have not been required to testify at any trials.
title: UEBERROTH ASKS ALL PLAYERS TO UNDERGO TESTS FOR DRUGS

text: ''Baseball is in trouble,'' the one-page letter said. ''The shadow that drugs have cast is growing larger and darker by the day. It threatens you, your families and all of us who make our living from and take pride in the game.
title: UEBERROTH ASKS ALL PLAYERS TO UNDERGO TESTS FOR DRUGS

text: ''Baseball's reputation is at stake,'' it continued, ''and it is our responsibility, both yours and mine, to stop this menace before more damage is done. We need to act and act quickly to restore our good name and preserve baseball's place as the national pastime for us, our children and for the generations to come.''
title: UEBERROTH ASKS ALL PLAYERS TO UNDERGO TESTS FOR DRUGS

text: Both at the news conference and in the letter, Mr. Ueberroth stressed that the test results would be confidential and that players who tested positive for illegal drugs would be counseled, but not punished.
title: UEBERROTH ASKS ALL PLAYERS TO UNDERGO TESTS FOR DRUGS

text: Mr. Ueberroth did not specify which drugs the tests would cover, saying only that ''illegal drugs'' were his target. The minor league program uses urinalysis to screen for cocaine, marijuana, heroin, amphetamines and morphine. The commissioner seemed to draw a distinction between amphetamines and the other drugs for the major league players, saying that medical personnel ''might mention'' positive amphetamine tests to players ''and might not.''
title: UEBERROTH ASKS ALL PLAYERS TO UNDERGO TESTS FOR DRUGS

text: Amphetamines, which stimulate the central nervous system and require a prescription, are also widely used among players, according to the testimony in Pittsburgh.
title: UEBERROTH ASKS ALL PLAYERS TO UNDERGO TESTS FOR DRUGS

text: Mr. Ueberroth said he was not surprised by what the players had told the court, adding, ''Baseball is on trial and has suffered some public humiliation over the last few weeks.'' He said the issue had led some unspecified advertisers to ''put their plans in abeyance until they see what we do with the problems.''
title: UEBERROTH ASKS ALL PLAYERS TO UNDERGO TESTS FOR DRUGS

text: ''I expect the players to come forward,'' Mr. Ueberroth said. ''It's in their best interests to do so.
title: UEBERROTH ASKS ALL PLAYERS TO UNDERGO TESTS FOR DRUGS

text: ''The players are already guilty by association,'' he said. ''There is cynical speculation every time a player misjudges a ball or plays below expectations. We cannot let this season conclude without positively attacking the problem.''
title: UEBERROTH ASKS ALL PLAYERS TO UNDERGO TESTS FOR DRUGS

text: In appealing directly to the individual players, the commissioner apparently hoped to meet with more success than he did when he announced his minor-league testing program in May. Union officials said then they were satisfied the voluntary program established with the owners last year was working and had been presented with no evidence that would persuade them to change their minds.
title: UEBERROTH ASKS ALL PLAYERS TO UNDERGO TESTS FOR DRUGS

text: Mr. Ueberroth repeatedly referred to the mandatory testing program yesterday, saying it had brought about a ''dramatic decrease'' in drug use among minor league players and nonplaying personnel. Asked several times for details, he said he could not give any because he did not have specific results.
title: UEBERROTH ASKS ALL PLAYERS TO UNDERGO TESTS FOR DRUGS

text: Asked how he could then characterize the results as dramatic, he said, ''In dealing with our medical people, those are the words they use.''
title: UEBERROTH ASKS ALL PLAYERS TO UNDERGO TESTS FOR DRUGS

text: Despite Mr. Ueberroth's remarks about possible legislation to clean up baseball, three of the committees involved in the area are not at this time planning any investigations or hearings, according to staff members.
title: UEBERROTH ASKS ALL PLAYERS TO UNDERGO TESTS FOR DRUGS

text: Those groups are the Senate Subcommittee on Children, Family, Drugs and Alcoholism, the House Subcommittee on Health and the Environment and the House Select Committee on Narcotics Abuse and Control.
title: UEBERROTH ASKS ALL PLAYERS TO UNDERGO TESTS FOR DRUGS

text: A staff member of the House panel on narcotics said this evening that the committee might hold a general hearing on urinalysis, including both the civil liberties aspects and how reliable it was.
title: UEBERROTH ASKS ALL PLAYERS TO UNDERGO TESTS FOR DRUGS

text: Senator Arlen Specter, Republican of Pennsylvania and a member of the Senate Judiciary Committee, said immunity was granted to too many ballpayers in the investigation in Pittsburgh.
title: UEBERROTH ASKS ALL PLAYERS TO UNDERGO TESTS FOR DRUGS

text: He also said that the players who admitted using cocaine should be suspended and that players who sold cocaine should be given more severe punishment. The comments, according to Mr. Specter's news secretary, were made in answer to questions during a monthly taped news conference with his Republican colleague, Senator John Heinz, for distribution in the state. His news secretary said Mr. Specter had no plans for any investigation or hearings. Mr. Specter is a former District Attorney from Philadelphia.
title: UEBERROTH ASKS ALL PLAYERS TO UNDERGO TESTS FOR DRUGS

text: The Coast Guard seized a small freighter in a shipping channel here today and a spokesman said it was carrying 111 aliens and 75 to 100 pounds of marijuana.
title: Ship Carrying Aliens Seized

text: Maybe he meant it or it might have been just a morale booster, but Dexter Manley, the Washington Redskins' defensive end, looking ahead to Sunday's game against the unbeaten Chicago Bears, told The Chicago Sun Times: ''We're going to have to knock Walter Payton out of the game.''
title: In Quotes

text: The Bears reacted benevolently to the report. ''I don't read those things,'' said Mike Ditka, the Bears' coach. ''I am convinced some of those things are said in frustration, some out of stupidity.'' And from Payton: ''No comment, it's ridiculous.'' . . . The Minnesota Vikings' nose tackle, Tim Newton, was fined $50 after pleading guilty to a charge of possession of less than two ounces of marijuuana, a misdemeanor.
title: In Quotes

text: Special to the New York Times
title: VERMONT INTENSIFIES RAIDS ON MARIJUANAN GROWERS

text: The police in Vermont have conducted an aggressive campaign this summer to crack down on large marijuana-growing operations and have already seized nearly triple the number of marijuana plants that were found last year.
title: VERMONT INTENSIFIES RAIDS ON MARIJUANAN GROWERS

text: But officials say the discovery of more than 2,000 opium plants last month in West Charleston, Vt., might have been the most surprising result of their campaign against marijuana.
title: VERMONT INTENSIFIES RAIDS ON MARIJUANAN GROWERS

text: The police have raided several large and sophisticated marijuana operations this summer, including one found on the property of the Town Clerk in Goshen, Vt., a rugged and sparsely populated town in the Green Mountains.
title: VERMONT INTENSIFIES RAIDS ON MARIJUANAN GROWERS

text: In the woods around the house of the clerk, Anna Marie Tonzini, and her husband, Pietro Tonzini, the police found a half-dozen small plots of well-fertilized and irrigated marijuana plants, according to Sgt. Dean George of the Vermont State Police. In all, the police seized about 1,500 marijuana plants, two all-terrain vehicles, a dozen rifles, an antitank rocket launcher and about 2,000 rounds of ammunition, Sergeant George said.
title: VERMONT INTENSIFIES RAIDS ON MARIJUANAN GROWERS

text: The Tonzinis and three other suspects have been charged with cultivation of marijuana, the sergeant said.
title: VERMONT INTENSIFIES RAIDS ON MARIJUANAN GROWERS

text: Sgt. Robert J. Vallie, supervisor of special investigations for the State Police, said this kind of marijuana operation, and the discovery of large caches of weapons, indicates that marijuana production in the state has moved beyond ''the subsistence type back-to-nature person that was growing three or four plants for personal consumption.''
title: VERMONT INTENSIFIES RAIDS ON MARIJUANAN GROWERS

text: Now, Sergeant Vallie said, growers in the state cultivate marijuana plants in the thousands to market in the major Eastern cities. ''A lot of people in the communities have been surprised by the scale of the operations that have been going on in their own backyards,'' he said.
title: VERMONT INTENSIFIES RAIDS ON MARIJUANAN GROWERS

text: In other raids around the state, the police have seized as many as 4,000 marijuana plants and large arsenals of weapons, including hand grenades, Sergeant Vallie said.
title: VERMONT INTENSIFIES RAIDS ON MARIJUANAN GROWERS

text: It was on a marijuana raid in the northern Vermont town of West Charleston that the police found the 2,000 opium poppies, said State's Attorney Philip H. White of Orleans County. Many of the poppy pods had already been slit to extract the raw opium that is used in the production of heroin and other products, he said.
title: VERMONT INTENSIFIES RAIDS ON MARIJUANAN GROWERS

text: ''Previously it was believed that opium was not being grown in the U.S.,'' Mr. White said. He said the discovery of opium in Vermont, Michigan, California and Washington might indicate that drug dealers were finding it difficult to import opium or opium products from abroad.
title: VERMONT INTENSIFIES RAIDS ON MARIJUANAN GROWERS

text: Sergeant Vallie said that marijuana growers had told the police that they viewed Vermont as a congenial place to establish operations, in part because of what they saw as a ''lack of aggressive enforcement.'' $10,000 Federal Grant But a year ago, he said, the state received a $10,000 grant from the Federal Drug Enforcement Administration and established a state marijuana eradication team. In 1984, he said, the police seized 5,700 plants. As of Aug. 31, they had already seized nearly 16,000 plants this year, he said. The police estimate the value of those plants at $16 million.
title: VERMONT INTENSIFIES RAIDS ON MARIJUANAN GROWERS

text: The presence of large caches of firearms indicates that growers feel they must use force to protect their crops from theft, Sergeant Vallie said. ''They're most concerned about potential ripoffs,'' he said. ''They've got a substantial investment, and they're afraid of a poacher coming in and wiping them out overnight.''
title: VERMONT INTENSIFIES RAIDS ON MARIJUANAN GROWERS

text: Mr. White said minor incidents of violence had already occurred in Orleans County in retaliation for suspected thefts. ''Every fall there's a problem of kids in the area going on the fields and stealing it,'' he said.
title: VERMONT INTENSIFIES RAIDS ON MARIJUANAN GROWERS

text: He also said the cost of enforcing the marijuana laws and the violence associated with large-scale operations might also raise the issue of legalization of marijuana. ''That debate is going to resurface,'' he predicted.
title: VERMONT INTENSIFIES RAIDS ON MARIJUANAN GROWERS

text: In Room 165 at DuSable High School, teen-agers can receive not only general medical care but also birth control pills and condoms.
title: SEX AND SCHOOL CLINIC: A CITY AT ODDS

text: That has touched off a citywide debate on morality and the proper role of the public school system that is expected to reach a peak at a school board meeting Wednesday, when opponents and supporters of the three-month-old clinic face off. The future of a second clinic, scheduled to open in another high school in February, is also now in doubt.
title: SEX AND SCHOOL CLINIC: A CITY AT ODDS

text: At the center of the controversy are two South Side institutions: the DuSable High School and the Provident Medical Center, which is operating the school clinic. DuSable, which was established 50 years ago as the city's main black public secondary school, counts among its graduates Mayor Harold Washington, the comedian Redd Foxx and John H. Johnson, publisher of the magazines Ebony and Jet.
title: SEX AND SCHOOL CLINIC: A CITY AT ODDS

text: Provident, which calls itself ''the heart of health care in the black community,'' is 92 years old and was the site of the first open-heart surgery performed in the United States, by Dr. Nathan Hale Williams in 1893.
title: SEX AND SCHOOL CLINIC: A CITY AT ODDS

text: Critics of the clinic say the school board, by making contraceptives available at the school, has, in the words of the Rev. Arthur M. Brazier, ''given up on the morality of black kids.''
title: SEX AND SCHOOL CLINIC: A CITY AT ODDS

text: Mr. Brazier, who is the pastor of one of the city's largest black churches, said: ''There's a problem with marijuana. Are schools going to set up clinics to show kids how to avoid good and bad strains of marijuana?''
title: SEX AND SCHOOL CLINIC: A CITY AT ODDS

text: Supporters say that this is the ideal place to promote birth control, given a 58.5 percent dropout rate that is largely attributable to teen-age pregnancy and an infant mortality rate of 2.7 for each 100 births, twice the state average. In 1984, according to city health statistics, teen-age girls in the DuSable area gave birth to 300 babies.
title: SEX AND SCHOOL CLINIC: A CITY AT ODDS

text: Officials say that good medical care is a rarity for these students, 70 percent of whom live below the poverty level.
title: SEX AND SCHOOL CLINIC: A CITY AT ODDS

text: Judy Steinhagen, principal of DuSable, said she did not condone a way of life different from the way she was reared. ''But I know that the reality is that teens are sexually active,'' she added.
title: SEX AND SCHOOL CLINIC: A CITY AT ODDS

text: A student, Jan Williams, agreed. It is ridiculous, the 17-year-old senior said, for adults to believe that teen-agers will refrain from sexual activity just because it is forbidden.
title: SEX AND SCHOOL CLINIC: A CITY AT ODDS

text: ''Everybody's going to do it,'' she said. '' 'No' is gradually fading out of everybody's vocabulary.''
title: SEX AND SCHOOL CLINIC: A CITY AT ODDS

text: Inside the school, students are also debating the subject of the clinic, which they are allowed to use only if their parents have signed general consent forms.
title: SEX AND SCHOOL CLINIC: A CITY AT ODDS

text: ''You have to look at it from a parent's point of view and then from a teen-ager's point of view,'' suggested Johnny Holmes, a 17-year-old senior.
title: SEX AND SCHOOL CLINIC: A CITY AT ODDS

text: ''For a parent it's kind of mind boggling, because they don't know what their kids might be doing,'' he said. ''Now from a teen-ager's point of view, it's sort of like a gift. All they have to do is just go right in the school, pick up what they have to and do what they have to.''
title: SEX AND SCHOOL CLINIC: A CITY AT ODDS

text: A basic question surrounding the DuSable clinic is whether it will encourage promiscuity. Mr. Holmes thinks it will have no impact on those who are already sexually active. ''This is just pushing the ones who were confused closer to having sex,'' he added, ''because they feel they have more protection now.''
title: SEX AND SCHOOL CLINIC: A CITY AT ODDS

text: Anthony Jones, a 16-year-old sophomore, said many students felt this way: ''If the clinic is giving it to you, it's telling you: 'Go ahead. Have sex.' Since they're giving it out, why not?'' Although many students said they liked the convenience of the clinic for treatment of such things as stomach aches, sports injuries or allergies, few said they had actually gone in for birth control information.
title: SEX AND SCHOOL CLINIC: A CITY AT ODDS

text: Amid the controversy, several girls, including Miss Williams and Valerie Cole, a 15-year-old sophomore, said they were reluctant to be seen in the clinic for fear that everyone would assume they were obtaining contraceptives.
title: SEX AND SCHOOL CLINIC: A CITY AT ODDS

text: ''I don't have time for all that and I have my reputation to keep up,'' Miss Cole said.
title: SEX AND SCHOOL CLINIC: A CITY AT ODDS

text: On Wednesday the school board is expected to reconsider its vote of Jan. 23 that approved the clinic. In an interview, Dr. Doris J. McCulley, medical director of Provident and the DuSable facility, said: ''The question is whether they will rescind their original consent. There's a distinct possibility.'' According to its records, the clinic saw 476 students in its first two months and dispensed contraceptives, mainly condoms, to 169 of them.
title: SEX AND SCHOOL CLINIC: A CITY AT ODDS

text: The clinic is jointly financed by the Illinois Department of Public Health and a group of private foundations. Its annual budget is $225,000.
title: SEX AND SCHOOL CLINIC: A CITY AT ODDS

text: Other cities have comprehensive health clinics in public high schools, but most of them give only counseling on family planning and do not dispense contraceptives.
title: SEX AND SCHOOL CLINIC: A CITY AT ODDS

text: Despite the unwanted attention, the clinic was as busy as ever on Friday morning. In the first hour, 11 students had been seen, including a girl whose ring had become stuck on her finger and a boy who had injured his eye while playing football. And, according to Louise McCurry, the nurse-practitioner, the gynecologist was completely booked up.
title: SEX AND SCHOOL CLINIC: A CITY AT ODDS

text: THE police in six communities in New Jersey began last December to check the brain waves of some motorists in hopes of catching those driving under the influence of drugs.
title: DRUGGED DRIVERS

text: Using a new device called Admit (for Alcohol Drug Motorsensory Impairment Test), they sought to measure a driver's impairment from a variety of drugs, including cocaine, heroin, marijuana and barbiturates.
title: DRUGGED DRIVERS

text: The device, an electronystagmograph, was designed by Dr. S. Thomas Westerman, a physician in Shrewsbury, N.J., and marketed by the Pharmometrics Corporation of New Brunswick, N.J. It monitors brain activity through electronic sensors in a headband that is strapped around the driver.
title: DRUGGED DRIVERS

text: But the device had not yet been accepted by the courts as reliable, so the police - in Shrewsbury, Eatontown, Little Silver, Oceanport, Red Bank and Tinton Falls, all in Monmouth County - were screening only drivers who volunteered to be tested.
title: DRUGGED DRIVERS

text: The equipment works fine, says Police Chief Raymond Mass of Shrewsbury - ''you really have to see it to believe it'' - but no arrests have yet been made in any of the communities.
title: DRUGGED DRIVERS

text: ''We're still trying to find that first perfect case,'' the Chief explains. ''We want to get a case that we're reasonably sure we can carry all the way through the judicial system.''
title: DRUGGED DRIVERS

text: He acknowledges that the voluntary aspect of the program ''makes it tough'' to get suspects - but not impossible.
title: DRUGGED DRIVERS

text: ''When they're high on drugs, as far as they're concerned, they've got the world by the tail,'' he says. ''We're hoping we can get one like that.''
title: DRUGGED DRIVERS

text: Cases of AIDS are doubling each year. Well before any vaccine or treatment can be developed, the disease may kill tens of thousands and their care will cost billions. Yet AIDS is so hard to contract that further transmission could in theory be halted immediately by public health measures. Why aren't authorities rushing to take them?
title: CHOOSING BETWEEN TWO KILLERS

text: AIDS is spread in two main ways, anal intercourse and the sharing of unclean needles by drug addicts. Homosexual groups have educated their members effectively in how to avoid AIDS, but the message has not reached drug abusers, who account for 30 percent of the 4,387 cases of AIDS reported in New York since 1981.
title: CHOOSING BETWEEN TWO KILLERS

text: There's more society can do to inhibit sexual transmission. Society now winks at prostitution. But if prostitutes prove to be major transmitters, which is not yet clear, state health authorities should drive out of business those exposed to the virus. Homosexual bath houses that have not already closed voluntarily should be forced to do so if they don't observe stringent health precautions.
title: CHOOSING BETWEEN TWO KILLERS

text: Meanwhile, prevention of AIDS among drug abusers has scarcely begun. David Sencer, New York City's Health Commissioner, recently recommended to Mayor Koch that drug abusers be encouraged to use clean needles. By ''forcing'' them to use old ones, he said, ''we are condemning large numbers of addicts to death from AIDS.'' He suggests selling needles without prescription, and setting up sites at which used needles could be exchanged for sterile ones.
title: CHOOSING BETWEEN TWO KILLERS

text: The proposal provoked an immediate outcry. The mayoral candidate Carol Bellamy ascribed the plan to Mayor Koch and called it ''one of the most hare-brained ideas I've heard from city government.'' It surely creates a tormenting problem, of having to choose between two killers.
title: CHOOSING BETWEEN TWO KILLERS

text: Drug addiction is a scourge, but AIDS is a scourge that multiplies. Addicts are the principal route by which the disease passes into the general population. The number of such victims is small, but will soon reach significance if it keeps doubling each year. Clean needles would protect not only addicts but also those to whom they can trans-mit AIDS: their spouses (by sexual relations), children born to addict mothers with AIDS and the clients of drug-using prostitutes who have AIDS.
title: CHOOSING BETWEEN TWO KILLERS

text: Law enforcement officials argue strongly against the idea on practical grounds. They doubt that present addicts care enough about their health to use clean needles. In raids on shooting galleries, the police often find addicts sharing a needle in preference to using clean ones lying nearby. Meanwhile, making needles freely available might induce more young people to become addicts, just as the paraphernalia sold for smoking marijuana facilitates its widespread use.
title: CHOOSING BETWEEN TWO KILLERS

text: Law enforcers also advance a moral argument. To make needles freely available gives social sanction to a different deadly curse. The spread of AIDS through drug abuse may claim innocent victims -but so do the street crimes committed by addicts. How can cities ravaged by heroin condone its use? The medical case is entitled at least to presumptive, initial support. The issue is more needles, not more heroin.
