New York's law against the open sale of needles is a pragmatic barrier; lowering it before an overriding health concern does not weaken the moral stand against drug abuse. AIDS is a wildfire plague and no reasonable means of halting it can be lightly ignored.
title: CHOOSING BETWEEN TWO KILLERS

text: Dr. Sencer's proposal is sensible and deserves a try. At the same time, concern about lending civic sanction to drugs deserves scrupulous respect. If needles are made more accessible, the result must be closely monitored. The idea can be abandoned if the supposed benefits aren't promptly evident.
title: CHOOSING BETWEEN TWO KILLERS

text: A million Americans, by Federal estimate, have already been exposed to the AIDS virus. Every means of halting further spread must be seized. Small wonder that an epidemic of superstition and suspicion is spreading even faster than the disease. People like the parents in Queens so angry about letting AIDS children into their schools are acting out their fears. They're right to be afraid; it's their remedy for AIDS that's mistaken.
title: CHOOSING BETWEEN TWO KILLERS

text: Amid this spreading fear, the Reagan Administration remains shamefully silent, leaving an amazing burden of leadership on city officials like Health Commissioner Sencer and Schools Chancellor Nathan Quinones. Before many months pass, New York will look back with pride on their stalwart stands against apathy and panic.
title: CHOOSING BETWEEN TWO KILLERS

text: The 1985-86 stamp collecting season will get off to a lively start with the annual Stamp Festival scheduled for Friday through next Sunday at Madison Square Garden in New York City. Show hours are Friday 11 A.M. to 7 P.M., Saturday 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. and Sunday 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. Admission is $3 each day. The show, which is sponsored by the American Stamp Dealers' Association, will feature over 60 dealers, selected postal agencies, exhibits, door prizes, an auction, lectures and an attractive souvenir card. The souvenir card will be distributed free of charge to each paying adult. In keeping with the show's railroad theme, the card features a full color reproduction of the 1901 2 cent Pan-American block that depicts the Empire State Express.
title: ANNUAL STAMP FESTIVAL WILL OPEN THIS WEEK

text: The dealers, all members of the sponsoring organization, come from all parts of the United States. Some international representation also is expected. Postal agencies include the United States Postal Service, the United Nations Postal Administration and agents for Canada, Papua New Guinea, Turkey, Ireland and Austria. The United Nations offers a special cachet marking the issuance of the sixth group of sheets in the Flags series. Although the official first day cancel will be available only at United Nations Headquarters on Friday, stamps will be on sale at Stamp Festival and the cachet can be obtained on all three show days.
title: ANNUAL STAMP FESTIVAL WILL OPEN THIS WEEK

text: Exhibits offer a mixture of advanced and beginner material. Award-winners include ''Philately and Murder'' and ''Soldiers' Mail of World War I.'' Separate junior and ''fun'' categories have been established by the A.S.D.A. to encourage exhibits by less serious collectors who will not have to compete with advanced philatelists. The ''fun'' category was an experiment that proved popular in the 1984 show since it emphasized the pleasure of collecting and displaying stamps.
title: ANNUAL STAMP FESTIVAL WILL OPEN THIS WEEK

text: Door prizes include a free trip to Ameripex, the international stamp show scheduled for Chicago from May 22 to June 1, 1986. All Stamp Festival visitors will be eligible. The drawing will be held on Sunday at the close of the show. Collectors do not have to be on hand at the drawing.
title: ANNUAL STAMP FESTIVAL WILL OPEN THIS WEEK

text: The official auction will be conducted at the show by William A. Fox Auctions, Inc. of Springfield, N.J. The company will offer over 2,000 lots of United States, Confederate States, British Commonwealth and general foreign stamps and covers. Four sessions will be held, Saturday at noon and 3 P.M.; Sunday at noon and 2 P.M. Lots will be on view during show hours all day Friday, Saturday and Sunday until 11:45 A.M.
title: ANNUAL STAMP FESTIVAL WILL OPEN THIS WEEK

text: Collectors and dealers can participate in two off-site sales to be held during the show period. Greg Manning Auctions, Inc. will offer United States and worldwide material at the Holiday Inn-Coliseum, 440 West 57th Street. On Thursday beginning at 2 P.M. 442 lots of never hinged modern United States stamps in wholesale quantities will be auctioned together with sheets, booklets, coils and plate blocks in quantity. At 4 P.M., 717 lots of desirable United States stamps and covers will be offered. Highlights include choice examples of the first issue, Bank Notes, Columbians and Washington-Franklin heads.
title: ANNUAL STAMP FESTIVAL WILL OPEN THIS WEEK

text: The Friday sessions at the Holiday Inn start at 2 P.M. and 5 P.M. Over 1,100 lots of popular and scarce British Commonwealth and general foreign stamps and covers will be brought to the auctioneer's block. Strength is noted in Australia, Belgium, Canada, the Falkland Islands, France, Netherlands, Newfoundland, Rhodesia, Saudi Arabia, Switzerland and Victoria. Other areas of note are Austria, Cyprus, Italy, St. Pierre & Miquelon, Spain and Scandinavia.
title: ANNUAL STAMP FESTIVAL WILL OPEN THIS WEEK

text: The most exciting auction for many collectors and dealers will be the Saturday evening auction of large lots and collections at 5 P.M. at the Penta Hotel, 7th Avenue and 33rd Street, just across from the Madison Square Garden complex. Nearly 450 lots of United States and foreign material will be offered with expected realizations ranging from $50 to $27,500. Individual country collections, dealer stocks and bulk accumulations will be up for bids.
title: ANNUAL STAMP FESTIVAL WILL OPEN THIS WEEK

text: A more specialized auction will be held by Richard C. Frajola, Inc. on Sept. 28. The Airposts and Aeronautics collection of the late Robert Schoendorf is scheduled to begin at 1 P.M. at the Danbury, Conn. Hilton Inn.
title: ANNUAL STAMP FESTIVAL WILL OPEN THIS WEEK

text: The sale includes United States and French balloon flights, United States pioneer flights, foreign airmail covers, trans-oceanic record flights and Zeppelin covers. Manuscripts and collateral material, autographs and balance lots also are featured.
title: ANNUAL STAMP FESTIVAL WILL OPEN THIS WEEK

text: Because of the informative text that accompanies lot descriptions, the Frajola catalogues have earned awards in philatelic literature competitions. A copy of the illustrated catalogue can be obtained for $5 from Richard C. Frajola, Inc. Moody Lane, Danbury, Conn. 06811.
title: ANNUAL STAMP FESTIVAL WILL OPEN THIS WEEK

text: The varied approaches that can be taken to common themes are exemplified by a souvenir card issued by the United States and stamp issues from Palau and the Federal Republic of Germany. The themes link the three stamp-issuing entities philatelically as well as politically.
title: ANNUAL STAMP FESTIVAL WILL OPEN THIS WEEK

text: The United States card and West German stamp set were issued to honor Mophila '85, the international philatelic exhibition held in Hamburg, Sept. 11-15. The card depicts a classic United States stamp while a modern West German issue features classic cars. The text of the card is printed in German and was designed by Joe Brockert of the Postal Service's Stamps Division.
title: ANNUAL STAMP FESTIVAL WILL OPEN THIS WEEK

text: The Mophila card is available at Postal Service Philatelic Centers in uncanceled form and by mail order in canceled or uncanceled form. The canceled card uses two Stutz Bearcat coil stamps and a steering wheel cancellation in keeping with the classic car theme. Uncanceled cards are $2 each and canceled cards are $2.22. Mail orders are subject to a $5 minimum and a 50-cent handling fee. Orders and payment by check or money order should be sent to Mophila '85 Souvenir Card, Philatelic Sales Division, Washington, D.C. 20265-9997.
title: ANNUAL STAMP FESTIVAL WILL OPEN THIS WEEK

text: The West German stamps were issued Aug. 13 and are printed as setenant pairs that depict a team of horses with a mounted posthorn rider on one of the stamps and a trailing stage coach on the other stamp. The semi-postal issues include a surcharge for the benefit of a foundation that promotes activities in the field of philately and postal history.
title: ANNUAL STAMP FESTIVAL WILL OPEN THIS WEEK

text: The Palau set of four 44-cent stamps demonstrates political links between Germany and Palau. The stamps will be released next Thursday in setenant block form. They commemorate the centenary of the Vatican Treaty of 1885 and depict the raising of the German flag at Palau in 1885, an early German Trading post, a village meeting house and the S.M.S. Cormoran, which was the last German vessel to carry mail in German Micronesia.
title: ANNUAL STAMP FESTIVAL WILL OPEN THIS WEEK

text: Centuries before Ferdinand Magellan opened up the islands of the Pacific Ocean to foreign traders and explorers in the early 16th century, Micronesians settled in the Palau island chain. Palau is part of a larger cluster of islands discovered by Spain and named the Caroline Islands. Although Spain legally claimed the Carolines, it concentrated most of its efforts in the nearby Marianas.
title: ANNUAL STAMP FESTIVAL WILL OPEN THIS WEEK

text: By the 19th century, other nations began to demonstrate a stronger interest in Palau. Great Britain dominated trade and the United States was active in whaling and missionary work. Germany also had become interested in the commercial potential of the islands. In 1885 Pope Leo XIII negotiated a settlement that avoided a naval confrontation between Germany and Spain. The Vatican Treaty confirmed Spain's sovereignty and granted trading rights to Germany and Britain and missionary privileges to the United States.
title: ANNUAL STAMP FESTIVAL WILL OPEN THIS WEEK

text: Following the defeat of Spain in the Spanish-American War, in 1899 the Spanish lost the island chain to Germany. Official German rule continued into 1914. With the outbreak of World War I, Japan declared war against Germany and seized control of Micronesia.
title: ANNUAL STAMP FESTIVAL WILL OPEN THIS WEEK

text: In 1920 the League of Nations awarded Japan a mandate to govern the area. By 1935 Japan had annexed the region in defiance of international law. During World War II the islands were the scene of bitter fighting. Following the surrender of Japan, the area became a United States Trust Territory. This stats prevails today, although negotiations have been held that may eventually lead to self-government by the people of Palau.
title: ANNUAL STAMP FESTIVAL WILL OPEN THIS WEEK

text: It usually takes a while for collectors to develop an interest in stampless covers. Died-in-the-wool stamp collectors may never develop an interest in this specialty. Nevertheless, covers showing postal uses without stamps - usually dating back to the period before stamps were issued -have a select following of specialists interested in postal history.
title: ANNUAL STAMP FESTIVAL WILL OPEN THIS WEEK

text: ''Cover'' - meaning an outer envelope - is technically incorrect in those instances where early missives were folded letters with no outer protection, often sealed with wax to keep the pages intact. In general usage, however, ''stampless covers'' is used to designate either form.
title: ANNUAL STAMP FESTIVAL WILL OPEN THIS WEEK

text: One of the main reference works in this field is the ''American Stampless Cover Catalog,'' published by David G. Phillips Publishing Co., Inc. The first edition appeared in 1965, edited by United States postal history specialist E. N. Sampson, who incorporated the contents of earlier catalogues for American colonial postmarks, United States stampless covers and United States territorial postmarks. The current edition was edited by Benjamin Wishnietsky and published in 1978.
title: ANNUAL STAMP FESTIVAL WILL OPEN THIS WEEK

text: The catalogue is a compilation of the postal markings of the United States and those territories that later became a part of the United States as found on stampless covers from the early 1700's to around 1870. Manuscript town markings from the colonial and territorial periods are listed although the catalogue is primarily a listing of handstamped postmarks.
title: ANNUAL STAMP FESTIVAL WILL OPEN THIS WEEK

text: During the statehood period, manuscript markings became too numerous to allow full listing. Such markings are included only for towns for which no handstamps have been reported.
title: ANNUAL STAMP FESTIVAL WILL OPEN THIS WEEK

text: The bulk of the catalogue is devoted to state-by-state listings. A nine-page general information section explains the format and provides an introduction to stampless cover collecting. A concluding section offers listings of independent mail services, inland waterways and ocean ship mail, express mail, forts and camps, free franks (markings indicating free carriage of mail for Presidents, members of Congress, etc.), railroads and ''way'' markings (letters received by a mail-carrier on his way between post offices).
title: ANNUAL STAMP FESTIVAL WILL OPEN THIS WEEK

text: The catalogue includes prices. In the seven years since the third edition was published these have become obsolete except as indications of relative values. The price is $30 from dealers or from David G. Phillips Publishing Co., Inc., 666 N.E. 128th Street, North Miami, Fla. 33161.

text: The use and availability of cocaine and other dangerous drugs will remain high in 1985, but marijuana and heroin use will decline slightly, Attorney General Edwin Meese told a Senate committee today.
title: LEVEL OF USE OF ILLEGAL DRUGS WILL STAY HIGH, MEESE SAYS

text: ''We expect that cocaine availability this year will remain at high levels, although the number of users is expected to stabilize,'' Mr. Meese told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. ''Over the past year, we have seen cocaine-related hospital emergencies and deaths rise sharply, reflecting increased frequency and complexity of cocaine use.''
title: LEVEL OF USE OF ILLEGAL DRUGS WILL STAY HIGH, MEESE SAYS

text: The Attorney General said cocaine availability and use remained widespread in 1984. Reporting to the committee as chairman of the National Drug Enforcement Policy Board, he also said of 1984: ''There was an increase in the illicit use of all dangerous drugs, especially methamphetamine and PCP. Unfortunately, our indicators suggest that this trend will continue in 1985.''
title: LEVEL OF USE OF ILLEGAL DRUGS WILL STAY HIGH, MEESE SAYS

text: Despite these trends, Mr. Meese declared that as a result of the Federal antidrug efforts ''we are beginning to see a measure of success from our national strategy.''
title: LEVEL OF USE OF ILLEGAL DRUGS WILL STAY HIGH, MEESE SAYS

text: Heroin Use Declined in 1984
title: LEVEL OF USE OF ILLEGAL DRUGS WILL STAY HIGH, MEESE SAYS

text: He said heroin use declined slightly last year and it was not expected to change this year. No major changes in heroin availability are forecast for 1985, he said.
title: LEVEL OF USE OF ILLEGAL DRUGS WILL STAY HIGH, MEESE SAYS

text: Marijuana use also declined slightly in 1984 primarily as a result of declining use by young people, Mr. Meese said, adding that he expected the trend to continue this year. He said there had been shortages of Colombian marijuana and a decrease in domestically produced marijuana.
title: LEVEL OF USE OF ILLEGAL DRUGS WILL STAY HIGH, MEESE SAYS

text: ''Last year, with 48 states participating, over 12 million plants were eradicated,'' he said. ''We are projecting that over 20 million plants will be desroyed this year.''
title: LEVEL OF USE OF ILLEGAL DRUGS WILL STAY HIGH, MEESE SAYS

text: But even with increased Federal law enforcement efforts and new diplomatic pressures on drug-producing countries to destroy their crops, Mr. Meese said, ''the only way we will ultimately be successful in the war against drugs is to curb the demand for them.''
title: LEVEL OF USE OF ILLEGAL DRUGS WILL STAY HIGH, MEESE SAYS

text: The Attorney General said legalizing drug use to curb the demand ''does not work.'' Asked under what circumstances he would favor cutting off foreign aid, refusing to refinance bank loans or other tough steps to force drug-producing countries to eradicate their crops, Mr. Meese said he would support such actions ''as a last resort.''
title: LEVEL OF USE OF ILLEGAL DRUGS WILL STAY HIGH, MEESE SAYS

text: A parachuting smuggler wearing combat fatigues and carrying pistols and knives plunged to his death today in a backyard when his parachute failed to open, the police said today. At his side was 79 pounds of cocaine.
title: PARACHUTIST DIES WITH COCAINE SACK

text: The authorities identified the victim as Andrew Thornton, 41 years old, a former Army paratrooper and narcotics officer for the Lexington, Ky., Police Department who joined a drug gang.
title: PARACHUTIST DIES WITH COCAINE SACK

text: ''I've never had a landing in my backyard before,'' said Fred Myers, who saw Mr. Thornton's body out his window this morning.
title: PARACHUTIST DIES WITH COCAINE SACK

text: Investigators said they had no idea what happened to whatever aircraft dropped Mr. Thornton. He broke his neck when he hit the ground in the Myers yard, a few blocks from Island Home Airport, a small airfield south of downtown Knoxville.
title: PARACHUTIST DIES WITH COCAINE SACK

text: No Flight Plan Is Found
title: PARACHUTIST DIES WITH COCAINE SACK

text: ''Obviously, he came out of some kind of airplane, helicopter or blimp,'' said Jack Barker, a spokesman for the Federal Aviation Administration. ''There was no flight plan filed that's not accounted for. If anybody was in an airplane carrying coke, they wouldn't be filing a flight plan.''
title: PARACHUTIST DIES WITH COCAINE SACK

text: The parachutist died between midnight and 3 A.M. this morning, the officers said, and no plane landed at Island Home after 11 P.M.
title: PARACHUTIST DIES WITH COCAINE SACK

text: Mr. Myers alerted the police at 8:30 A.M.
title: PARACHUTIST DIES WITH COCAINE SACK

text: Mr. Thornton pleaded guilty to conspiracy to possess marijuana in Fresno, Calif., in 1982, served six months on the charge and was free on parole, according to Brian Leighton, an assistant Federal attorney in Fresno.
title: PARACHUTIST DIES WITH COCAINE SACK

text: Mr. Leighton described Mr. Thornton as ''dangerous'' and said he had been under investigation for a theft of military equipment from the China Lake Naval Weapons Center in California. The equipment was to be traded for drugs in Colombia by the drug gang, Mr. Leighton said.
title: PARACHUTIST DIES WITH COCAINE SACK

text: ''These people were smuggling large amounts of drugs into the United States,'' he said.
title: PARACHUTIST DIES WITH COCAINE SACK

text: The man suspected of being the leader of the smuggling gang, Bradley Bryant, is also a former member of the Lexington, Ky., narcotics squad. He is serving a 30-year Federal sentence on drug charges.
title: PARACHUTIST DIES WITH COCAINE SACK

text: Mr. Thornton carried $4,500 in cash, two pistols, two knives, night-vision goggles, ropes and food, the Knoxville police said. In a duffle bag at the victim's side, the authorities found 79 pounds of cocaine in brown plastic.
title: PARACHUTIST DIES WITH COCAINE SACK

text: Tony Acri, assistant agent in charge of the Atlanta division of the Federal Drug Enforcement Agency, said it was not unheard of for smugglers to parachute.
title: PARACHUTIST DIES WITH COCAINE SACK

text: ''No. 1, a parachutist is not picked up on radar,'' he said, ''and especially during a night drop there's not much noise and it doesn't arouse suspicion unless you fall on somebody's house or your chute doesn't open.''
title: PARACHUTIST DIES WITH COCAINE SACK

text: A former Minister of Energy and Communications of the Central American nation of Belize has been sentenced to seven years in prison and fined $50,000 for conspiring to smuggle more than 1,000 pounds of marijuana and cocaine into the United States.
title: Ex-Official of Belize Sentenced in Drug Plot

text: Elijio Briceno, 47 years old, who held the Cabinet post until his party lost elections last fall, was sentenced Monday in Federal District Court here where he was convicted Aug. 1.
title: Ex-Official of Belize Sentenced in Drug Plot

text: Mr. Briceno, who was arrested in Miami in April after a meeting with undercover agents, told the judge he was sorry that he had ''brought shame'' on himself, his family and his country.
title: Ex-Official of Belize Sentenced in Drug Plot

text: According to Sam Currin, the United States Attorney, Belize is the fourth largest supplier of marijuana to the United States, after Colombia, Mexico and Jamaica. He said the jail sentence would ''send a strong message to corrupt Latin American officials.''
title: Ex-Official of Belize Sentenced in Drug Plot

text: THE latest action in the Becton Regional High School Drug Prevention Program is a blow to a safe environment for teen-agers. On a motion by the American Civil Liberties Union, a court has ordered the school board not to start mandatory urine and blood testing for drugs as a requirement for admission to high school each year, pending full hearing in court. [Last Tuesday, both sides agreed to a temporary restraining order issued by Judge Peter Ciolino in Superior Court. Trial was scheduled for Nov. 12. Meanwhile, the drug tests will not be conducted.] The issue revolves around confusion about the nature of teen-age drug abuse.
title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;

SCHOOLS NEED AN ENVIRONMENT FREE OF DRUGS

text: The Civil Liberties Union argues that it is a criminal issue in that urine and blood screening would involve requiring teen-agers to give evidence against themselves resulting in criminal prosecution.
title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;

SCHOOLS NEED AN ENVIRONMENT FREE OF DRUGS

text: The school board is treating teen-age drug abuse as a disease and taking appropriate preventive medical measures to protect not only the individual but also the community.
title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;

SCHOOLS NEED AN ENVIRONMENT FREE OF DRUGS

text: The board's position is that ''immunization'' is needed to protect teen-agers in school from ''carriers'' of the disease - that is, teen-age users who would, through peer influence, involve other students in drug use.
title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;

SCHOOLS NEED AN ENVIRONMENT FREE OF DRUGS

text: The decision by the board of trustees for Becton Regional High School on the advice of the Superintendent, Alfred Marbaise, is a strong stand on behalf of students' right to a drug-free environment in the schools. The decision has stirred up a major controversy involving teachers, school board officials and civil libertarians about the issue of rights.
title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;

SCHOOLS NEED AN ENVIRONMENT FREE OF DRUGS

text: Civil libertarians see the board's decision as a violation of student's rights. But the issue in this case is: What kind of rights are we defending for students?
title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;

SCHOOLS NEED AN ENVIRONMENT FREE OF DRUGS

text: The board's position is to defend the right of young people to a safe, nonthreatening environment for the purposes of another fundamental right of the young in America: a public education.
title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;

SCHOOLS NEED AN ENVIRONMENT FREE OF DRUGS

text: Our legal system embodies a number of protective rights for those under the age of majority. We protect them from abuse by adults, including their own parents. With child labor laws, we protect them from abuse in the work setting. We protect them from financial responsibility -meaning debt - and civil court liability, because they are not yet prepared in their developmental process to handle decisions in those areas.
title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;

SCHOOLS NEED AN ENVIRONMENT FREE OF DRUGS

text: Given the basic principle that society has an obligation to protect children from physical, psychological and situational danger during their growing-up process, the decision by Becton Regional High School officials embodies protection for the basic right of growing up safely.
title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;

SCHOOLS NEED AN ENVIRONMENT FREE OF DRUGS

text: Urine screening of students, however, is not a panacea.
title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;

SCHOOLS NEED AN ENVIRONMENT FREE OF DRUGS

text: Those of us who have worked in the field know that a lot of teen-agers and young adults who are urine screened successfully pass even though they are regular drug users. The reason is that screeners do not know how to get and adequately test urine samples.
title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;

SCHOOLS NEED AN ENVIRONMENT FREE OF DRUGS

text: For instance, most of the marijuana screens that are done for Delta-9 Tetrahydrocanabinol are done at an 80-nanogram level. Therefore, many moderate regular users, including kids who come to school high or get high on school property, would pass that test at a lower THC urine level than 80 nanograms. Adequate testing of high school students must be done for a content of 20 nanograms to catch the majority of regular users.
title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;

SCHOOLS NEED AN ENVIRONMENT FREE OF DRUGS

text: Secondly, kids who are into drugs know how to beat the testing system. Many of them get clean urine samples from nonusers for the screening. Others adulterate urine smaples by dilution.
title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;

SCHOOLS NEED AN ENVIRONMENT FREE OF DRUGS

text: Given the difficulty of urine sampling as a technique for providing a safe and drug-free environment, I would suggest that not all students be tested, but only those where there is some evidence of a problem.
title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;

SCHOOLS NEED AN ENVIRONMENT FREE OF DRUGS

text: This would require training - all school personnel - not only counselors, teachers and administrators, but also cafeteria, maintenance and bus-driving personnel - to recognize the simple symptoms of intoxication by alcohol, marijuana or other substances. Where there is evidence of possible intoxication, that student would be required to have a urine screen immediately.
title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;

SCHOOLS NEED AN ENVIRONMENT FREE OF DRUGS

text: The same principles should apply here that apply to the breathalizer test in driving. The individual has the right to refuse the test, but that would mean automatic suspension from school - just as there is automatic suspension of the driver's license for a driver who refuses to take the breathalizer test.
title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;

SCHOOLS NEED AN ENVIRONMENT FREE OF DRUGS

text: It is true that young people have a right to an education in this country. But they must be capable of taking advantage of that education, and that excludes violence, disruptive behavior and, in this case, intoxication. Not only is learning impossible for an intoxicated student, but the intoxicated student also interferes with the rights of others to a safe environment and an adequate education.
title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;

SCHOOLS NEED AN ENVIRONMENT FREE OF DRUGS

text: Finally, there is an issue I am most familiar with in my work with teen-agers who have drug problems.
title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;

SCHOOLS NEED AN ENVIRONMENT FREE OF DRUGS

text: It is heartbreaking to watch the struggle of young people who have worked for many weeks to become drug free, see them go back to school and be exposed to the aroma of marijuana and to the pressure of their peers to regress, with all of the psychological cues present that trigger their overwhelming craving for the drug high.
title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;

SCHOOLS NEED AN ENVIRONMENT FREE OF DRUGS

text: Kids who have a drug problem and have undergone treatment with the support of their families and are in recovery have the right to be protected from exposure to drugs in a publicly run institution. After all, drug use is a violation of city, state and Federal laws.
title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;

SCHOOLS NEED AN ENVIRONMENT FREE OF DRUGS

text: We need to recognize that students do not have a right to use drugs; rather, kids have a right to go to school and to learn in a drug-free environment.
title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;

SCHOOLS NEED AN ENVIRONMENT FREE OF DRUGS

text: The idea that kids under the age of majority have the right to make a free choice to use or not use illicit drugs flies in the face of all we know about the growing-up process psychologically.
title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;

SCHOOLS NEED AN ENVIRONMENT FREE OF DRUGS

text: Teen-agers have not developed mature adult decision-making processes, one of the major tasks of the adolescent developmental period. There is no way they can make a good choice about drugs. They simply don't have the processes to do that.
title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;

SCHOOLS NEED AN ENVIRONMENT FREE OF DRUGS

text: They are particularly vulnerable, physically and psychologically, to the drug high, because the qualities in the psyche that resist addiction to alcohol and other substances are nonexistent in the teen-agers. These processes and qualities are the major developmental tasks for the adolescent period and are not completed until the early 20's.
title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;

SCHOOLS NEED AN ENVIRONMENT FREE OF DRUGS

text: Consequently, the idea that kids ought to make free choices flies in the face of our knowledge about adolescence and our legal concept of protecting underage people from dangerous situations beyond their ability to cope.
title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;

SCHOOLS NEED AN ENVIRONMENT FREE OF DRUGS

text: The Becton Regional High School trustees need to refine their policy and procedures to protect students from criminal prosecution as a result of the physical examination and the blood and urine screens. By doing this, they will define drug use as a disease and deal with it as a preventive health issue.
title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;

SCHOOLS NEED AN ENVIRONMENT FREE OF DRUGS

text: This preventative medicine approach to drug use is based upon the nature of teen-age drug use as we now see it from a clinical and medical viewpoint and is in the best interests of our young people.
title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;

SCHOOLS NEED AN ENVIRONMENT FREE OF DRUGS

text: Miller Newton, president and director of Kids of Bergen County Inc., holds a doctorate in anthropology and human-services administration from Union Graduate School in Cincinatti and a Master of Divinity from Princeton Theological Seminary. He is the author of ''Gone Way Down: Teenage Drug Use Is a Disease'' and a co-author of ''Not My Kid: A Parent's Guide to Kids and Drugs.''
title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;

SCHOOLS NEED AN ENVIRONMENT FREE OF DRUGS

text: By Fox Butterfield, Special To the New York Times
title: JURY HEARS TAPE ON GANG WARS IN BOSTON TRIAL

text: Gennaro J. Angiulo, in the sanctuary of his headquarters in Boston's North End, was reminiscing about gang wars in the 1960's.
title: JURY HEARS TAPE ON GANG WARS IN BOSTON TRIAL

text: He and his brothers, he said, ''buried 20 Irishmen to take this town over.''
title: JURY HEARS TAPE ON GANG WARS IN BOSTON TRIAL

text: ''We can't begin to dig up half'' the people ''we got rid of,'' he said, adding, ''And I'm not bragging, either.''
title: JURY HEARS TAPE ON GANG WARS IN BOSTON TRIAL

text: But unknown to Mr. Angiulo, the Federal Bureau of Investigation had secretly planted electronic listening devices in his office.
title: JURY HEARS TAPE ON GANG WARS IN BOSTON TRIAL

text: This week a tape recording of that conversation was played in Federal District Court here at the trial of Mr. Angiulo and four other reputed leaders of organized crime in Boston. The trial, which began in June, is expected to last until November.
title: JURY HEARS TAPE ON GANG WARS IN BOSTON TRIAL

text: Tapes Termed Key to Case
title: JURY HEARS TAPE ON GANG WARS IN BOSTON TRIAL

text: The five men are charged with violating the Federal antiracketeering law. As part of the indictment, they have been charged with six murders, threatening witnesses, gambling, loansharking and fixing a court case.
title: JURY HEARS TAPE ON GANG WARS IN BOSTON TRIAL

text: Tape recordings made at Mr. Angiulo's office and a nearby social club in four months early in 1981 constitute the heart of the Government's case and, according to Federal prosecutors, provide the most extensive evidence yet made public about organized crime.
title: JURY HEARS TAPE ON GANG WARS IN BOSTON TRIAL

text: On the tapes the 66-year-old, silver-haired Mr. Angiulo, four of his brothers and other associates talk candidly about murder, the structure of a crime syndicate that the F.B.I. refers to as ''La Cosa Nostra,'' or the Mafia, and its strict code of secrecy and loyalty, as well as its hierarchical nature.
title: JURY HEARS TAPE ON GANG WARS IN BOSTON TRIAL

text: According to testimony by F.B.I. agents, Mr. Angiulo was the head of the Boston organization, a description repeated on many of the tapes, where he is referred to as the ''boss'' and demands subservience from his counselor, lieutenants and ''soldiers,'' or ordinary members of La Cosa Nostra.
title: JURY HEARS TAPE ON GANG WARS IN BOSTON TRIAL

text: The tapes indicate that Mr. Angiulo spent considerable time analyzing the antiracketeering law. He calculated, incorrectly as it turned out, that the Federal courts would rule that the law could only be applied if suspected members of organized crime infiltrated a legitimate business, not an illegimate business.
title: JURY HEARS TAPE ON GANG WARS IN BOSTON TRIAL

text: In one conversation, Mr. Angiulo tells Ilario M. A. Zannino, one lieutenant in his organization, ''Our argument is we're illegitimate business.''
title: JURY HEARS TAPE ON GANG WARS IN BOSTON TRIAL

text: ''We're a shylock,'' Mr. Zannino interjected, picking up the thrust of the argument.
title: JURY HEARS TAPE ON GANG WARS IN BOSTON TRIAL

text: ''We are a bookmaker,'' Mr. Angiulo went on. ''We're selling marijuana. We are illegal here, illegal there. Arsonists. We are everything.'' ''Pimps,'' Mr. Zannino suggested. ''So what?'' Mr. Angiulo asked. ''Prostitutes,'' Mr. Zannino said. ''The law does not cover us, is that right?'' Mr. Angiulo asked.
title: JURY HEARS TAPE ON GANG WARS IN BOSTON TRIAL

text: ''That's the argument,'' Mr. Zannino replied.
title: JURY HEARS TAPE ON GANG WARS IN BOSTON TRIAL

text: ''I wouldn't be in a legitimate business for all the money in the world,'' Mr. Angiulo concluded. 'This Thing of Ours'
title: JURY HEARS TAPE ON GANG WARS IN BOSTON TRIAL

text: In their effort to prove that Mr. Angiulo and the others belonged to La Cosa Nostra, Government prosecutors have played tapes in which the men discuss the organization, often referring to it as ''this thing,'' or ''this thing of ours,'' a literal translation of ''la cosa nostra.''
title: JURY HEARS TAPE ON GANG WARS IN BOSTON TRIAL

text: On one tape Mr. Zannino, worried about a renewed outbreak of gang warfare in Boston, reports that he rushed from his daughter's funeral to meet with Mr. Angiulo.
title: JURY HEARS TAPE ON GANG WARS IN BOSTON TRIAL

text: ''My poor daughter,'' Mr. Zannino said. ''I come back from the grave. My heart is broken. But this thing comes first. I love this thing more than anything.''
title: JURY HEARS TAPE ON GANG WARS IN BOSTON TRIAL

text: Mr. Zannino, who is 65, was originally scheduled to stand trial with Mr. Angiulo, but the case has been postponed because of his chronic heart problems.
title: JURY HEARS TAPE ON GANG WARS IN BOSTON TRIAL

text: After a separate trial this spring based on parts of the same tape recordings, Mr. Angiulo's former lawyer, William J. Cintolo, was sentenced to two years in prison for conspiring to prevent witnesses from testifying against Mr. Angiulo.
title: JURY HEARS TAPE ON GANG WARS IN BOSTON TRIAL

text: Mr. Angiulo's son Jason and six other people are scheduled to go on trial on racketeering charges after this trial ends.
title: JURY HEARS TAPE ON GANG WARS IN BOSTON TRIAL

text: Many of the tapes played in court have dealt with murder. On one, Mr. Zannino is heard boasting to two colleagues, ''We clipped Barboza,'' a reference to Joseph (Barboza) Baron, a gangland enforcer who turned Government witness and was shot to death in San Francisco in 1976.
title: JURY HEARS TAPE ON GANG WARS IN BOSTON TRIAL

text: On another tape, Mr. Angiulo can be heard angrily discussing the possibility of killing the girlfriend of one of his soldiers because she had informed the mother of a stabbing victim that another of his soldiers was the assailant. ''It has come to the point we got to do something about it,'' Mr. Angiulo said.
title: JURY HEARS TAPE ON GANG WARS IN BOSTON TRIAL

text: ''Do you want me to -- ''
title: JURY HEARS TAPE ON GANG WARS IN BOSTON TRIAL

text: ''Kill her,'' Mr. Zannino suggested. ''Kill her,'' Mr. Angiulo agreed. In March 1984, three years after that conversation, a man in a ski mask fired three shots at the woman, Eva McDonough, in a North End bar, but she was not seriously injured.
title: JURY HEARS TAPE ON GANG WARS IN BOSTON TRIAL

text: The tapes indicate frequent contact between the Angiulo group in Boston and Raymond L. S. Patriarca, the reputed overall boss of organized crime in New England. Mr. Patriarca, who lived in Providence, R.I., died in July 1984. When the Angiulos wanted to arrange a meeting, they would call Providence and ask for ''an ice cream.''
title: JURY HEARS TAPE ON GANG WARS IN BOSTON TRIAL

text: Over the objections of the defense Federal District Judge David S. Nelson let the jury and the press see transcripts of the tapes.
title: JURY HEARS TAPE ON GANG WARS IN BOSTON TRIAL

text: The defense contends the transcripts are inaccurate and misleading.
title: JURY HEARS TAPE ON GANG WARS IN BOSTON TRIAL

text: The Reagan Administration announced today that it had ruled out use of the herbicide paraquat to eradicate marijuana this year but would resume use of other chemical herbicides in its campaign to end production of the plants on Federal lands.
title: U.S. RULES OUT USE OF A HERBICIDE IN RESUMPTION OF MARIJUANA PLAN

text: Federal officials said that paraquat, an acid that can produce severe lung damage in humans if ingested, was still being seriously considered for use in future years. They said the Government decided against use of paraquat this year because of labeling changes required under a Federal court order.
title: U.S. RULES OUT USE OF A HERBICIDE IN RESUMPTION OF MARIJUANA PLAN

text: The announcement temporarily allayed concerns of environmentalists and others who feared that the Government would immediately resume spraying paraquat on marijuana fields, a practice that was halted in 1983.
title: U.S. RULES OUT USE OF A HERBICIDE IN RESUMPTION OF MARIJUANA PLAN

text: In the meantime, the Drug Enforcement Administration said that it would immediately begin using two herbicides considered less risky by Federal officials in the Government's month-old program to eradicate domestic marijuana production.
title: U.S. RULES OUT USE OF A HERBICIDE IN RESUMPTION OF MARIJUANA PLAN

text: Environmental groups said today that they would sue the Government to stop the herbicide plan.
title: U.S. RULES OUT USE OF A HERBICIDE IN RESUMPTION OF MARIJUANA PLAN

text: The agency's Administrator, John C. Lawn, said at a news conference that the herbicidal campaign began this morning when law-enforcement officials applied one of the chemicals, glyphosate, to about 10,000 marijuana plants in five plots in the Middle West.
title: U.S. RULES OUT USE OF A HERBICIDE IN RESUMPTION OF MARIJUANA PLAN

text: He refused to identify the exact location because, saying, ''We cannot jeopardize the safety of our personnel working on the site.''
title: U.S. RULES OUT USE OF A HERBICIDE IN RESUMPTION OF MARIJUANA PLAN

text: The Federal program began last month with manual and mechanical efforts to destroy the plants. Mr. Lawn said that resuming use of herbicides would permit Federal agents to kill marijuana in areas difficult to reach by foot.
title: U.S. RULES OUT USE OF A HERBICIDE IN RESUMPTION OF MARIJUANA PLAN

text: In 1983, the agency sprayed paraquat on marijuana plants in Georgia and Kentucky, producing a Federal court challenge by several environmental groups and the National Organization for the Reform of Marijuana Laws, which seeks to decriminalize marijuana use.
title: U.S. RULES OUT USE OF A HERBICIDE IN RESUMPTION OF MARIJUANA PLAN

text: Paraquat is a widely used weedkiller that can be lethal if inhaled.
title: U.S. RULES OUT USE OF A HERBICIDE IN RESUMPTION OF MARIJUANA PLAN

text: Under a consent decree that settled the suit, the D.E.A. agreed not to spray paraquat until after the Government prepared a statement on the action's effect on the environment and made changes in the chemical's labeling.
title: U.S. RULES OUT USE OF A HERBICIDE IN RESUMPTION OF MARIJUANA PLAN

text: The two-inch-thick impact statement was completed in July and found that ''there is a slight risk that heavy smokers of marijuana could be affected by paraquat-sprayed marijuana.'' The document also opened the way for use of glyphosate and the other herbicide, 2,4-D.
title: U.S. RULES OUT USE OF A HERBICIDE IN RESUMPTION OF MARIJUANA PLAN

text: Federal officials said that the required labeling changes for the paraquat are still months away.
title: U.S. RULES OUT USE OF A HERBICIDE IN RESUMPTION OF MARIJUANA PLAN

text: Mr. Lawn said that glyphosate is a weedkiller that could be bought at a neighborhood drugstore. Recent studies, he said, showed that someone would have to smoke at least 139 cigarettes tainted by the chemical for there to be a health danger.
title: U.S. RULES OUT USE OF A HERBICIDE IN RESUMPTION OF MARIJUANA PLAN

text: But Jay Feldman, coordinator for the National Coalition Against the Misuse of Pesticides, said his group and others would sue the D.E.A. to block the herbicide plan.
title: U.S. RULES OUT USE OF A HERBICIDE IN RESUMPTION OF MARIJUANA PLAN

text: Chuck Muncie, the Minnesota Viking running back who was reinstated in July after a one-year suspension for drug problems, has been suspended for the season opener against the San Francisco 49ers because he missed two therapy sessions, according to Pete Rozelle, the commissioner of the National Football League. . . . Another Viking with a drug-related difficulty is Tim Newton, a rookie nose tackle. He was ticketed on a petty-misdemeanor charge of marijuana possession Thursday night in Minneapolis. Newton had been expected to start tomorrow in the team's opener against the San Francisco 49ers, but now his status is unclear.
title: Muncie Is Suspended

text: South Africa closed 454 schools for students of mixed race after days of unrest in Cape Town's mixed-race areas. A Cabinet official said the Government could no longer guarantee the students' safety. The announcement came as Nelson Mandela, the black nationalist and South Africa's most prominent political prisoner, underwent medical tests for the second time this year. He is 67 years old. [Page 1, Column 6.]
title: NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 7, 1985

text: President Reagan said he was sorry that he ''carelessly gave the impression'' last month that he thought racial segregation had been eliminated in public places in South Africa. ''I didn't intend to say that,'' he told reporters about his remarks in a radio interview last month. Meanwhile, the White House considered a series of compromises designed to prevent Congress from overriding an expected veto of sanctions legislation against South Africa. [1:5.]
title: NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 7, 1985

text: Japan's limit on military spending to 1 percent of the country's gross national product will stay intact despite Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone's urging that it be abandoned. The governing party turned down the proposal, a major defeat for Mr. Nakasone, the party's leader. But Government and party leaders agreed to adopt as official policy a Japanese Defense Agency plan for steadily increased weapons purchases over the next five years. [4:4.]
title: NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 7, 1985

text: New U.S. foreign trade moves are expected to be announced soon by President Reagan, Administration and Congressional sources said. They will be aimed at what the Government regards as unfair trade practices by Japan, the European Economic Community, South Korea and Brazil that keep out exports from the United States and other countries. [1:1.]
title: NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 7, 1985

text: A sharp drop in the jobless rate in August was widely regarded as a sign that a long-anticipated economic rebound might be near. The Labor Department said the rate fell three-tenths of a percentage point to 6.9 percent, the lowest level since President Reagan took office. The rate had held steadily at 7.2 percent in the six previous months. [1:2.]
title: NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 7, 1985

text: All 31 people aboard were killed when a Midwest Express Airlines twin-engine DC-9 jetliner crashed and burned after taking off from Mitchell Field in Milwaukee. [1:5.]
title: NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 7, 1985

text: Cocaine use by Keith Hernandez was admitted publicly by him for the first time. At the trial of an accused cocaine dealer in Pittsburgh, the Mets' first baseman testified that he used cocaine for three years from July 1980 to June 1983 and played one game in 1980 under the drug's influence. He was the second player to testify at the trial that he had used cocaine. [1:3.]
title: NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 7, 1985

text: An obscure comet has swung around the Sun and is traveling outward to an intersection with the flight path of an equally obscure American spacecraft that is to fly through the comet's tail next week. The meeting of the comet, named Giacobini-Zinner, and the spacecraft is expected to provide many new data about the composition of comets. [1:2.]
title: NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 7, 1985

text: Details of the Titanic's discovery were given by Dr. Robert D. Ballard, the expedition's chief scientist. He said the ship was a ''noble sight,'' and that there were heaps of luggage and coal lying beside her. [1:1.]
title: NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 7, 1985

text: Election of a new presiding bishop will preoccupy the triennial General Convention of the Episcopal Church which begins today in Anaheim, Calif. The bishop will be the church's leader for perhaps the next 12 years. Four bishops have been nominated, but there is no clear favorite, church members say. [7:1.]
title: NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 7, 1985

text: The Navy's plans for a fighting fleet of 600 ships would commit so much of its future budgets to shipbuilding that it may be unable to provide enough aircraft, crews, munitions, maintenance and other essentials to keep the ships operating, a Congressional panel was told. [8:6.]
title: NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 7, 1985

text: Attempts to eradicate marijuana with the herbicide paraquat was ruled out this year by the Reagan Administration. It said, however, that it would resume the use of other chemical herbicides in its campaign to end production of marijuana on Federal lands, and that parquat was still being seriously considered for use in future years. Environmentialists opppose paraquat's use. [10:5.]
title: NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 7, 1985

text: Endangerment of state pension funds was foreseen by New York State Comptroller Edward V. Regan if states cut their business dealings with South Africa over the apartheid issue. Mr. Regan, New York's highest elected Republican official and custodian of its $26 billion in pension funds, said President Reagan should support anti-apartheid Federal legislation to prevent the states from acting independently to take economic sanctions against South Africa. This could jeopardize the stability of their pension funds, he said. [5:1.]
title: NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 7, 1985

text: A explosion at the Long Island home of a former Latvian policeman who had been accused of being a Nazi war criminal, seriously injured a bystander who saw that the house was on fire and ran to alert the occupants. A caller to a newspaper claimed the Jewish Defense League was reponsible. Several hours later, a man who had been accused of concealing his membership in the Nazi SS died of injuries received three weeks ago in an almost identical bombing outside his house in Paterson, N.J. [25:2.] Page 31
title: NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 7, 1985

text: Your articles on cocaine use among baseball players (Aug. 19 and 20) should be commended. Peter Ueberroth also deserves credit for his concern with baseball's integrity, but the commissioner's proposal for mandatory drug testing must be condemned.
title: Even Baseball Players Can Have Civil Rights

text: Results of drug screens are frequently inaccurate, and their use as evidence in criminal proceedings violates constitutional rights.
title: Even Baseball Players Can Have Civil Rights

text: A urine test that registers positive for THC (i.e., marijuana), for example, merely indicates ''contact'' with the drug a week to 10 days before the test, possibly longer. ''Contact'' may have been on private time or through passive inhalation, and on-the-job use cannot be properly inferred.
title: Even Baseball Players Can Have Civil Rights

text: Last year, the Army, perhaps the first employer to administer arbitrary drug screens, found 20,012 of 20,681 tests registering positive invalid because of faulty lab activity. The Army subsequently condemned the urinalysis as ''not scientifically or legally supportable for disciplinary purposes'' (news story, March 31). Similarly, the Centers for Disease Control found a 4 percent false-positive rate in drug screening that it has monitored.
title: Even Baseball Players Can Have Civil Rights

text: Mr. Ueberroth must also recognize the constitutional issues surrounding mandatory drug tests, especially in a criminal proceeding, such as the coming Pittsburgh case, in which players are on trial. While questions of constitutional limits on search and seizure, self-incriminating evidence and invasion of privacy are in dispute, and the test's accuracy remains dubious, the results of a mandatory urinalysis must not jeopardize a player's livelihood. NEAL KLAUSNER Advocate for the Unemployed Unemployment Action Center New York University School of Law New York, Aug. 26, 1985
title: Even Baseball Players Can Have Civil Rights

text: Symbols of devil worship were found in the homes of some of the 16 people slain in the ''night stalker'' case, according to news reports.
title: SATANIC SYMBOLISM REPORTED IN HOMES OF 'STALKER' VICTIMS

text: A suspect in the case, Richard Ramirez, 25 years old, was arrested Saturday after he was pursued and beaten by a group of residents in East Los Angeles when he allegedly tried to steal a car.
title: SATANIC SYMBOLISM REPORTED IN HOMES OF 'STALKER' VICTIMS

text: Mr. Ramirez was being held without bail for investigation of one unspecified count of murder and for attempted automobile theft and assault. He is to be arraigned Tuesday.
title: SATANIC SYMBOLISM REPORTED IN HOMES OF 'STALKER' VICTIMS

text: The police say Mr. Ramirez is the prime suspect in 16 slayings and at least 21 assaults since Feb. 8.
title: SATANIC SYMBOLISM REPORTED IN HOMES OF 'STALKER' VICTIMS

text: Unidentified sources quoted today by The Los Angeles Times and Los Angeles television stations KABC and KCBS said five-pointed stars associated with witchcraft and devil worship, were painted on walls in the homes of some of the victims.
title: SATANIC SYMBOLISM REPORTED IN HOMES OF 'STALKER' VICTIMS

text: The San Francisco Examiner quoted Ray Garcia, 27, a former El Paso classmate of the suspect, as saying that Mr. Ramirez was obsessed with satanic themes in the 1979 rock album ''Highway to Hell,'' from the band AC-DC.
title: SATANIC SYMBOLISM REPORTED IN HOMES OF 'STALKER' VICTIMS

text: Mr. Garcia said Mr. Ramirez's favorite song was ''Night Prowler.'' The lyrics, in part:
title: SATANIC SYMBOLISM REPORTED IN HOMES OF 'STALKER' VICTIMS

text: Was that a noise out your window Or a shadow on your blind?
title: SATANIC SYMBOLISM REPORTED IN HOMES OF 'STALKER' VICTIMS

text: And you lie there naked
title: SATANIC SYMBOLISM REPORTED IN HOMES OF 'STALKER' VICTIMS

text: Like a body in a tomb; Suspended animation As I slip into your room.''
title: SATANIC SYMBOLISM REPORTED IN HOMES OF 'STALKER' VICTIMS

text: The Times and KABC also said investigators last month searched an area of East Los Angeles where they believed a satanic cult had met, and found shoe prints that matched prints found at the scene of some of the slayings.
title: SATANIC SYMBOLISM REPORTED IN HOMES OF 'STALKER' VICTIMS

text: The police refused to confirm or deny the reports.
title: SATANIC SYMBOLISM REPORTED IN HOMES OF 'STALKER' VICTIMS

text: The suspect's father, Julian Ramirez told The El Paso Times that he could not ''in my heart'' believe his son was guilty.
title: SATANIC SYMBOLISM REPORTED IN HOMES OF 'STALKER' VICTIMS

text: Mr. Ramirez told the El Paso newspaper he had not seen his son in two or three years because drugs had caused them to grow apart. ''I believe the marijuana he's been smoking put him out of control,'' said the father, an employee of the Santa Fe Railway, in an interview published today.
title: SATANIC SYMBOLISM REPORTED IN HOMES OF 'STALKER' VICTIMS

text: Richard Ramirez's sister, Rosa Flores, told The Orange County Register that her brother, the youngest of five children, began having problems at age 12 when he started smoking marijuana and graduated to harder drugs, including PCP, or phencyclidine hydrochloride. She said he also suffered epileptic seizures periodically.
title: SATANIC SYMBOLISM REPORTED IN HOMES OF 'STALKER' VICTIMS

text: Members of the ''night stalker'' task force were to meet with the police in suburban Montclair Monday or Tuesday to determine if two men who were fatally shot as they slept early Saturday were the serial killer's latest victims, said the authorities in Montclair.
title: SATANIC SYMBOLISM REPORTED IN HOMES OF 'STALKER' VICTIMS

text: By E. J. Dionne Jr., Special To the New York Times
title: UNITY OVER DRUGS GROWS AT MEETING

text: Participants in a United Nations conference on crime say the spread of drug abuse in the third world seems to have brought the industrialized nations and the poorer, drug-producing countries a little closer together.
title: UNITY OVER DRUGS GROWS AT MEETING

text: The conference, which opened here this week, has been marked by some sharp East-West exchanges, but participants say that it has so far been surprisingly free of the polemics that often mark United Nations meetings.
title: UNITY OVER DRUGS GROWS AT MEETING

text: ''Unlike Caracas five years ago, I have heard virtually no name-calling against our country,'' said Norman A. Carlson, an American delegate and the Director of the Federal Bureau of Prisons.
title: UNITY OVER DRUGS GROWS AT MEETING

text: In comparison to the last congress on crime, which was held in Venezuela, he said, ''there is a much greater spirit of cooperation here.'' #122 Nations Participate The conference, the Seventh United Nations Congress on the Prevention of Crime and the Treatment of Offenders, has drawn together law enforcement officials from 122 nations. It is to end Sept. 6.
title: UNITY OVER DRUGS GROWS AT MEETING

text: Pino Arlacchi, an Italian delegate who is an expert on combating crime, said that in the past, developing countries that had been criticized for producing drugs would in turn accuse rich countries of blaming them for addiction problems created by wealthy socities.
title: UNITY OVER DRUGS GROWS AT MEETING

text: ''The big difference is that the producing countries are now also consuming countries,'' he said.
title: UNITY OVER DRUGS GROWS AT MEETING

text: Mr. Arlacchi traced a sharp change in the world's attitude toward drugs since the 1950's, when, he said, ''even the Europeans saw drugs as just an American problem.''
title: UNITY OVER DRUGS GROWS AT MEETING

text: ''Then, in the '60's, the problem spread to Europe, and it became the third world versus the industrialized countries,'' said Mr. Arlacchi. ''Now, the third world is suffering from this tragedy, too.''
title: UNITY OVER DRUGS GROWS AT MEETING

text: ''It has ceased to be a North-South issue,'' Leticia R. Shahani, the secretary general of the congress, said, adding, ''There is now a solidarity on this issue,''
title: UNITY OVER DRUGS GROWS AT MEETING

text: In a dramatic speech, Abdelkarim Tandjaoui, Counselor of the Supreme Court of Algeria, declared:
title: UNITY OVER DRUGS GROWS AT MEETING

text: ''Some countries had compromised their conscience and were in fact competing with each other in the production of drugs. Drugs were easily available in some countries because of the tremendous profits from such trade.''
title: UNITY OVER DRUGS GROWS AT MEETING

text: But participants at the conference said the shift has not necessarily made it easier to control drug trafficking. Mr. Arlacchi noted that the hundred of millions of dollars involved in the drug business is especially influential in poor countries, and it has given drug traffickers increased power in third world banking and politics.
title: UNITY OVER DRUGS GROWS AT MEETING

text: Other changes in the drug business that are making enforcement of drug laws more difficult, he said, included the growth in international money markets and the increasing importance of off-shore ''fiscal paradises,'' where virtually all financial transactions are kept secret.
title: UNITY OVER DRUGS GROWS AT MEETING

text: Perhaps even more challenging, he argued, is a steady ''unification of illegal markets throughout the world.''
title: UNITY OVER DRUGS GROWS AT MEETING

text: ''Illegal markets in drugs increasingly overlap with those in guns and even in information,'' he said in an interview. ''The recent spy scandals show that trafficking in intelligence is now done mainly for money and not for moral or ideological reasons.''
title: UNITY OVER DRUGS GROWS AT MEETING

text: The overlap with the gun trade is especially widespread. In his paper, Mr. Arlacchi argued that arms traders tend ''to employ the same network of logistics, intelligence and financial infrastructure as drugs.''
title: UNITY OVER DRUGS GROWS AT MEETING

text: There is also, he wrote, ''an increasing tendency to use drugs as a basis for financing the acquisition of arms.''
title: UNITY OVER DRUGS GROWS AT MEETING

text: Carlos Camacho-Leiva, a delegate from Colombia, which is believed to be the main exporter of cocaine to the United States, said that drug production had been ''linked to political problems'' in his country. ''People involved in guerrilla warfare are collaborating with drug traffickers,'' he said.
title: UNITY OVER DRUGS GROWS AT MEETING

text: Another political problem was pointed up in a paper by Walter J. Leamy of Interpol's drug subdivision.
title: UNITY OVER DRUGS GROWS AT MEETING

text: Mr. Leamy said that in the Middle East, ''armed conflict makes it almost impossible to monitor the illegal production of opiates, particularly heroin, and cannabis.''
title: UNITY OVER DRUGS GROWS AT MEETING

text: The political sensitivity of some of these questions, Mr. Arlacchi said, will make it difficult for the United Nations congress to deal with them openly.
title: UNITY OVER DRUGS GROWS AT MEETING

text: A field of more than 1,700 marijuana plants has been discovered and destroyed near one of Eglin Air Force Base's landing sites, according to a base spokesman. The field was the fifth discovered over the past months on the base's 728-mile reservation, the base spokesman said Thursday.
title: MARIJUANA FOUND AT AIR BASE

text: CRAMPTON HODNET. By Barbara Pym. (Dutton, $14.95.) The self-deluding, smug clergyman. The intelligent woman pondering spinsterhood. The imperious grande dame. The high-minded student and her married suitor, well into his midlife crisis. These and other characters familiar from Barbara Pym's later books assemble for the first time in this early work (1939-40), now published posthumously. As is ever the case in a Pym novel, the scope of the action is constricted but made compelling by understatement, an underlying sense of compassion and a precision of language through which mundane vocabulary is elevated into art. Crampton Hodnet is the name of a parish invented by the clergyman as an unnecessary alibi for an innocent walk in the woods, and it comes to signify all the imaginary excuses and rationalizations by which the book's inhabitants live. They watch themselves and each other closely, alert for any lapse of North Oxford decorum, and together preserve a world of interchangeable parts where no one is indispensable and equilibrium is maintained above all else. The novel is framed with three flirtations - two improbable, one predictable and all ultimately transitory. ''Falling in love is never ordinary to the people who indulge in it,'' a woman says, settling into her unmarried state. But passion implies a risk of uncertainty and is unstable; no character is capable of extricating him or herself sufficiently from past comforts or habits to indulge in passion for long. In pre-World War II academic Britannia, convention rules.
title: IN SHORT: FICTION

text: Though the disparate parts of this novel do not quite mesh into the seamless wonder of later works like ''Less Than Angels,'' ''Jane and Prudence'' or ''Quartet in Autumn,'' they do contain in their humor, insights and small surprises, a freshness that is irresistible. ''Crampton Hodnet'' may not be the book with which to launch or fully explain a Barbara Pym addiction, but it most certainly is one that will feed it.
title: IN SHORT: FICTION

text: Forty profesional boxers, including Hector (Macho) Camacho, the World Boxing Council lightweight champion, have been suspended by the New Jersey Athletic Commission for failing mandatory drug tests.
title: CAMACHO, 39 OTHERS PENALIZED

text: Tom Cannon, a spokesman for Irwin Kimmelman, the New Jersey Attorney General, confirmed the suspensions but would not identify the fighters involved. But Camacho's name was confirmed by Don Elbaum, a promoter, who said he received a list of the suspended boxers. The test Camacho failed reportedly came after his victory over Louis Burke on Jan. 19 in Atlantic City.
title: CAMACHO, 39 OTHERS PENALIZED

text: Camacho and 35 others have been suspended for 90 days. Four others have been suspended indefinitely for twice failing tests since they were instituted for New Jersey boxers in January. Officials and boxing promoters would not disclose the names of the four fighters, but they are reportedly not as highly ranked as Camacho, the 23-year-old from Harlem. The 36 other boxers failed the tests once.
title: CAMACHO, 39 OTHERS PENALIZED

text: Cannon would not say what drugs were found in the tests, which are designed to detect marijuana, cocaine, heroin and other drugs.
title: CAMACHO, 39 OTHERS PENALIZED

text: ''Urine samples were taken before and after fights,'' Cannon said yesterday, ''and apparently drugs were discovered.''
title: CAMACHO, 39 OTHERS PENALIZED

text: Approximately 1,000 boxers in New Jersey have received the mandatory tests since January.
title: CAMACHO, 39 OTHERS PENALIZED

text: Boxing authorities in New York and Nevada indicated the suspended fighters would not be allowed to fight in those states until the suspensions expired or were lifted.
title: CAMACHO, 39 OTHERS PENALIZED

text: Camacho, who won his title August 10, will probably not be affected by the suspension because he is unlikely to fight again in the next 90 days.
title: CAMACHO, 39 OTHERS PENALIZED

text: If the suspensions are honored by the two states, several scheduled bouts in the immediate future could be affected. At least two bouts slated for Atlantic City within the next 10 days may be affected, said Cannon.
title: CAMACHO, 39 OTHERS PENALIZED

text: Elbaum named Stanley Ross, Bernard Benton and Roger Stafford as on the list of suspended fighters. Benton is scheduled to fight Alonzo Ratliff for the W.B.C. cruiserweight title on Sept. 21 in Las Vegas, Nev., on a card headed by the Larry Holmes-Michael spinks heavyweight title fight.
title: CAMACHO, 39 OTHERS PENALIZED

text: As it rambles through the high country near the northern coast of California, U.S. 101 is also called the Redwood Highway. It is the spine of a region with attractions that include the wine-growing counties of Napa, Sonoma and Mendocino, a rugged, rocky coastline and, as a traveler approaches the Oregon state line, small fishing towns.
title: ELEGANT LODGINGS IN REDWOOD COUNTRY

text: More than anything else, the region is dominated by the redwood tree, a natural wonder that grows hundreds of feet into the air and turns the surrounding wilderness into vaulted cathedrals pierced by shafts of sunlight and covered by a delicate canopy of feathery branches.
title: ELEGANT LODGINGS IN REDWOOD COUNTRY

text: In the midst of the redwood country, near Garberville (about 200 miles north of San Francisco), I found the Benbow Inn. It was a case of any port in a storm, a search for a place to stay on a chilly night.
title: ELEGANT LODGINGS IN REDWOOD COUNTRY

text: What I discovered, however, was a remote but quite elegant inn that looked as if it might have been transplanted from the Black Forest in Germany. A three-story, half-timbered chalet-like building perched on the western side of U.S. 101, it overlooks a small lake and a branch of the Eel River, one of the major waterways of the redwood country.
title: ELEGANT LODGINGS IN REDWOOD COUNTRY

text: Inside, the atmosphere hints at an English country inn, with dark wood paneling and heavy beams in the lobby, a huge stone fireplace and couches for guests to enjoy the fire. French doors open to a large, landscaped patio, and, at one end of the lobby, is a dining room with high ceilings, pastel wallpaper and fresh flowers on every table.
title: ELEGANT LODGINGS IN REDWOOD COUNTRY

text: In the lobby, half-finished jigsaw puzzles are set up on tables, waiting for guests to complete them; between 3 and 4 P.M. each day, tea and scones are served to guests staying at the inn. There's also an inviting fireplace in the bar, a pleasant venue for a drink before dinner either in the main dining room or, when the weather permits, beneath an umbrella on a large patio overlooking the river.
title: ELEGANT LODGINGS IN REDWOOD COUNTRY

text: Camping and hiking among the redwoods is one of the joys of a visit to California, and Benbow Lake is pleasant for swimming and fishing during the warm months - there's also a nine-hole golf course and a putting green nearby.
title: ELEGANT LODGINGS IN REDWOOD COUNTRY

text: Its scenic grandeur notwithstanding, this region has also been the setting for the cultivation of marijuana on a scale large enough to engage the attention of Federal as well as local officials. During the past three years, they have mounted a series of helicopter raids aimed at eradicating the crop.
title: ELEGANT LODGINGS IN REDWOOD COUNTRY

text: Except for the sound of a helicopter now and then, however, guests at the Benbow Inn are not aware of the battle between lawmen and growers because the raids take place in more remote areas of the region.
title: ELEGANT LODGINGS IN REDWOOD COUNTRY

text: Over the years, Herbert Hoover and
title: ELEGANT LODGINGS IN REDWOOD COUNTRY

text: Eleanor Roosevelt have been among the guests at the Benbow, which was opened in 1926 and attracted many visitors through the 1940's, but fell into disrepair. A few years ago, Charles and Patsy Watts, formerly owners of the Vagabond Inn in Carmel, Calif., took it over and started an extensive restoration program.
title: ELEGANT LODGINGS IN REDWOOD COUNTRY

text: There are 55 rooms, each with a private bathroom, antique furnishings and a stack of worn detective novels. Some rooms in the main building are quite small, so it is best to ask for one of 18 rooms in a new section known as the terrace. The rooms in the terrace section, a few steps from the main inn, are large, decorated with lavish woodwork and overlook the river.
title: ELEGANT LODGINGS IN REDWOOD COUNTRY

text: The food served at the inn is generally of a high quality, with an emphasis on seafood and classic French dishes as well as on fresh vegetables. Two or three vegetables are always offered (organically grown squash from a nearby garden was one choice this summer) as well as a rice pilaf or baked potato. Recently, the a la carte menu included entrees such as poached salmon stuffed with mushrooms, trout amandine, prawns sauteed in chartreuse with apples, cucumbers and cream sauce and filet of sole steamed with grapes and orange juice in addition to chicken, duck, quail and veal dishes. For dessert one could have chocolate mousse - or a white chocolate mousse with marinated blackberries.
title: ELEGANT LODGINGS IN REDWOOD COUNTRY

text: Presiding over the inn's kitchen is Eric Villard, a 29-year-old chef who moved from France to California in 1979. At first, Mr. Villard said, he tried to buy fresh salmon and other fish from fishermen on the coast 30 miles or so away, but the supply was unpredictable. ''If you had bad weather, no salmon,'' he said. But he solved the problem by having fresh fish and other items shipped by Greyhound bus from San Francisco.
title: ELEGANT LODGINGS IN REDWOOD COUNTRY

text: Another thing he learned about the restaurant business in this beautiful American wilderness area is that it is wise to print the menu in English. ''When I started, I printed the menu in French. But it didn't work. It scared people away.''
title: ELEGANT LODGINGS IN REDWOOD COUNTRY

text: Rates at the Benbow Inn (445 Lake Benbow Drive, Garberville, Calif. 95440; 707-923-2124) are $62 to $82 for the smaller rooms and $95 in the terrace section. Several deluxe rooms, some with fireplaces, are also available in both sections of the inn for $125 to $150 (all rates are for one or two people in a room; families with children are welcome).
title: ELEGANT LODGINGS IN REDWOOD COUNTRY

text: In April, May, October and November (except for certain holidays and special events), lower rates are available for two- or three-day stays.
title: ELEGANT LODGINGS IN REDWOOD COUNTRY

text: Over the Christmas holidays, a program of special dinners and parties with caroling and performances by artists from the San Francisco Opera Company are scheduled.
title: ELEGANT LODGINGS IN REDWOOD COUNTRY

text: Room rates do not include any meals; dinner for two in the inn's dining room, including a bottle of California wine, costs about $50.
title: ELEGANT LODGINGS IN REDWOOD COUNTRY

text: The Arcata-Eureka Airport, 80 miles north of Garberville at McKinleyville, is served by United, Wings West and West Airlines; the airport has Avis, Hertz and National car rental agencies.
title: ELEGANT LODGINGS IN REDWOOD COUNTRY

text: Visitors who do not drive can call the Yellow Cab service of Eureka (707-442-4551); fare from the airport to the Benbow Inn is about $80.
title: ELEGANT LODGINGS IN REDWOOD COUNTRY

text: MANY politicians will appear at Labor Day gatherings tomorrow mouthing platitudes about industrial workers being the backbone of the United States, but few of these speakers will believe what they say. For many Americans in this age of high technology, industrial workers are at best an anachronism, at worst an embarrassment.
title: WORKERS IN FICTION: LOCKED OUT

text: Steelworkers, truck drivers and men and women on assembly lines have not entirely vanished from the pages of American fiction, but they are no longer the heroes they occasionally were at earlier times in our literature. Since World War II, few novels about the working class have been set in the present; instead, the authors have nostalgically looked to by-gone eras of labor militancy. Some of this fiction is based on the activities of the Industrial Workers of the World, the radical labor union founded in 1905. Among such works are Irving Stone's ''Adversary in the House'' (1947), a fictional biography of the Socialist leader Eugene V. Debs; Wallace Stegner's ''Preacher and the Slave'' (1950), based on the life of Joe Hill, an I.W.W. member who some saw as a martyr; Marcia Davenport's ''Valley of Decision'' (originally published in 1942 and reprinted in 1979), which describes the lives of immigrants who worked in the Pittsburgh steel industry early in the century; Mary Lee Settle's ''Scapegoat'' (1980), set in a West Virginia mining town in 1912; and Meredith Tax's ''Rivington Street'' (1982), which centers on the lives of Russian immigrants who lived on New York's Lower East Side and worked in the garment industry.
title: WORKERS IN FICTION: LOCKED OUT

text: When contemporary working-class life has been addressed at all in modern American fiction, it has usually been in a peripheral manner. In recent years, the closest we have come to genuine working-class novels - those that deal directly with life on the job - are Ernest Hebert's ''Dogs of March'' (1979), a stirring story of New Hampshire family members employed as mill workers, and Robert Ward's ''Red Baker'' (1985), a solid if not outstanding book about Baltimore steelworkers who lose their jobs when a mill closes down. Both received some good reviews but people were not moved to buy large numbers of copies. Yet even ''Red Baker'' is not that concerned with the working lives of industrial laborers.
title: WORKERS IN FICTION: LOCKED OUT

text: Though its protagonist is a lifelong resident of a steel mill community in Baltimore, the reader learns little about life in the mill. The story centers on the destructive effects of unemployment and is far more concerned with alcohol, drugs, aging and community disintegration than with on-the-job problems.
title: WORKERS IN FICTION: LOCKED OUT

text: Other recent fiction that touches on working-class life does so in a similarly oblique way. In ''Shiloh,'' a 1982 collection of her short stories, Bobbie Ann Mason writes of a disabled former truck driver who smokes marijuana and has no interest in looking for other work. Raymond Carver has written stories, collected in ''Cathedral'' (1983), of the unemployed and the alcoholic. William Kennedy's Pulitzer Prize-winning ''Ironweed'' (1983) is among those books that longingly look back at labor history. But in Mr. Kennedy's 1930's, just as in novels set in the present, the theme is the disintegration of the unemployed. Similarly, in the South Philadelphia of Pete Dexter's ''God's Pocket'' (1984), violence joins with alcohol to form the essence of working-class life. These are chronicles of decline, not paeans to working-class heroes. I T is tempting to suggest that the current literary uninterest in workers is a reflection of the present atmosphere of political conservatism and that the mood is likely to pass if the pendulum swings back toward liberalism. There is, though, little in American literature's past treatment of workers to support such a view. Throughout most of this nation's history the industrial working class has been largely ignored in our fiction. The important exceptions were a few novelists with socialist connections early in the 20th century and a host of ''proletarian'' writers during the Great Depression of the 1930's.
title: WORKERS IN FICTION: LOCKED OUT

text: Jack London has been called our first working-class writer. He came from a background of poverty and knew the problems of the poor. London went far beyond the genteel socialism of William Dean Howells's novels and declared himself a revolutionary. Yet the stories that brought London fame and temporary fortune -''Call of the Wild'' and ''The Sea-Wolf,'' for example -have little to do with the working class and espouse a philosophy that contradicted the writer's professed socialism. His most popular fiction looks backward to a primitive, pre-industrial time of rugged individualism, not forward to a cooperative utopia. These same writings emphasized the brutal social Darwinism that often coexisted with the spirit of progressive reform of the first decade of this century.
title: WORKERS IN FICTION: LOCKED OUT

text: London showed a distaste for the class from which he had risen. His kinship with workers - he was employed as a longshoreman, and in jute mills, bowling alleys and canneries - may have attracted him to socialism, but his almost fanatical desire for success turned his feeling for the working class into a classic mixture of love and hate. In this, London was an extreme expression of the attitudes of many of his countrymen - real Americans ought not to be industrial workers.
title: WORKERS IN FICTION: LOCKED OUT

text: The reception that greeted the most successful working-class novel of the early 20th century, ''The Jungle'' (1906) by Upton Sinclair, paradoxically indicated American readers' minimal interest in the lives of laborers. Sinclair described at great length the conditions under which Jurgis Rudkus, a Lithuanian immigrant, lived in Chicago and worked in the meatpacking industry. In 1904 the author wrote to his editor, ''The novel I plan would be intended to set forth the breaking of human hearts by a system which exploits the labor of men and women for profits.'' Although this romantic socialist was never a novelist of the first rank, ''The Jungle'' is a powerful evocation of working-class life. London said of it, ''What 'Uncle Tom's Cabin' did for black slaves, 'The Jungle' has a large chance to do for the wage slaves of today.''
title: WORKERS IN FICTION: LOCKED OUT

text: Though the enormous popularity of ''The Jungle'' made Sinclair an international celebrity, the book did little to win sympathy for the workingmen of America to whom he dedicated it. Winston Churchill wrote in a review that the novel had disturbed ''the digestions and perhaps the consciences of mankind.'' He was wise to add the note of uncertainty. When Sinclair related that the meat in the packing houses was often diseased and that vermin infested the work areas, many readers were less concerned with the workers than with what might be in their breakfast sausage. ''I aimed at the public's heart,'' Sinclair lamented, ''and by accident hit it in the stomach.''
title: WORKERS IN FICTION: LOCKED OUT

text: The progressive era - roughly 1902 to 1917 - was a time of middle-class reformers and of general prosperity. It was to be expected that for consumers, an issue such as tainted meat would attract greater interest than the problems of meatpackers. Other realists of the early 20th century, Frank Norris and Theodore Dreiser among them, touched on the lives of workers, but concentrated their efforts on the higher reaches of the social order. After World War I, interest in reform of any kind - whether for consumers or producers - waned and the substantial American literature of the 20's had almost nothing to say about labor.
title: WORKERS IN FICTION: LOCKED OUT

text: The Great Depression of the 1930's brought workers to the center stage of American letters. The first of the new naturalist works was John Dos Passos' ''U.S.A.'' trilogy, inspired by his revulsion at the 1927 execution of Sacco and Vanzetti.
