There is no single working-class hero in this highly original work; rather, Dos Passos fuses working Americans into one protagonist. He portrays a nation of exploiters and exploited. One character who seems to sum up the author's view of the evils of capitalism is Charley Anderson, who starts out as an honest mechanic but is captivated by greed and leaves the working class behind, thereby beginning a process of personal decline.
title: WORKERS IN FICTION: LOCKED OUT

text: Most of the ''proletarian'' fiction of the 30's, written to serve political rather than artistic purposes, is not worth discussing. One of the exceptions is ''The Disinherited'' (1933) by Jack Conroy.
title: WORKERS IN FICTION: LOCKED OUT

text: Conroy described industrial labor as few novelists since the 30's have. The protagonist says, ''But I never really escaped by quitting and changing jobs. All the factories had the same conveyors, the same scientific methods for extracting the last ounce of energy. The same neon tubes pulsing with blue fire and the same automatons toiling frantically beneath the ghastly rays that etched dark shadows under their eyes and blackened their lips to resemble those of a cadaver.''
title: WORKERS IN FICTION: LOCKED OUT

text: The most noted of the Depression-era novelists who wrote about workers was John Steinbeck. ''In Dubious Battle'' (1936) chronicles a strike by migrant farm workers in California. In ''The Grapes of Wrath'' (1939), the single most important novel of the working class in our history, Steinbeck relates the tragic trek of displaced Okies to the Golden State. For laborers, machinery may seem to be the enemy but, Steinbeck shows, the problem is of a different sort: ''Is the tractor bad? Is the power that turns the long furrows wrong? If this tractor were ours it would be good - not mine, but ours. . . . We could love that tractor then as we have loved this land when it was ours.''
title: WORKERS IN FICTION: LOCKED OUT

text: In both these novels, Steinbeck dealt with agricultural, not industrial, workers. The distinction is crucial. He found it easier to disturb the consciences of Americans with novels about rural workers than Upton Sinclair had with his portrayal of urban immigrants in a meatpacking plant. Of course the vastly different economic circumstances between the time of ''The Jungle'' and that of ''The Grapes of Wrath'' partly explains the different reactions. In the Depression, readers were more receptive to literature about the working class simply because so many people were suffering. ''Even if they were not hungry and hopeless themselves,'' Harvey Swados has observed, ''the depression generation had burned into them the dulled and shamed glances of men who were [hungry and hopeless] and who could no longer feed their wives and children.''
title: WORKERS IN FICTION: LOCKED OUT

text: Such conditions easily account for the greater literary and social interest in labor in the 30's. But it is significant that even in that decade - one of extreme industrial dislocation - most working-class literature still did not deal with industrial laborers, and the heroes of most proletarian novels remained tenant farmers, miners, migrant workers and others who, as Edmund Wilson said in ''The American Jitters'' (1932), had never been ''broken to the abject life of the industrial cities.'' From Steinbeck's farmers through James T. Farrell's lower-middle-class Studs Lonigan, to the tramps of Nelson Algren's ''Somebody in Boots'' (1935), the subjects are most often outside the mainstream of American labor.
title: WORKERS IN FICTION: LOCKED OUT

text: Here lies an indication of the reasons behind Americans' general uninterest in industrial workers: those workers have never fit the self-image that Americans like to maintain. The American Eden was, of course, founded in the wilderness. The Jeffersonian idea that American farmers were far superior to the urbanized masses of Europe became ingrained in American thought. Agriculture, it has usually been thought, is the truly American way of life; industry is ''foreign.'' This notion was reinforced in the later 19th and early 20th centuries when immigrants constituted so much of the urban working class. A MERICANS cherish the myth of success as much as they do the agrarian myth. It is permissible to be a laborer early in life, as long as you rise to better things later; but he who remains an industrial worker is seen by most Americans as unsuccessful. The heroes of the Horatio Alger stories rose from the working class, no one aspires to be a worker.
title: WORKERS IN FICTION: LOCKED OUT

text: A third myth to which most Americans pay homage is that of self-reliance. The agrarian myth held that farmers were independent, though they are extraordinarily dependent on weather, world market fluctuations, transportation systems, interest rates and many other variables. But in the public mind, the farmer was what all Americans longed to be: independent and self-reliant. Not so the industrial worker; his complete dependence for his livelihood upon the owners of factories and machinery was apparent.
title: WORKERS IN FICTION: LOCKED OUT

text: If industrial workers are not close to nature and have to depend on others to earn a living, how can they be Americans? Quite easily in reality, since most Americans fit these categories. But when we think of a ''real'' American, an industrial laborer does not come to mind. It seems odd that other forms of popular culture have of late done a better job than literature in depicting the problems of laborers. One thinks of such films as ''Norma Rae'' and ''The Deer Hunter,'' television's ''All in the Family,'' which on occasion at least showed sympathy for Archie Bunker. Popular musicians have also addressed the issue in their songs: Billy Joel's ''Allentown,'' Dire Straits' ''Industrial Disease'' and Bruce Springsteen in ''My Home Town.'' Perhaps the wider audience that exists for these cultural forms has a greater interest in the problems of labor than the much more limited group that buys books.
title: WORKERS IN FICTION: LOCKED OUT

text: If, however, many of those who show greater interest in fiction about the upwardly mobile would prefer to forget workers, they might be asked to pause on Labor Day to remember that someone has to make the steel for the Mercedes. But they probably would retort that Americans are no longer likely to make the steel.
title: WORKERS IN FICTION: LOCKED OUT

text: A World War II veteran, who at the age of 17 became the nation's youngest Medal of Honor winner, said today that he was not ''a big wheel in a dope racket'' but was rather a victim of bad luck.
title: U.S. WAR HERO DENIES ANY PART IN DRUG RACKET

text: The former marine, Jacklyn Lucas, 57 years old, was arrested Wednesday on marijuana and weapons charges. He was released from the Cecil County Detention Center after his son posted $5,000 bail. Mr. Lucas was arrested when the Maryland state police raided a cornfield and found 90 marijuana plants, valued at $90,000.
title: U.S. WAR HERO DENIES ANY PART IN DRUG RACKET

text: Mr. Lucas said he began living in the cornfield, at the invitation of an unidentified friend, in northeast Maryland in July, setting up a tent and spreading out equipment. He only received permission from the landowner to live there about a week ago, said a police spokesman, Sgt. Bill Tower.
title: U.S. WAR HERO DENIES ANY PART IN DRUG RACKET

text: ''They think I'm a big wheel in a dope racket,'' Mr. Lucas said. ''I don't smoke it or raise it. I knew the stuff was there on the farm, but I couldn't run up to my friend and tell him not to grow it. He did a lot of things for me.''
title: U.S. WAR HERO DENIES ANY PART IN DRUG RACKET

text: The spokesman said the police were informed about the marijuana crop by a Department of Natural Resources airplane that was flying in the area.
title: U.S. WAR HERO DENIES ANY PART IN DRUG RACKET

text: Troopers who searched the tent said they found several marijuana plants in the process of being dried, and a shotgun, rifle and three pistols, all loaded.
title: U.S. WAR HERO DENIES ANY PART IN DRUG RACKET

text: He Dived Atop a Grenade
title: U.S. WAR HERO DENIES ANY PART IN DRUG RACKET

text: Mr. Lucas won the Medal of Honor when, six days after his 17th birthday, he dived onto a grenade to protect his fellow marines as they made their way up a hill in the invasion of Iwo Jima.
title: U.S. WAR HERO DENIES ANY PART IN DRUG RACKET

text: Mr. Lucas pulled a second grenade under him, smothering both blasts under his body. When American troops, after routing the enemy, came back to Mr. Lucas, they discovered he was alive and took him to a hospital.
title: U.S. WAR HERO DENIES ANY PART IN DRUG RACKET

text: Mr. Lucas was awarded the Medal of Honor by President Truman at the White House, and was invited by John F. Kennedy to sit on the Presidential platform as he took the oath of office.
title: U.S. WAR HERO DENIES ANY PART IN DRUG RACKET

text: The citation awarded to Mr. Lucas praised him for ''conspicous gallantry and intrepidity at the risk of his life above and beyond the call of duty.''
title: U.S. WAR HERO DENIES ANY PART IN DRUG RACKET

text: The doctor who treated Mr. Lucas was quoted in newspaper reports of the day as saying, ''Maybe he was too damn young and too damn tough to die.''
title: U.S. WAR HERO DENIES ANY PART IN DRUG RACKET

text: But since that day, Feb. 20, 1945, Mr. Lucas said he had been victimized by bad business investments and two divorces that had left him ''nearly destitute.''
title: U.S. WAR HERO DENIES ANY PART IN DRUG RACKET

text: Mr. Lucas, who said he owed the Internal Revenue Service $135,000, was living in a friend's garage since his house burned to the ground earlier this year and he moved to the cornfield.
title: U.S. WAR HERO DENIES ANY PART IN DRUG RACKET

text: By Nathaniel C. Nash, Special To the New York Times
title: ONE OF THE TOUGHEST IMAGE PROBLEMS IN TOWN

text: It is a fact of ambassadorial life that much time is spent polishing the image of one's country. But for some on Embassy Row, that is a harder task than just attending state functions and being seen with the right people.
title: ONE OF THE TOUGHEST IMAGE PROBLEMS IN TOWN

text: Rodrigo Lloreda, Colombia's Ambassador to the United States, acknowledges that his country has an image problem. Mention Colombia, and pictures of drug traffickers, bales of marijuana and cocaine factories spring to mind.
title: ONE OF THE TOUGHEST IMAGE PROBLEMS IN TOWN

text: Mr. Lloreda despairingly concedes that this is rightly so, for Colombia is a major source of drugs in the international market. Still, he contends that not enough credit is given for his country's progress in the last two years against drug trade. More important, he complains that Colombians and Colombian organizations tend to be singled out by United States law enforcement agencies for harassment and suspicion. As a result, he says, he regularly is called upon to settle minor political crises throughout the 50 states.
title: ONE OF THE TOUGHEST IMAGE PROBLEMS IN TOWN

text: At least one United States official defends the stance on Colombia.
title: ONE OF THE TOUGHEST IMAGE PROBLEMS IN TOWN

text: ''We're not just picking on Colombians or Colombian airlines,'' said Dennis Murphy, a spokesman for the Customs Service. ''We're going to stop drugs coming in from any country. And it will continue.''
title: ONE OF THE TOUGHEST IMAGE PROBLEMS IN TOWN

text: Whatever the case, Mr. Lloreda (pronouned your-RAY-dah) has embarked on what amounts to a public relations campaign to tell the ''positive story'' of Colombia in this country and try to persuade middle-level law enforcement officials to avoid immediate suspicion toward everything Colombian.
title: ONE OF THE TOUGHEST IMAGE PROBLEMS IN TOWN

text: He says results do not seem to be immediately forthcoming.
title: ONE OF THE TOUGHEST IMAGE PROBLEMS IN TOWN

text: ''I just got a call today from Atlantic City,'' he said the other day in discussing the image problem. ''Of the 10,000 illegal aliens in the city, the district attorney decided to crack down on the 500 Colombians. He didn't do anything about the Europeans, the Asians, the Africans. Just the Colombians because they're supposedly all drug dealers.''
title: ONE OF THE TOUGHEST IMAGE PROBLEMS IN TOWN

text: Such diplomatic fires, both big and small, have often been Mr. Lloreda's lot in his nine months in Washington, as he races to the scene as Colombia's top diplomatic official to work out an amicable solution. Perhaps it is good training for a man who admits he would like to be President of Colombia and might well have a chance.
title: ONE OF THE TOUGHEST IMAGE PROBLEMS IN TOWN

text: Indeed, a number of Colombia's recent presidents have held the position as Ambasssador to the United States. And Mr. Lloreda, having served as a Senator, Minister of Education, Foreign Minister and Vice President, is well positioned for higher office when he returns to Colombia, State Department officials say.
title: ONE OF THE TOUGHEST IMAGE PROBLEMS IN TOWN

text: But the Ambassador is vexed by what he sees as a pattern of bias against his country. Take the case, he said, of the Boeing 747 owned by Avianca, the Colombian airline, that was seized earlier this year.
title: ONE OF THE TOUGHEST IMAGE PROBLEMS IN TOWN

text: United States Customs officials found cocaine in the nightly shipment of flowers from Bogota, and even though the Colombian police had alerted Customs that the narcotics were on the plane, ''they impounded the plane anyway,'' Mr. Lloreda said, forcing Avianca to give Customs the right to revoke its flying rights here if another case occurred.
title: ONE OF THE TOUGHEST IMAGE PROBLEMS IN TOWN

text: ''Now where in the world do you see that happening?'' he said in objecting to the severity of the restriction. ''It was just the need on the part of the Customs agents to show the American public they were being tough on Colombian drugs.''
title: ONE OF THE TOUGHEST IMAGE PROBLEMS IN TOWN

text: Today the Customs Service again showed a tough arm, fining Eastern Airlines more than $1 million after finding nearly a ton of cocaine on Colombia-Miami flights.
title: ONE OF THE TOUGHEST IMAGE PROBLEMS IN TOWN

text: Continuing his argument, the Ambassador said, ''I saw a TV spot recently that the United States wiped out 432,000 marijuana plants. Well, last year, we killed 9 million plants, and we didn't get any TV for that.''
title: ONE OF THE TOUGHEST IMAGE PROBLEMS IN TOWN

text: He recalled another incident this spring when the United States Attorney's office for the Southern District of New York froze on a Friday afternoon all the accounts of Colombia's Banco Cafetero in New York because three transactions had been traced to suspected money-laundering operations in Panama. ''But why did they shut down the whole bank?'' he asked. ''What if they found the same transactions at Citibank or Chemical? It's absurd.''
title: ONE OF THE TOUGHEST IMAGE PROBLEMS IN TOWN

text: As a result of such incidents, Mr. Lloreda is trying to convince United States law agencies that Colombia is cooperating with drug eradication efforts. ''The top officials know we are doing a good job,'' he said. ''It's the middle level people who think they need publicity that give us the hardest time.''
title: ONE OF THE TOUGHEST IMAGE PROBLEMS IN TOWN

text: As a step, he held a news conference last week in New York to announce a $1 billion loan by a syndicate of 200 private banks, led by Chemical Bank of New York, to develop oil and coal facilities in Colombia.
title: ONE OF THE TOUGHEST IMAGE PROBLEMS IN TOWN

text: It was one of the largest extensions of new credit by American banks to a Latin American country in two years, and Colombia could get that much credit because it had subjected itself to some very close monitoring and austerity measures recommended by the International Monetary Fund. But again, Mr. Lloreda complains about the treatment Colombia received from the American banks.
title: ONE OF THE TOUGHEST IMAGE PROBLEMS IN TOWN

text: ''All through the debt crisis, we continued to pay our principle and interest,'' he said. ''But the banks adopted a blanket policy for all Latin American countries. They treated us just as if we were in default.''
title: ONE OF THE TOUGHEST IMAGE PROBLEMS IN TOWN

text: Mr. Lloreda is keenly aware of the effects of negative and positive publicity. For eight years, he was the editor in chief of El Pais, the largest newspaper in his hometown of Cali.
title: ONE OF THE TOUGHEST IMAGE PROBLEMS IN TOWN

text: Still, for all his country's image problems in the United States, the Ambassador's tasks sometimes have a lighter side.
title: ONE OF THE TOUGHEST IMAGE PROBLEMS IN TOWN

text: 'I've been working on apples lately,'' he said, explaining that in exchange for Colombian exports to the United States, Colombia has agreed to certain imports from this country, among them apples.
title: ONE OF THE TOUGHEST IMAGE PROBLEMS IN TOWN

text: ''When too many apples end up in Bogota, I'm the one who gets the calls,'' he said.
title: ONE OF THE TOUGHEST IMAGE PROBLEMS IN TOWN

text: Your ''Talk of Alderpoint'' (Aug. 16), the mountainous northern California community of solitude seekers, marijuana growers and police helicopters, omitted some salient facts.
title: 'A Huge Oak Tree Crashed to the Ground'

text: My grandchildren and two small great-grandchildren have a seven-acre homestead 750 feet above the Eel River.
title: 'A Huge Oak Tree Crashed to the Ground'

text: They cultivate an orchard of 37 fruit trees and a vineyard, and raise livestock. They are not ''growers.''
title: 'A Huge Oak Tree Crashed to the Ground'

text: I was visiting them when daily flights of helicopters from a camp on the Eel River passed so close to the treetops that they made the trees sway. The children were afraid to play outdoors. And with reason. While we were sitting together in the living room, a helicopter passed, and in its wake a huge oak tree crashed to the ground, taking with it five smaller birches that formed a natural circle where the children like to play. All this not 20 feet from where we sat.
title: 'A Huge Oak Tree Crashed to the Ground'

text: A tree expert examined the fallen oak, broken off about 15 feet above its base, and said the tree was perfectly sound, and the splintering of its trunk was undoubtedly due to the daily constant vibrations caused by the low flights of the helicopters. This was one of many instances of harassment by the police and their helicopters.
title: 'A Huge Oak Tree Crashed to the Ground'

text: A group of these mountain residents brought their cases before an attentive judge, who issued a caution that the helicopters should not fly so low. Nothing for damages (none were asked). But the damage, psychologically as well as physically, has been done.BERNICE SMAILER Glassboro, N.J., Aug. 16, 1985
title: 'A Huge Oak Tree Crashed to the Ground'

text: By Robert Lindsey, Special To the New York Times
title: WESTERN GOVERNORS SEE DEFICIT PERIL

text: Governors of eight Western states ended a three-day meeting here today after being repeatedly told that record Federal budget deficits were creating serious long-term economic problems for the West.
title: WESTERN GOVERNORS SEE DEFICIT PERIL

text: Speakers at the annual meeting of the Western Governors Association said the deficits were artificially inflating the value of the American dollar in international trade and making it more difficult for Western farmers and manufacturers to sell products abroad.
title: WESTERN GOVERNORS SEE DEFICIT PERIL

text: While conceding that exports from other regions of the nation were also affected by a strong dollar, the Governors were told that the Wes was suffering disproportionately because of its proximity to markets in Asia, the fastest growing in the world.
title: WESTERN GOVERNORS SEE DEFICIT PERIL

text: ''With the high dollar and high interest, there's not a confounded thing we can do'' to deal with severe financial problems facing Western farmers, Gov. John V. Evans of Idaho, a Democrat, told the meeting. ''Our hands are tied.''
title: WESTERN GOVERNORS SEE DEFICIT PERIL

text: Moreover, the Governors were warned that if Congress bowed to mounting pressure to impose tariffs designed to protect American-made goods against lower-priced imports from Asia, the West would almost certainly face retaliation in the form of tariffs against its products.
title: WESTERN GOVERNORS SEE DEFICIT PERIL

text: Six of the eight Governors who attended the meeting, along with the Governors of Guam, American Samoa and the Northern Marianas Trust Territory, are Democrats, and much of the talk about the implications of America's growing trade imbalance was in partisan terms.
title: WESTERN GOVERNORS SEE DEFICIT PERIL

text: President Reagan was accused of weakening the nation's ability to compete overseas and of allowing foreign manufacturers to drive domestic manufacturers out of business by pursuing policies that cut taxes, raised military spending and left the nation with chronic high deficts.
title: WESTERN GOVERNORS SEE DEFICIT PERIL

text: To pay its bills, the Governors contended the United States has had to borrow heavily, resulting in an overvalued dollar in international trade.
title: WESTERN GOVERNORS SEE DEFICIT PERIL

text: ''The fact is, this whole thing burgeoned over the last five years because of this insane deficit,'' asserted Gov. George Sinner of North Dakota, a Democrat.
title: WESTERN GOVERNORS SEE DEFICIT PERIL

text: He said the outcry from the Governors reflected thinking in the hinterlands and added: ''We've said it over and over again - get the deficit down. It's the President's fault. He has to take the blame.''
title: WESTERN GOVERNORS SEE DEFICIT PERIL

text: To some extent, Mr. Reagan was defended by others at the meeting. Gov. Victor G. Atiyeh of Oregon, a Republican, said much of the nation's trade imbalance could be corrected if Americans did a better job of salesmanship overseas. ''To blame everything solely on the high dollar,'' he said, was an attempt to come up with ''a simple answer to a complex problem.''
title: WESTERN GOVERNORS SEE DEFICIT PERIL

text: Richard M. Fairbanks, a United States Ambassador at Large whose specialty is Pacfic affairs, agreed that ''we have to get our budget under control.''
title: WESTERN GOVERNORS SEE DEFICIT PERIL

text: But he added that even if the budgets were reduced, serious problems would remain, including Japanese trade barriers to American imports.
title: WESTERN GOVERNORS SEE DEFICIT PERIL

text: ''There are a lot of things the United States does that are wrong,'' Mr. Fairbanks said. ''We don't claim to be doing everything right. But lest we be carried away in an orgy of self-flagellation, let's remember we are doing some things right.''
title: WESTERN GOVERNORS SEE DEFICIT PERIL

text: 'A 40% Subsidy of Imports'
title: WESTERN GOVERNORS SEE DEFICIT PERIL

text: Still, most speakers had little good to say about the Reagan Administration's policies. Stanley H. Barer, a Seattle lawyer who specializes in international trade, noted that from 1980 to the end of 1984 the value of the dollar grew 53 percent and, after a decline this year, was still worth 40 percent more than it was in 1980.
title: WESTERN GOVERNORS SEE DEFICIT PERIL

text: ''That acts as a 40 percent subsidy of imports - it weakens our ability to trade,'' Mr. Barer told the Governors in a discussion of trade issues at the University of Hawaii's East-West Center. Largely because of the dollar's higher value, he said, the nation's foreign trade deficit ballooned from $36 billion in 1980 to $124 billion last year and is projected at $150 billion this year.
title: WESTERN GOVERNORS SEE DEFICIT PERIL

text: Noting that Japan and other large exporters were being blamed for the deficit, Mr. Barer, whose clients include Japanse companies, said, ''Maybe we're the problem, not the rest of the world.'' He warned that ''there will be retaliation against Western wheat and wood products'' if Congress passed legislation designed to protect the nation's beleaguered textile industry.
title: WESTERN GOVERNORS SEE DEFICIT PERIL

text: Deficit Called a World Problem
title: WESTERN GOVERNORS SEE DEFICIT PERIL

text: Nam Duck Woo, chairman of the Korean Traders' Association who is a former Prime Minister of South Korea, told the Governors that until the recent rise in the value of the dollar, American textile manufacturers had 70 percent of the world market. ''Now they are in trouble,'' he said. ''The root of the problem is the value of the dollar.''
title: WESTERN GOVERNORS SEE DEFICIT PERIL

text: Also attending the meeting, besides Governors Atiyeh, Evans and Sinner, were Gov. George R. Ariyoshi of Hawaii, Gov. Ted Schwinden of Montana, Gov. Toney Anaya of New Mexico and Gov. Booth Gardner of Washington, all Democrats, and Gov. Norman H. Bangerter of Utah, a Republican.
title: WESTERN GOVERNORS SEE DEFICIT PERIL

text: Gov. Richard D. Lamm of Colorado, who missed the meeting because of a family illness, was elected chairman of the association, succeeding Governor Ariyoshi.
title: WESTERN GOVERNORS SEE DEFICIT PERIL

text: Salvage workers today raised a sunken trawler off Cape Cod and found 103 bales of marijuana aboard, bringing to nearly 600 the number of bales found in the scuttled ship, officials said.
title: More Marijuana Taken From Sunken Trawler

text: Investigators planned to trace a registration number on the 60-foot vessel to try to determine the boat's owner, according to the Coast Guard.
title: More Marijuana Taken From Sunken Trawler

text: Fishermen discovered the sunken boat Wednesday about two miles from Wellfleet. The authorities believe the vessel was scuttled when its occupants ran into trouble. Divers removed nearly 500 bales of marijuana from her hull over the next three days.
title: More Marijuana Taken From Sunken Trawler

text: A salvage company from New Bedford raised the vessel and pumped her out so the rest of the load could be removed.
title: More Marijuana Taken From Sunken Trawler

text: TOM, a 19-year-old witness, told Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato and United States Representative Benjamin A. Gilman last week that he had started using drugs when he was ''about 12.''
title: DRUG-ABUSE HEARING HELD

text: ''My mother was dating a man who was dealing marijuana,'' Tom said.
title: DRUG-ABUSE HEARING HELD

text: ''I didn't realize what it could do.'' By the time he was in high school, Tom said, he was using LSD and Quaaludes, his grades were falling and, by 17, ''I was on the verge of suicide.''
title: DRUG-ABUSE HEARING HELD

text: In the Ceremonial Courtroom at the County Courthouse, Senator D'Amato asked Tom if it were fair to say that at the age of 14 his ''very existence'' was dominated by drugs.
title: DRUG-ABUSE HEARING HELD

text: ''I was constantly worried about my next high,'' answered Tom, one of five recovering addicts, aged 20 or younger, who testified at a Congressional hearing last Tuesday about drug abuse.
title: DRUG-ABUSE HEARING HELD

text: Senator D'Amato, who has held such hearings recently in Syracuse, Rochester and Utica, N.Y., is a member of the Senate Drug Enforcement Caucus. He is sponsoring legislation that would enable Washington to use an estimated $360 million ''in assets seized from this nation's drug czars'' to finance a three-point drive in the areas of law enforcement, prevention through education and rehabilitation.
title: DRUG-ABUSE HEARING HELD

text: Senator D'Amato invited Representative Gilman, whose constituents include residents of the town of Greenburgh and who is the ranking minority member of the House Select Committee on Narcotics Abuse and Control, to participate.
title: DRUG-ABUSE HEARING HELD

text: Another teen-ager, Bill, said he ''felt strong peer pressure from the students in my dorm'' to take drugs when he went away to preparatory school in 10th grade. ''It was a way to escape reality,'' Bill said. ''I was lonely.''
title: DRUG-ABUSE HEARING HELD

text: Bill, now 17, said he had used marijuana and drank alcohol, ''then LSD and a little cocaine'' until he was suspended twice in the 11th grade.
title: DRUG-ABUSE HEARING HELD

text: Before the hearing began, Senator D'Amato told a news conference that in the ''epidemic'' of drug abuse ''the only thing going down is the age of the abusers.''
title: DRUG-ABUSE HEARING HELD

text: About 75 percent of the nation's prison inmates have ''serious drug and alcohol problems'' Senator D'Amato added. He said that the General Motors Corporation spends $616 million a year ''in health insurance for their employees who have drug and alcohol problems.''
title: DRUG-ABUSE HEARING HELD

text: Senator D'Amato said in a statement that ''we are holding this hearing in Westchester because this county and neighboring Rockland are home to several of the most successful drug- and alcohol-prevention treatment programs that exist today, including Daytop Village in Hartsdale, Phoenix House in Yorktown Heights and Recovery Center in Ossining.''
title: DRUG-ABUSE HEARING HELD

text: Two of the teen-agers who testified live in Bronxville, one in Tarrytown, one in Queens and one in New Jersey.
title: DRUG-ABUSE HEARING HELD

text: The seven-county mid-Hudson region - of which Westchester accounts for ''nearly half the population'' - has the ''highest levels of marijuana use in the state,'' said County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke, citing state figures.
title: DRUG-ABUSE HEARING HELD

text: Mr. O'Rourke, who expressed support for Senator D'Amato's proposed legislation, said that 84 people died of drug overdoses in Westchester between 1982 and 1984, with 25 such fatalities last year.
title: DRUG-ABUSE HEARING HELD

text: Dr. Mitchell S. Rosenthal, a psychiatrist and president of the Phoenix House Foundation, told the hearing that ''we are far too comfortable with the stereotypes of drug abuse, stereotypes that allow us to continue believing that drug abuse is something that happens in the school yards of the inner city, and that it happens in the grimy alleyways of East Harlem and the East Village, but not here in Westchester.''
title: DRUG-ABUSE HEARING HELD

text: Tom, who has completed four months of a Phoenix House ''intervention'' program, said he ''learned I don't need drugs to be accepted'' and has returned home after a period of staying with a friend.
title: DRUG-ABUSE HEARING HELD

text: Tom's upbeat story was matched by the four other young people. One of them is a student at Phoenix House's special residential high school in Yorktown Heights. The other three, including Bill, have undergone treatment for drug addiction at the Hartsdale clinic of Daytop Village.
title: DRUG-ABUSE HEARING HELD

text: Bill said all Daytop counselors ''had been in the program'' and ''gave you a role model.'' He said he had returned to Bronxville High School last January, ''graduated this spring with an honors average,'' holds a summer job and will enter Fordham University in the fall.
title: DRUG-ABUSE HEARING HELD

text: ''I've been straight for over a year,'' Bill said.
title: DRUG-ABUSE HEARING HELD

text: The president of Daytop Village, Monsignor William B. O'Brien, said there were 282 young people awaiting places in his organization's residential-treatment programs, which are overcrowded and underfinanced.
title: DRUG-ABUSE HEARING HELD

text: ''How much would you need for the 282?'' Senator D'Amato asked Monsignor O'Brien.
title: DRUG-ABUSE HEARING HELD

text: ''We'd need another residence center,'' Monsignor O'Brien replied. ''Probably about $1.25 million. We'll lose some of those 282 to jail cells for lack of space.''
title: DRUG-ABUSE HEARING HELD

text: DURING his 15 years as a corrections officer with Westchester County, Benjamin Jones said he has noticed a lot of changes in the inmate population. He has seen greater numbers of younger people being incarcerated and has watched them return to the penetentiary again and again.
title: PRISON MINISTRY TAKES A NEW APPROACH

text: ''I started seeing a lot of young kids coming to jail, some that I knew personally,'' said Mr. Jones, a Mount Vernon resident. ''Everyone has a story - 'I didn't do the crime. I was at the wrong place at the wrong time.' But the fact is they are locked up in jail. There's got to be a way to keep them out. There's got to be some way to reach them.''
title: PRISON MINISTRY TAKES A NEW APPROACH

text: Mr. Jones discussed his concerns with his wife, Jacqueline, and she suggested they speak with their pastor, the Rev. Calvin Sampson of the Shiloh Baptist Church in New Rochelle. Mr. Sampson, known for his interest in young people, was enthusiastic about developing a prison-prevention program and suggested combining it with two other elements - a ministry for those already in prison, and assistance for men and women being released.
title: PRISON MINISTRY TAKES A NEW APPROACH

text: ''I have always had an abiding interest in what I call the 'decarcerated,' '' Mr. Sampson said. ''I felt I wanted to get involved part and parcel in a prison ministry. Not just going into prison to make a speech, but to work with those inside and help those getting out. I felt it was our spiritual and moral mandate.''
title: PRISON MINISTRY TAKES A NEW APPROACH

text: Mr. Sampson and Mr. Jones -along with the chaplain of the County Department of Correction, the Rev. Charles Albert, and with the help of a recently released prison inmate, Jack Dews - have formed a three-pronged prison ministry program that has received the blessings of County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke, Correction Commissioner John Maffucci and Warden Norwood Jackson.
title: PRISON MINISTRY TAKES A NEW APPROACH

text: The program got under way at the Shiloh Baptist Church last May at a presentation for young people and their parents at which Warden Jackson showed slides and described conditions at the jail and penitentiary. Coordinators of the prison-ministry program have been assigned in Yonkers, New Rochelle, Mount Vernon, Mamaroneck, Port Chester, White Plains, Ossining and Peekskill.
title: PRISON MINISTRY TAKES A NEW APPROACH

text: Mr. Sampson is no stranger tn the problems of the incarcerated; he has worked with the in-house ministry that serves the 900 inmates of the county penitentiary, jail and women's unit. The ministry, led by Mr. Albert, includes 14 volunteer clergymen representing various religions and ethnic groups. Mr. Albert, an associate minister of the Strait Gate Church of Christ in Mamaroneck, said the in-prison clergymen ''address themselves to the prisoners' hopelessness; we are concerned about their spirit, body and soul.''
title: PRISON MINISTRY TAKES A NEW APPROACH

text: The clergymen work with the Correction Department's counselors and social workers to meet the prisoners' ''emotional, psychological and spiritual needs,'' Mr. Albert said, but there is no similar network of support after the prisoners are released. Nor, he added, is there a countywide effort to turn young people away from crime.
title: PRISON MINISTRY TAKES A NEW APPROACH

text: ''Crimes among juveniles and teen-agers have gone up throughout the country,'' Mr. Albert said. He cited a multiplicity of reasons, such as television violence, impersonal schools, and the belief, which he shares, that ''the church has lost its impact to establish morals and values'' - that ''there has been an abdication on the part of the church and of parents.''
title: PRISON MINISTRY TAKES A NEW APPROACH

text: Also, Mr. Sampson added, increasing numbers of young people are growing up in broken families, a condition that may lead them to join ''gangs of boys and girls who are going nowhere.'' These young people ''fall under group pressure,'' Mr. Sampson said. ''They have to learn that a friend is not your friend if he's going to get you into trouble.''
title: PRISON MINISTRY TAKES A NEW APPROACH

text: As part of the prison-prevention component, programs will be presented to various youth groups and schools in the eight targeted communities. ''We will conduct seminars about the dangers of getting into trouble with the law and the perils of prison life,'' Mr. Sampson said. ''We must call upon people of good will in the community, caring adults, to have young people realize they are throwing their lives away.
title: PRISON MINISTRY TAKES A NEW APPROACH

text: ''Those of us who were lucky enough to get an education and become achievers seem to have crossed the bridge and left the others behind. That's what I think is wrong in Westchester County with many people who have been successful. They're on a pedestal. The youth can't reach them and talk to them.''
title: PRISON MINISTRY TAKES A NEW APPROACH

text: The two main speakers at the seminars will be Mr. Jones and Mr. Dews, who will tell the young people and their parents about the realities of prison life. Mr. Dews, born and raised in New Rochelle, said he began selling marijuana during his senior year in high school and, enjoying the recognition of his peers and the money, eventually became part of ''a major drug-selling crowd that gathered in a baseball field in New Rochelle.''
title: PRISON MINISTRY TAKES A NEW APPROACH

text: Soon after he was sentenced to Auburn Correctional Facility in upstate New York, where he spent eight years, Mr. Dews injured his spine in a fall and was confined to a wheelchair. Moved by the compassion of inmates and prison officers who helped him regain his ability to walk again, and influenced by a deeply religious prison nurse, Mr. Dews started attending church services and joined a therapy group, in which, he said, ''I found out how selfish and immature I was, how I was living my life with total disregard for others.''
title: PRISON MINISTRY TAKES A NEW APPROACH

text: ''Here is not just a decarcerated person speaking,'' added Mr. Sampson. ''Here is someone who turned around.''
title: PRISON MINISTRY TAKES A NEW APPROACH

text: But for Mr. Dews, as for other former prisoners, ''outside support is at least 70 percent of being able to function,'' he said.
title: PRISON MINISTRY TAKES A NEW APPROACH

text: The third aspect of the prison ministry program is to supply outside support for prisoners being released into the community. A prison advisory board, consisting of leading clergymen in the eight communities, will work with community residents and businessmen to help ex-offenders find job training, jobs and housing. County funds are expected to be allocated for clothing, rent and other needs.
title: PRISON MINISTRY TAKES A NEW APPROACH

text: As stated in a proposal setting up the program: ''Members of the advisory board will utilize their ability, credibility and visibility as ministers and laymen in the community, and their knowledge of the community through the eyes and ears of their parishoners and friends, to coordinate and advocate the vocational, educational, social and religious readjustment of the decarcerated. The community re-integration support system will function as a community-based extension of the in-house ministerial effort which provides a continuous support system directed toward the reduction of deviant behavior, recidivism and the development of responsible, productive citizens.''
title: PRISON MINISTRY TAKES A NEW APPROACH

text: ''A former inmate needs at least three years of support to be able to stand on his own,'' said Mr. Albert. ''We will provide a community of love, compassion and kindness.''
title: PRISON MINISTRY TAKES A NEW APPROACH

text: E. Richard Barnes, a former California Assemblyman who denounced President Richard Nixon's historic trip to China as ''suicidal idiocy,'' has died at the age of 79.
title: E. Richard Barnes, 79, Dies; Former California Legislator

text: Mr. Barnes died of natural causes Wednesday at his El Cajon home, said Jean Middleswart, a secretary at Greenwood Mortuary in neighboring San Diego.
title: E. Richard Barnes, 79, Dies; Former California Legislator

text: Mr. Barnes, a Republican, served in the Legislature from 1963 to 1973. He favored capital punishment and the abolition of Federal income taxes, and opposed busing to achieve integration in public schools and liberalizing marijuana laws.
title: E. Richard Barnes, 79, Dies; Former California Legislator

text: Assemblyman Barnes's condemnation of the Nixon trip to China in 1971 alienated some supporters and contributed to his 1972 election loss.
title: E. Richard Barnes, 79, Dies; Former California Legislator

text: Before entering politics Mr. Barnes was a Navy chaplain and served as a pastor in Methodist churches in Pennsylvania and New York. He had also directed the San Diego office of the Christian Anti-Communism Crusade for a year.
title: E. Richard Barnes, 79, Dies; Former California Legislator

text: He is survived by two sons and two daughters.
title: E. Richard Barnes, 79, Dies; Former California Legislator

text: By Joseph F. Sullivan, Special To the New York Times
title: A NEW BREED OF CRIME FIGURE

text: When the customers of the Hole-in-the-Wall luncheonette at 115 Delancy Street got hungry, they sent out for food.
title: A NEW BREED OF CRIME FIGURE

text: The ''customers,'' who met daily to discuss business, were members of the Luchese crime organization, and the real business of the luncheonette was gambling and loan sharking, according to Federal law-enforcement officials.
title: A NEW BREED OF CRIME FIGURE

text: This week, a Federal grand jury handed up racketeering indictments against 26 people accused of being New Jersey members of the New York-based Luchese crime group, which the authorities say is headed by Anthony Corallo.
title: A NEW BREED OF CRIME FIGURE

text: In interviews today, law-enforcement officials close to the investigation described the defendants as ''young, aggressive, intelligent and sophisticated'' people in their 30's who in buying half-million-dollar homes and flashy sports cars broke with the ''old code'' and low-key way of life of their elders.
title: A NEW BREED OF CRIME FIGURE

text: ''They are all related by blood or marriage and for this reason, were very tough to penetrate,'' one Federal official familiar with the investigation said. ''They dress casual but upscale, and when they wanted to get in touch with each other they used beepers.''
title: A NEW BREED OF CRIME FIGURE

text: According to the indictment, the Luchese organization is principally involved in gambling and loan-sharking operations in northern New Jersey, and through these operations the members have been able to take control of at least one business.
title: A NEW BREED OF CRIME FIGURE

text: They also cooperate in a network that brings drugs from South America and the Caribbean through Florida to New Jersey and New York, according to a report on Organized Crime in New Jersey written by Lieut. Col. Justin J. Dintino, Deputy State Police Superintendent.
title: A NEW BREED OF CRIME FIGURE

text: Members of the Luchese group maintain close working relations with members of the Genovese and DeCavalcante organizations who operate in some of the same territories, Colonel Dintino said. In all, seven crime factions are active in New Jersey, the authorities said.
title: A NEW BREED OF CRIME FIGURE

text: The Luchese group was aggresive enough to move quickly to fill a vacuum in the gambling operations in the Ironbound section of Newark a few years ago when Angelo Bruno, the reputed crime boss of Philadelphia, and his Newark representative, Anthony Caponegro, were killed within a short time of each other.
title: A NEW BREED OF CRIME FIGURE

text: The killings were the result of a dispute within the Bruno group, according to police sources, but the Luchese organization took the opportunity to move into the Ironbound and set up shop in the Hole-in-the-Wall.
title: A NEW BREED OF CRIME FIGURE

text: Colonel Dintino described the Luchese members in New Jersey as ''a small but powerful group of individuals'' who were able not only to take over the territory held by the Bruno faction but also to move into some gambling operations run by Tino Fiumara, whom he identified as a Genovese group figure, after Mr. Fiumara was sent to prison.
title: A NEW BREED OF CRIME FIGURE

text: According to Thomas W. Greelish, the acting United States Attorney for New Jersey, the leader of the New Jersey faction of the Luchese group, one of those indicted Monday, is Anthony Accetturo, 47 years old, of Hollywood, Fla., who fled New Jersey 10 years ago when he was subpoenaed to testify before the State Commission of Investigation.
title: A NEW BREED OF CRIME FIGURE

text: The state police said Mr. Accetturo was groomed for leadership in the New Jersey faction by Joseph Abate of Atlantic City, who is identified by Colonel Dintino as a caporegime, or underboss, in the Luchese group and who is now described by the police as in semiretirement.
title: A NEW BREED OF CRIME FIGURE

text: Mr. Accetturo was pictured as ''young, intelligent and very aggressive'' when he moved to Florida and found what one Federal law-enforcement official called ''virgin territory.''
title: A NEW BREED OF CRIME FIGURE

text: Mr. Greenlish said the activities of Mr. Accetturo and the other 25 defendants ''range from an extorted 25 percent takeover of a gem-distribution business'' in Florida to ''loan sharking at interest rates of 156 per cent annually.''
title: A NEW BREED OF CRIME FIGURE

text: In its gambling business, investigators said, the organization often ''extended credit to their big customers, just like OTB in New York.'' As the gambling debts mounted, they were rolled over into loan-shark debts, and soon the members of the operation became partial or full owners of the gambler's business.
title: A NEW BREED OF CRIME FIGURE

text: The defendants are charged with taking over the Carmata Oil Company of Whippany in that fashion. One of the defendants, Robert Caravaggio, was installed as chief executive officer. The indictment charges that the company thereafter sent inflated oil bills to its customers, including the Paterson Board of Education and the Newark Community Housing Corporation.
title: A NEW BREED OF CRIME FIGURE

text: Mr. Greelish said Mr. Accetturo's chief lieutenant was one of his cousins, Michael Taccetta, 38, of Florham Park. The two would keep in touch by telephone. During the winter Mr. Taccetta and others would go to Florida on vacation, but they would also meet with Mr. Accetturo at his home for an annual business and policy meeting, according to the Federal source.
title: A NEW BREED OF CRIME FIGURE

text: ''In that way they operated no differently than any large corporation,'' he said.
title: A NEW BREED OF CRIME FIGURE

text: The Federal investigators used court-approved electronic surveillance and ''a lot of gumshoe'' work to collect the evidence that led to the indictment, the Federal source said.
title: A NEW BREED OF CRIME FIGURE

text: ''Because they are all related and grew up together,'' the source said, ''it was very difficult to try to penetrate their operation with an undercover man or to get people to cooperate with us.''
title: A NEW BREED OF CRIME FIGURE

text: The investigation by the Federal Bureau of Investigation took four years, according to Robert Wright, the assistant special agent in charge of the Newark F.B.I. office, and led to the filing of the 12-count indictment by the grand jury. The indictment charges the defendants, 21 from New Jersey and 5 from Florida, with conspiracy, racketeering, trafficking in cocaine, selling marijuana and distributing stolen credit cards.
title: A NEW BREED OF CRIME FIGURE

text: Mr. Greelish said he believed the indictment was the most comprehensive ever returned in New Jersey against a reputed organized-crime group.
title: A NEW BREED OF CRIME FIGURE

text: The indictment described the New Jersey faction as the Taccetta Group Enterprise, and Mr. Greelish said that although Michael Taccetta was the ''chief executive officer'' responsible for the daily operation of the organization, all the members recognized Mr. Accetturo's primacy and relied on him to set policy and to intercede with other crime groups.
title: A NEW BREED OF CRIME FIGURE

text: Some members of the organization have been arrested in the past on charges ranging from homicide to gambling, but they have rarely come to wide public attention.
title: A NEW BREED OF CRIME FIGURE

text: Twenty-six people were accused today of running the New Jersey branch of an organized-crime group, officials said.
title: 26 INDICTED ON CHARGE OF RUNNING ORGANIZED-CRIME GROUP IN JERSEY

text: Acting on a sealed indictment returned in Newark, law-enforcement authorities in Florida and New Jersey conducted dawn raids today, arresting 20 of the 26.
title: 26 INDICTED ON CHARGE OF RUNNING ORGANIZED-CRIME GROUP IN JERSEY

text: The prosecutor, United States Attorney Thomas W. Greelish, said the indictment ''brings to a dramatic halt the operation'' of the New Jersey branch of the Luchese crime organization. These 26 defendants constitute ''the vast bulk'' of the Luchese group operating in New Jersey, he said.
title: 26 INDICTED ON CHARGE OF RUNNING ORGANIZED-CRIME GROUP IN JERSEY

text: Mr. Greelish said he believed that the indictment, returned Monday by a Federal grand jury, was the most comprehensive ever returned in New Jersey against a reputed organized-crime group. It culminated a four-year investigation by the Federal Bureau of Investigation, said Robert Wright, assistant special agent in charge of the Newark division of the F.B.I.
title: 26 INDICTED ON CHARGE OF RUNNING ORGANIZED-CRIME GROUP IN JERSEY

text: Federal authorities described one of the defendants, Anthony Accetturo, 47 years old, of Hollywood, Fla., as the leader of the New Jersey operation. Mr. Greelish said another defendant, Michael Taccetta, 38, of Florham Park, N.J., acted as the ''chief executive officer.'' According to the authorities, Mr. Accetturo set policy for the operation and resolved disputes.
title: 26 INDICTED ON CHARGE OF RUNNING ORGANIZED-CRIME GROUP IN JERSEY

text: Mr. Greelish said the group's activities ''range from an extorted 25 percent takeover of a gem-distribution business'' in Florida to ''loan sharking at interest rates of 156 percent annually.''
title: 26 INDICTED ON CHARGE OF RUNNING ORGANIZED-CRIME GROUP IN JERSEY

text: The indictment in New Jersey is part of a nationwide crackdown against reputed members of organized crime. In February, nine men were charged in Manhattan with participating in a ''commission'' that governs the five organized-crime factions in New York. They are awaiting trial. The prosecutor in the New York cases, Rudolph W. Giuliani, the United States Attorney in Manhattan, declined to comment on the details of the New Jersey case, but said: ''I think the investigation of organized crime around the country is quite impressive. Since it is a nationwide organization, almost anything done in any part of the country helps us and vice versa.''
title: 26 INDICTED ON CHARGE OF RUNNING ORGANIZED-CRIME GROUP IN JERSEY

text: The 81-page indictment charges that the 26 men were members of a group, which Federal authorities called the Taccetta Group Enterprise, that conducted a wide range of illegal activities, including loan sharking and gambling, the sale of cocaine and marijuana, the acquisition and distribution of counterfeit credit cards and the use of a now-defunct oil company to commit fraud.
title: 26 INDICTED ON CHARGE OF RUNNING ORGANIZED-CRIME GROUP IN JERSEY

text: George Abdy, a Totowa, N.J., lawyer, who said he knew several of the men charged, said today: ''An indictment is no evidence of guilt. It's just a mere allegation. And most of it is based on hearsay, which is unreliable.'' He did not indicate which of the defendants he might be representing.
title: 26 INDICTED ON CHARGE OF RUNNING ORGANIZED-CRIME GROUP IN JERSEY

text: Mr. Wright of the F.B.I. said most of the arrests were made at the suspects' homes. One man, James Fede, 31, of Newark, eluded capture by jumping out of a second-story window at a residence in Belleville, N.J., the authorities said.
title: 26 INDICTED ON CHARGE OF RUNNING ORGANIZED-CRIME GROUP IN JERSEY

text: The indictment charges that from 1979 to 1983, one of the defendants, Robert Caravaggio, 45, of Livingston, N.J., was the chief executive officer of a company called Carmata Petroleum Inc., which ''he operated for the benefit'' of the Taccetta group.
title: 26 INDICTED ON CHARGE OF RUNNING ORGANIZED-CRIME GROUP IN JERSEY

text: Under Mr. Caravaggio's direction, the indictment charges, inflated fuel oil bills were sent to Carmata Petroleum customers, including the Paterson, N.J., Board of Education and the Newark Community Housing Corporation.
title: 26 INDICTED ON CHARGE OF RUNNING ORGANIZED-CRIME GROUP IN JERSEY

text: Mr. Wright said the Carmata company, formerly situated in Whippany, N.J., was no longer in operation.
title: 26 INDICTED ON CHARGE OF RUNNING ORGANIZED-CRIME GROUP IN JERSEY

text: The indictment describes in detail a loan-sharking operation, including allegations of beatings and threats of beatings for people in arrears on payments. It also contends that the enterprise was active in a range of gambling that included numbers, horse betting and video gambling machines.
title: 26 INDICTED ON CHARGE OF RUNNING ORGANIZED-CRIME GROUP IN JERSEY

text: The 12-count indictment includes two counts, naming all 26 defendants, charging conspiracy and a ''pattern of racketeering activity'' under the Federal Racketeer-Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act.
title: 26 INDICTED ON CHARGE OF RUNNING ORGANIZED-CRIME GROUP IN JERSEY

text: The indictment also includes seven counts relating to cocaine and marijuana possession and distribution, naming 14 people; one count relating to the operation of a gambling enterprise, which names 10 people, and two counts relating to credit-card fraud, naming 10 people.
title: 26 INDICTED ON CHARGE OF RUNNING ORGANIZED-CRIME GROUP IN JERSEY

text: These are the others charged in the indictment: Martin Taccetta, 34, of Florham Park. Michael Perna, 43, of Belleville. Thomas Ricciardi, 33, of Lakewood, N.J. Alfonse T. Cataldo, 43, of Florham Park. Jerome Voglino, 43, of Livingston, N.J. Robert Spagnola, 38, of Mountainside, N.J. James Gammero, 37, of Belleville. Frank Benedetto, 67, of Newark. Michael Ryan, 35, of Belleville. Donald Cross, 40, of Lyndhurst, N.J. Walter Esposito, 35, of Florham Park. Marianne Esposito, 33, of Florham Park. Joseph Licata, 44, of Florham Park. Gerald Cohen, 44, of Pompano Beach, Fla. Frank Suppa, 45, of Hollywood, Fla. Gerald DeLuca, 40, of Maplewood, N.J. Giacomo DiNorscio, 45, of Pompano Beach, Fla. Victor Cantillo, 51, of Berkeley Heights, N.J. Manuel Monteiro, 45, of Pompano Beach, Fla. John Redman, 31, of Parsippany, N.J. Daniel Ricciardi, 31, of Florham Park. Marco Minichino, 35, of Bloomfield, N.J. All were arrested except Martin Taccetta, Daniel Ricciardi, Mr. Fede, Mr. Gammero, Mr. Licata and Mr. Minichino, according to the authorities. Bail was denied today for five of the defendants: Michael Taccetta, Thomas Ricciardi, Mr. Perna, Mr. DeLuca and Mr. Redman.
title: 26 INDICTED ON CHARGE OF RUNNING ORGANIZED-CRIME GROUP IN JERSEY

text: The following article is based on reporting by Murray Chass
title: COCAINE DISRUPTS BASEBALL FROM FIELD TO FRONT OFFICE

text: Cocaine use among baseball players has been so pervasive in recent years that the drug's debilitating effects have tarnished individual performances, shortened careers and influenced the outcome of games and pennant races, club officials and players say.
title: COCAINE DISRUPTS BASEBALL FROM FIELD TO FRONT OFFICE

text: John McHale, president of the Montreal Expos, said cocaine was the reason his team did not win its division championship in 1982, when the team generally was considered to be the best in the National League.
title: COCAINE DISRUPTS BASEBALL FROM FIELD TO FRONT OFFICE

text: ''I don't think there's any doubt in '82 that whole scenario cost us a chance to win,'' McHale said. ''We felt we should've won in '82. When we all woke up to what was going on, we found there were at least eight players on our club who were into this thing. There's no question in my mind and Jim Fanning's mind - he was managing the club that year - that cost us a chance to win.''
title: COCAINE DISRUPTS BASEBALL FROM FIELD TO FRONT OFFICE

text: Executives and managers also acknowledge that cocaine has become a major factor in trade talks and has made managers suspicious when they see players make mistakes on the field.
title: COCAINE DISRUPTS BASEBALL FROM FIELD TO FRONT OFFICE

text: Although people involved in the game have been reluctant to assess the impact cocaine has had on baseball, a three-month investigation by The New York Times found that the subject is one that players and club officials have thought much about, in part because of growing evidence of extensive cocaine use among players. In a series of interviews marked by unusual candor, several members of each group agreed to discuss their experiences and conclusions.
title: COCAINE DISRUPTS BASEBALL FROM FIELD TO FRONT OFFICE

text: Two top players who underwent drug rehabilitation, Tim Raines of the Montreal Expos and Lonnie Smith of the Kansas City Royals, told how the drugadversely affected their play. Smith told of hiding his cocaine in pockets in his socks; Raines told of carrying cocaine in gram bottles in his uniform pants pocket and of using it between innings in the restroom behind the dugout.
title: COCAINE DISRUPTS BASEBALL FROM FIELD TO FRONT OFFICE

text: In 1982, the Expos finished in third place, six games from first in the National League's East Division. Raines, who the season before had established a major league record for stolen bases by a rookie, was one of the players McHale belatedly discovered was using cocaine.
title: COCAINE DISRUPTS BASEBALL FROM FIELD TO FRONT OFFICE

text: ''It certainly hurt my performance,'' said Raines, a 25-year-old outfielder, who underwent addiction treatment after the 1982 season. ''I struck out a lot more; my vision was lessened. A lot of times I'd go up to the plate and the ball was right down the middle and I'd jump back, thinking it was at my head. The umpire would call it a strike and I'd start arguing. He'd say, 'That ball was right down the middle.' When you're on drugs, you don't feel you're doing anything wrong.''
title: COCAINE DISRUPTS BASEBALL FROM FIELD TO FRONT OFFICE

text: The question of how cocaine affects baseball is a complex one, if only because success in the major leagues is difficult to achieve and depends on many factors. The history of the game is filled with stories of promising youngsters who failed to achieve stardom, or even mediocrity, and of established players who suddenly, without explanation, lost their abilities. Sometimes, alcohol has been cited as the villain and, sometimes, unspecified ''off the field'' problems have been blamed. Cocaine is the latest factor in the formula, different if for no other reason than it is illegal.
title: COCAINE DISRUPTS BASEBALL FROM FIELD TO FRONT OFFICE

text: Moreover, the effects of cocaine can vary, depending on when, how much and how often an individual uses it. The effects can be dramatic if a player uses it just before or during a game. If a player restricts his use to non-game times and uses it only occasionally, there could be little or no effect, doctors say. For those who use cocaine regularly but not on the field, the effects might show up gradually.
title: COCAINE DISRUPTS BASEBALL FROM FIELD TO FRONT OFFICE

text: ''There is no doubt in my mind that the stimulant does improve performance but it is short-lived,'' said Dr. Howard S. Rubin, who has studied the drug's effect on athletes as president and clinical director of the California Institute for Behavioral Medicine. ''After a brief time, it becomes destructive.'' Questions About Use Arise in Trade Talks A government source in Pittsburgh, where at least 11 active players, including Raines and Smith, and one former player testified before a grand jury, said a common tale told by players there was that they had a good game after using cocaine for the first time, then kept using it in the belief that it helped their performance. However, they eventually discovered that the drug hampered them and diluted their talent.
title: COCAINE DISRUPTS BASEBALL FROM FIELD TO FRONT OFFICE

text: Perhaps the clearest example could be that of Willie Wilson, who was one of four Kansas City players imprisoned after the 1983 season on cocaine charges. Although Wilson said the issue of the drug's effect on his performance was irrelevant because he never used it during games, his .332 batting average that won the American League batting title in 1982 plummeted to .276 in 1983, the only time he has batted under .300 in the six seasons he has been a regular in the Royals' outfield.
title: COCAINE DISRUPTS BASEBALL FROM FIELD TO FRONT OFFICE

text: John Schuerholz, general manager of the Kansas City Royals, stopped short of blaming cocaine for the team's failure to win the American League West title in 1982, when the team finished three games from first. The Royals learned later that several of their starting players had been using cocaine regularly.
title: COCAINE DISRUPTS BASEBALL FROM FIELD TO FRONT OFFICE

text: ''It's so hard to isolate the effect the problem had on the club,'' Schuerholz said. ''We didn't win the pennant. We did have a drug problem. But that's not to say we could've won if we hadn't had the problem. I don't know if we would have won without the problem. But we've always challenged for titles.''
title: COCAINE DISRUPTS BASEBALL FROM FIELD TO FRONT OFFICE

text: Whitey Herzog, who took over a last-place team when he became the St. Louis manager in mid-1980, said that perhaps 40 percent of his players were using cocaine at the time. Asked what effect it might have had on their play, he said pointedly, ''We were dead last when I got here.''
title: COCAINE DISRUPTS BASEBALL FROM FIELD TO FRONT OFFICE

text: One owner, who asked not to be identified, said he understood that use was especially prevalent among relief pitchers. If the owner's understanding is correct and those pitchers use cocaine during games, it would fit the pattern described by doctors who say the drug can give a user a 45-minute high. That stimulant would be enough to carry a relief pitcher through perhaps three innings.
title: COCAINE DISRUPTS BASEBALL FROM FIELD TO FRONT OFFICE

text: It is easy, of course, for clubs to keep track of the players who have undergone rehabilitation. It is not so easy for them to know which players are users when the clubs become involved in trade talks with other teams.
title: COCAINE DISRUPTS BASEBALL FROM FIELD TO FRONT OFFICE

text: Bill Giles, president of the Philadelphia Phillies, said possible drug use is a subject of immediate interest in trade talks. ''That's one of the first things clubs ask,'' he said. ''Is he healthy and is he clean?''
title: COCAINE DISRUPTS BASEBALL FROM FIELD TO FRONT OFFICE

text: Or there is the approach noted by Tom Haller, general manager of the San Francisco Giants: ''What you ask is whether this guy takes care of himself. I guess that's one way of asking if he's clean.''
title: COCAINE DISRUPTS BASEBALL FROM FIELD TO FRONT OFFICE

text: Schuerholz said that trades often are not made because of a suspicion of drug use. ''I've heard people say on a lot of occasions, 'I won't involve myself with this guy because I've heard of this or that,' '' Schuerholz said.
title: COCAINE DISRUPTS BASEBALL FROM FIELD TO FRONT OFFICE

text: Dick Howser, the Royals' manager, added, ''You probably spend as much time researching that as you do finding out about whether a guy can bunt or hit-and-run.''
title: COCAINE DISRUPTS BASEBALL FROM FIELD TO FRONT OFFICE

text: Murray Cook, general manager of the Expos, said clubs ''try to get as much information as you can on anybody.''
title: COCAINE DISRUPTS BASEBALL FROM FIELD TO FRONT OFFICE

text: Cook also talked of the problem of sifting through and investigating the rumors. ''That's happened with a lot of players,'' he said. ''They've been painted with a brush. It's such a nebulous area, trying to determine whether or not a player is involved with drugs. It's easy to generalize. It's easy to say this player is performing in such a fashion, he's got to be using drugs. The drug situation is pretty unpredictable. It's hard to tell who's involved, who isn't. You've got to be very careful. It makes it very difficult.''
title: COCAINE DISRUPTS BASEBALL FROM FIELD TO FRONT OFFICE

text: The issue also creates difficulties for players. Chili Davis, a Giant outfielder, was one of four players on the current San Francisco team mentioned by a former Giant as having used cocaine in recent years. ''I tried it before,'' Davis acknowledged. ''It wasn't for me. It made my body deteriorate. It made me feel bad. The day after I tried it, I felt drained.''
title: COCAINE DISRUPTS BASEBALL FROM FIELD TO FRONT OFFICE

text: Davis, who had his worst season in 1983, said that he was approached by both the Federal Bureau of Investigation and Giants coaches that season. ''The coaches,'' he said, ''whisper, 'Hey, they think you're on cocaine. You're not getting mad when you make outs any more.'
title: COCAINE DISRUPTS BASEBALL FROM FIELD TO FRONT OFFICE

text: Davis said he stopped using the drug after being approached by the F.B.I. But some of the suspicion lingered.
title: COCAINE DISRUPTS BASEBALL FROM FIELD TO FRONT OFFICE

text: Davis said, ''Last year, an ex-player came up to me and said, 'They got you; they're watching you.' I said, 'What are they watching me for?' '' Reaching the Majors And Wanting to 'Fit In' Nothing, though, was more difficult for the Expos than the discovery that cocaine had undermined their efforts a few years ago.
title: COCAINE DISRUPTS BASEBALL FROM FIELD TO FRONT OFFICE

text: ''It slipped in the back door and you didn't even know it was in the house,'' McHale said sadly. Raines, the rookie sensation, was the only member of the 1982 Expos publicly identified as a cocaine user. He voluntarily entered a treatment center after the season. ''Now that I look back,'' Raines said not long ago, ''I probably was the only one that did undergo treatment, but I wasn't the only one that needed to.''
title: COCAINE DISRUPTS BASEBALL FROM FIELD TO FRONT OFFICE

text: McHale said some of the Montreal cocaine users ''seemed to be so far gone'' that the Expos didn't try to rehabilitate them. Raines, he said, ''worked hard'' at his rehabilitation.
title: COCAINE DISRUPTS BASEBALL FROM FIELD TO FRONT OFFICE

text: ''He probably cost us six, eight, 10 games doing things we couldn't believe he was doing,'' McHale said of the outfielder. ''We moved him to second base for a while and there were times he held the ball without making a play. He'd be on first base and he couldn't run; they picked him off. He couldn't find balls in the outfield. After we found out what was wrong, we said why couldn't we spot it? You look for excuses, like maybe there's too much pressure on him, or maybe he has problems at home.''
title: COCAINE DISRUPTS BASEBALL FROM FIELD TO FRONT OFFICE

text: Raines said he became involved with cocaine through older teammates. He wouldn't discuss his testimony in Pittsburgh or identify any of his teammates who were involved with him, but added, ''When I got anything, it was always from a player.'' Over all, he said he used the drug with ''eight or nine'' players, mostly teammates but also some players from other teams.
title: COCAINE DISRUPTS BASEBALL FROM FIELD TO FRONT OFFICE

text: Raines described himself as a ''sort of quiet guy'' when he arrived in the major leagues in 1981. ''I never knew what drugs were when I was growing up,'' he said. ''Once I got into the big leagues, you just sort of want to fit in. I felt it was just an experiment I tried, and I got hooked. You can't just turn it on and off that easily. I just got in with the wrong people.''
title: COCAINE DISRUPTS BASEBALL FROM FIELD TO FRONT OFFICE

text: Raines said he never found it difficult to get cocaine. ''Anytime there's a big party, there's going to be drugs around,'' he related. ''That's the easiest thing to do, to meet someone.''
title: COCAINE DISRUPTS BASEBALL FROM FIELD TO FRONT OFFICE

text: Parties and players and cocaine seem to be a popular combination. When players attend parties, other people often want to ingratiate themselves with these stars by giving them whatever they want.
title: COCAINE DISRUPTS BASEBALL FROM FIELD TO FRONT OFFICE

text: Ron Davis, a relief pitcher with the Minnesota Twins, recalled how, when he played for the Yankees, he and teammates would go to parties in New York. ''I have seen a lot of cocaine around, not that any of our players took it,'' Davis said. ''But it was there if you needed it. A guy would come up to you and say, 'Let's go into the back room, I got some stuff.' He was giving it to us for free if we wanted it. Some of us left. We didn't want to get blamed for using it.'' Sliding Head First To Protect His Cocaine Raines, on the other hand, used -and used and used. During the 1982 season, he said, he had three months of particularly heavy use, using cocaine virtually everyday. But he was careful about where he bought the drug.
title: COCAINE DISRUPTS BASEBALL FROM FIELD TO FRONT OFFICE

text: ''You're taking a chance as an athlete to try to obtain some and risk it being an undercover agent,'' he said. ''I never went out and sought to get it from someone on the street. I never had the guts to do it. When I got anything, it was always from a player.''
title: COCAINE DISRUPTS BASEBALL FROM FIELD TO FRONT OFFICE

text: It didn't take Raines long to become a regular user.
title: COCAINE DISRUPTS BASEBALL FROM FIELD TO FRONT OFFICE

text: ''You find yourself liking it,'' he said. ''You try it again and again. All of a sudden, it gets to the point where you have to have it. It's like an upper. You come down, you feel sluggish, sick. When you're high, you feel normal, but it's not really normal.''
title: COCAINE DISRUPTS BASEBALL FROM FIELD TO FRONT OFFICE

text: Players don't normally take naps in the dugout between innings either, but Raines at times did just that, being exhausted from staying up late using cocaine.
title: COCAINE DISRUPTS BASEBALL FROM FIELD TO FRONT OFFICE

text: In 1982, Raines did not have what for him was a normal season. His average dropped 27 points to .277; he drove in only six more runs in more than twice as many times at bat as he had the previous season and he struck out nearly three times as often. He also had only seven more stolen bases than he had the year before in the strike-shortened season. In 1981, he stole one out of every 1.97 times he reached base; in 1982, he stole one out of every 3.26 times.
title: COCAINE DISRUPTS BASEBALL FROM FIELD TO FRONT OFFICE

text: Raines said he often went into the bathroom behind the dugout to use more between innings. Where did he keep it?
title: COCAINE DISRUPTS BASEBALL FROM FIELD TO FRONT OFFICE

text: ''I had it in little gram bottles that I kept in my pocket,'' he related. ''Actually, a lot of times, I would put it in my batting glove and then in my pocket. I was trying to find ways of not getting caught.'' When he slid into a base, Raines added, he was sure to protect his investment. ''Usually,'' he said, ''when I carried it in my pocket, I'd go in head first.'' Delivering Cocaine By Federal Express Lonnie Smith, who said he used cocaine for several years, was another player who took great care to protect his stash. A heavy user when he played the outfield for the St. Louis Cardinals in 1983, Smith told of the different ways he concealed his supply.
title: COCAINE DISRUPTS BASEBALL FROM FIELD TO FRONT OFFICE

text: ''The majority of the time, I hid it on me,'' he said. ''I had these Playboy socks with pockets in them and I'd stick it in there. I had ways of folding my clothes, 10, 12 pairs of pants in a suitcase. I learned it from a Latin friend in Venezuela. People who wanted to check wouldn't take the time.''
title: COCAINE DISRUPTS BASEBALL FROM FIELD TO FRONT OFFICE

text: During the offseason, he said, he and his supplier had a simple system of delivery. ''We Federal Expressed it back and forth,'' Smith, 29, explained. ''I Federal Expressed the money, he Federal Expressed the stuff. He would use a phony address for his address. I thought it was kind of creative in a way. He'd send me newspapers from Philadelphia and tape the stuff inside the papers.''
title: COCAINE DISRUPTS BASEBALL FROM FIELD TO FRONT OFFICE

text: During the season, he said, his supplier, who lived in Philadelphia, where Smith began his major league career, would call ''and ask me if I needed anything.'' The supplier, Smith added, also would travel to other cities, including New York and Pittsburgh, to deliver cocaine to him.
title: COCAINE DISRUPTS BASEBALL FROM FIELD TO FRONT OFFICE

text: Smith wouldn't name his supplier, but he said he identified him to F.B.I. agents who interviewed him and to the Pittsburgh grand jury when he testified. Smith was said by government officials to be one of several players who would be called to testify at the trial next month of Curtis Strong, a Philadelphia caterer who was one of seven alleged dealers indicted by the grand jury. Asked if Strong was his supplier, Smith laughed and said, ''I better not say. There's more than one dealer in Philly.''
title: COCAINE DISRUPTS BASEBALL FROM FIELD TO FRONT OFFICE

text: Smith said marijuana had been ''my drug of choice'' but then ''I got involved with cocaine and I started to have a problem. There's no doubt I was addicted. I started losing interest in things. I didn't care about the game. The majority of the time we were in a hurry to get the game over with and do it all over again.''
title: COCAINE DISRUPTS BASEBALL FROM FIELD TO FRONT OFFICE

text: ''Three or four'' Cardinal teammates, he said, were using cocaine with him, but ''at no point did I think any of them were as hooked as I was. They had more will power to control the habit than I did.''
title: COCAINE DISRUPTS BASEBALL FROM FIELD TO FRONT OFFICE

text: He first used cocaine, he said, when he was playing winter baseball in 1977, before he reached the major leagues, but he said he didn't use it regularly until after the 1980 season, his first full season in the majors, ''when I started making more money.'' The Cardinals won the World Series in 1982, and over the following winter Smith's drug use increased. ''I really went over the bend with it because I didn't have anything to do,'' he said. ''I did it almost every day during that winter.''
title: COCAINE DISRUPTS BASEBALL FROM FIELD TO FRONT OFFICE

text: He estimated that from 1979 until he entered rehabilitation in June 1983 for four weeks, he spent about $50,000 or $60,000 on cocaine, ''give or take a few thousand. I started buying in bigger quantities, eighths and quarters. I almost tried buying an ounce.'' At times, he said, he used the drug with friends and teammates, but ''the majority of time, you do it solo. It's so expensive and it goes so fast, you like to hoard it.''
title: COCAINE DISRUPTS BASEBALL FROM FIELD TO FRONT OFFICE

text: Smith acknowledged talking to players on other teams about cocaine on the field before games. ''We would have conversations sometimes,'' he said, ''trying to find out who had connections, who could get something. It was usually during practice before a game, loosening up, running sprints, talking to guys. I think that's how some of the information got around in the drug investigation.''
title: COCAINE DISRUPTS BASEBALL FROM FIELD TO FRONT OFFICE

text: In 1983, Smith, never considered an outstanding outfielder, played even worse than usual defensively, finishing with a .941 fielding average compared with a .970 average the year before. His success at stealing bases was also not so great as in the year before. ''I think it slowed me down, not just running but my mental thinking,'' Smith said, discussing the effect cocaine had on his play. ''I wasn't as alert. My body was getting run-down, burnt out, as they say. I think it affected me. Other people didn't because I was still getting hits.''
title: COCAINE DISRUPTS BASEBALL FROM FIELD TO FRONT OFFICE

text: Smith wound up the season with a .321 batting average, 14 points better than the previous year. But over all, he said, the cocaine use affected his play.
title: COCAINE DISRUPTS BASEBALL FROM FIELD TO FRONT OFFICE

text: ''Look at my defense,'' he said. ''It seemed like I was averaging two or three errors a game. I was getting picked off. Everything I swung at was away.''
title: COCAINE DISRUPTS BASEBALL FROM FIELD TO FRONT OFFICE

text: ''Whitey thought I was having problems but not drugs,'' Smith said, referring to Manager Whitey Herzog. ''He thought I was having emotional problems. No one wants to believe a guy is doing bad because of drug problems. But the more I did it, the worse I felt. My need kept getting greater and I couldn't fight that need.''
title: COCAINE DISRUPTS BASEBALL FROM FIELD TO FRONT OFFICE

text: He told of locking himself in a room, not answering the phone, not talking to anyone. ''I was getting away from my family,'' he said. ''My addiction was changing my thinking and my feelings, and I no longer was the same person.'' Using Meal Money For Purchases on Road Smith's story is not different from those of others who have talked of their involvement with cocaine. The drug can become all-consuming, and the players addicted to it virtually lead their lives with it at the center. Law enforcement officials say some players would make sure their suppliers always were nearby so they wouldn't have to carry large quantities of cocaine with them. The players obtain cocaine from suppliers before games for use during the games, then make another purchase after the games for use then. They use alcohol and pills to come down from the cocaine high so they can sleep, then start with cocaine again when they wake up, again making sure the suppliers are on hand to deliver the morning's supply.
title: COCAINE DISRUPTS BASEBALL FROM FIELD TO FRONT OFFICE

text: These officials also told of how some players have had their paychecks sent to their agents but still have had money to buy drugs. Among other resources, officials said, they have used the meal money they get when they are on the road and they have used money they get from shoe companies for wearing their shoes. Some players also have sold cocaine to other players as an accommodation, officials said, but there has been no indication - or at least known evidence - that any players have sold the drug for profit.
title: COCAINE DISRUPTS BASEBALL FROM FIELD TO FRONT OFFICE

text: Whether or not there is evidence, clubs are careful about acquiring players who may have involvement with drugs. In fact, eyebrows around the league were raised earlier this season when the Royals obtained Smith from the Cardinals, considering the shattering experience the Royals had only two years ago.
title: COCAINE DISRUPTS BASEBALL FROM FIELD TO FRONT OFFICE

text: ''We checked him out thoroughly, and that's mild,'' Howser, the Kansas City manager, said. ''A club that's been involved like we were has to be overcautious.
