That's the most embarrassing thing that has happened. If we're even suspicious that a guy is involved, we wouldn't go after him. I don't know that winning would be worth going through that again.'' Sackful of Chicken Tips Off a Manager Howser was as surprised as anyone when several members of the Royals were implicated in the Kansas City drug case. He said he can look back at various incidents now and see that they might have been the result of drug use, but he said he had no way of knowing then.
title: COCAINE DISRUPTS BASEBALL FROM FIELD TO FRONT OFFICE

text: ''The peoples' work habits weren't as good,'' he said, ''and when your work habits are bad, your skills decline. Their drive dropped off quite a bit. The tenacity, the ability to stay after it, they don't seem to be as tough mentally. They're kind of docile, milquetoast. The frustrating thing as a manager is you're around these guys for seven months and that slips by you.''
title: COCAINE DISRUPTS BASEBALL FROM FIELD TO FRONT OFFICE

text: He told of how one of the players who eventually was found to be involved walked into the clubhouse one day at 4:55 P.M. carrying a sackful of chicken. The players were supposed to be in uniform at 5 P.M.
title: COCAINE DISRUPTS BASEBALL FROM FIELD TO FRONT OFFICE

text: ''That's kind of a tipoff,'' Howser said. ''The thing that disappointed me about this guy was he had good work habits; he came from a good organization. He was supposed to be in here early one day and when he didn't show up, we called him and he was asleep at 3 o'clock.''
title: COCAINE DISRUPTS BASEBALL FROM FIELD TO FRONT OFFICE

text: Speaking later of Willie Aikens, the first baseman who pleaded guilty to a drug charge and served time in prison, Howser said, ''His work habits dropped off. He used to have a smile on his face, but his attitude changed. I thought he was mad at me or the organization.''
title: COCAINE DISRUPTS BASEBALL FROM FIELD TO FRONT OFFICE

text: Aikens, who hit four home runs for the Royals in the 1980 World Series, has not played well since his drug experience and this season has played in the minor leagues. He declined to talk about his cocaine use. Asked if cocaine has ended careers prematurely, Howser said, ''No question about it.''
title: COCAINE DISRUPTS BASEBALL FROM FIELD TO FRONT OFFICE

text: The known cases of cocaine use also have made managers suspicious about other players.
title: COCAINE DISRUPTS BASEBALL FROM FIELD TO FRONT OFFICE

text: ''I've checked lockers and their bags while they're on the field,'' Billy Martin, the Yankees' manager, said, speaking of the time he managed the Oakland A's, ''trying to find different stuff, people I've suspected. I've never found anything and I've tried hard.''
title: COCAINE DISRUPTS BASEBALL FROM FIELD TO FRONT OFFICE

text: Buck Rodgers, the Montreal manager, said he didn't have to look too hard when he managed the Milwaukee Brewers.
title: COCAINE DISRUPTS BASEBALL FROM FIELD TO FRONT OFFICE

text: ''One of my players came in late for a Sunday game in Minnesota,'' Rodgers related. ''Being late was just part of it. He couldn't stop sniffing. He walked in and every player on the team watched him walk across and then everybody looked at me to see if I was watching. So everybody had some idea.''
title: COCAINE DISRUPTS BASEBALL FROM FIELD TO FRONT OFFICE

text: Suspicion has become a first reaction in certain instances.
title: COCAINE DISRUPTS BASEBALL FROM FIELD TO FRONT OFFICE

text: ''When a ballplayer shows some symptoms on the field,'' Jim Frey, manager of the Chicago Cubs, said, ''when his personality as a player on the field changes, you question it because of today's culture. Sometimes you say to yourself, 'I wonder if maybe this fellow is using something.' That's a natural reaction.''
title: COCAINE DISRUPTS BASEBALL FROM FIELD TO FRONT OFFICE

text: On the other hand, Chuck Tanner, the Pittsburgh manager, whose team was the center of controversy during the drug investigation in Pittsburgh earlier this year, said he tries to resist suspicion.
title: COCAINE DISRUPTS BASEBALL FROM FIELD TO FRONT OFFICE

text: ''If every time a guy boots a ball, you wondered what it was, you'd go crazy,'' Tanner said. ''Everybody makes an error. Every pitcher loses a game. Guys in the Hall of Fame lost games.''
title: COCAINE DISRUPTS BASEBALL FROM FIELD TO FRONT OFFICE

text: Even experience doesn't make a manager an expert, though. Rod Scurry, a Pirates relief pitcher, underwent rehabilitation for cocaine use and returned to the team. ''It was up to me to take care of him after he came back,'' Tanner said. ''So I'd ask him and he said he felt good. When he didn't show up, I was surprised. If I thought there was a problem, I would've tried to help him.''
title: COCAINE DISRUPTS BASEBALL FROM FIELD TO FRONT OFFICE

text: Scurry returned to rehabilitation a second time for substance abuse, though the Pirates never said the treatment was for drug abuse.
title: COCAINE DISRUPTS BASEBALL FROM FIELD TO FRONT OFFICE

text: Players who have undergone treatment for cocaine use acknowledge that it is difficult to remain free of drugs afterward, not unlike an alcoholic with alcohol. Steve Howe, the relief pitcher released by Los Angeles earlier this season and recently signed by the Minnesota Twins, has been treated twice.
title: COCAINE DISRUPTS BASEBALL FROM FIELD TO FRONT OFFICE

text: ''You're always tempted,'' Lonnie Smith said. ''If you socialize with people, you run across the wrong people. You're tempted almost every day out of the year. It's not easy. There's no known cure for the disease.''
title: COCAINE DISRUPTS BASEBALL FROM FIELD TO FRONT OFFICE

text: NEXT: A convicted drug dealer recalls late-night parties with the players.
title: COCAINE DISRUPTS BASEBALL FROM FIELD TO FRONT OFFICE

text: MEDICAL technology that can measure minute amounts of chemicals in the body has raised disturbing questions on Long Island about whether teachers should be subjected to tests for illicit drug use as a condition for employment or job advancement.
title: DRUG TESTING FOR TEACHERS STIRRING CONCERN

text: The issue was brought into focus in the Patchogue-Medford School District in eastern Suffolk County, where a teachers' union won a court decision in June that said school administrators' plans to require such tests for 23 teachers seeking tenure were illegal.
title: DRUG TESTING FOR TEACHERS STIRRING CONCERN

text: Despite that decision, the administrators have gone ahead with plans to require drug testing for prospective teachers and other new employees. It is believed to be the first time that a Long Island school system has made drug testing a requirement for employment.
title: DRUG TESTING FOR TEACHERS STIRRING CONCERN

text: Such testing is believed to be increasing across the country, both in private industry and among public workers, leading to concern by civil liberties groups and others. Richard Emery, counsel for the New York Civil Liberties Union, confirmed that the practice was on the rise in the New York area. For example, the school board in East Rutherford, N.J., plans to require that students take urine tests to check for drug use.
title: DRUG TESTING FOR TEACHERS STIRRING CONCERN

text: So advanced is the current technology for measuring drugs in urine samples that even the smallest amounts would be discerned by devices like gas chromotography/mass spectrometry analyzer, a computer-controlled instrument in the toxicology laboratory at the Brunswick Hospital Center in Amityville.
title: DRUG TESTING FOR TEACHERS STIRRING CONCERN

text: ''It provides us with a fingerprint of any compound we test for that is present,'' said Dr. William Closson, the hospital's chief of clinical chemistry.
title: DRUG TESTING FOR TEACHERS STIRRING CONCERN

text: Administrators in the school district, with the support of the school board, will send urine samples that show traces of drugs in initial testing for more exacting tests at the hospital, whose testing equipment, Dr. Closson said, is among the most sophisticated available. He said it allows for urine screenings identical to those given to athletes at the Olympic Games last summer.
title: DRUG TESTING FOR TEACHERS STIRRING CONCERN

text: Dr. Closson said he had advised the administrators and the school board members on what drugs to test for in the urine sample. They settled on a list of 10 drugs, excluding marijuana because the hospital equipment is so sensitive it would detect traces in the urine of a person who has merely been in the presence of someone who was smoking marijuana.
title: DRUG TESTING FOR TEACHERS STIRRING CONCERN

text: The list includes cocaine, morphine, secobarbital, lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD), phencyclidine, also known as PCP or ''angel dust,'' amphetamines, and mood-altering drugs sometimes prescribed by doctors.
title: DRUG TESTING FOR TEACHERS STIRRING CONCERN

text: Dr. Closson said the hospital performs similar tests for ''half a dozen'' other private and public concerns he declined to identify. ''It's becoming more popular,'' he added.
title: DRUG TESTING FOR TEACHERS STIRRING CONCERN

text: Henry P. Read, the district's Superintendent, had sought to use the results of urine screening in evaluating the 23 district teachers who became eligible for tenure last spring. He said that any of the teachers found to have drug traces in their urine would be asked to explain why. The use of some drugs on the list would be accepted as reasonable, he said, if the users provided prescriptions signed by doctors.
title: DRUG TESTING FOR TEACHERS STIRRING CONCERN

text: But for those who lacked reasonable excuses, he said, school officals would consider denying tenure and notifying the police of the illicit drug use.
title: DRUG TESTING FOR TEACHERS STIRRING CONCERN

text: Mr. Read said the policy was aimed at holding the more than 600 teachers in the district to the same standards regarding drug abuse that the district sets for its 9,500 students.
title: DRUG TESTING FOR TEACHERS STIRRING CONCERN

text: ''You can't have role models who use cocaine,'' Mr. Read said. He said there were no plans to require urine testing for students.
title: DRUG TESTING FOR TEACHERS STIRRING CONCERN

text: In its suit in State Supreme Court in Riverhead, the teachers' union, the Patchogue-Medford Congress of Teachers, charged that the district's requirement that the 23 teachers submit urine samples violated their contract and their constitutional protection against unreasonable search.
title: DRUG TESTING FOR TEACHERS STIRRING CONCERN

text: In interviews, the teachers said they were offended because they were not consulted before the district director of personnel in May instructed the 23 teachers to report to the school nurse to provide urine samples.
title: DRUG TESTING FOR TEACHERS STIRRING CONCERN

text: ''It is demeaning and unnecessary,'' said Anthony Conetta, president of the union and a high school mathematics teacher.
title: DRUG TESTING FOR TEACHERS STIRRING CONCERN

text: Mr. Conetta said there has never been a teacher in the district whose behavior hinted of drug abuse. He said the proposed testing had lowered teacher morale and raised fears that the testing might be required in the future for tenured teachers, who comprise most of the teaching staff.
title: DRUG TESTING FOR TEACHERS STIRRING CONCERN

text: Mr. Read said he proposed the policies after hearing reports that some teachers were using drugs in social settings outside of school. ''Drug use in some quarters is not being taken as seriously as it should be,'' he said.
title: DRUG TESTING FOR TEACHERS STIRRING CONCERN

text: The district contended in court that teachers seeking tenure had been required by contract for years to undergo physical examinations to test for disease. The drug analysis merely broadened the scope of an examination that already included urinalysis, the district said.
title: DRUG TESTING FOR TEACHERS STIRRING CONCERN

text: The issues brought to court were novel because the technology for screening urine for minute traces of drugs has become available only in the last several years.
title: DRUG TESTING FOR TEACHERS STIRRING CONCERN

text: Justice Thomas M. Stark of the State Supreme Court found that the urine tests amounted to a search and seizure under the Fourth Amendment, which prohibits ''unreasonable searches and seizures.''
title: DRUG TESTING FOR TEACHERS STIRRING CONCERN

text: He said such bodily invasions were constitutional only if there was suspicion of drug abuse ''based upon supportable objective facts and pursuant to established administrative standards,'' elements that the judge said were not present in the district's case.
title: DRUG TESTING FOR TEACHERS STIRRING CONCERN

text: The district has appealed the ruling, according to Susan F. Alevas, Mr. Read's executive assistant. But she said the decision, in the district's view, applies only to the 23 teachers who were the plaintiffs.
title: DRUG TESTING FOR TEACHERS STIRRING CONCERN

text: She said the school district believes the decision allows it ''to use the drug screen for all new candidates and for permanent employees seeking promotions into different categories.'' She said that administrators, teachers, custodians, secretaries, food-service workers, nurses and bus drivers were included.
title: DRUG TESTING FOR TEACHERS STIRRING CONCERN

text: Mrs. Alevas said the new policy did not require the school board's approval, although she said the board unanimously supported it.
title: DRUG TESTING FOR TEACHERS STIRRING CONCERN

text: Daniel Galinson, the attorney for the teachers' union, said the union had no jurisdiction over testing of nonmembers.
title: DRUG TESTING FOR TEACHERS STIRRING CONCERN

text: The district's policy has raised concern among civil libertarians. Mr. Emery, of the State Civil Liberties Union, said the policy was typical of a growing trend toward mass surveillance.
title: DRUG TESTING FOR TEACHERS STIRRING CONCERN

text: ''It's a totalitarian method that intrudes deeply into the privacy of people,'' he said of the district's drug-testing policy. ''It puts a chill on the rights of people who deserve the presumption that they are acting lawfully, especially when their job performance is not in question. It treats everybody like criminals.''
title: DRUG TESTING FOR TEACHERS STIRRING CONCERN

text: He said the scope of intrusive surveillance has been greatly expanded by new technology, such as the instruments used at the Brunswick Hospital Center. New methods of surveillance, he said, were opening up new areas of law.
title: DRUG TESTING FOR TEACHERS STIRRING CONCERN

text: The district points with pride to special substance-abuse training that many teachers have received and to drug-abuse prevention programs for students ranging from the elementary level to high school.
title: DRUG TESTING FOR TEACHERS STIRRING CONCERN

text: The district's approach is based, in part, on a 1984 report titled ''Strategies for Controlling Adolescent Drug Use,'' prepared by the Rand Corporation of Santa Monica, Calif., under a grant from the Conrad Hilton Foundation. The report concluded that to prevent drug use, ''the optimal method is to approach adolescents through the schools, as the antismoking programs do.''
title: DRUG TESTING FOR TEACHERS STIRRING CONCERN

text: In June, the district was one of three in New York to receive a certificate of excellence from the State Division of Substance Abuse Services for its programs.
title: DRUG TESTING FOR TEACHERS STIRRING CONCERN

text: Superintendent Read said he wanted a teaching staff ''that makes no bones'' about its willingness to help carry out the programs. ''Faculty commitment is absolutely essential,'' he said, adding that not using drugs was part of the commitment.
title: DRUG TESTING FOR TEACHERS STIRRING CONCERN

text: ''They have a right to test if they have a legitimate reason,'' said Mr. Conetta, the teachers' union president. ''What we object to is the manner in which it is being done. It's sort of like a witch hunt.''
title: DRUG TESTING FOR TEACHERS STIRRING CONCERN

text: Mr. Conetta, who holds tenure and is not among district employees who must submit to the drug testing, said he would ''probably refuse'' if he were ever asked to take the test, either voluntarily or as a condition of employment.
title: DRUG TESTING FOR TEACHERS STIRRING CONCERN

text: The teachers who were plaintiffs in the lawsuit were granted tenure without undergoing the drug testing, Mrs. Alevas said.
title: DRUG TESTING FOR TEACHERS STIRRING CONCERN

text: In 1974, Baron Sumter was convicted of marijuana possession and sentenced to two years in prison. But the judge never told him when to surrender. For years Mr. Sumter has been living with his wife and two children in the central California town of Prunedale.
title: AFTER DECADE OF FREEDOM, WHEELS OF JUSTICE TURN

text: On Wednesday, Mr. Sumter, a brick mason, began serving the sentence.
title: AFTER DECADE OF FREEDOM, WHEELS OF JUSTICE TURN

text: ''We were stunned,'' said his wife, Alice. ''I sat with my kids and watched as they took him away. The kids were absolutely hysterical.I can't believe this is happening in the United States. He's been a model citizen all this time. He made a mistake when he was 25 or 26 and hasn't done a thing since. After not hearing from them for six or seven years, we figured it was over.''
title: AFTER DECADE OF FREEDOM, WHEELS OF JUSTICE TURN

text: Reached Thursday night in San Francisco where he was attending a meeting, Gov. Bruce Babbit of Arizona was apparently moved by the case.
title: AFTER DECADE OF FREEDOM, WHEELS OF JUSTICE TURN

text: ''I would think there's a strong case for commutation or other adjustment of the sentence,'' he said.
title: AFTER DECADE OF FREEDOM, WHEELS OF JUSTICE TURN

text: It would take about 30 days for the Arizona Department of Pardons and Paroles to make a recommendation in the case, he said. ''At that point I would have the power to commute the sentence,'' he added. ''The facts, as they are presented, are very appealing.''
title: AFTER DECADE OF FREEDOM, WHEELS OF JUSTICE TURN

text: Told of the Governor's words, Mr. Sumter's wife screamed with delight: ''Oh my goodness, I'm overwhelmed. This is absolutely wonderful.'' Mr. Sumter, 38, had been free on $1,500 bail pending the outcome of his appeal for his 1974 conviction in Yuma County Superior Court for possession of 125 pounds of marijuana. While awaiting results of the appeal, he was given permission to move to Prunedale.
title: AFTER DECADE OF FREEDOM, WHEELS OF JUSTICE TURN

text: The Arizona Supreme Court rejected his appeal on Dec. 29, 1975, but the judge never told Mr. Sumter when to begin serving his term.
title: AFTER DECADE OF FREEDOM, WHEELS OF JUSTICE TURN

text: The judge and the prosecutor left office shortly after the court decision and apparently no one familiar with the case was around to follow up on it.
title: AFTER DECADE OF FREEDOM, WHEELS OF JUSTICE TURN

text: A clerk discovered the mistake not long ago ago while cleaning out old files.
title: AFTER DECADE OF FREEDOM, WHEELS OF JUSTICE TURN

text: Special to the New York Times
title: COLOMBIANS IN MIAMI SEEK TO IMPROVE IMAGE

text: Enrique Cabrera, a Colombian businessman here, says he gets two reactions to the ''Colombian Import and Products'' sign on his truck. Teen-agers wave happily at him on the street. Police officers do not.
title: COLOMBIANS IN MIAMI SEEK TO IMPROVE IMAGE

text: ''When a policeman comes by, he looks at me like he wants to stop me and search me,'' Mr. Cabrera said. ''That's the way it is.'' Alba Alzate, a Colombian housewife, said she got the same line every time.
title: COLOMBIANS IN MIAMI SEEK TO IMPROVE IMAGE

text: ''Every American, I swear, they say, 'Right on, right on, you're from Colombia!' '' she said. ''I say, 'Why?' They say, 'You have the best marijuana.' ''
title: COLOMBIANS IN MIAMI SEEK TO IMPROVE IMAGE

text: Wisecracks, slights and suspicion, provoked by countrymen who, according to the Federal Drug Enforcement Administration, control much of the cocaine trafficking in the United States, have been the burden of the estimated 125,000 Colombians in Dade County. For the last five years, drug-related shootings, slayings and mayhem have been virtually all the community has heard about Colombians.
title: COLOMBIANS IN MIAMI SEEK TO IMPROVE IMAGE

text: Earlier this year a group of Colombian businessmen got tired of the jokes and formed the Colombian-American Society to try to improve their nation's image and assist fellow Colombians to adapt to the Miami area.
title: COLOMBIANS IN MIAMI SEEK TO IMPROVE IMAGE

text: ''Everything now is to change the image,'' said Mr. Cabrera, who serves as the group's president. ''We're going to work very hard.''
title: COLOMBIANS IN MIAMI SEEK TO IMPROVE IMAGE

text: To that end, the society drew more than 30,000 people to Tropical Park in July to mark Colombia's national independence day and to try to polish the image of the Colombian-American community.
title: COLOMBIANS IN MIAMI SEEK TO IMPROVE IMAGE

text: Amid blaring bands, sizzling dishes and festivities conducted in Spanish, were several stands where for $6 a customer could buy a T-shirt that spelled out the attempt to change Colombia's economic image: ''Perico. . ? No, cafe!'' Local businessmen are trying to replace cocaine, known as perico, with coffee as Colombia's best-known export, said a shirt vendor, Hugo Rodriguez.
title: COLOMBIANS IN MIAMI SEEK TO IMPROVE IMAGE

text: ''It was an idea of those of us who aren't in the drug business,'' he said.
title: COLOMBIANS IN MIAMI SEEK TO IMPROVE IMAGE

text: The Colombian-American Society hopes that such tactics will help to turn around the American perception of Colombians here.
title: COLOMBIANS IN MIAMI SEEK TO IMPROVE IMAGE

text: ''The Colombian community here is a large community, a hardworking community,'' said Armando Soto, the society's secretary. ''And because of a few people we are getting a lot of press. We are getting the bad news and we never took the time to get the good news.''
title: COLOMBIANS IN MIAMI SEEK TO IMPROVE IMAGE

text: The society counts as members nearly 80 of the estimated 2,000 Colombian-owned businesses in Florida. The Colombians are the second largest group of Hispanic immigrants in Florida, after the Cubans. The Immigration and Naturalization Service reports that for the last five years, 11,000 Colombians have immigrated annually to the United States.
title: COLOMBIANS IN MIAMI SEEK TO IMPROVE IMAGE

text: One immigrant, Victor Villa, 35 years old, who operates a bakery and is planning to open another, said he protected his investments by steering clear of the drug trade.
title: COLOMBIANS IN MIAMI SEEK TO IMPROVE IMAGE

text: ''It's quite dangerous,'' Mr. Villa said. ''I don't mess with them and they don't mess with me.''
title: COLOMBIANS IN MIAMI SEEK TO IMPROVE IMAGE

text: Looking to Example of Cubans
title: COLOMBIANS IN MIAMI SEEK TO IMPROVE IMAGE

text: Mr. Cabrera said that the Colombians looked to the Cubans as an example of building an effective expatriate community. ''Politically we're learning from them,'' he said.
title: COLOMBIANS IN MIAMI SEEK TO IMPROVE IMAGE

text: Mr. Cabrera said 13,500 Colombians were registered to vote in Miami. ''I wouldn't be surprised if we had a Colombian Mayor before too long,'' he said.
title: COLOMBIANS IN MIAMI SEEK TO IMPROVE IMAGE

text: But first, said Mr. Cabrera, who travels frequently between Miami and Bogota, the Colombian capital, the problem of perceptions must be countered. He said that on a recent trip back from Bogota he was closely questioned by a customs official.
title: COLOMBIANS IN MIAMI SEEK TO IMPROVE IMAGE

text: According to Mr. Cabrera, when he told the official he was returning from a business trip to Colombia, the official asked, ''Not the white powder?''
title: COLOMBIANS IN MIAMI SEEK TO IMPROVE IMAGE

text: ''I said, 'No, not the white powder.' There's always the wisecrack. It makes me angry.''
title: COLOMBIANS IN MIAMI SEEK TO IMPROVE IMAGE

text: By William Robbins, Special To the New York Times
title: IN A COAST MOUNTAIN FASTNESS, PEACE (AND POLICE HELICOPTERS)

text: At first the poster on a gatepost near a Confederate flag might seem symbolic of an attitude here in the remote coastal mountains of northern California, 200 miles above San Francisco.
title: IN A COAST MOUNTAIN FASTNESS, PEACE (AND POLICE HELICOPTERS)

text: Below the muzzle of a revolver, it carries the words: ''Never mind the dog - beware of owner.''
title: IN A COAST MOUNTAIN FASTNESS, PEACE (AND POLICE HELICOPTERS)

text: In fact, the visitor here is unlikely to encounter anything more menacing than a wave of the hand from the porch of the General Store or the veranda of Alderpoint's other retail establishment, the Bum Steer, a new tavern.
title: IN A COAST MOUNTAIN FASTNESS, PEACE (AND POLICE HELICOPTERS)

text: In the tavern it is easy enough to get a friendly game of eight-ball started under the amiable eye of Al Carr, the proprietor, but the conversation should stick to the game.
title: IN A COAST MOUNTAIN FASTNESS, PEACE (AND POLICE HELICOPTERS)

text: In a land that seems to have more than its share of people seeking to escape the intrusions of modern life and perhaps living on the fringes of the law, it is poor form to ask about an opponent's background and occupation.
title: IN A COAST MOUNTAIN FASTNESS, PEACE (AND POLICE HELICOPTERS)

text: An occasional deer hunter may fire a gun from the tavern's veranda, but only out of exuberance generated by pure air, wild mountain scenery and perhaps a few beers. The barrel is always aimed out toward the neighboring cliff that drops down to the Eel River.
title: IN A COAST MOUNTAIN FASTNESS, PEACE (AND POLICE HELICOPTERS)

text: The loungers on the river beach below the line of fire are likely to take exception, though they seem bothered by little else, especially by apparel. The dress code on swimsuits is with or without.
title: IN A COAST MOUNTAIN FASTNESS, PEACE (AND POLICE HELICOPTERS)

text: Many of the hundred-odd people here, like the owners of the cabins hidden in coves and groves along the mountainsides, leave their doors unlocked, day or night, whether they are at home or away.
title: IN A COAST MOUNTAIN FASTNESS, PEACE (AND POLICE HELICOPTERS)

text: One reason, some say, is that there is likely to be little inside to steal. The most valuable possession is likely to be outside -one of the ubiquitous satellite dishes needed to bring in the exterior world of television. A thief would have a long way to haul his booty down narrow, twisting mountain trails.
title: IN A COAST MOUNTAIN FASTNESS, PEACE (AND POLICE HELICOPTERS)

text: The three-county area around Alderpoint is known locally as the Emerald Triangle for its principal crop, marijuana, which has recently been the subject of helicopter raids by the police. The area's most striking features are the mountains, the solitude enjoyed when the nearest sign of civilization is a winking light on a neighboring mountaintop, the people and the way they live.
title: IN A COAST MOUNTAIN FASTNESS, PEACE (AND POLICE HELICOPTERS)

text: The best-selling book is a new paperback, ''Cash Crop,'' on a culture centered on the area's best-selling product. According to its author and publisher, Ray Raphael, a former New Yorker, the people can be divided into two groups: growers and nongrowers. Some say the growers are far more numerous.
title: IN A COAST MOUNTAIN FASTNESS, PEACE (AND POLICE HELICOPTERS)

text: But for some residents the distinction breaks down. ''I'm not a grower,'' one said the other day. ''I just have a few plants.'' There was a sharp distinction, he said, between people who moved here to live and others who ''came to grow.'' Those others, he said, have developed ''plantations'' for commercial distribution, a few so large that they have armed guards.
title: IN A COAST MOUNTAIN FASTNESS, PEACE (AND POLICE HELICOPTERS)

text: After generations, civilization still appears only lightly to have invaded the mountain fastness. First there were the trappers, then the homesteaders, then the moonshiners, then the loggers.
title: IN A COAST MOUNTAIN FASTNESS, PEACE (AND POLICE HELICOPTERS)

text: Now new wanderers have decided to sojourn here, fugitives from the crowds of San Francisco, Seattle, Chicago or New York. The newcomers, often bearded and long-haired, have found a peaceful coexistence with old loggers and a few former moonshiners.
title: IN A COAST MOUNTAIN FASTNESS, PEACE (AND POLICE HELICOPTERS)

text: They come by a narrow blacktop road that turns and twists back on itself, often running along precipices above breathtaking views of rocks, peaks and valleys. The nearest town, Garberville, population 1,200, is 18 miles and 40 tortuous minutes away. So is the nearest doctor or dentist. For many, the mountains provide the protection they did for the moonshiners of old, though the big growers have proved vulnerable to law-enforcement parties in helicopters.
title: IN A COAST MOUNTAIN FASTNESS, PEACE (AND POLICE HELICOPTERS)

text: The mountains have attracted a varied group for varied reasons. There is Peter, (that is not his real name), a refugee educator from a major college who sought out the wilderness because, he said, ''I just don't agree with the public educational system.'' Here, he said, ''my life is integrated - there is still the intellectual but I'm learning to work with my hands, too.''
title: IN A COAST MOUNTAIN FASTNESS, PEACE (AND POLICE HELICOPTERS)

text: ''Bonnie Blackberry'' one of his friends, is a former teacher. ''I just couldn't take it any more in the city,'' she said. ''I think I am a very sensitive person.'' Here in the mountains, she said, she ''makes out fine'' teaching part time in a one-room schoolhouse just off a precipitous dirt road, braiding beadwork and ''growing my organic garden.''
title: IN A COAST MOUNTAIN FASTNESS, PEACE (AND POLICE HELICOPTERS)

text: Another of Peter's friends is an artist in stained glass who felt hemmed in by the gentrification of the San Francisco area's Marin County and found that ''I can do my work here as well as anywhere else - and live too.''
title: IN A COAST MOUNTAIN FASTNESS, PEACE (AND POLICE HELICOPTERS)

text: Much of what everyone here seems to feel was summed up by Al Carr, the tavern owner, a former cowboy from a Wyoming ranch, for whom Alderpoint was the end of a long search. ''I went to Alaska,'' he said. ''My wife went south. We were both searching for the best place to live. We met here. And here in these mountains is where we'll stay.''
title: IN A COAST MOUNTAIN FASTNESS, PEACE (AND POLICE HELICOPTERS)

text: One of the six transit police officers on trial in the death of Michael Stewart told a grand jury last year that the 25-year-old prisoner was ''bucking, kicking and scratching'' with such fervor that she assumed he was an ''emotionally disturbed person.''
title: OFFICER TOLD GRAND JURY STEWART WAS COMBATIVE

text: Two-thirds of the grand jury testimony of Officer Susan Techky, including segments that led to her indictment for perjury, were read to the jurors in State Supreme Court yesterday by Patricia Mazza, the court reporter who recorded the testimony on May 3, 1984.
title: OFFICER TOLD GRAND JURY STEWART WAS COMBATIVE

text: The testimony of Officer Techky was the most detailed firsthand account offered so far by one of the six officers who were with Mr. Stewart in the early morning hours of Sept. 15, 1983, after his arrest for scrawling graffiti in a subway station at First Avenue and 14th Street.
title: OFFICER TOLD GRAND JURY STEWART WAS COMBATIVE

text: It described what the 32-year-old officer saw and did when she ran up to Union Square after hearing screams over a walkie-talkie in the underground District 4 headquarters moments after her shift had ended.
title: OFFICER TOLD GRAND JURY STEWART WAS COMBATIVE

text: Officer Techky told the grand jury that she suspected the ''combative'' prisoner ''might possibly have done drugs'' because she ''couldn't imagine anyone having that much fight in him.'' She said that even with his hands cuffed behind his back, Mr. Stewart grabbed and scratched the officers trying to restrain him.
title: OFFICER TOLD GRAND JURY STEWART WAS COMBATIVE

text: According to an assistant district attorney, John Fried, tests of Mr. Stewart showed no signs of cocaine, heroin, barbituates or angel dust. He had a high level of alcohol in his blood, and was not tested for marijuana.
title: OFFICER TOLD GRAND JURY STEWART WAS COMBATIVE

text: Officer Techky told the grand jury that she spent approximately seven minutes on the street kneeling by the upper half of Mr. Stewart's body and pressing on his back. She said that she saw no officers kick the prisoner - the grounds for her perjury charge - or strike him barehanded or with a club.
title: OFFICER TOLD GRAND JURY STEWART WAS COMBATIVE

text: When Mr. Stewart was bound and loaded into a vehicle, Officer Techky's testimony said, he was no longer fighting or screaming, but was conscious, free of bruises on the unclothed parts of his body and not bloodied. He was taken to Bellevue Hospital Center, where he died 13 days later.
title: OFFICER TOLD GRAND JURY STEWART WAS COMBATIVE

text: When Officer Techky reached the street, she said, Officer John Kostick and Officer Henry Boerner were squatting near Mr. Stewart's feet. She could not fully see them, she testified, but assumed they were restraining the prisioner's flailing legs. She said that Officer Anthony Piscola was not in the vicinity of the prisoner and presumably remained in the police vehicle that had brought Mr. Stewart and Officers Kostick, Boerner and Piscola from the scene of the graffiti arrest to district headquarters.
title: OFFICER TOLD GRAND JURY STEWART WAS COMBATIVE

text: According to Officer Techky's testimony, Sgt. Henry Hassler stood near the prisoner but did not touch him. Sgt. James Barry, she said, put his night stick between the prisoner's handcuffs to immobilize his hands. Along with Officer Techky, the two sergeants are charged with lying to a grand jury in saying that they did not see anyone kick Mr. Stewart.
title: OFFICER TOLD GRAND JURY STEWART WAS COMBATIVE

text: Less extensive accounts of Mr. Stewart's arrest and conduct from the other indicted officers, three of them charged with criminally negligent homocide and assault as well as perjury, were presented to the jury earlier in the trial in the form of notes taken during investigative interviews several hours after the incident.
title: OFFICER TOLD GRAND JURY STEWART WAS COMBATIVE

text: Officer Techky was not interviewed, for reasons neither the prosecutor nor the defense attorneys could explain, and her grand jury testimony was read to the jurors at this juncture of the trial as an equivalent presentation.
title: OFFICER TOLD GRAND JURY STEWART WAS COMBATIVE

text: Mr. Fried said that portions of grand jury testimony from the other five officers would eventually be offered in evidence to support the perjury charges against all six. It was unclear whether the officers would testify.
title: OFFICER TOLD GRAND JURY STEWART WAS COMBATIVE

text: By Robert Mcg. Thomas Jr.
title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS;The Right Track

text: For someone who is serving a 15-year Federal sentence for conspiracy to distribute cocaine and marijuana, Larry Burt is an optimistic sort. This may be because of his involvement in a prison rehabilitation program stressing ''positive addiction,'' specifically, addiction to long-distance running.
title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS;The Right Track

text: As a prisoner at the Federal Correctional Institution in Fort Worth, Tex., the 37-year-old Burt has been allowed, under the watchful eyes of prison guards, to participate in local running events. The program of positive addiction seems to be working, at least for Burt, who has completed two marathons in the program and is apparently hooked on the sport. He also seems to be susceptible to runner's high, which in this case is obscuring some hard realities.
title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS;The Right Track

text: Buoyed by his success in the program, Burt applied for a spot in the New York City Marathon on Oct. 27, and, because his application was one of the first received and his credentials were in order, he was accepted.
title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS;The Right Track

text: That, however, does not mean that he will be at the starting line this fall. According to prison officials, the running program is limited to local events, and Burt will not be allowed to go to New York for the race, no matter how positive his addiction.
title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS;The Right Track

text: This does not mean that his acceptance by New York will go for naught. Under the rules, a runner whose application is accepted in any year can defer his appearance in the race for up to two years, which means that Burt's acceptance can be used as late as the race scheduled for October 1987 - five months after his probable parole date, May of 1987.
title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS;The Right Track

text: Americans worried about the decline of Yankee ingenuity may take cold comfort at that being demonstrated by native growers of marijuana. These are high times on the pot farm. During the 1980's, growers in the United States have become the fourth-largest suppliers of marijuana on our own streets, after Colombia, Mexico and Jamaica.
title: D-DAY IN THE WAR ON MARIJUANA

text: Some Americans seem to find wry amusement in the Government's difficulty in uprooting this covert enterprise. But that didn't daunt Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d.
title: D-DAY IN THE WAR ON MARIJUANA

text: Flying on Monday to the Ozark National Forest in northwestern Arkansas, a major sector of the bucolic pot belt, Mr. Meese was prevented by mountain mists from a helicopter tour with reporters and photographers, to the plant-chopping battlefront. But his presence at the opening of ''Operation Delta-9,'' a combined marijuana eradication effort of Federal, state and local law officers sponsored by the Justice Department's Drug Enforcement Administration, gave the campaign a high profile. This year's drive will for the first time involve all 50 states, the drug agency says.
title: D-DAY IN THE WAR ON MARIJUANA

text: Mr. Meese announced the first three days' results at a news conference later in the week: the destruction of 342,000 marijuana plants and the arrest of 175 growers. He said the publicity had prompted an encouraging wave of reports from citizens of undiscovered illegal plots. He promised that in the United States no observed marijuana plant - the source of a narcotic far more dangerous, he said, than Americans realize - would survive.
title: D-DAY IN THE WAR ON MARIJUANA

text: Mr. Meese's main target was perhaps skepticism about the Government's ability to eradicate the high-grade domestic crop. And the skeptics he probably sought most urgently to convince were in Central America, where pressure from Washington to strike at marijuana grown for export to the United States has generated a demand for proof that the United States does not apply a lenient double standard to its domestic growers.
title: D-DAY IN THE WAR ON MARIJUANA

text: The cultivation of cannabis has come to be an industry in which Americans excel. New laws now make it possible for prosecutors to seize the farms and homes of growers, and so clandestine patches of the weed have bloomed not only on private land but on thousands of acres of Uncle Sam's own backyard - in the national forests and national parks and on Federal grazing lands, even on Indian reservations. The Government cannot confiscate land it already owns.
title: D-DAY IN THE WAR ON MARIJUANA

text: These growers are typically squatters who come and go surreptitously to tend their crops, the authorities say, causing violence to the public and environmental insult to the wilderness.
title: D-DAY IN THE WAR ON MARIJUANA

text: Some of the plots are wired with booby traps to drive off curious campers. Hikers have been run off by gunfire. Wandering into hidden marijuana plots, backpackers have stepped on boot-piercing punji sticks or have been caught in webs of fish hooks suspended at eye level from nearly invisible lines. Large sections of some national forests have been abdicated to the marijuana growers -ruled off limits to the public and to Federal rangers alike as too dangerous to hike.
title: D-DAY IN THE WAR ON MARIJUANA

text: And while demand for marijuana remains strong -the Drug Enforcement Administration estimates that 15,000 to 17,000 tons of it were consumed in the United States last year - imports, if not down, may be getting shaky. This could only encourage domestic growers who, according D.E.A. estimates, had inched up to about 12 percent of the American market last year.
title: D-DAY IN THE WAR ON MARIJUANA

text: As in the Prohibition years, public apathy and skepticism about the Government's goals and effectiveness in curbing drug use remains high. A recent report by the General Accounting Office says the National Narcotics Border Interdiction System, a new program to seize drugs entering the country, is expending almost all its resources on marijuana and making no substantial headway against cocaine. ''They're always ahead of us,'' William Rosenblatt, the senior Customs Service agent in Miami said of cocaine smugglers. ''They scheme 18 hours a day how to smuggle coke into the U.S.''
title: D-DAY IN THE WAR ON MARIJUANA

text: Anti-smuggling efforts by the United States, even against marijuana, remain full of holes but show sporadic signs of vigor. Last week, impatient with what officials termed the laxity of Air Jamaica in flying in uninspected marijuana-laden luggage, Federal Customs agents at Kennedy International Airport seized one of the Caribbean nation's new wide-body jets for a day and fined the airline $18,000.
title: D-DAY IN THE WAR ON MARIJUANA

text: The most effective attack on foreign marijuana is to kill it before it can be harvested and exported, and Washington has been leaning hard on Central American governments to do so. Officials in Colombia, which has been supplying 70 percent of the marijuana consumed here, told members of the House Select Committee on Narcotics during a tour there last week that intense dusting with the herbicide glyphosate may have wiped out much of the commercial crop.
title: D-DAY IN THE WAR ON MARIJUANA

text: THREE state-police airplanes flew across rural areas of Connecticut last week as part of a nationwide effort to eradicate marijuana crops.
title: STATE JOINS BATTLE AGAINST MARIJUANA

text: ''You look for anything that's different,'' said Sgt. John A. Leonard of the Statewide Narcotics Task Force, who was a spotter while Sgt. Robert Maslan piloted the single-engine Cessna Skylane 1,400 feet over a corn field just outside Meriden.
title: STATE JOINS BATTLE AGAINST MARIJUANA

text: Sergeant Leonard said the locations that appeared to be suspicious would be checked out on the ground. The authorities said that they planned to keep the fields where marijuana was found under surveillance, but that they would to take no action until the harvest season, usually late September or early October, in hopes of capturing the growers.
title: STATE JOINS BATTLE AGAINST MARIJUANA

text: The air searches were the first time state authorities have taken part in a nationwide marijuana-eradication effort. The raids, Operation Delta 9, involved more than 2,200 Federal, state and local law-enforcement officers.
title: STATE JOINS BATTLE AGAINST MARIJUANA

text: ''Connecticut is not a violator in the ranks of California or some Western states,'' the agent in charge of the Hartford office of the Federal Drug Enforcement Administration, Jerome Mattioli, said. ''Our growing season is much shorter.''
title: STATE JOINS BATTLE AGAINST MARIJUANA

text: Mr. Mattioli said that although there was no way to estimate how much marijuana might be growing in the state, experience indicated that most is cultivated in plots smaller than 100 by 150 feet. Often, he said, the plants are concealed in the middle of corn fields or in wooded areas on public lands.
title: STATE JOINS BATTLE AGAINST MARIJUANA

text: ''There might be anywhere from 5 to 50 plots in various sizes in the state,'' he said. ''You figure each plant might produce a pound of usable marijuana from the seeds and leaves.''
title: STATE JOINS BATTLE AGAINST MARIJUANA

text: In addition to cultivated plots, Mr. Mattioli said, because marijuana is a weed, it is often found growing wild along railroad tracks and highways.
title: STATE JOINS BATTLE AGAINST MARIJUANA

text: ''It doesn't need all the water or fertilizer that people like to afford their rosebushes or corn,'' he said. ''It's kind of self-sustaining.
title: STATE JOINS BATTLE AGAINST MARIJUANA

text: ''We've gone through fields in other states, burnt out the plants and tried to cut them down, but the seeds are like an armor. They fall to the ground or birds will carry them away, and you've got a marijuana field growing somewhere else.''
title: STATE JOINS BATTLE AGAINST MARIJUANA

text: The commander of the state's narcotics group, Capt. James Mooney, said that although high-grade imported marijuana commanded up to $2,000 a pound, marijuana cultivators in the state could realize $600 a pound wholesale.
title: STATE JOINS BATTLE AGAINST MARIJUANA

text: ''You're talking good money,'' he said.
title: STATE JOINS BATTLE AGAINST MARIJUANA

text: Although the marijuana grown here accounts for a small percentage of the drug sold in the state, Captain Mooney said the potential existed for larger crops:
title: STATE JOINS BATTLE AGAINST MARIJUANA

text: ''Look at how many state forests we have. I don't think there's one town that's not within 10 miles of a state forest here in Connecticut.''
title: STATE JOINS BATTLE AGAINST MARIJUANA

text: Captain Mooney cited Maine, where the Connecticut State Police received their training in marijuana detection.
title: STATE JOINS BATTLE AGAINST MARIJUANA

text: ''In Maine, they found large, large plots of marijuana,'' he said. ''Maine is a lot colder. It has a shorter growing season. The soil conditions are no better, if not worse than Connecticut.''
title: STATE JOINS BATTLE AGAINST MARIJUANA

text: Since the state began its eradication effort last September, seven arrests have been made. Last week, Federal prosecutors sued to seize a home in Prospect, where agents had confiscated 20 pounds of marijuana and 336 plants that were being cultivated in a basement.
title: STATE JOINS BATTLE AGAINST MARIJUANA

text: ''He had grow lights,'' Captain Mooney said. ''He had the floor all dug up for drainage.''
title: STATE JOINS BATTLE AGAINST MARIJUANA

text: The authorities announced last week a toll-free telephone number, (800) 44 D-R-U-G-S, for reporting suspected cases of marijuana cultivation and trafficking. Thirty-five thousand pamphlets are being distributed by the state police as part of an education program will include radio and television announcements.
title: STATE JOINS BATTLE AGAINST MARIJUANA

text: ''What we're going to do is sort of nip it in the bud,'' Mr. Mattioli said. ''D.E.A. and the state police are getting a head start, preventative enforcement, if you will.''
title: STATE JOINS BATTLE AGAINST MARIJUANA

text: The United States Attorney for Connecticut, Alan H. Nevas, said that he thought recently enacted Federal legislation to enable the Government to seize the assets of drug traffickers could cause some growers apprehension.
title: STATE JOINS BATTLE AGAINST MARIJUANA

text: ''The fact that there is a potential out there for people to lose their homes and their property through forfeiture,'' he said, ''is a very, very important deterrent factor.''
title: STATE JOINS BATTLE AGAINST MARIJUANA

text: By William E. Schmidt, Special To the New York Times
title: U.S. INVESTIGATION DRAWS ATTENTION TO FEDERAL JUDGE IN MISSISSIPPI

text: HATTIESBURG, Miss. Aug. 7 - For the past 12 months scores of witnesses have paraded through the second floor of the United States Courthouse here, where a special Federal grand jury has been investigating allegations of public corruption in southern Mississippi.
title: U.S. INVESTIGATION DRAWS ATTENTION TO FEDERAL JUDGE IN MISSISSIPPI

text: To date, a prominent Hattiesburg businessman and the former District Attorney of Forrest County have pleaded guilty to various charges growing out of the grand jury. Of three other men charged in a related drug case, one pleaded guilty, a second was convicted and the third is a fugitive.
title: U.S. INVESTIGATION DRAWS ATTENTION TO FEDERAL JUDGE IN MISSISSIPPI

text: The grand jury is the latest in a series of Federal investigations into allegations of official corruption and what some call the excesses of ''good ol' boy'' politics in Mississippi. Since 1979, Federal prosecutors in Mississippi have scored more than three dozen convictions in corruption cases specifically involving a variety of public officials and agencies.
title: U.S. INVESTIGATION DRAWS ATTENTION TO FEDERAL JUDGE IN MISSISSIPPI

text: But the grand jury in Hattiesburg has drawn special attention across the state because the investigation has involved Federal District Judge Walter L. Nixon, Jr., a member of a prominent political family along the state's Gulf Coast. Appointed to the Federal bench in 1968 by President Johnson, Judge Nixon, 56 years old, now presides as the chief judge for the district court that covers the southern half of Mississippi.
title: U.S. INVESTIGATION DRAWS ATTENTION TO FEDERAL JUDGE IN MISSISSIPPI

text: Judge Not Accused of Wrongdoing
title: U.S. INVESTIGATION DRAWS ATTENTION TO FEDERAL JUDGE IN MISSISSIPPI

text: In two key indictments returned by the grand jury, which was convened at the request of prosecutors from the Justice Department's Public Integrity Section, the Washington-based unit assigned to prosecute wrongdoing by public officials, Judge Nixon's name has figured prominently.
title: U.S. INVESTIGATION DRAWS ATTENTION TO FEDERAL JUDGE IN MISSISSIPPI

text: Even so, Judge Nixon has not been indicted, nor has he been accused of any wrongdoing by the grand jury, which has ranged over matters as diverse as a failed scheme to smuggle 2,200 pounds of marijuana into Hattiesburg to the sale of an entire island off the Mississippi coast. Judge Nixon testified before the grand jury early last summer.
title: U.S. INVESTIGATION DRAWS ATTENTION TO FEDERAL JUDGE IN MISSISSIPPI

text: A receptionist in Judge Nixon's office in Biloxi this week referred all inquiries about the investigation to Walter F. Goodman Jr., a lawyer in Jackson, who said, ''I am not in a position to discuss Judge Nixon's affairs with you.''
title: U.S. INVESTIGATION DRAWS ATTENTION TO FEDERAL JUDGE IN MISSISSIPPI

text: Judge Nixon's name was directly linked to the investigation last summer when the grand jury indicted Wiley Fairchild, a building contractor in Hattiesburg. The indictment charged that Mr. Fairchild sought to influence Judge Nixon by giving him oil and gas leases. After negotiations with prosecutors, Mr. Fairchild, 52, pleaded guilty to giving an illegal gift to a Federal judge.
title: U.S. INVESTIGATION DRAWS ATTENTION TO FEDERAL JUDGE IN MISSISSIPPI

text: In a hearing in the case, Reid H. Weingarten, the Justice Department attorney handling the case, said Mr. Fairchild's intent was ''to affect in the future Judge Nixon's official action if his son's case came before him and other matters.''
title: U.S. INVESTIGATION DRAWS ATTENTION TO FEDERAL JUDGE IN MISSISSIPPI

text: Judge Nixon was never involved in any Federal proceedings involving Mr. Fairchild's son, Drew, who was later charged by this grand jury with conspiracy to smuggle marijuana. The judge flatly denied any wrongdoing in a public statement issued last summer, and argued that he had purchased the leases ''as a normal and straightforward business transaction.'' Later, the Justice Department issued a public ''announcement'' specifically stating that Judge Nixon was not a defendant in the Fairchild case, nor was he accused of wrongdoing.
title: U.S. INVESTIGATION DRAWS ATTENTION TO FEDERAL JUDGE IN MISSISSIPPI

text: Then, in June, Judge Nixon's name came up in an indictment of Paul H. (Bud) Holmes, a close friend of Judge Nixon's who, as the District Attorney of Forrest County from 1980 to 1984, was directly involved in a state narcotics case against Drew Fairchild.
title: U.S. INVESTIGATION DRAWS ATTENTION TO FEDERAL JUDGE IN MISSISSIPPI

text: Among other things, the indictment described a telephone call in late 1982 in which Federal prosecutors allege that both Judge Nixon and Mr. Holmes sought to reassure Mr. Fairchild, in the words of the indictment, ''that his son's drug case would be resolved to Wiley Fairchild's satisfaction.''
title: U.S. INVESTIGATION DRAWS ATTENTION TO FEDERAL JUDGE IN MISSISSIPPI

text: In describing the events in a rare public court hearing in June, Mr. Weingarten said Mr. Fairchild got in touch with Judge Nixon ''because he felt Nixon owed him a favor.'' As a result, Mr. Weingarten said, Judge Nixon visited Mr. Fairchild in his office, and then telephoned him later that day from Mr. Holmes's farm, saying, ''Everything is going to be all right.''
title: U.S. INVESTIGATION DRAWS ATTENTION TO FEDERAL JUDGE IN MISSISSIPPI

text: Accused of Lying to Grand Jury
title: U.S. INVESTIGATION DRAWS ATTENTION TO FEDERAL JUDGE IN MISSISSIPPI

text: Mr. Weingartern went on to say that the Judge then handed the telephone to Mr. Holmes, who told Mr. Fairchild: ''When this man asks me to do something, I do it. I don't ask questions.''
title: U.S. INVESTIGATION DRAWS ATTENTION TO FEDERAL JUDGE IN MISSISSIPPI

text: In two other counts of the indictment, Mr. Holmes, whose various activities have ranged from partial ownership of a Nevada casino to acting as an agent in behalf of the professional football star Walter Payton, was accused of lying to the grand jury about allegations of attempts to improperly influence other cases pending before Judge Nixon.
title: U.S. INVESTIGATION DRAWS ATTENTION TO FEDERAL JUDGE IN MISSISSIPPI

text: In one of those, the indictment says, Mr. Holmes lied to the grand jury when he denied that he told Bill Burgin, a state senator facing a criminal trial before Judge Nixon, that he could ''fix'' the case ''by giving Judge Nixon gambling money.''
title: U.S. INVESTIGATION DRAWS ATTENTION TO FEDERAL JUDGE IN MISSISSIPPI

text: Both Mr. Holmes and his attorney, James K. Dukes, declined to comment on the matters this week.
title: U.S. INVESTIGATION DRAWS ATTENTION TO FEDERAL JUDGE IN MISSISSIPPI

text: The Holmes indictment was not accompanied by any interpretation by Federal prosecutors of the activities attributed to Judge Nixon.
title: U.S. INVESTIGATION DRAWS ATTENTION TO FEDERAL JUDGE IN MISSISSIPPI

text: Mr. Holmes, who had been charged with four counts of perjury and one of obstruction of justice, pleaded guilty to a lesser charge, misbehavior in the presence of the grand jury, as part of a plea bargain agreement in which Federal prosecutors apparently agreed to drop the five-count felony indictment.
title: U.S. INVESTIGATION DRAWS ATTENTION TO FEDERAL JUDGE IN MISSISSIPPI

text: He is scheduled for sentencing next month.
title: U.S. INVESTIGATION DRAWS ATTENTION TO FEDERAL JUDGE IN MISSISSIPPI

text: In addition to Mr. Fairchild and Mr. Holmes, the special grand jury indicted Drew Fairchild and two other men on drug conspiracy charges growing out of the original incident in August 1980, when narcotics agents seized an airplane containing 2,200 pounds of marijuana at Hattiesburg airport.
title: U.S. INVESTIGATION DRAWS ATTENTION TO FEDERAL JUDGE IN MISSISSIPPI

text: Mr. Fairchild, who pleaded guilty, is currently serving a six-month sentence in Federal prison.
title: U.S. INVESTIGATION DRAWS ATTENTION TO FEDERAL JUDGE IN MISSISSIPPI

text: Since the proceedings within a grand jury are secret, and a Federal judge has forbidden Federal prosecutors and others from discussing the investigation, the precise scope of the grand jury investigation is not known.
title: U.S. INVESTIGATION DRAWS ATTENTION TO FEDERAL JUDGE IN MISSISSIPPI

text: Of the dozens of witnesses who have been subpoenaed to testify in the grand jury's ten sessions, most have been parties to these or other Federal court cases in which Judge Nixon presided.
title: U.S. INVESTIGATION DRAWS ATTENTION TO FEDERAL JUDGE IN MISSISSIPPI

text: The grand jury has called witnesses who were involved in a 1981 civil trial in which the Federal Government sought to condemn a 717-acre barrier island off the Mississippi coast. In early 1982, Judge Nixon ordered the Government to pay a Florida developer approximately $9 million in damages plus interest for the island. The developer had bought the property two years before for $100 in cash and a $1.7 million note.
title: U.S. INVESTIGATION DRAWS ATTENTION TO FEDERAL JUDGE IN MISSISSIPPI

text: In addition to four prosecutors attached to the investigation in Hattiesburg, lawyers from the Justice Department's Public Integrity Section have been involved in recent weeks in at least two other episodes in Mississippi, including a grand jury investigation into the collapse last year of a major Mississippi bank.
title: U.S. INVESTIGATION DRAWS ATTENTION TO FEDERAL JUDGE IN MISSISSIPPI

text: Mr. Weingarten prosecuted the Government's case against Federal District Judge Alcee Hastings of Miami, who was the first sitting Federal judge ever to be criminally indicted. He was acquitted in 1983 of allegations of soliciting a bribe and obstruction of justice.
title: U.S. INVESTIGATION DRAWS ATTENTION TO FEDERAL JUDGE IN MISSISSIPPI

text: James Tucker, the chief of the crminal division under United States Attorney George Phillips of Jackson, said that since 1979 his office has successfully prosecuted more than 40 cases against various state, Federal and local officials in Mississippi on charges ranging from bribery and kickbacks to embezzlement of public funds. Among them are three state senators, five county supervisors and the former heads of four state agencies.
title: U.S. INVESTIGATION DRAWS ATTENTION TO FEDERAL JUDGE IN MISSISSIPPI

text: The Federal Aviation Administration said today that it had dismissed three Miami air traffic controllers for purportedly peddling cocaine and marijuana at work and had ordered six others to enter rehabilitation programs.
title: 3 Miami Air Controllers Dismissed Over Drugs

text: The action ended a seven-week agency investigation of employees at the Miami air traffic control center. The 220 controllers direct the routes of up to 5,300 flights a day.
title: 3 Miami Air Controllers Dismissed Over Drugs

text: The agency said there was no evidence that the controllers had used drugs at work. Complaints from co-workers prompted the investigation.
title: 3 Miami Air Controllers Dismissed Over Drugs

text: An Air Jamaica jet impounded by Customs agents at Kennedy International Airport Wednesday in a move to force the line to tighten security against drug smuggling was returned to service yesterday, the airline said.
title: Jamaica Pays Fee For Jet's Return

text: The jet left for Montego Bay and Kingston on schedule at 10:30 A.M. A Customs spokesman, Michael Kaufman, said Air Jamaica had given an $18,000 check as a penalty fee to the acting director of the Kennedy Airport Customs Area, Robert Trotta, at 8 P.M. on Wednesday.
title: Jamaica Pays Fee For Jet's Return

text: Forty-five pounds of marijuana were found in luggage when the A-300 Airbus arrived Tuesday night from Jamaica. Customs officials said that in the last nine months, 10,000 pounds of marijuana had been confiscated from Air Jamaica flights.
title: Jamaica Pays Fee For Jet's Return

text: By Alfonso A. Narvaez, Special To the New York Times
title: SCHOOL'S DRUG-TEST PLAN MEETS CRITICISM IN JERSEY

text: A decision by the school board here to require all high school students to be tested once a year for alcohol and drug use ran into immediate opposition today from the American Civil Liberties Union and some education groups.
title: SCHOOL'S DRUG-TEST PLAN MEETS CRITICISM IN JERSEY

text: The regulation, approved Wednesday night in a 5-to-4 vote, requires that the test be performed by a physician at the school or by a student's private physician. The action followed a vote by the board in June authorizing spending for the test.
title: SCHOOL'S DRUG-TEST PLAN MEETS CRITICISM IN JERSEY

text: Failure to submit to the test would mean ''exclusion'' from the school and all school activities, according to the District Superintendent, Alfred L. Marbaise, who is one of the main advocates of the plan.
title: SCHOOL'S DRUG-TEST PLAN MEETS CRITICISM IN JERSEY

text: ''We will require that everybody be fully certified by a doctor as coming to school in a good, healthy condition, or they'll be excluded from school until they do,'' Mr. Marbaise said today in an interview.
title: SCHOOL'S DRUG-TEST PLAN MEETS CRITICISM IN JERSEY

text: He emphasized that the results of the tests would not be given to the police, nor would they lead to the suspension of students. Rather, the tests would be used to enroll any student found to be using drugs or alcohol in a confidential rehabilitation program.
title: SCHOOL'S DRUG-TEST PLAN MEETS CRITICISM IN JERSEY

text: State education officials in Trenton said they thought the tests, for all 515 students at the Henry P. Becton Regional High School, the only high school in the district, were the first in the nation to be required by a school system.
title: SCHOOL'S DRUG-TEST PLAN MEETS CRITICISM IN JERSEY

text: An attorney for the American Civil Liberties Union of New Jersey, John L. Weichsel, said he would file suit to block the testing. In addition, two major education groups in the state said they would not support the school district in its stand on the policy.
title: SCHOOL'S DRUG-TEST PLAN MEETS CRITICISM IN JERSEY

text: The testing is scheduled to begin with football players and cheerleaders, who will return to school this month, before the beginning of the fall term, Mr. Marbaise said.
title: SCHOOL'S DRUG-TEST PLAN MEETS CRITICISM IN JERSEY

text: Tests will be conducted in September on the rest of the students at the four-year school, all of whom are to submit a urine sample for testing.
title: SCHOOL'S DRUG-TEST PLAN MEETS CRITICISM IN JERSEY

text: The school's physician, Dr. Thomas Bellavia, said the tests would look for about 12 different substances, including marijuana, heroin, cocaine and PCP, also known as ''angel dust.''
title: SCHOOL'S DRUG-TEST PLAN MEETS CRITICISM IN JERSEY

text: The president of the school board, Adelle Dempsey, who voted against the proposal, said she approved of drug testing but was concerned that some of the proposal's wording might not withstand challenges.
title: SCHOOL'S DRUG-TEST PLAN MEETS CRITICISM IN JERSEY

text: Mrs. Dempsey said efforts by school officials to deter drug and alcohol use through lectures, speeches and drug-awareness programs had not worked.
title: SCHOOL'S DRUG-TEST PLAN MEETS CRITICISM IN JERSEY

text: Mr. Marbaise, the district superintendent, said about 15 to 20 students at the school, which draws students from the Bergen County communities of Carlstadt and East Rutherford, were drug or alcohol users.
title: SCHOOL'S DRUG-TEST PLAN MEETS CRITICISM IN JERSEY

text: ''We're kind of taking a first step in saying we don't want anybody involved in drug use,'' he said. ''We're sticking our necks out. We're saying we care enough to say it's wrong, we're going to stop it, and we're going to do everything we can to stop it.''
title: SCHOOL'S DRUG-TEST PLAN MEETS CRITICISM IN JERSEY

text: The school board's action drew a protest from Pilar Odenheim of Carlstadt, who attended the meeting Wednesday and whose daughter, Carla, is a senior at the school.
title: SCHOOL'S DRUG-TEST PLAN MEETS CRITICISM IN JERSEY

text: She said that the tests would only deal with one or two months of the school year and that once the testing was over, students who use drugs would resume their activities.
title: SCHOOL'S DRUG-TEST PLAN MEETS CRITICISM IN JERSEY

text: Mr. Weichsel, the attorney for the Civil Liberties Union, said he would challenge the tests as violating constitutional protections against unlawful search and seizure and protection of privacy.
title: SCHOOL'S DRUG-TEST PLAN MEETS CRITICISM IN JERSEY

text: Meanwhile, spokesmen for the New Jersey School Boards Association and the New Jersey Educational Association, the state's largest teachers union, said that the regulation was excessive and that their organizations would not defend legal challenges to it.
title: SCHOOL'S DRUG-TEST PLAN MEETS CRITICISM IN JERSEY

text: The once-independent city of Kokura, now carved into two wards of this industrial center, is the lucky stepchild of Japan's nuclear suffering.
title: JAPANESE RECALL ATTACK THAT WASN'T

text: It is the city that escaped the atomic bomb, and even now, 40 years later, it looks back with a bittersweet mixture of relief and guilt common among many survivors.
title: JAPANESE RECALL ATTACK THAT WASN'T

text: On Aug. 9, 1945, a B-29 bomber called Bock's Car set out from Tinian Island in the Marianas with the intention of attacking Kokura, a city of 130,000 people. The American military's ''short list'' of candidates for nuclear strikes named four cities -Hiroshima, Kokura, Nagasaki and Niigata. Three days earlier, Hiroshima was destroyed. Now it was Kokura's turn.
title: JAPANESE RECALL ATTACK THAT WASN'T

text: The crew of Bock's Car was under strict orders to have a clear view of its target, a huge arsenal that supplied the Japanese Army with everything from bullets to bombs. Much of Kokura's population worked in the arsenal. The city stood as a military bastion in an industrial zone ringing the northern tier of the Japanese island of Kyushu. The region had been extensively damaged by conventional bombing and, people here agree, Kokura was a likely candidate for an atomic weapon.
title: JAPANESE RECALL ATTACK THAT WASN'T

text: But up high, in Bock's Car, the target could not be seen. Haze and smoke kept it hidden. Three times, the B-29 passed over the city with its bomb bay doors open. Each time, the bombardier, Capt. Kermit Beahan, looked in vain for the arsenal and announced, ''No drop.''
title: JAPANESE RECALL ATTACK THAT WASN'T

text: Finally, low on fuel and starting to receive antiaircraft fire from the ground, Bock's Car abandoned Kokura and darted southwest to its secondary target.
title: JAPANESE RECALL ATTACK THAT WASN'T

text: At 11:02 A.M. that Aug. 9, it dropped a plutonium bomb dubbed ''Fat Man'' on the graceful port of Nagasaki. Thus Nagasaki gained the unhappy distinction of becoming the second - and, just maybe, the last -city to suffer a nuclear attack. Kokura became a footnote.
title: JAPANESE RECALL ATTACK THAT WASN'T

text: Months later, word spread about what might have been, and ''people felt, of course, like they'd had a narrow escape,'' according to Saburo Yonezu, a local historian.
title: JAPANESE RECALL ATTACK THAT WASN'T

text: ''We have complicated feelings,'' Mr. Yonezu said. ''We are half grateful that we survived. But the other half is that we also feel sorry that Nagasaki suffered instead of us.''
title: JAPANESE RECALL ATTACK THAT WASN'T

text: And so at 11:02 A.M. on Friday, when Nagasaki grieves, Kokura will, too.
title: JAPANESE RECALL ATTACK THAT WASN'T

text: Several hundred people probably will follow recent local tradition and attend a memorial service in front of a plain monument built on public land once occupied by the arsenal. There is a bell, presented by the city of Nagasaki, and an abstract statue in metal by a sculptor named Amane Isa.
title: JAPANESE RECALL ATTACK THAT WASN'T

text: If the past is a guide, those at the service will include survivors of Hiroshima and Nagasaki, 2,279 of whom live in Kokura, by official count.
title: JAPANESE RECALL ATTACK THAT WASN'T

text: ''A certain number of people usually come to pray by themselves,'' said Kazutoshi Ueda, a city official responsible for memorial plans. ''We know that survivors in Hiroshima and Nagasaki are reluctant to identify themselves, so there might be some here who feel the same.''
title: JAPANESE RECALL ATTACK THAT WASN'T

text: The arsenal is gone now, replaced by a park and the central public library. As a municipality, Kokura is also gone. In 1963, it merged with four other cities in northeast Kyushu to form a metropolis, Kitakyushu, whose size qualified it for greater local autonomy. It is a city of one million, a churning port and industrial center with a new overhead monorail and old electric trollies doomed to be replaced before long by something with an internal combustion engine.
title: JAPANESE RECALL ATTACK THAT WASN'T

text: Kokura, with 400,000 residents, thinks of itself as the new city's pace-setter. Centuries ago, it was a way station for feudal lords making eastward pilgrimages to the Shogun in Edo, as Tokyo used to be called. Ask people in Kokura where the region's center of politics and culture lies, and they will quickly assure you that it is not in any of the other four cities that make up Kitakyushu.
title: JAPANESE RECALL ATTACK THAT WASN'T

text: A Residue of Ill Will
title: JAPANESE RECALL ATTACK THAT WASN'T

text: There remains, some say, a residue of ill will against the United States, both for seeking to destroy Kokura and for occasional unpleasantness caused by soldiers during the American postwar occupation.
title: JAPANESE RECALL ATTACK THAT WASN'T

text: ''I think that that anger over the use of inhumane weapons against Japanese cities may be prevalent anywhere in Japan,'' Mr. Yonezu said.
title: JAPANESE RECALL ATTACK THAT WASN'T

text: It lingers, as might be expected, in Nagasaki, where 70,000 people are estimated to have died as a direct result of the atomic bomb. Kermit Beahan, the man who pushed the button that released the bomb, learned that two months ago.
title: JAPANESE RECALL ATTACK THAT WASN'T

text: A psychotherapist in Houston, Glenn Van Warrebey, wrote to Nagasaki city officials, saying that Mr. Beahan had told him of feeling remorse. According to the therapist, Mr. Beahan, now a space technology consultant in Houston, wanted to apologize in person to the hibakusha, as survivors are called in Japanese.
title: JAPANESE RECALL ATTACK THAT WASN'T

text: Mayor Hitoshi Motoshima replied that it was out of the question. ''Although there are survivors willing to meet and speak with Mr. Beahan, there are those who say the agony of the hibakusha continues even today,'' he said in a letter to Dr. Van Warrebey that was made public by Nagasaki officials.
title: JAPANESE RECALL ATTACK THAT WASN'T

text: ''I cannot find it in my heart to meet Mr. Beahan,'' the Mayor said.
title: JAPANESE RECALL ATTACK THAT WASN'T

text: Kokura can understand that. Although unscathed physically, it bears scars on its memory.
title: JAPANESE RECALL ATTACK THAT WASN'T

text: Two years ago, a Kitakyushu publisher issued a children's book describing what might have happened had there been no haze over the arsenal that morning in 1945. Based on an article in local editions of the national daily Asahi Shimbun, using simulations and educated guesses, the book said 55,000 would probably have been killed and 11,000 seriously wounded.
title: JAPANESE RECALL ATTACK THAT WASN'T

text: Albeit theoretical, the book showed how Kokura remains haunted by its close call. Each Aug. 9, in the midst of their summer vacations, public-school students are brought back to the classrooms for lessons on what almost happened to their city.
title: JAPANESE RECALL ATTACK THAT WASN'T

text: Mr. Ueda, the city official, needs no such reminder.
title: JAPANESE RECALL ATTACK THAT WASN'T

text: He was a student himself then, and though he could not see the B-29 any more than it could see him, he heard the engines clearly.
title: JAPANESE RECALL ATTACK THAT WASN'T

text: ''My house was right near the target, so I guess I wouldn't be here,'' he said. ''Later, my feelings of pain for the people of Nagasaki were keen. I felt strongly that it's not someone else's problem, but my own.''
title: JAPANESE RECALL ATTACK THAT WASN'T

text: Gunmen blasted dozens of holes early today in a helicopter used in raids Monday and Tuesday on marijuana growers.
title: Drug Raid Copter Fired On

text: The helicopter was parked near houses occupied by the families of three sheriff's deputies in Humboldt County. There were no reports of injuries and no arrests were made. The rifle shots put the leased craft out of commission and caused $60,000 in damages. Federal, state and local authorities are investigating.
title: Drug Raid Copter Fired On

text: Three men were arrested on the street in a quiet Queens neighborhood yesterday as law enforcement authorities acted on mounting complaints of open drug dealing in the middle-class area.
title: COMPLAINTS LEAD TO DRUG ARRESTS

text: For months, residents of the area around 221st Street and Hempstead Avenue in Queens Village had complained about the cocaine and marijuana sellers who had turned some of the local streets into what the residents called an illicit-drug market.
title: COMPLAINTS LEAD TO DRUG ARRESTS

text: The sales had involved small amounts of drugs, but the residents of the middle-class area had resented the blighting effect of the drug dealers hanging out in front of their homes and the customers driving up to make their purchases.
title: COMPLAINTS LEAD TO DRUG ARRESTS

text: Law enforcement officials said they hoped that the arrests would provide relief for the neighborhood by making the area a ''hot'' one that other drug sellers would avoid.
title: COMPLAINTS LEAD TO DRUG ARRESTS

text: The operation began as nine Queens detectives quietly converged on the area. Six parked or drove around in nearby streets. A seventh, in a van, parked at 221st Street and 103d Avenue - a block from Hempstead Avenue -and prepared videotape the activities outside. The van's tinted windows prevented anyone outside from seeing inside.
title: COMPLAINTS LEAD TO DRUG ARRESTS

text: The remaining two detectives, posing as brothers who were looking to buy marijuana and cocaine, began cruising slowly in their car.
title: COMPLAINTS LEAD TO DRUG ARRESTS

text: Within 45 minutes, the three purported drug sellers were in custody.
title: COMPLAINTS LEAD TO DRUG ARRESTS

text: The operation was carried out by the detective squad of District Attorney John J. Santucci.
title: COMPLAINTS LEAD TO DRUG ARRESTS

text: Observing from the van, detectives - and reporters invited by Mr. Santucci - watched as the detectives' car drove slowly along 221st Street, with two young men trotting next to it, and stopped near the van. One of the young men joined the detectives in the car before it drove away.
title: COMPLAINTS LEAD TO DRUG ARRESTS

text: The detectives' leader, Lieut. Remo Franceschini, said later that the man had gotten into the car to complete a marijuana deal and was arrested. The two other arrests were similarly made.
title: COMPLAINTS LEAD TO DRUG ARRESTS

text: Those in custody, all Queens Village men, were identified as Kenneth Kelly, 22 years old, of 217-10 Hollis Avenue, charged with felony sale of cocaine; Eliott Russell, 24, of 108-16 227th Street, charged with misdemeanor sale of marijuana, and Claude Chamblain, 20, of 100-44 22lst Street, also charged with a misdemeanor marijuana sale.
title: COMPLAINTS LEAD TO DRUG ARRESTS

text: The Customs Service seized an Air Jamaica jetliner at Kennedy International Airport yesterday, saying the line had failed to provide adequate security against narcotics smuggling.
title: U.S. SEIZES AIR JAMAICA JET IN DRUG CASE

text: ''It's a case of sending a message,'' said a Customs spokesman, Michael Kaufman. He said the agency had repeatedly asked the airline, the Jamaican flag carrier, to tighten security.
title: U.S. SEIZES AIR JAMAICA JET IN DRUG CASE

text: The seizure occurred as the plane was about to take off for Kingston with 245 people. Mr. Kaufman said he thought it was the first seizure of a commercial plane at an airport in the New York area under a Federal law that enables confiscating vehicles suspected of transporting narcotics.
title: U.S. SEIZES AIR JAMAICA JET IN DRUG CASE

text: Customs officials in Washington said agents had seized at least six other commercial airliners in the last two years, mostly in Florida, in drug-related incidents.
title: U.S. SEIZES AIR JAMAICA JET IN DRUG CASE

text: Since last October, Customs has seized almost 10,000 pounds of marijuana arriving on Air Jamaica flights - mostly in baggage not checked to any passenger or in cargo not listed on the planes' manifests, according to Mr. Kaufman.
title: U.S. SEIZES AIR JAMAICA JET IN DRUG CASE

text: The vice president of marketing and sales for the airline, Bill Cavanagh, confirmed in a statement that the plane had been confiscated after some marijuana had been brought from Jamaica. But, he said, ''Air Jamaica and U.S. Customs officials have been working in close cooperation for many months to insure that the carrier aircraft are not used for the transportation of any such illegal substance.''
title: U.S. SEIZES AIR JAMAICA JET IN DRUG CASE

text: The most recent incident occurred Tuesday night, when 45 pounds of marijuana was discovered in a bag that arrived on Air Jamaica Flight 17 from Jamaica, Mr. Kaufman said. A man described by Mr. Kaufman as a ramp employee was arrested in that incident as baggage was being unloaded from the plane.
title: U.S. SEIZES AIR JAMAICA JET IN DRUG CASE

text: Last Saturday, Customs seized 200 pounds of marijuana on an Air Jamaica plane at Kennedy.
title: U.S. SEIZES AIR JAMAICA JET IN DRUG CASE

text: ''This was the straw that broke the camel's back,'' Mr. Kaufman said of the incident Tuesday. He said a decision had been initiated by the director of the Kennedy Airport Customs Area to seize the plane, a wide-body A-300 Airbus, on the runway before it could leave for Kingston, the capital of Jamaica.
title: U.S. SEIZES AIR JAMAICA JET IN DRUG CASE

text: ''The seizure of a jet this size in New York is uncommon, to say the least,'' Mr. Kaufman said. ''This is not a thing we do every day. It was determined that Air Jamaica has not been cooperating, and a decision had to be made.''
title: U.S. SEIZES AIR JAMAICA JET IN DRUG CASE

text: Mr. Kaufman added that the airline should be checking its flight and ground personnel more closely.
title: U.S. SEIZES AIR JAMAICA JET IN DRUG CASE

text: A spokesman for Air Jamaica, Dinaz Boga, said she was surprised by the Customs Service statements. ''Air Jamaica has a system set up down there in full operation,'' she said.
title: U.S. SEIZES AIR JAMAICA JET IN DRUG CASE

text: Mr. Kaufman said at least two letters had been sent to the airline, warning that if security was not improved, ''strong action'' would be taken. In addition, he noted, Customs officials visited Jamaica to assist Air Jamaica executives to stop the smuggling.
title: U.S. SEIZES AIR JAMAICA JET IN DRUG CASE

text: Mr. Cavanagh said that discussions between Jamaican and United States officials were under way and that he expected the plane would be released in time for a flight to Jamaica this morning.
title: U.S. SEIZES AIR JAMAICA JET IN DRUG CASE
