text: A Customs spokesman in Washington, James Mahan, said that the Jamaican Ambassador to the United States, Keith Johnson, had had ''a very cordial meeting'' with a deputy Customs commissioner, Alfred DeAngelus, for an hour and that Mr. Johnson had ''pledged full cooperation with the U.S. Customs Service in strengthening security.''
title: U.S. SEIZES AIR JAMAICA JET IN DRUG CASE

text: Air Jamaica, according to Mr. Mahan, will have to pay a penalty of $18,000 before the plane is returned.
title: U.S. SEIZES AIR JAMAICA JET IN DRUG CASE

text: A Customs officer, Michael Fisher, said yesterday that on Tuesday at 10:30 P.M., as luggage was being unloaded to a conveyer belt, he saw a worker walking away with a bag.
title: U.S. SEIZES AIR JAMAICA JET IN DRUG CASE

text: After his drug-sniffing dog was attracted to the suitcase and a search revealed the marijuana cache, Officer Fisher and Officer Glenn Butler of the Port Authority police arrested the man. He was identified by the Port Authority police as Melvin Bernhard, 25 years old, of South Ozone Park, Queens, a baggage handler. The police could not supply the name of the service company for which Mr. Bernhard works.
title: U.S. SEIZES AIR JAMAICA JET IN DRUG CASE

text: Customs agents confiscated the plane at 10:30 A.M., minutes before it was to depart, and it was parked at the British Airways Terminal. Passengers were asked to leave, and, Miss Boga said, they were taken home or housed at a hotel near the airport until a flight could be made available. She said last night that she did not know how many people were at the hotel.
title: U.S. SEIZES AIR JAMAICA JET IN DRUG CASE

text: A passenger on the canceled flight, Bevan Campbell of Kingston, said last night that he was unhappy about the inconvenience. ''I might lose my job,'' he added.
title: U.S. SEIZES AIR JAMAICA JET IN DRUG CASE

text: Another passenger, Donna Martin, said she was concerned about family members waiting for her at the airport in Kingston, but could not fault the airline for what had happened. ''They handled it responsibly,'' Miss Martin said.
title: U.S. SEIZES AIR JAMAICA JET IN DRUG CASE

text: This was the first time, Miss Boga said, that an Air Jamaica plane had been confiscated by Customs.
title: U.S. SEIZES AIR JAMAICA JET IN DRUG CASE

text: By George Volsky, Special To the New York Times
title: U.S. SAYS SMUGGLERS BRING RECORD COCAINE FLOW

text: Despite improved vigilance by Federal and local agencies, more cocaine than ever is entering the United States, law-enforcement officials say. And they expect that improved smuggling strategies and unrelenting demand will keep the record-breaking flow coming.
title: U.S. SAYS SMUGGLERS BRING RECORD COCAINE FLOW

text: The officials said Miami was the center of cocaine traffic in this country, adding that about three-quarters of the cocaine intercepted nationwide last year was seized in the Florida-Caribbean district of the Drug Enforcement Administratioon. With a long coast and thousands of unused airstrips, south Florida has for years been the main point of entry of cocaine into the United States, which, according to recent statistics, has seen a dramatic increase in cocaine use at all social and economic levels.
title: U.S. SAYS SMUGGLERS BRING RECORD COCAINE FLOW

text: The officials, interviewed over several months, cited a shift from the use of large ships and airplanes for transporting cocaine to a wave of smaller boats and planes. They say this makes interception harder and, as one official said, ''overwhelms our interdiction resources.''
title: U.S. SAYS SMUGGLERS BRING RECORD COCAINE FLOW

text: Trying to counter this new transportation technique, Congress has appropriated funds for a fleet of 104 high-speed boats to be stationed in south Florida and manned by United State Coast Guard and Customs personnel.
title: U.S. SAYS SMUGGLERS BRING RECORD COCAINE FLOW

text: Concealment of cocaine has also become more professional. For example, it was by chance that agents of the United States Customs Service discovered 300 pounds of cocaine packed inside artificial yams in a freighter that had just docked at the Port of Miami in June. Agents said the artfully painted fiberglass yams were almost impossible to distinguish from the real ones they were mixed with.
title: U.S. SAYS SMUGGLERS BRING RECORD COCAINE FLOW

text: ''They're always ahead of us,'' William Rosenblatt, the top Customs Service agent in the area, said of cocaine smugglers. ''They scheme 18 hours a day how to smuggle coke into the U.S. We often work more than 10 hours daily, but what we basically do is to react.''
title: U.S. SAYS SMUGGLERS BRING RECORD COCAINE FLOW

text: In Washington, a new report by the General Accounting Office says the National Narcotics Border Interdiction System, a new program to coordinate the seizing of drugs at the borders, was spending nearly all its energy on marijuana and making almost no effort on cocaine.
title: U.S. SAYS SMUGGLERS BRING RECORD COCAINE FLOW

text: The officials interviewed suggested that the effort against narcotics smuggling had been weak basically because agents lacked detailed knowledge of the inner workings of the international drug business.
title: U.S. SAYS SMUGGLERS BRING RECORD COCAINE FLOW

text: Major drug organizations are very difficult to penetrate, they say. The smugglers who have been arrested are usually people in the low and middle levels of drug smuggling rings, and they refuse to cooperate with investigators because they fear reprisals by the organization.
title: U.S. SAYS SMUGGLERS BRING RECORD COCAINE FLOW

text: Officials here have complained that over the last few years their resources have grown only moderately while the number of people working in drug syndicates has more than doubled.
title: U.S. SAYS SMUGGLERS BRING RECORD COCAINE FLOW

text: A result is that Latin American cocaine is increasingly available to supply what by all indications is a steadily expanding demand for the drug in the United States.
title: U.S. SAYS SMUGGLERS BRING RECORD COCAINE FLOW

text: According to Congressional staff experts, national cocaine consumption, which in 1984 was about 85 metric tons, will exceed 100 tons this year. The Drug Enforcement Administration estimated consumption of cocaine at 34 to 45 metric tons in 1981, 45 to 54 metric tons in 1982 and 50 to 61 metric tons in 1983.
title: U.S. SAYS SMUGGLERS BRING RECORD COCAINE FLOW

text: Basing his statement on customs service projections, Senator Lawton Chiles, Democrat of Florida, said last month that 20 percent more cocaine would enter the Southeastern United States this year than in 1984. ''From time to time there are suggestions that we are beginning to win the war on drugs,'' Senator Chiles said. ''But in Florida and in the Southwest we are still in the trenches.'' #22 Kilograms Intercepted These estimates contrast with the situation in 1967, when a commission on law enforcement appointed by President Johnson did not find cocaine consumption a matter of concern. That year agencies intercepted 22 kilograms in all at a time when experts estimated that seizures accounted for less than 10 percent of what was smuggled.
title: U.S. SAYS SMUGGLERS BRING RECORD COCAINE FLOW

text: According to official reports, cultivation of coca leaves and their processing into coca paste, from which pure cocaine is refined, is taking place in Argentina, Brazil, Ecuador, Mexico, Nicaragua and Venezuela in addition to the traditional sources of the drug, Bolivia, Colombia and Peru.
title: U.S. SAYS SMUGGLERS BRING RECORD COCAINE FLOW

text: To be sure, more cocaine than ever is being discovered at the point of entry, or relatively shortly after arrival in the United States. But larger cocaine seizures only suggest that proportionately more is getting through, according to law-enforcement officials.
title: U.S. SAYS SMUGGLERS BRING RECORD COCAINE FLOW

text: ''An analysis by the House Subcommittee on Operations has concluded that we are intercepting only 0.5 percent of the drug coming by air and about 5 percent of the sea shipments,'' said John P. Cusack, chief of staff of the House Select Committee on Narcotics.
title: U.S. SAYS SMUGGLERS BRING RECORD COCAINE FLOW

text: ''This is really frightening,'' he said, ''because it shows that we have made no progress in detecting what is being shot at us.''
title: U.S. SAYS SMUGGLERS BRING RECORD COCAINE FLOW

text: According to the Drug Enforcement Administration, 4,400 kilograms of cocaine was seized nationally in 1982, 7,300 kilograms in 1983 and 11,742 kilograms in 1984. In the first six months of this year, in south Florida alone over 13,000 kilograms of cocaine was seized, more than in the entire country in 1984.
title: U.S. SAYS SMUGGLERS BRING RECORD COCAINE FLOW

text: ''Colombian traffickers - and so far Colombia has been mostly what the cocaine problem is all about - have perfected the drug transportation, distribution and financing of operations,'' said S. B. Billbrough, assistant special agent in charge of the D.E.A. district office in Miami.
title: U.S. SAYS SMUGGLERS BRING RECORD COCAINE FLOW

text: ''They have realized that small planes and boats are very difficult to detect on the radar screens,'' Mr. Billbrough said. ''Moreover, they use their boats and planes more efficiently. They have established refueling, transshipment and repair facilities in the Bahamas, Belize, Jamaica, the Dominican Republic, Haiti, Puerto Rico, Turks and Caicos and other smaller Caribbean islands.''
title: U.S. SAYS SMUGGLERS BRING RECORD COCAINE FLOW

text: Traffickers have also become more proficient in packaging, rapid loading and unloading of shipments and in communications. Mr. Cusack believes many Americans are working for the drug syndicates.
title: U.S. SAYS SMUGGLERS BRING RECORD COCAINE FLOW

text: Mr. Billbrough said that even though the United States had been pressing foreign countries to step up their antidrug campaigns, ''the extent of their cooperation is not known.''
title: U.S. SAYS SMUGGLERS BRING RECORD COCAINE FLOW

text: ''The problem in working with them,'' he said, ''is that drug business has become an important part of their economies.''
title: U.S. SAYS SMUGGLERS BRING RECORD COCAINE FLOW

text: The Colombian Government recently arrested 1,400 people in its efforts to root out illegal processing and smuggling of cocaine and seized tons of the drug. But officials say there have been no signs that this has lessened the amount shipped to the United States.
title: U.S. SAYS SMUGGLERS BRING RECORD COCAINE FLOW

text: Recently Jamaica ordered bulldozing of some airstrips to deny their use to marijuana-laden planes. But according to law-enforcement reports from Jamaica, traffickers are now using general aviation facilities.
title: U.S. SAYS SMUGGLERS BRING RECORD COCAINE FLOW

text: What some officials call an ''Americanization of the drug business'' has also been detected in South Florida. In the Miami area alone, 22 small cocaine laboratories were discovered in 18 months by the Miami-Dade Organized Crime Bureau.
title: U.S. SAYS SMUGGLERS BRING RECORD COCAINE FLOW

text: Arthur R. Nehrbass, commander of the bureau, a former agent in charge of the Federal Bureau of Investigation's Miami office, said the trend indicated that more cocaine refining facilities would be established in the United States.
title: U.S. SAYS SMUGGLERS BRING RECORD COCAINE FLOW

text: Like other experts interviewed, Mr. Nehrbass spoke about what he called ''a new breed of cocaine traffickers.'' Until about five years ago, he said, three or four Colombian syndicates dominated the processing and transportation of cocaine to the United States. Syndicate agents sold the drug to other Hispanic people, among them a strong Cuban contingent here, who were in charge of the wholesale and, in part, of the retail end of the business.
title: U.S. SAYS SMUGGLERS BRING RECORD COCAINE FLOW

text: In recent years ''Colombians have moved into the distribution of cocaine, too,'' he said, adding, ''About 17 Colombian families are known to be engaged now in the cocaine business in the United States.''
title: U.S. SAYS SMUGGLERS BRING RECORD COCAINE FLOW

text: According to Mr. Billbrough, Colombians have established a ''heavy interaction'' with organized crime families in New York City and with Hispanic criminal elements in other cities, especially Los Angeles.
title: U.S. SAYS SMUGGLERS BRING RECORD COCAINE FLOW

text: There have been other substantial changes in the last few years, law-enforcement officials said.
title: U.S. SAYS SMUGGLERS BRING RECORD COCAINE FLOW

text: ''The flamboyance has disappeared,'' said William Dingfelder, spokesman for Vice President Bush's South Florida Task Force on Drugs. ''Smugglers are more sophisticated and knowledgeable in the use of computer software and hardware.
title: U.S. SAYS SMUGGLERS BRING RECORD COCAINE FLOW

text: ''For them, the drug operations is a regular business. They can establish a corporate structure, with heads of production, transportation, marketing and investment departments, with their own collection service, public relations and, of course, a strong professional enforcement section.''
title: U.S. SAYS SMUGGLERS BRING RECORD COCAINE FLOW

text: According to Mr. Rosenblatt, after a period of violence in the early 1980's, ''the pecking order has been established in the drug syndicates.''
title: U.S. SAYS SMUGGLERS BRING RECORD COCAINE FLOW

text: ''The time 'cocaine cowboys' could kill enemies all over Miami in broad daylight, is over,'' he said. ''The killing is now more professional and discreet. These people realize that gang-style executions are bad for business.''
title: U.S. SAYS SMUGGLERS BRING RECORD COCAINE FLOW

text: Law-enforcement officers have noticed that a number of Americans have entered the drug business. ''Often small-town 'redneck' elements put together a modest investment syndicate, travel to Bogota and buy a small quantity of cocaine which then is transported to their areas,'' Mr. Billbrough said. ''This leads to larger investments, bigger smuggling operations, more contacts with Colombians and more Americans involved. This pattern has been repeated time and time again.''
title: U.S. SAYS SMUGGLERS BRING RECORD COCAINE FLOW

text: In the face of all this, law-enforcement agencies are trying to improve their intelligence capabilities. ''We are getting better, even though we are often caught flatfooted,'' said Mr. Billbrough. ''We are expanding our analytical resources through the National Narcotics Intelligence Consumer Committee, which coordinates foreign and domestic information from 12 agencies engaged in antidrug campaigns.''
title: U.S. SAYS SMUGGLERS BRING RECORD COCAINE FLOW

text: For years Federal investigators have been trying to learn the destination of profits realized by the drug syndicates, presuming that a large part has been invested in the United States.
title: U.S. SAYS SMUGGLERS BRING RECORD COCAINE FLOW

text: It has been difficult because in the course of transfers of millions of dollars made by American financial institutions to banks around the globe and back into this country, the sender's identity is invariably covered up.
title: U.S. SAYS SMUGGLERS BRING RECORD COCAINE FLOW

text: ''Traffickers are back to where they were in the late 1970's,'' said Mr. Nehrbass. ''Now we see cash going out of the country. They use speedboats to move the dollars in the Bahamas, Grand Cayman and Panama, which is relatively easy because they seldom intercept boats, planes or passengers leaving the country.''
title: U.S. SAYS SMUGGLERS BRING RECORD COCAINE FLOW

text: Mr. Nehrbass said he thought that the United States was ''making progress now,'' but, like his colleagues, believes that the cocaine problem can be overcome only with an extensive educational campaign among young people to counteract the notion that cocaine makes people happy, lucid and powerful without harming them.
title: U.S. SAYS SMUGGLERS BRING RECORD COCAINE FLOW

text: Analyzing the overall drug-enforcement effort, Mr. Cusack said: ''We are still losing ground. We know that coke is now available in almost every town in the United States and in many schoolyards. We simply have to invest more money and resources into this bucket.''
title: U.S. SAYS SMUGGLERS BRING RECORD COCAINE FLOW

text: The prosecution in the Michael Stewart case disclosed yesterday that Mr. Stewart, a 25-year-old Brooklyn man who died nearly two years ago while in the custody of the transit police, was arrested in 1981 for smoking marijuana.
title: Stewart Arrested In '81 for Drugs

text: Six transit officers are on trial in State Supreme Court in Manhattan in connection with Mr. Stewart's death.
title: Stewart Arrested In '81 for Drugs

text: He was arrested for scrawling graffiti on a wall in a subway station.
title: Stewart Arrested In '81 for Drugs

text: The prosecutor, John Fried, also told the defense that Mr. Stewart sought a job at the Transit Authority as a token clerk in 1981 and, in his interview, said that he smoked eight or nine marijuana cigarettes a week and that he would not stop if he were hired. He was not hired.
title: Stewart Arrested In '81 for Drugs

text: Mr. Fried said he disclosed the material relating to drug use after he had learned of the defense's medical theory that the combination of alcohol and marijuana Mr. Stewart had taken, along with the battle he put up in ''resisting arrest,'' caused him to have a heart attack.
title: Stewart Arrested In '81 for Drugs

text: Mr. Fried said no evidence of drugs was found in Mr. Stewart's blood. He maintains that Mr. Stewart was beaten by the police and that he died 13 days later as a result of his injuries.
title: Stewart Arrested In '81 for Drugs
